name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the outcome of the high level conference on employment in Europe (Milan, 8 October) (2014/2898(RSP)).

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, It is with pleasure that I would like to share with you the results of the High-Level Conference on Employment. This issue is considered to be a priority issue by the Italian Presidency, in line with the conclusions of the June European Council, which identified growth and employment as priority themes for the Work of the European Union over the next five years. This issue remains very topical in view of the particularly high unemployment rates: 11.5% in the euro area in August, with marked differences between Member States and worrying points with regard to youth unemployment: 23.1% in the euro area, over 50% in some Member States. In this context, also on the basis of the indications of the extraordinary European Council in August, the Italian Presidency organised the High Level Conference on Employment in Milan on 8 October, as a follow-up to the conferences held in Berlin in July 2013 and in Paris last November, which focused on youth employment. The main aim of the work of this last edition was to reflect on the need to provide new and coordinated responses for the revival of growth and employment, including through appropriate investment policies. During the work of the Conference, in which 16 Heads of State or Government took part, the conditions necessary for the creation of new jobs and for improving the correspondence between supply and demand for labour were examined. First of all, it was agreed on the crucial ity of structural reforms, which were seen as crucial to restarting the labour market and promoting employment. It was noted, however, that these conditions were necessary but not sufficient and should be supplemented by action on the application. In addition to the reforms, a growth environment is crucial, which inevitably leads to a revival of investment. The need to provide shared and coordinated responses at EU level was therefore discussed. The Conference was divided into three sessions: an opening technique for the directors of public employment services, followed by a working lunch of ministers dealing with employment issues and in the afternoon the session at the level of Heads of State or Government. The Breakfast of Labour Ministers focused on direct measures and instruments for promoting employment, particularly youth employment. In this regard, ministers made a request to the Commission to strengthen the Youth Employment Initiative, which should become a structural scheme of the European Union with a request to significantly increase the amount of pre-financing of the funds dedicated to it. The need for more effective procedures for implementing the Youth Guarantee was also mentioned, a programme which is successfully taking off in several Member States, as illustrated by the directors of public employment services at the opening technical session. As regards the implementation of direct employment programmes, the contribution of the European Investment Bank was recognized, among other things, in stressing the importance of investment in human capital and training. The transition from school to work and dual training have been cited as a virtuous model and the role of employment services has been mentioned. The actions of the Heads of State or Government in stressing the importance of national reforms to increase the efficiency and transparency of the labour market underlined the need to identify instruments to accompany the growth of the real economy and promote investment within the framework of the rules governing the governance of the economy in the euro area and in the single market. Equally important is the identification of strategic sectors with high growth potential on which to focus the attention of the institutions. Finally, sectors of the digital economy, transport and energy were mentioned as priorities.

name: László Andor
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, the meeting of Heads of State and Government last week in Milan reconfirmed their determination to make the Youth Guarantee a reality. As you know, the Commission under the leadership of President Barroso has taken a number of initiatives to improve the employment situation and the life prospects of young people. The Youth Guarantee is a key structural reform of our time. Its implementation is at the core of the EU coordination of employment policies and it is therefore central to the European Semester and the country-specific recommendations.  The Youth Guarantee is a comprehensive policy which includes the modernisation of vocational training, strengthening of public employment services, greater support for apprenticeships and traineeships, as well as financial incentives for job creation and business start-ups. All these measures need to be combined in order to ensure that every young person under the age of 25 receives a good quality offer of a job, continued education, apprenticeship or traineeship within four months after leaving school or becoming unemployed. The Youth Guarantee focuses both on improving the quality of labour supply, for instance through training, and on stimulating demand for young people’s labour, for instance targeted wage or recruitment subsidies and apprenticeship grants.  The Youth Guarantee is being implemented across Europe. Some Member States have amended their legislation, others have introduced new policy instruments to scale up labour market-related measures for young people. For example, in Spain, the number of vocational education in training (VET) centres of companies involved in dual projects and of VET students has doubled since 2013. In Slovakia, hiring subsidies are proving effective in supporting long-term unemployed young people. The Youth Guarantee has already resulted in 12 000 jobs in Slovakia, mainly in SMEs, and most of them sustainable.  In parallel, vocational education is also being modernised. Just last week I visited a second-chance school in Turin, Italy, where young people are learning various crafts such as baking or brewing, and cooperative enterprises play an important role in offering them first employment.  The EU budget provides important financial support for the roll-out of the Youth Guarantee. The first instrument to be used was obviously the European Social Fund for 2007-2013 from which Member States have planned to finance human capital investment up to 2015. On top of that, we have the EUR 6.4 billion Youth Employment Initiative, whose implementation has been frontloaded to 2014-15 in terms of budgetary commitments. As I already informed you in September, we expect that operational programmes covering 85% of the Youth Employment Initiative will be adopted by the end of this year. Importantly, expenditure on Youth Employment Initiative projects has been eligible since 1 September 2013. This means that many Member States have been spending their money from this envelope for more than a year and the expenditure will be reimbursed after the operational programmes are adopted. In addition, the Member States have proposed to allocate more than EUR 4 billion from the European Social Fund 2014-2020 to the investment priority specifically supporting young people’s labour market integration. Considerable further resources from the ESF are also being programmed for general job search support measures, entrepreneurship support or vocational training investments from which young people will also benefit.  The Youth Guarantee has a cost, but it should be considered an investment. Investing in the Youth Guarantee’s implementation here and now is crucial for preserving the EU’s future growth potential. As you know, the economic value of the Youth Guarantee has been highlighted by the OECD, the ILO and Eurofound. More recently, the G20 strongly supported it and invited countries to step up implementation. The economic value of the Youth Guarantee is related both to building up the human capital stock and to improving the flow of this human capital into and within the labour market. In other words, it pays off to ensure that young people quickly find relevant jobs where their productive potential can be realised. For this we need not only education and training, but also active labour market policies, high-performing public employment services, as well as measures stimulating demand for labour, such as targeted hiring subsidies, all embedded together in the Youth Guarantee Schemes. These investments and their returns are harder to measure than, for instance, infrastructure investments, but they are very important, both to strengthen the human capital stock and to improve labour market flows and transitions. That is why the Youth Guarantee expenditure should be considered as an investment. Heads of State and Government and Ministers meeting last week in Milan reconfirmed that the Youth Guarantee is – and should remain – the framework for our efforts to improve youth employment across Europe. I am therefore confident that the value of these investments will be recognised also in the EU’s future plans for investment. Some Member States still seem to be facing constraints when it comes to their ability to pre-finance the implementation of the Youth Guarantee measures from their national budgets. As you know very well, the EU structural investment funds provide only very limited pre-financing in the 2014-20 period, namely 1% in the year 2014, which can be increased to 1.5% in cases of the Youth Employment Imitative for countries that had recently been subject to a macroeconomic adjustment programme. We may all agree that this level of pre-financing is low, but unfortunately it is closely linked to the overall design of the multiannual financial framework and in particular to the very low payment ceiling for the first couple of years. The EU budget, as you know, is suffering from a severe shortage of payment appropriations, which also means that there was no room to envisage higher pre-financing rates for the Youth Employment Initiative, at least not in the absence of a change of attitude from some Member States. However, the European Investment Bank has been offering to Member States the possibility of bridge financing, with their investments to be later reimbursed from the Youth Employment Initiative. In this way the EIB could help to resolve this liquidity problem. A couple of Member States have already discussed with the EIB the possibilities and I am sure the bank’s doors remain open to all Member States. I reiterated the same messages last Thursday during the formal EPSCO meeting attended by the Employment and Social Affairs Ministers. Honourable Members, the Milan Summit delivered one important message: if we want to have more employment in Europe we need to combine structural reforms with support for aggregate demand. The Youth Guarantee is a structural reform and it also helps in boosting demand for young workers. Successful delivery of the Youth Guarantee supported in a timely way by the relevant EU funds remains a priority for the Commission. I am sure that it will continue to be treated as an urgent and important issue also by the incoming Commission.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Madam President, Commissioner, thank you for your very enlightened and just intervention in more ways than one. For my part, I would like to remind the Council that there are six commandments to remember. I give the short version, you will not have ten, you will only have six. But remember these six commandments to successfully integrate young people into the job market. The first commandment is to combat unse qualified exits from training systems. A large proportion of young people coming out of training - almost 20% - have no qualifications and find themselves directly unemployed. This is the first point on which you must make a real effort: to fight against exits without qualifications. The second commandment is to modernize training in general, not just vocational training. Indeed, we are now in a situation where young engineers are also unemployed. It is the training that needs to be modernized, by hanging it in a much more operational way in the world of work. The third commandment is to give back to learning, alternation and internships. Internships have been misguided throughout Europe, and apprenticeships and alternation, in most European countries, are considered to be smaller training. These are essential training courses that correspond to a form of spirit for young people. The fourth commandment is to have a vision of "new skills, new jobs". We have worked on it and you know very well that in the coming years, by 2020, 15% of low-skilled jobs will disappear again. We have to be prepared for that, otherwise we will continue to run after time. The fifth commandment is to have no longer only knowledge, but also skills and abilities. Finally, the sixth command, for the Council, is to put in place operational programs. While heads of state or government absolutely wanted to abolish the ESF, I see that today it is still the first lever of the youth guarantee.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Once again one of these media-effective summits, once again nothing substantially new. By pushing the Black Peter back and forth – who is to blame in Europe for not making progress in combating youth unemployment – we are not helping the young people of Europe. I would like to thank the Italian Presidency for really focusing on growth and employment, because without growth we will not create new jobs in Europe. The Member States must finally ensure that young people in Europe have a perspective. How long will it take for us to finally have a truly sustainable and co-ordinated strategy in implementing the Youth Guarantee? It must also be about concrete changes: where is what is blocked, where does anything fit with the implementation at the moment? It must not be the case that money does not arrive. Some people are already talking about the fact that we will no longer need any money in the future. I appeal to the Member States: do something! Create jobs for young people! Qualify the young people! We need the perspective for Europe!

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for We must stop talking here only about the symptoms of youth unemployment, but should begin to deal with the causes. My message here today is that the eurozone is going to be there. Instead of curing the economy, the Heads of State or Government and the European Commission are trying to save the euro. In the meantime, my country, Germany, is also infected by this disease. In all the hearings i attended when it came to the Commissioners, I have noted that it has been pointed out everywhere that restoring competitiveness in the euro area is the great priority. In order to save the euro, the exact opposite is happening: instead of advocating subsidiarity in Europe, centralism is now being preached – it is also necessary to save the euro. Instead of maintaining ownership of public and bank debt in one country, this responsibility is now being socialised. In other words, if everyone is responsible, then in the end no one is responsible. Instead of creating competition in Europe, the opposite is now being called for. Commissioner Andor, in particular, has excelled here with proposals for the socialisation of social security systems. An economic system based on centralism, harmonisation and debt socialisation will not be able to remain competitive.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, progress on the Youth Guarantee and on the Youth Employment Initiative is, at best, uneven. It is much too slow. Yes, we know that six or nine billion – whatever it is – is not enough; it is not nearly enough for the youth guarantee. On this point I agree with Angela Merkel: spend the money before you look for more. But at another level, we all know the inflexibility of some Member States when it comes to ensuring that the EU budget is fit for purpose. I suppose for many Member States the real question is: do they have the resources or the freedom to use those resources for job creation? You yourself referred to this, Commissioner. In that context I am more inclined to agree with Prime Minister Renzi, who said that the current rules were designed for the Europe of many years ago, as he said, for another world. Our governments must have the ability to respond to change. To be stuck in a moment, to believe that one size fits all, to believe that there is one and only one solution to the on-going crisis, that is budget consolidation, that is a negation of what Europe is about. We say time and time again Europe must respond to change. Yet history, fear and, in some cases, distrust keeps us stuck in the same rut. Just before the job summit, the IMF warned the EU to beef up its investments in public infrastructure, which will boost demand in the short-term and help potential output in the medium-term. In Europe, those countries who want to spend are not allowed to and those countries who can spend have decided not to. It is a recipe for stagnation, deflation, flat growth and, sadly, for an erosion in citizens’ belief that the EU can work effectively to tackle its problems. Finally, what structural changes do we need? Yes, we need to align skills and training with market opportunities and we need to invest in sustainable technologies, eliminate red tape, etc. But structural reform cannot be a code word for an opportunity just to provide cheap labour. At a seminar at Parliament last week, a young unemployed Portuguese person said that firing parents to employ their sons and daughters at half their wages is no solution. And yes, while we all need to serve our internships and our apprenticeships, the Youth Guarantee cannot be an opportunity to use and abuse young people. I agree with the Swedish Prime Minister: we need decent jobs.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: gue/NGL Group. – Madam President, perhaps the results of this conference have been theoretically interesting, as a number of proclamations have resulted, as we know, about goodwill, the efforts that everyone has made to improve this catastrophic situation. Moreover, they said – President Barroso and Mr Commissioner – that there is a serious problem, a problem that also has to be solved, which is the importance of creating quality jobs. All right, we all agree. Now let us move on to the other part, to the reality of the impact of the European Commission's action. By the way of the troikas – of which, we know, there are two European institutions that are part of it – a relentless fight is underway against what you consider to be the rigid models of the labour market. Read, what we understand, workers' rights and decent wages.  For example, recently in my country, in Portugal, the government decided to raise the minimum wage from a measly 485 euros to another measly 505 euros. After all, twenty euros minimum wage increase. But a few days later, the European Commission or its alter ego showed enormous concern and discontent with this measure.  How is it possible to explain to you that quality employment means decent rights and wages for workers? Or how do you think that there are more and more workers, employed people, who are both poor – in fact, as the latest data revealed last Friday? Or do you know exactly that and make a few misunderstandings? For know that workers resist, fight and do not let themselves be deceived.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, let me frank: I am one of the youngest Members of this Parliament, and in the election campaign I went around telling young people that I wanted to fight so that young people in Europe would have a voice in this Parliament and so that their needs would be put first in the European Union. Now, after the Council two weeks ago in Milan I could go back to my constituency – to Gelsenkirchen, a city with a long history of unemployment – and tell the young people there that we are doing a lot here, that even the Council Presidency is calling one youth summit after another, and that we are really fighting to solve this problem. I am not going to say that to the young people that I am representing. I am not going to say that because this summit is not what needs to be done at the moment in the European Union. This summit should have been a wake-up call; it should have been a very clear message to change the way that we are dealing with the crisis and with the problem of youth unemployment at the moment. Instead, over and over again, we see people shaking hands and hear flowery speeches by Ministers telling us how important this problem is, but not showing commitment to really solving this problem at a European level. Young people do not need important powerful men and women at press conferences with photo opportunities. They need a change. They need a very clear end to business as usual. They need Jyrki Katainen to be a real investment Commissioner. They need Valdis Dombrovskis to realise that the new liberal agenda of recent years has fuelled inequality all over Europe. They need Jean-Claude Juncker to stop the blind and antisocial austerity measures that have been implemented in the crisis countries in recent years. This is what we, as young people in Europe, need in order to have a future.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a summit on employment in Europe, yes, but to do what? After Berlin and Paris, the Milan summit, to accept this evidence that youth employment must be Europe's priority, at the risk that they will turn away from the European Union. One more summit to push open doors but above all to break our economy again and again with deadly measures for youth employment, such as lower labour costs or market liberalization.  Europe continues tirelessly to deal with the effects of unemployment rather than tackling the causes of this endemic unemployment that affects all strata of our society, especially the youngest. In order to save jobs in Europe, we should protect ourselves from globalisation, free trade and unbridled liberalism; protect ourselves from broken-priced products from all over the world that are ruining our agri-food and industrial production; rethinking the Schengen Agreements and ending the aberrant system of seconded workers; help our businesses, particularly PMIs, SMEs and TPEs, which account for 80-90% of salaried jobs.  For youth employment, in particular, manual work should be revalued, apprenticeships should be re-established as a sure way to obtain qualifications, vocational training reform, and tutoring should be used within our companies.  Ladies and gentlemen, I say this solemnly: Europe is no longer an opportunity for young people, who are fleeing to other continents.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: Madam President, it is obvious that young people have been a victim of the economic crisis of the past years without having caused that crisis, and that is why it falls upon us to look at the problem of youth unemployment and creating employment opportunities for youth as an utmost priority.  So what shall we do to improve the situation of youth and bring youth back to the labour market? My first answer is labour market reform. All of those countries which have dared to make labour market reforms, even if difficult, even if unpopular ten years ago, their economies are stronger and more resilient and more competitive now. All of the countries which have postponed labour market reforms are in a more difficult situation. Too often youth is the victim of a rigid labour market which protects those who are already employed but takes away the opportunities for young people to enter the labour market.   My second answer is that we need to provide a framework in which the private sectors feel confident to invest, through competitiveness, innovation, research, solid public budgets and most notably structural reforms, because it is the private sector which mainly creates the jobs. Thirdly, Commissioner, I am a supporter of the Youth Guarantee Scheme because I think unemployment levels are so high in Europe that every measure which leads to bringing youth unemployment down is good. But we need to improve the Youth Guarantee Scheme. We need to tailor it to Member States, because we have it now in practice, and we have been talking about it for one, almost two years but we see that young people in Europe are not really finding many more jobs. What I would like to ask you is to make sure that you get the public employment services which are already meeting at European level more involved in tailoring the Youth Guarantee Scheme so that it responds to the needs of the people in various EU Member States. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Mr. Mureşan, you speak very nicely! My question to you is: have you ever created a job and know how to create a job in the private sector?

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: blue-card answer. – The distinguished MEP is asking me whether I know how the private sector creates jobs. My true belief is that it is not the public sector which creates the jobs of the future; it is indeed mainly the private sector and mainly the SMEs. Our duty is to put at their disposal an economic framework in which they feel confident to invest – so economic reform, a competitive and economic framework in which public money is managed with care, and not what basically your political family is advocating, which is spending more of people’s money and putting more public debt on their shoulders.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: Madam President, another summit, another failed act. It is necessary to understand once and for all the scale of the problem and the nature of the problem. We now have Member States in the European Union with an unemployment rate of more than 40 %. And what's behind this is that the engine of job creation has stopped working. That's the true nature of the problem. Therefore, this is not only solved by improving the professional insertion of young people or with an improvement in educational and formative system, however important it may be. This requires much larger-scale investment. This requires the creation of the missing jobs. And so we need to have much more access to credit for small and medium-sized enterprises, more time to reduce the public deficit, structural funds with faster access, and we have to face the need to build a real European investment support fund of the future.  This is what a real resolution of the problem of youth unemployment is all about. Do not play with the ambitious term, the important promise of the Young Guarantee.   (The speaker agrees to answer a question under the "blue card" procedure in accordance with Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – I agree with everything he has said, but I want to ask the following question: there has been talk here that we need training, we need investment, we need job creation, we need access to credit for SMEs. I agree with this, but no one will take credit, no one will create jobs unless we have a market. And my question is this: do you not think that the Commission, the European Union, needs to lean more on protecting the internal market of the European Union from all the avalanche of goods that comes in and creates unfair competition for industrialists and service providers in the European Union?

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. – Madam President, this is indeed a good question, but I think that the European economy must be forward-looking. It is true that we are faced with global competition, but Europe has to know how to produce products and services from the future, and that is why we have to know how to use the qualifications of our young people. They're prepared for it.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Commissioner Andor. Both the European Union and you personally still have a completely misunderstood cause of this crisis. In order to help employment and economic growth, the European Union is blindly using only two instruments. More regulation and more redistribution. If this does not work, it does even more of the same, even more regulation and even more redistribution. The complete opposite is needed to create jobs. The European Union's current strategy is much worse than if the European Union were doing nothing, because it only amplifies the same problems it is trying to solve. Four things are needed to really solve the problems: firstly, to strengthen the internal market as a fundamental pillar of the European Union; If you don't abide by these points, you can meet as much as you want, you won't solve youth unemployment.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Italian Presidency for organising this Conference on Work in Milan because it is essential to work together on a solution to this serious problem of unemployment. It is essential to do this together with representatives of national governments, European institutions and the private sector, because common solutions need common answers in my view. One of the main causes of youth unemployment, as has already been said, is that it is still not possible to match the qualifications of young Europeans with the needs of the labour market: simply to match demand with supply. This disease – and let me use the word – prevents our young people from finding work after school, simply because they have not been able to acquire the skills that businesses need.  If this inconsistency between education and the profession is not resolved as soon as possible, the Europe of tomorrow cannot be healthy, competitive and cannot return to growth!  However, we need concrete action. Let me tell you one: I am now launching a project in the Czech Republic aimed at bringing together successful entrepreneurs and young people through traineeships that will enable young people to get in touch first-hand with successful production realities. The aim is not to create yet another traineeship project, but to give opportunities to motivated young people and make them understand what the real needs of the labour market are. It would also be nice to propose this programme at European level in order to invest in our future and to give young people the opportunity to find the right motivation.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: Madam President, the Berlin and Paris summits are the realization of a failure and, unfortunately, the Milan Conference brings nothing new: insufficient and out-of-time budgets; fuzzy objectives — aggressive labour reforms against workers are insisted on; wage reductions and less rights and protection. In short, precarious work, increased temporality and unwanted part-time jobs.  In Spain, which is set an example, with more than 50% of youth unemployment, training contracts barely reach 7,800 contracts per month; with 50% youth unemployment, as I say, this is absolutely ridiculous. This is not the solution. In short, with all these policies decided at the summits, all that is found is the increase in poverty, the increase in inequality between our countries and within the European Union itself.  And an investment plan is announced without even knowing if there's going to be new money to carry it out. Do we think 1 % of the European Union budget is sufficient? It's absolutely ridiculous. We want to generate jobs and we want it to be of quality. Let's stop big summits and start putting resources for growth, to stimulate demand and public investment and utilities! States, in this situation, have to act as employers of last resort, and this will also stimulate private investment, because other words cannot access the appropriations.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen of the Council, a Summit is more than anything — and we have already had a few.  I do not know, bringing together sixteen heads of state and government for these poor conclusions seems frankly very un constructive. We have been told, once again, about structural reforms, of continuing to comply with the fiscal frameworks already established, which we know have been a real failure. He tells us, Mr Andor, that the great structural reform on employment is the Youth Guarantee. Don't tease us! The great structural reform, the major structural reforms in terms of occupation are the labour reforms that have been made in each of the countries and that have been a real disaster — in Spain, since the implementation of the last, 400 000 less occupied people . They tell us about investment and growth, but they do not give us anything, which has been customary in this House and finally they do not tell us about fundamental issues: what about the forced mobility of our young people, with the long-term disabled, with the impact of reforms on equality between men and women? And one last thing: don't talk about education when, right now, we are expelling young people from higher education because of the reform we are doing, because, for example, in college, rates are already absolutely unsusable for many of our young people. So please start turning these policies around that lead us to failure.

name: Laura AGEA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Prime Minister Matteo Renzi said in Milan: a Europe that thinks only of constraints is arid, without growth there is no work, without work there is no dignity, without dignity there is no Europe. Let us talk about constraints: for months the Five Star Movement has been calling for flexibility on the 3% limit and what we hear from the people and socialists is always the same: there is no growth without discipline. The PD, Renzi's party, has unreservedly approved austerity super-commissioner Katainen and is preparing to approve Europe's new government: Juncker's Austerity Commission. Without work there is no dignity! President Renzi said something right. Unfortunately, he simply says so, because in Italy the President wants to make redundancies easier by abolishing the guarantees that workers have. Without dignity there is no Europe, but what we are seeing here is a Europe without dignity, a Europe that asks the Greeks to give the Partion as collateral for a loan. A Europe that requires budgetary balance. So we imagine that President Renzi has said what he really thinks: more discipline, less growth, fewer rights and as far as work is concerned, he has not thought about it.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: Madam President, I would like to think that today I stand here before you not so much as an MEP but as a young person, because the growing numbers of young people that are unemployed in Europe is scaring me, for two reasons. First, I am afraid that my generation could be a lost generation and second, a lot of the young people of today will decide not to realise their potential here in Europe.  Programmes like the Youth Employment Initiative and the Youth Guarantee, borne out here in this agenda, have ambitious goals backed by substantial funding, and while there is much talk about their aspirations, we know very little about their achievements. I would very much like to know how many young people have benefited from the Youth Guarantee so far, and what trends we are observing in the reduction of unemployment as a result.   I do understand that perhaps the achievements might be difficult to assess and that there is a sound reason for that, but we need to adopt a fundamentally different approach, one that goes beyond pledges and guarantees and devises a grand strategy for tackling the problems faced by youth instead.  A three-step plan proposed last year which is based on tax breaks, entrepreneurship investment and skill-based education was backed by the Council and the European Parliament. Providing such a model, as it tackles several key components simultaneously, is crucial. Providing security and stability for the young people on our continent requires more than individual programmes and initiatives. It requires an overhaul of old practices, a reform from the bottom up, a change of thinking, culture and decisive action. As the Commissioner said, investing in the Youth Guarantee is crucial. I would say: let us start thinking about how to invest in people more than in guarantees. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Liisa JAAKONSAARI
text: blue card question. – First of all, I want to correct one mistake that you made. You said the Youth Guarantee Initiative was born here. It wasn't born here. It is an Austrian-Finnish innovation. It has emerged in the Member States, as many other initiatives must.  You had a good analysis, but I would now like to ask a question on the basic issue. What do you think of the fact that an overemphasised policy of discipline and austerity has actually led to an increase in youth unemployment in many countries?

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: blue-card answer. – I am a true believer that we should create the right environment for young people to develop their potential, to have a place where they can become entrepreneurs and create their own SMEs. I do not believe that the government is the one that should create jobs, and I do not think that budgetary discipline has anything to do with that.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done This summit is now the third of its kind. It is important – I do not want to say wonderfully – but it is very important that these summits exist at all, that the issue of employment has been discussed in a sufficiently serious framework. However, the result is more than sobering. The EUR 300 billion investment plan has been discussed, but it is simply not enough for the Member States to wait for the concrete plans. It is therefore long past time to invest more and sustainably again. I say this also to the previous speaker. This is the only way we can boost employment, domestic demand and the economy as a whole. So it is always about the big picture, about the macroeconomic picture in which young people are embedded with their fates and which we cannot easily wipe away. To do this, the Member States need more flexibility in deficit rules. Sustainable investments, such as infrastructure, renewable energy or education and training, are to be excluded from the calculations. Saving at all costs is the wrong way to go. Even the IMF tells us this in the meantime. And you have all taken note of that. Youth employment was a central theme of this summit. I can no longer list the number of times we have discussed this issue here in this Chamber and how many times we have urged swift action. Nevertheless, the situation of young people is becoming increasingly difficult. because what good is it for a young person who has already completed his third postgraduate degree when there are simply no jobs? Once again, the macroeconomic environment must be right! In implementing the Youth Guarantee, some countries need to step up their efforts. Yes that's right. At the same time, however, the Commission must simplify the processes so that the money from the Youth Initiative is finally collected. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: the blue card. – I want to ask: as if there is money, as if there are funds and systems, but unemployment is not falling, but it is increasing. Whether or not it seems to be too bureaucratic, it seems to be too bureaucratic and one should think about how to decentralise it and allow more local government to be put in place so that local authorities specifically address those problems, rather than just leaving it to national states and solving problems through national programmes.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I would like to agree with you on this. Of course, the procedures need to be simplified. I have looked at a few examples of the Commission's attempts to support projects here. I think that, precisely in simplifying the processes, in the cooperation of labour market administrations, a lot can certainly be made much more unbureaucratic. Here I share your view very well.

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a summit for nothing. This is how many media outlets presented, not only before but unfortunately after, the situation at the time of the Milan summit. It is also in this spirit, it seems, that a number of partners and participants in this summit came out, thinking that this summit had served no purpose. However, the issue, which concerns us all, is crucial for Europeans and is obviously crucial for the unemployed who are concerned and especially for young people. I had simply said to myself, perhaps very naively, that this summit would at least serve to put on top the pile the terrible unemployment of young people, which is our top priority. But the tools that we have put in place, and which we have been talking about since 9 a.m. this morning, are slow to get started and are not being implemented. Only two Member States have actually implemented the Youth Guarantee. How is this possible, when 24% of our young people are unemployed in Europe? How can we imagine that the Commission is not pushing the Member States to implement this scheme which it often talks about and which does not materialize? Should we stand idly by and allow this despair, which is accompanied by extremist sensibilities, to rise and progress? So, beyond the financial aspects that we have talked about, beyond the tools, we need to move the whole system: mobility, the correspondence between studies and the demand for employment, infrastructure, support, especially SMEs, which are the only ones to create jobs. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – My question is this. Speaking about youth unemployment particularly, and youth guarantees, would not the best guarantee for that youth be that they are not saddled for generations with massive amounts of debt caused by the addiction to over-spending by our current political elite? Would it not be better to give them, the future generations, a dynamic, low-taxation, fair-taxation economy where they can work hard and excel and make the future far better than our present?

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: "blue card" answer. Madam President, for us the stakes are precisely both the urgency of the response and this idea of responsibility and solidarity towards the new generation to prevent it from being a lost generation, as quite often itself qualifies itself. It's our responsibility. It is European and should not lead us to gargle simply with words but to set in motion a global European will, cooperating, moving forward on all fronts (education, the economy, mobility, infrastructure) and choosing our priorities.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: Madam President, these summits aim to express concern at the highest level about a dramatic problem for millions of young people without a future, for which they provide solutions that are not only inefficient but too often make the situation worse. At best, they offer a precarious horizon based on underemployment.  The Youth Guarantee employment programme, as we have already denounced here, is based on the premise that the main difficulty for young people in finding employment is their employability, that is, they do not have sufficient training or flexibility. The problem is how priorities are set: is it about benefiting large companies or solving people's problems?  The loosening and continuous precarization of working conditions means sacrificing people to solve the problems generated by financial speculation. The solutions go the other way: what we have to do is put the economy at the service of citizens and not put citizens at the service of the private interests of financial corporations. (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Jérôme LAVRILLEUX
text: "blue card" question. Madam President, I have just heard our colleague denounce big business, the private sector, and say that more government intervention is needed. But I did not quite understand what concrete solutions it proposed to promote the employment of young people, other than the use, no doubt, as in France, of public but precarious contracts that mean that after two years, our young people find themselves unemployed again. I would therefore be very happy to hear the solutions proposed by our colleague, rather than systematic criticism.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: "blue card" response. – Mr Lavrilleux, we can find solutions in many ways, as long as the way is the will to make people's needs the priority. Studies indicate that, only by promoting green employment, two million jobs would be created in Spain.  However, if management is to destroy the labour market, if the solution is to reduce redundancy — as Mr Renzi wants to do - if the solution is to raise the retirement age rather than reduce it to distribute the work, so we will not generate more jobs.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Madam President, the Milan Summit highlighted, by all leaders, high unemployment rates and, in particular, youth unemployment. President Schulz specifically stated that the crisis will only be over when Europe has a steady pace of growth and that we must now build the foundations for a better tomorrow. However, I would like to point out that unemployment is not being treated with wishful meals.  For example, the bulk of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund funds for the period 2014 to 2020 are intended to finance the cost of projects to help redundant people find a job or set up their own business. However, this has not contributed at all to the effort to reduce unemployment. On the contrary, unemployment rates are rising. There are 1,300,000 redundant people in Greece with training and skills desperately looking for work.  We are voting on reports, new measures and reforms to no real effect. And I ask you: can there be hope for young people without creating new jobs? Let us finally decide that money should go to development, not as a vague concept, but in targeted areas. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her It is, of course, very sad that there are so many unemployed people in Greece, but I fear that no social fund will help them. Greece has the common currency, the euro, and it is simply too expensive for Greece. Everything greece produces is too expensive. That's why it produces little. Industrial production is at the level of 1970. That is why they have the unemployed. The euro hurts Greece the most. (Applause)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I am not sure I heard a question there, but would you like to respond?

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: "blue card" answer. Madam President, not only is the euro bad for Greece, but also the way the government manages the money. For example, money from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, instead of going to the laid-off, goes to some companies that do skills seminars, etc. and which reap the bulk of the money, while little goes to the dismissed. And the money that the laid-off will get will be taken after at least ten months or even a year, and our government presents it as a primary surplus.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: Mr President, i should first of all thank László Andor for his work as Commissioner for Social Affairs and Employment, at a time when this has been a very difficult time for many people. It was precisely this difficult time that was the subject of the Milan summit. Of course, it is good for heads of government to come together to discuss the worrying employment situation, but it is even more wry if the 24 million unemployed people who are waiting at home at that time actually hear that nothing has come out of the summit. Jobs and growth are central to the new Commission, but how the Commission intends to spend that promised EUR 300 billion is not yet clear to me and not all heads of government seem equally enthusiastic about this plan. I would say that concrete proposals must be put on the table as soon as possible, because people cannot wait any longer, and all 28 Commissioners must put employment at the centre and think from their portfolio how they can contribute to growth and real good jobs.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a few days ago, when we looked at the Milan Labour Summit, our citizens hoped that something would change. Instead they saw for the umpteenth time the same disappointing show: a parade of powerful, well-dressed, unable to find a solution to the work problem.  Twenty-five million unemployed, including 18 million in the euro area, 3 million in Italy, are clasps calling on Europe to question the choices on which they have built the foundations of this failure. I am referring to the wrong currency, to the essential fixed budgetary parameters imposed by the European treaties. They have a world view that helps immigrants and does not help Europeans, does not help our young people, our unemployed. If the European Union wants to do so in the future, it must go beyond the good and superficial propaganda with which it has dealt with the problems to date. No more words, no more useless summits! It has to be done! We need a new monetary policy, we need a new investment policy that will support economic growth first. We need a new foreign policy that does not demonise economic partners that are vital to our entrepreneurs such as Russia. We need a different Europe, we need to change quickly before it is too late.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Madam President, let me first thank the Italian Presidency for having taken the initiative and the commitment to organise the high level conference on employment in Milan. It is important that Italy be insistent and determined on this front. Fixing unemployment and youth unemployment must remain Europe’s number one priority. For this reason, it is now essential that we make a unified effort towards creating quality jobs. We must remain focused, since – let me repeat this – the crisis is by no means over yet.  I particularly welcome the opening of a dialogue on the matter of the system of co-financing for European projects. Grounds for agreement were found on the need to reform the system, which at the moment does not allow countries – especially those engaging in reforms – to strike a proper balance between their deficit rules and growth.  This is a very important step in the right direction which will give Member States greater flexibility, which is much needed.  It will be essential for the next European Council on 23 and 24 October to sketch out specific proposals for jobs and job creation in Europe. In particular, it is imperative that very specific responses be given to the requests from the Parliament to know how the EUR 300 billion investment plan presented by President Juncker will be financed. Parliament is uncomfortable with vagueness on the issue of the sources of financing. The people demand and deserve clarifications on this.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: Blue card question. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I wanted to ask Mr Benifei how he thinks, if he has ever worked in a small and medium-sized Italian company, how a small and medium-sized company in Italy can be competitive and create new jobs with a tax rate of almost 70% with the labour market, how we have it and how you are setting it up with your party at the moment in Italy.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Answer to a blue card question. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Mrs Beghin for giving me the opportunity to reply, let us say that here, many colleagues in the EFDD Group, the Italian cricketers answer and ask questions on Italian issues instead of asking questions about what has been talked about here. We're not in a Grillo meetup! On the question that has been raised, which is not entirely relevant, I think that what we are trying to do in Italy, including in Europe, is to improve the situation for our businesses. But that seems to me to be a provocative question: it is difficult to answer in 20 seconds.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: Madam President, history seems to be repeating itself: European governments meet at summits and Europeans are walking to the edge of the precipice once again. It's kind of deja vu. After this summer, five years later, very negative macroeconomic data tell us that we are once again entering recession in Europe — this would already be the third – and all international analysts tell us that we are once again a source of the problems for the global economic recovery, further causing, as we have said today, a hugely painful unemployment rate, a lot of poverty , precariousness and forced emigration in many countries.  The worst part of all this is that some of this pain is self-imposed by the policies we are implementing. So please listen to all those who ask us to activate demand as the only way to use public sector lever and investment to get out of this economic crisis. Because otherwise it will be impossible to get jobs back, even for young people, on this continent. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: blue-card question. – I am actually here to represent the UK and not the rest of Europe. What we have seen in the UK is really high youth unemployment. We have got nearly one million people unemployed. That is unacceptable. And that is because of the fundamental principle of this place, of the free movement of people, which is driving wages down and unemployment up in my country, do you not agree?

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Please answer that ‘question’ in thirty seconds.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: "blue card" response. – It is difficult to answer a question which you have not asked, but I will tell you that I here come to represent the Europeans — not only the United Kingdom — and also to set out the problems faced by my country, which Catalonia suffers from, which is suffering from Spain, and I believe that the problems we are living in today cannot be attributed to free movement. And over the past century, by preventing free movement and bringing economies to protectionism, we have witnessed the greatest social, economic and political disasters this continent has experienced.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Madam President, today 1% of the youth guarantee funds have been paid to the Member States. The Commission blames the Member States, the Member States blame the Commission. In this game, it is the young people who lose out. So I just want to ask you the following question: What do you intend to do to speed up the process of a mechanism that was decided in 2013, knowing that it is now 2014?  First, do you envisage a proper framing of the measure, which allows everyone to find themselves in what they want to do in relation to these young people? Second, do you foresee the issue of pre-financing? Today, two Member States are entitled to pre-financing, why not all Member States? Thirdly, there is a sense that the Union is taking with one hand what it gives with the other. Because of austerity, some public operators have to save money and save money at the expense of young people. Could we not immunise the support of young people against the current austerity plans, which would enable the investment of both the Member States and the Union? (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 149, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: blue-card question. – I agree that young people are the losers when everyone bickers, but can we accept that ‘one size fits all’ does not always work? Can we accept that the needs of one country can be different from the needs of another? Of course we should be doing more to get our young people back into work, but could that not be done far better by the Member States themselves, directly on the things that they know about, if this were taken out of the EU budget and given back to the Member States to help young people themselves?

name: Maria ARENA
text: "blue card" answer. Madam President, I think that the youth guarantee satisfies the need for Member States to respond in particular to the situations experienced by young people. Contrary to what you say, the youth guarantee meets the specific needs of young people in neighbourhoods, not just in regions or in Member States. It is really a tool that, if fluidized in relation to the means given, could respond perfectly to realities on the ground.

name: Eva KAILI
text: Madam President, the results for employment in the European Union are disappointing, once again, as part-time jobs are not solid jobs, nor can one be complacent. The guarantee for young people is 'aspirin', to buy some time until we understand that we need to change cruising and strategy. We must stop being passive in our decisions and in tackling unemployment, and activate the direction of growth.  The digital age, as it is here, must not be overcome again by developments. We must further strengthen horizon 2020, link European capital to the private sector by boosting innovation, admit that the traditional way of tackling unemployment still allows it to increase in countries within the European Union and inequalities to widen. And if the North holds out, the South is wiped out.  The consequences in the age of globalisation, as we have understood lately, and epidemics are no longer limited by borders, especially between us, and if we do not change sail, we may soon meet the Commissioner for Crisis Management here more often. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: James CARVER
text: blue-card question. – Madam President, it seems to me that you are all following the mindset of that great philosopher, Homer. I am not speaking about the ancient Greek poet but the American cartoon character, Homer Simpson, when he said ‘a fool and his money are soon parted – I will pay good money to have that one explained to me’. Speaking as a small businessman, does my colleague not accept that the best way to stimulate employment and the economy is to have a bonfire of regulations, in distinct contradiction to the outpourings from the European institutions?

name: Eva KAILI
text: "blue card" question. Madam President, just as I said in my speech, we must strengthen the link between European funds and the private sector in order to give money to initiatives, especially in the field of innovation, because that is where we can create jobs for young people and women. We want further support, not rules that restrict the initiative. It's the other way around. We want aid, but not a benefit policy. This traditional way has proved that it cannot perform. We need money to develop initiatives, and not just to support people affected by unemployment for a certain period of time.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Dear colleagues, I think it is very important that we address the issue of job creation in every plenary session. As we know, the employment issue is also a priority in the EU Treaty and in the Europe 2020 strategy. This Europe 2020 strategy aims to reach the employment level of 75%. This is a very ambitious goal. With the exception of a few western European countries, I think the other Member States find it very difficult to reach. It is also difficult for us to achieve this objective and to help increase the level of employment by means that are effective. I would like to note here that I think it is a big mistake that we are only dealing with young people now, because there are many groups – the elderly, the low-skilled or the disabled – that are worth addressing, and this issue needs to be focused on them. So I suggest we take a more complex approach.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. I do agree with all those who believe that job creation is a priority and a recurring issue. The result is that the Commission has now embraced the proposal of many of us to raise the age limit of the European Youth Guarantee from 25 to 30 years. At the same time, despite all our efforts, it must be noted that the examination and verification of member states' accounts and statistical accounts is as important as many other instruments here. I can give an example of the case of my country, Hungary, where the government has, by the way, introduced a public works programme in which people are paid €150 a month for four to six hours of work a month, but these people are seen as employed. A word like 100, if we set sound goals here, that's a good thing, but control is just as important when it comes to their implementation.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, 'in the same play viewers'. We hear the same thing all the time. We see at the last summit in Milan that the European Union continues to support its competitiveness in the 'Chineseisation' of wages, that is to say in the reduction of wages, a wrong policy, while on the contrary it must invest in new technologies, education and training.  But, how to do that when with violent fiscal adjustment it reduces public spending on education itself? It therefore continues to rely on austerity and must boost demand. It continues to support the rescue of the banks: EUR 1.6 trillion was given to rescue the banks, i.e. to socialize the losses of the banks. Only EUR 6 billion to guarantee young people. Another EUR 1 trillion from Mr. Draghi, again for the banks. Failure, therefore, in the whole process, failure for Greece with the policies they implement there, the memorandum, which has dissolved and impoverished Greek society.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Madam President, the youth guarantee scheme as a new mechanism is in response to the economic crisis, a kind of firefighting measure. But it's not just the crisis that's to blame for youth unemployment, because the roots of this problem are much deeper in my belief.  That is why only strong cooperation and a strong partnership between the European, national, regional, local level can really yield results in this case. But also a sincere partnership with the education system and of course especially with the private sector where I particularly emphasize small and medium-sized enterprises.  I want to add three incentives to this: First, the creation of a really effective youth self-employment mechanism, secondly, the mobility of young people within the European Union, and thirdly, the conclusion that the digital market and energy as a youth employment sector are something that is current, which I have heard from Mr. Dell Vedova, but I also add agriculture and tourism.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: Madam President, I come from a people from southern Europe, galicia, battered by debt and struck by the troika. In my country, people are still out of work, thousands of young people have left the country in search of work since 2008, many thousands are still in the country looking for work for long hours, but they cannot.  I would really like to ask the Council and the Commission when there will be real measures to ensure that young people and other people without work have jobs, quality jobs, and that they do not become poor workers and workers as they do today.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: I would particularly like to ask my compatriot, Commissioner Andor, how much you, Commissioner, believe in the concept of decent work, the concept of 'decent job'? Many documents from the European Union and the Council of Europe are now talking about a respectable workplace, and not just any job. And my next question is: how do you think, in the last 5 years, since you have represented the world of work here as a Hungarian, as a new Commissioner for the Member States, how well have you managed to emerge from slavery, for example, your compatriots or the enslaved workers of the poorer Member States? How about the fact that a Hungarian woman recently summed up the situation of workers as 'replaceable objects'. Do we live our lives in vulnerability, disenfranchiseation, total disenfranchiseing of labour law? What result is this for you?

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. Europe needs major changes and, above all, a decisive modernisation of the European social model. Today, we are paying the highest price for the absence of these changes, which is high unemployment, not only among young people, but also among women and the elderly. We continue to replace many of our society's communities in their activities, handing out money without parallel implementing tools that give our society opportunities, not guarantees. No government can guarantee young people jobs, training or traineeships, and this is what the Youth Guarantee scheme is all about. It is not governments that have such competences, but entrepreneurs, which the European Union cares about by increasing bureaucracy or raising various burdens. Let us finally start working, providing opportunities for young people, and since we have already made this unwise decision about the Youth Guarantee programme, let us implement it with great responsibility. Today's implementation shows that this responsibility is lacking. Finally, where are the proposals for unemployed women and the elderly?

name: Milan ZVER
text: I congratulate the President-in-Office of Italy for holding this important conference in Milan, where youth unemployment has once again put high on the agenda. It will certainly have some positive effect, even if we know what it's like when the heads of government and states meet. However, I am less and less pleased that the Member States are not taking full advantage of all the resources they have in overcoming youth unemployment – not even European. Bureaucratic mills are grinding slowly in the Member States, it is known that only two countries have taken full advantage of the guarantee scheme. It is a good sign when the Commissioner talks about education, when he is looking for ways to tackle youth unemployment – that is a good thing. The key question remains who should create jobs. Administrative measures will not create productive jobs for young people. This is not a natural way, the natural path is to create better conditions for entrepreneurship.

name: László Andor
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, honourable Members, I believe the Milan Summit of Heads of State and Government was a step forward, compared to Berlin and Paris, because Prime Ministers and leaders of public employment services spoke in much more concrete terms about the Youth Guarantee and its implementation in their respective countries than in previous cases. Indeed, there were reports about the progress being made and the Commission also keeps reporting about the results of pilot projects, as well as the actual Youth Guarantee implementation, on its own website.  Ms Paunova and others who were asking about this can find information about it on the DG Employment website, and I have also been reporting regularly to this House about the progress made. The Youth Guarantee is, as you know, an EU-wide initiative, but it is not a uniform model. It is tailor-made. Countries themselves were designing their own youth guarantee implementation plans according to common guidelines which were provided at EU level. This is something to be emphasised, because Mr Mureșan as well as Mr Arnott were asking about this aspect. Certainly, the Youth Guarantee is tailor-made in the case of each and every EU Member State. We took inspiration from the pioneers, Austria and Finland, inside the EU and all countries have to apply the common principles – the four-month deadline, for example, and the importance of quality jobs, apprenticeships, training or learning according to their own needs and capacity.   We have to clarify in such a broad discussion what the Youth Guarantee actually is and what it is not. The Youth Guarantee is primarily about the school-to-work transition. It is about improving school and training performance; improving labour market performance and the connection between the two, because this is where many young people, including the so called NEETs, have been lost – and not only at the time of the crisis. We are not only responding to the crisis with the Youth Guarantee, but also to the previous model of economic development, which was not inclusive enough and because of which Europe was losing significant growth potential. The Youth Guarantee is certainly not a tool against deflation because, again, on deflation it is the European Central Bank which needs to act, and the surplus countries of the euro zone, by boosting investment and also wages. It is not a tool to generally promote industrial competitiveness, because innovation has to be promoted for that purpose, and it is certainly not a tool to respond to asymmetric shocks in the monetary union, because for that we would need a counter-cyclical fiscal capacity.  The new financial instrument, the Youth Employment Initiative, is in a way an embryonic fiscal capacity to respond also to the cyclical rise of youth unemployment in the European Union, but it has to function according to the rules of the structural funds. The Commission has to observe these rules and we have to be held accountable according to the regulations. I am sure that is also what the House would demand from the Commission. Nevertheless, the Commission has been doing its utmost to help the Member States to accelerate implementation of the Youth Guarantee and the financial instruments supporting it. We have been helping to design the programmes; we have been helping to exchange experiences and also accelerating the adoption when necessary.   Those who are still not satisfied with the speed, like Ms Steinruck and Mr Ropé, obviously would like to see a different type of fiscal capacity, for example in the form of automatic stabilisers, because that would indeed immediately provide financial support, but under the current design of the EMU, such capacity does not exist.    I think Mr Kósa is right. Apart from the young generation, we also have to speak seriously and also act seriously about the unemployment in the European Union. The youth, those under 25, represent about a fifth of total unemployment in the European Union. Total unemployment in the last one year has been falling, contrary to what some Members of this House actually believe. The problem is that it has not been falling fast enough, it has not been falling everywhere, and very often the quality of the new jobs is not what we would like to see. Indeed the quality of employment has also suffered during the crisis years and the Commission’s initiatives have to respond to all these aspects: the speed of job creation, the balanced nature of economic growth and also the quality of employment. Where the overall macroeconomic picture is concerned – and I agree with Ms Regner, this is very important – it is obviously true that the youth guarantee alone will not create a job-rich recovery. We outlined an employment package in 2012 with a host of measures that need to be taken: shifting taxation away from labour, for example, which Member States are capable of doing just very, very slowly, but it also should be seen as a priority. Boosting entrepreneurship and helping enterprises to employ more people is indeed an important part of this broader policy. But certainly, when we are facing the risk of another downturn it is also important that fiscal as well as monetary policies use their existing room for manoeuvre to stimulate the economy and to boost investment, which certainly should not remain just a buzz word of our time. I do not think it is helpful when some blame migrants for the level of unemployment in the EU, including for youth unemployment. In fact the two countries that receive the highest numbers of migrant workers in the Europe Union, Germany and the UK, are doing relatively well. Germany has had relatively low unemployment rates during the crisis as well and the UK is experiencing one of the fastest falls in unemployment, despite having received relatively large numbers of EU migrants. Finally, on the question of decent work, because indeed this has been a priority for the Commission, not only inside the EU but also internationally, just in the last one year we rolled out a number of initiatives: the quality framework on restructuring, the quality framework on traineeships, a new health and safety strategy for the next seven years and the European platform proposal against undeclared work. All these initiatives are supposed to help boost the quality of employment and improve industrial relations in the European Union, but certainly they do not cover all aspects of the employment policy in the Member States because a large part of it is dependent on national law, for example in the case which has been mentioned, about Hungary. Indeed, the Commission finds it regrettable that some of these domestic measures have caused serious damage to the quality of employment, and the country operates with an inflated public scheme which is on the one hand quite costly and secondly does not help many of the participants reintegrate into the labour market at a later stage. But we have been promoting this as well inside the EU and we have been doing that also internationally, in the context of the G20.  Just yesterday we had a meeting with the representatives of Bangladesh, involving the ILO as well, because we cannot allow unfair competition to continue internationally which does not respect the rights of workers and does not protect workers from risks to their health and safety at the workplace. I hope you find all these initiatives positive and helpful. We remain committed to boosting the quality of employment in general, but also specifically for young people in Europe.

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, very briefly because I do not think there are any conclusions to be drawn. I would like to thank all the Members who have spoken in this debate with passionate speeches pointing out the common interest and the common objective that I believe we all have in the various positions, which is to tackle and possibly start a solution, the issue of employment, youth employment in particular, employment in other categories with difficulties and possibly good employment. The start of solving structural problems, such as those posed by unemployment, cannot be separated from a coherent commitment by the Member States and the Institutions of the Union, which must be achieved through concrete and effective measures to be implemented quickly and without bureaucratic burdens. Other high-level meetings that reinforce the impetus launched by those organized in Berlin, Paris and Milan, which are obviously not places where solutions are found and implemented, but I believe they are places where open discussion and open discussion take concrete policies forward. They will certainly be able to contribute to the monitoring of the actions already decided upon and to deepen those analyses of the conditions necessary for the resumption of employment launched at the Milan Conference. I would therefore like to thank once again, Madam President, all those who have spoken for their attention and contribution.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This third high-level meeting (a whole programme!) is intended to exchange experiences to increase employment rates, encourage entrepreneurship and enable the establishment of instruments to combat unemployment. The implementation of the Youth Guarantee presented to us here as the miracle cure is only a palliative and does not allow for the long-term integration of young people into the labour market. Five million young people are currently unemployed in Europe and 6 billion euros are spent on the initiative (1200 euros per young people). Too little for concrete results or far too much for the futility of the measure, everyone will judge... On the other hand, you are talking about solving the problem of unemployment and reviving economic activity in Europe by implementing different policies, even though the EU has voted for the so-called 'detached workers' directive which creates real competition in our national labour markets and generates frightening social dumping. Is that not a profound contradiction?

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing – It is very important that young people find employment after school and be able to make full use of the acquired education, because if they fail to do so and do not develop a working habit at a young age, they can easily fall into frustration and stop believing in their own abilities, which will ultimately mean increasing tensions in society and an additional burden on the social systems of individual Member States. I think it is time to admit that the European employment model has serious problems and shortcomings, as evidenced by the 7.6 million jobs lost in the period 2007-2013. We need to show young people that they have the opportunity to get a job and give them hope for a better future. It must be acknowledged that, as a result of the reforms undertaken in individual Member States, the labour market situation has been partially stabilised, but I do not share Mr Barroso's boundless optimism, because the situation is still serious and we must approach it. However, I can agree that growth in Europe is very fragile and uneven, and that the Member States that have been responsible and have carried out structural reforms are now in significantly better shape and in a more favourable situation. Italy, where significant reform has been carried out to help young Italians under 25, can serve as a good example.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: The third employment meeting held in Milan on 8 October did not produce the desired results: good intentions and the relaunch of a programme agenda for employment, not only for young people, through the necessary reforms of the labour market.
