As structural unemployment and disparity in labour markets at national level, especially in terms of the skills of job seekers and the type of work available on the labour market, are increasing within the EU, reform is urgently needed. What went wrong, why no concrete and timely response was given on issues such as: wage bargaining models, adaptability to economic cycle conditions; rebalancing labour costs; planning and adoption of unemployment benefits and insurance schemes; degree of flexibility in and out of the labour market, labour mobility and rationalisation of contractual forms; and skills profile of unemployed workers? It is unacceptable that Heads of State or Government have failed to produce a joint document and have not formalised a dating programme to solve employment problems. Expectations do not pay off, especially during crises, and we are in danger of finding ourselves in subsequent analyses not only of poverty, but also of why extremism in Europe is taking place.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Youth unemployment is a theme that guests at every plenary session of the current legislature. Rightly so, because this is one of the more serious problems that Europe is currently facing. Youth guarantees are not a sufficient means of soles, but they are an important instrument that can provide important support for structural reforms carried out by Member States. However, their implementation must be accelerated. This should be used to reform labour markets in the Member States and to match young people's skills with employers' expectations. But that's not all. The permanent eradication of unemployment is only possible by creating new jobs. Economic growth needs to be stimulated, because only in this way will we create a good climate for business development. Employers who have been forced to cut jobs as a result of the crisis must be provided with good conditions for restoring these jobs. Furthermore, we must support the entrepreneurship of young people and create opportunities for them to set up their own businesses. The support system must be comprehensive and include both administrative facilitation and access to finance.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. Europe must develop instruments that promote growth and employment. Economic governance must also be strengthened," said The Italian Secretary of State, Benedetto Della Vedova, today during the debate on the outcome of the Milan Employment Summit, the third employment summit in 15 months. More generally, it could not have been maintained in the face of 25.7 million unemployed in Europe, of whom 5.3 million are young people aged between 15 and 24. And in the face of a frightening job situation, particularly in southern Europe: in Spain, Italy and Greece, one in two young people is out of work. EUR 15 billion is available annually at European level to promote youth employment measures. From the Youth Guarantee – where only three of the 34 applications submitted have so far been approved – to the Youth Employment Initiative for regions with youth unemployment of more than 25 percent. Experts agree that multi-billion-dollar EU unemployment programmes are at best a drop in the ocean. What Europe needs in order to sustainably increase employment is growth, which is a good framework for business and innovation, access to sources of finance and the reduction of bureaucracy. Jobs can only be created through targeted growth and competition policies as well as good business conditions.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Unemployment in the European Union is slowly decreasing thanks to efforts at European and Member State level. However, the pace and scope of these actions are still insufficient. The funds secured under the Youth Guarantee are being spent slowly and the implementation of unemployment policies in the Member States is progressing reluctantly. It is clear that reducing unemployment requires not only training programmes and funding for employment agencies, but also profound structural reforms concerning both the vocational education system and the functioning of small and medium-sized enterprises, which provide the most jobs and are responsible for the largest share of income. During the debate, many people stress that the fight against unemployment, in order to achieve a lasting effect, must address its causes and not just address the removal of symptoms. In order for employment initiatives to be effective and to achieve the EU target of 75% of employment for people aged 20-64, Member States need public investment to encourage small and medium-sized enterprises to create new jobs. The lack of economic growth will exacerbate the labour market crisis in the longer term. The Youth Guarantee will not replace macroeconomic instruments that operate universally across the market, improving not only the situation of young people, but also older workers whose experience and skills are as important for Europe's development as enthusiasm and modern education for young people.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – A major problem in the Union remains the high level of youth unemployment, which, despite the downward trend, remains high in some Member States. In this context, effective monitoring and exchange of best practices on the implementation of the Youth Guarantee and the strategy to combat unemployment is crucial at European level.  Another issue is the increase in the number of long-term unemployed. According to 2014 statistics, almost 13 million people have been unemployed for more than a year and more than a third of the unemployed have been unemployed for more than two years. Long-term unemployment has negative consequences both for people who are long out of work and for Member States' budgets. The cost of living without a job is estimated, for example, at PLN 10.5 billion. annually in Poland. However, most employment-related competences belong to the Member States, and it is therefore their responsibility and responsibility to have many aspects necessary to increase employment. The necessary measures include the correlation of education systems with the needs of the labour market facilitating the transition from education to employment and the development of the knowledge economy.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: , written.- Unemployment in the European Union has recorded record rates in the last five years, in particular youth unemployment. Urgent measures to boost job creation are essential. These measures must focus on successful projects of entrepreneurs and on strengthening their competitiveness. Supporting institutions should be developed to relieve entrepreneurs of administrative burdens, help modernise their business and facilitate their exit into other markets.  Still too few EU funds are directed directly to the projects of entrepreneurs and the strengthening of entrepreneurial infrastructure. Thus, in the Republic of Croatia, in the OP Regional Development and Competitiveness, which defines the use of 6.7 billion euros in the period from 2014-2020, only 14.1 percent of the funds or 970 million euros are allocated for the development of business competitiveness, i.e. for investments in medium and small entrepreneurs and support institutions. The European Commission should more actively encourage Member States to implement youth measures more faster and to use the resources allocated to young people.  Young people need jobs today, not in the future. Many talented and smart young people go to other continents. Europe, which is ageing at a galloping rate, has become a nursery for young people, and our economy cannot handle this. Conferences are important and I support their maintenance, but if they are not followed by measures and their implementation in practice become meaningless, and we do not want that.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. At the beginning of October, the European Union organised yet another conference on employment in Europe. On the program: always the same poncifs and wishful thinking... Youth employment would thus be the priority of the EU. Boosting growth and economic activity would also solve the problem of unemployment, etc. Obviously it's better when you say it... This conference, as we understand, was, in fact, just one more communication operation. The EU with its ultraliberal dogmatism is precisely at the root of the explosion of unemployment in Europe! And what about the European directive known as "detached workers" which has created appalling competition in the labour market in France, Germany, Italy... And what about the fact that the EU is demanding more and more immigration at a time when unemployment and impoverishment are exploding! In reality, without a return to reasoned protectionism, without the restoration of national borders, without the questioning of ultraliberal dogma (free and undistorted competition), national economies will remain sluggish and sustainably impacted by the devastating effects of globalization, and zero growth will soon sink into recession.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. – The risk that such important events, such as the Milan one on employment, could turn into a useless catwalk if concrete content is not developed is well founded. The Italian semester is almost over and there is still general talk without really addressing, and above all solving, youth unemployment, the all-Italian issue of the exodates and the difference in salary between men and women for the same job. No more walkways that distance the European institutions from the citizens. The Milan Summit, among other things, was in the run-up to serious floods in economically very important regions of Italy. There was no sympathetic reference at the summit to these events from eu summits.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: in writing. – I welcome the conclusions of the employment summit in Europe, held in Milan on the initiative of the Italian Presidency. Unemployment in the EU, especially among young people, women and people with disabilities, is scandalous. The EU has taken initiatives to boost employment from the Structural Funds, notably through the European Social Fund, but also through the Youth Initiative, which gives new opportunities to apprenticeships and enhance skills. Unfortunately, however, these actions are not enough. Particularly in the European South, which is plagued by the economic crisis and the ill-considered unemployment rates. That is why we need more determination and flexibility on the part of the EU. We need new targeted funding lines, which will contribute to the recovery of the European economy and to maintaining social cohesion. It is the responsibility of all of us to build a stable framework that favours public and private investment, creativity, start-ups, lifelong learning and mobility. The EU is one of the largest economies in the world, our young people and human resources, as a whole, the best it has ever had at its disposal. We must strengthen the competitiveness of the European market and keep our young people within borders.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: in writing. – The Milan Employment Summit has not only demonstrated that the EU does not want to, but also that it cannot tackle the problem of unemployment which is exacerbating and torturing millions of families. European Union policy distributes unemployment to more people, generalises flexible employment, especially among young people, gives employers free labour, with business subsidy programmes and fake training, crushes wages and struggles with rights that young people seek never to know. The aim of the EU and the parties supporting it is to reduce the demandingness of workers, especially young people. With the EU's "fundamental principles" on freedom of movement of capital and worker mobility, it ensures a cheap workforce in large groups, while at the same time throwing thousands of workers into unemployment. Despite the emerging competition, the EU's single aim is to make this situation permanent, this system cannot guarantee the right to work. It needs the armies of the unemployed to ensure cheap labour force, a basic condition for profits, competitiveness. Securing the right to full, permanent work requires organized struggle, overthrowing the system that produces unemployment, poverty and exploitation.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the report by Philippe De Backer, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: implementing the priorities for 2014 (2014/2059(INI)) (A8-0019/2014).

name: Philippe DE BACKER
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, let me first of all thank my colleagues shadow rapporteurs from the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs for their good cooperation, as well as the rapporteurs of the opinions of the various other committees. It is not always easy to overcome the ideological contradictions that exist in this House in this dossier, but I think we have managed to write a very sound report. I also think it is important for this Parliament to be in a state of opinion on the European Semester. It is a very important policy instrument for the Commission and for the European institutions to enable economic coordination between member states. I therefore call on the whole Parliament to support this report by a broad majority in tomorrow's vote. We all know that our European economy has experienced its worst crisis since the Second World War. The very weak economic recovery that is now occurring shows that the crisis is still not over and that we will have to make further efforts. We are therefore making agreements here in the European Parliament with the European institutions and the Member States to come out of the crisis together. Budgetary discipline, national reforms, but also European investment must make it possible to re-create economic growth and create jobs. That is also the key message of my report. That is also the key message I will be putting here today on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. The work isn't finished. The crisis has shown that we have lived long at the expense of future generations and this needs to be restored. The crisis has also shown that our economies are strongly linked, whether we like it or not. We cannot therefore afford to just look at our own backyard, because if we do that we are in the risk of actually losing an entire generation of young people. Member States will therefore have to show more ownership of the agreements they make with the European institutions. Politically, it is not always easy to explain what needs to be done; the necessary reforms to be implemented in the various Member States. But the European Semester makes it clear that coordination is needed. We must make the best use of European funds to support innovation, research, infrastructure investment. But at the same time, member states must also realise that ownership is necessary to make economic coordination possible, with this report and with the European Semester. If we do not do this, if we tolerate that certain Member States do not take Europe into account at the expense of other Member States, what is the future of the European Semester and what is the future of the European Union? I also think it is important to continue to debate in this House and to ask for more democratic control over the whole process. Here too, my report is very clear. The work isn't finished there either. We must ensure that the European Parliament can play its full role as a democratic institution that exercises democratic control over European processes. The community method is, of course, the preferred method for this. For example, we must ensure that democratic control is exercised over all programmes proposed by the Troika. My report also sets out very clearly what tasks are ahead of us. Firstly, a number of tasks at European level to strengthen our competitiveness, to ensure that the Member States, but also the European Union as a whole remain competitive, conquer new export markets and also make full use of it to support the growth that needs to come from SMEs, the business community and the private market. Structural reforms must also be carried out, in the labour market, in the pension system, in social security, not in order to organise social degradation, which is certainly not – but to modernise our social security, and to ensure that future generations can continue to benefit from that social security. The conclusion is therefore very clear. All Member States must take responsibility. Only 10% of European recommendations are actually put into practice today. Policies need to be better coordinated economically to ensure that we can create growth and jobs. We must also ensure that the course that Europe has chosen is maintained. It will also deliver results in terms of growth, jobs and employment in the long term. I believe that the right policy mix consists of a combination of monetary policy, fiscal policy and structural reforms. I therefore ask this House to present my report tomorrow with fully support. I hope that this will send a clear signal to the Council and the Commission to ensure that the European Semester remains the essential policy instrument needed to create new economic growth in Europe and the Member States.

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am pleased to have the opportunity to take part this morning in the debate on the European Semester. I have carefully examined the draft resolution which forms the basis of this debate and I am impressed by the wide range of issues that are addressed and the importance of the issues addressed. In fact, this morning's debate goes beyond the mechanics of economic coordination. We are here to discuss how Europe conducts its economic policy, its employment policy and all the other policies that contribute to employment and growth. The resolution focuses on the implementation of the priorities for 2014: implementation is key; we already have strategic guidelines, at Eu ropean Union level, the conclusions of the European Council and, for each Member State, country-specific recommendations. The implementation of these recommendations requires bold structural reforms, including in areas of national competence, which are sometimes at odds with acquired rights. The benefits are slow to show up, which in turn increases political pressure. The Council is strongly encouraging the Member States to carry out these reforms. This debate is about priorities for 2014, but we must recognise that the European Semester is not an exercise and cannot be an exercise in which priorities change radically from one year to the next. Some details may change from one year to the next, but the priorities themselves fall within a longer time horizon. That is exactly what the Presidency is doing this autumn. Let us look at the European Semester in the wider context of the Europe 2020 strategy and its mid-term review. The review must also strengthen the link between all the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy and the European Semester. That is why the Presidency has launched a political reflection at Council level on the mid-term review of the Europe 2020 strategy. We decided from the outset that all stakeholders should be involved in this exercise, including, for example, those involved in sectors such as agriculture, culture and cohesion. The exercise is still ongoing, but I would like to take this opportunity to highlight some of the initial results. Firstly, all the debates held so far have confirmed the importance of keeping the focus of the Europe 2020 strategy on employment and growth.  The second message is ambition. Despite the significant progress that has been made, especially with regard to energy and education, we must recognise that we are not yet on the right track in all areas. Employment, in particular, is a matter of grave concern. But, although progress is insufficient, we must not pursue less ambitious objectives. The third message concerns the strengthening of governance. Policy guidelines issued in the context of the European Semester can sometimes be bitter pills. But I am pleased to say that no one wants to weaken the semester. In fact, we must try to streamline the process and improve its results. We must also ensure that all those who have to implement the reforms are included in the process. This includes not only governments, but also parliaments and other stakeholders, both at national and EU level. Allow me to say a few words about sectoral contributions to this debate. With regard to competitiveness, the Council confirmed in September that the single market and industrial competitiveness must be firmly integrated into the Europe 2020 strategy. In the field of research and innovation, in particular, which play a key role in Europe's economic recovery, the quality of investment in research and innovation is just as essential as the level of expenditure. We must do more to promote a European research area. In the field of economic policy, the Council's approach is based on three pillars which represent a combination of measures to be implemented simultaneously and jointly by the Member States. The first is the structural reform, to which I have already referred and which is closely linked to the second. The second is investment, which is a key priority for the Italian Presidency, and the third is the need to consolidate confidence, through a differentiated budgetary policy geared to growth and respect for the Stability and Growth Pact, while at the same time making use of the flexibility inherent in its rules. The Council welcomes President-elect Juncker's announcement to present an investment initiative within the first three months of his term of office. Investment will help to relaunch demand in the short term, but will also contribute to increasing the long-term growth potential of the economy. With regard to employment and social affairs, the Council discussed the Europe 2020 strategy last week, and the Italian Presidency met the Heads of State at the beginning of October to find solutions to the problem of unemployment, but this concerns the in-depth debate we had at the previous point.  In this regard, I would like to draw your attention to the letter signed by 22 Member States, with the support of the Italian Presidency, which stresses the need for better integration of gender equality into the revised strategy. In conclusion, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have set out the main points of our work so far. The Ministers for the Environment, Cohesion, Education, Culture, Transport, Energy and Telecommunications will also contribute. We will then carry out a synthesis work, with the preparation of a report for the General Affairs Council in December. We hope that this joint political reflection will be of use to the new Commission when preparing its proposals for the mid-term review. Thank you for your attention.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. - Mr President, let me start by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Philippe De Backer, and all the other Members for their valuable contribution to Parliament’s report on the European Semester. This report is a timely and important contribution to the topical debate on economic governance in the EU. The report touches upon a wide range of issues, many of which are related to Parliament’s expectations of the Commission in the future.  Provided that Parliament confirms the new College tomorrow, the new Commission can be in place at the beginning of November. So we are currently in the middle of transition. I therefore hope you understand that here today I will not be in a position to answer all your questions related to the future actions of the new Commission. However, I can assure you that this does not mean that we are not listening. On the contrary, we have taken into consideration the points you have raised in the report. I can also assure you that this will have the attention of the new Commission. I fully agree with you that the most pressing challenge ahead of us is to create sustainable growth and generate jobs. The European Semester has been an extremely useful exercise in identifying and coordinating policy responses to the challenges faced by individual Member States and the EU as a whole. The Member States are adjusting to the reinforced coordination process and common rules we built together in the depths of the crisis. The Semester has proven to be fundamental in presenting incentives for significant fiscal and structural reforms in the Member States. These are the very reforms that are essential to exit the crisis stronger and more united. The market turbulence of last week reminded us of the need to stay the course with reforms, in order to secure the confidence of the markets and, in doing so, unlock our growth potential and open up more job opportunities. This continues to be at the very core of the EU’s agenda going forward. There is clearly room for improvement. The next Commission will review the Europe 2020 Strategy and will present the upcoming annual Growth Survey at the launch of the next European Semester cycle. In the report there is, quite rightly, a great focus on the importance of implementing and monitoring the recommendations in the European Semester. The recommendations must be concrete. They must not only address fiscal consolidation, but also structural reforms that can create sustainable and socially-balanced growth. Jobs are making the EU market more competitive.  The success of the European Semester depends on implementation. This is why we monitor the implementation of reforms throughout the year and take action in case of insufficient or harmful policy development. It is important to recall that non-compliance with recommendations will not in itself trigger sanctions, but nor is it meant to. This is about policy coordination. Implementation of the country-specific recommendations ultimately relies on national policy-making at the national parliaments. In this regard, I wish to take the opportunity to emphasise three significant findings in the report. First is the importance of putting in place a comprehensive mechanism that promotes the exchange of best practices between all national and EU-level actors responsible for getting more young people into work. In this regard, it is essential to speed up the implementation of programmes such as COSME, Erasmus+ and Horizon 2020, with nearly EUR 80 billion of funding available over seven years.  The second point is to devote more attention to improving the quality of jobs in order to match peoples’ skills with the real needs of the labour market. Finally, I strongly support our fight against tax fraud and tax evasion and to shift the tax burden away from labour towards other forms of taxation that are less detrimental to growth and employment. One such example is environmental taxation.  I see much agreement between the report and the Commission’s own position. I hope this will be highlighted in our constructive and fruitful debate today.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. - (C) A policy is only as effective as it is implemented. This also applies, of course, to the financial semester.  The global financial crisis clearly showed how the Western world since the mid-1970s only in small steps, later with momentum, has lived above its means. The financial crisis also showed how the economies of the EU countries are connected. A country's economic concern is therefore not solely their own concern. Sooner or later, it will also be the whole of europe's concern. In the 1950s and 1960s, we had another idea that, within the national legislative framework, we were able to overcome the challenges of the past, but countless studies – the studies of Wolfgang Streeck, Joseph Stiglitz, Thomas Piketty – show that the golden time is long over, and as you can see from the list of speakers, I will continue from a slightly different perspective in a minute and a half.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: drafts member of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. - Mr President, Commissioner, this is the third year in a row that I am in this debate and it is true that we have good reports as a result of consensus, but do you know what is really sad? It's just that today I could do exactly the same intervention as a year ago, that two ago and that three ago. I could repeat to you that excess austerity continues to suffocate us economically in the European Union and continues to cause the highest unemployment rates in our history.  I could tell you again that the wild wage devaluation strategy we are implementing to gain competitiveness is making us more dependent on outside economic situations, but it is also impoverishing us inside.  I could tell you again that, after the saving of public money that we have set out to bail out the banks, credit still does not reach businesses and families, and that what comes in is at very high rates, precisely because we never demand economic credit offsets to give that money.  I could tell you that some structural reforms that we have promoted, even if necessary — labour, health, pension reforms — have depressed our domestic demand and multiplied inequality between Europeans.  I could tell you again that only with monetary policy do we not come out of the crisis, that we need to be courageous with fiscal policy, with stimulus, with investment. That it is a shame that we only spend six billion euros to combat youth unemployment, but what is the greatest shame is that States have not yet used them, and that those who plan to do so only use them to promote precariousness.  I could tell you all this again. But, at the gates of the third recession in the European Union, at the gates of the highest unemployment and poverty rates in our entire history, I can only think of one question to ask you, Commissioner, gentlemen of the Council: what the hell are you waiting for to change and to rectify?

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. - (C) Precisely because we lived above our resources, we have had to create common rules and tools such as the Stability and Growth Pact and the Europe 2020 target.  But the rules must, of course, be followed in order for them to be effective. The country-specific recommendations made by the European Commission in 2013 show that Member States have implemented only 10%. That's not good enough, of course.  The economic forecasts show that the economic crisis is by no means over and that we need to step up to meet our challenges. From an ENVI perspective, which we are therefore trying to adopt this time, this is first and foremost about the use of resources. We need to provide better measurement tools to see how we use our financial and strained resources and our ecological resources. [end in Finnish] Yes lopuksi, jotta kääntäjillä olisi mahdollisimman vaikeata, haluan toivottaa komissaari Kataiselle ja hänen uudelle avustajalleen Sallalle kaikkea hyvää.

name: Sergio Gaetano COFFERATI
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. - (IT) Mr President, Commissioner, as you know and as Mr De Clercq also knows, i.e. the commission of the European Parliament, i.e. the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and Industrial Policy, i.e. the Committee on Economic and Monetary Della Vedova, the internal market is one of the three pillars of economic and social activity of this sum of organisations and institutions that today gives birth to the European Union. We have stressed this very much in the report, together with other colleagues, because it is important for the future of the Union, that we move forward along the path of creation and uniformity in the production of services well, even under conditions that then affect both companies and people who work. And it is important – as was mentioned – that in order to create jobs and to give continuity and strength to growth, the single market has very important elements of competitiveness within it. We must therefore start, and I would like to stress this from research and innovation. I would like to say, however, that in order to have research and innovation, we need to have resources at our disposal. It is a little strange that in the next few hours we will be discussing a budgetary hypothesis that cuts expenditure on research and innovation. Perhaps stopping to reflect is useful.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, the European Semester is an important component of the system of economic governance in the EU. Its key instruments are country-specific recommendations (CSRs) that aim at ensuring better coordination of economic policies and fostering crucial structural reforms in the Member States. However, the overall effectiveness of CSRs is still limited. Only 10 to 15% of CSRs have been fully implemented by Member States in 2013. As a result, macroeconomic imbalances still persist, progress in implementing badly needed structural reforms is slow and uneven and strong economic growth in Europe is still to come. In the report, the European Parliament calls on the Member States to undertake more effort to fully implement CSRs. What is at stake is the very credibility of the European Union and its ability to definitively overcome the current crisis. One way to improve the efficiency of the European Semester is to make sure that reasons and causes for unsatisfactory implementation of CSRs are properly analysed and eliminated and that the whole elimination process is more disciplined. Another way is to radically strengthen national ownership of CSRs in individual Member States in order to mobilise sufficient political capital in favour of reforms. More involvement by national parliaments could also help. It would also improve democratic control over the whole exercise. In the process of preparing this report, a wide range of proposals and amendments have been submitted and discussed. We eventually managed to come up with a draft that represents a reasonable compromise and which reflects most of the key priorities of major political groups. Therefore, I call on all Member States and all Members of the House to vote in favour of the report. We, as the European Parliament, should support the European Commission in its efforts to fully use the framework of the European Semester to improve economic governance in Europe.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – This report before us, at least in our hopes, shows the true face of Europe, as far as economic policies are concerned. It is important that we finally face up on this continent that the process or processes called structural reforms, which are carried out by individual governments, have indeed been implemented in a misguided way in many places, and the result is not necessarily the nice figures in economic policy statistics, but in many cases impoverishment and other downward social processes. We have therefore seen 6 pivotal points on the part of the Socialists and Democrats which, at least in its present form, appear to be part of the report until tomorrow's vote. One is to highlight the equal importance of private and public investment. The other, and this is a very important thing, is to prevent tax evasion or fraud, because one of europe's greatest resources may be the tax that has not yet been collected. Similarly, it is the diligent and all-important appearance of equal opportunities between men and women that is of particular importance to us, as is a more balanced tax system. What is a big debate in Europe today, but also here, must be order, the right to free movement of workers. A lot of people are questioning that. We want to keep him in it. Finally, the EUR 300 million projected by Mr Juncker should be fresh money. If all this is all right, we are happy to support the report.

name: Sampo TERHO
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, at the beginning of the process of drafting the report, I think the rapporteur's economic policy proposals made good points. I believe that Mr de Backer had made the right assessments of the member states' financial problems and also presented good solutions to them.  However, the problem with the report from the outset has been its federalist emphasis on concentrating power from the Member States on the EU institutions. In particular, there has been a desire to make country-specific recommendations more binding, even at the risk of punishment. In a way, this was to be expected, because ever since the European Semester began, there have been fears that here too we will do what is always the case in the federal development of the EU. First, a looser arrangement is created under the pretext of accepting and accepting a new preening of power in the Member States, but once it stabilises, this preclusive will be tightened up.  The federalism of the report was further underlined by the desire to create a single common representation in the euro area in international economic policy for a. In addition, the report wanted to record a kind of pre-approval of the third pillar of the Banking Union, which would include pan-European deposit protection. So both the EU's power and solidarity are to be promoted by this report.  The ECR Group believes that the economic policy powers of the Member States should not be reduced, but that the guidelines issued by the EU should be advisory in nature. In other words, similar to the economic guidelines distributed by the OECD to the various countries. After all, economic policy is at the heart of politics, and it is not conceivable that decision-making on it should be transferred away from the democratically elected parliaments of the Member States.  As far as federalism is concerned, the report is unacceptable to the ECR Group, which wants to lighten and reform the EU. As the negotiation process progressed, the report's good economic policies were watered down, we have no choice but to vote against the report.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: the blue card question addressed to Tibor Szanyi – But I wanted to put the question to the previous speaker. My question is, the gentleman mentioned, that the EUR 300 billion from the Juncker Commission must therefore somehow be included in this report, and my question is, who will pay for this EUR 300 billion?

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card answer. – The truth is that I have just consulted my colleagues, so I do not know if the question has been raised.

name: Sylvie GOULARD
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, Mr President of the Council, why are we here today? Sometimes, when you read this long document , and I thank the rapporteurs for doing a lot of synthesis work, you get the impression that you are putting everything and anything into it. It is a bit sad, because when we introduced the European semester into the six-pack - I was one of the rapporteurs at the time, alongside other colleagues present today - we had two objectives in mind.  The first was to make national parliaments aware that we had a common good: European prosperity, the single currency. It is something that Europeans have in common and yet it is something that is decided on two different levels. The debates that exist in countries like mine, as in Italy at the moment, or even in Germany from another angle, clearly show that this sense of interdependence and learningership - as they say in good French - common rules are unfortunately not always present. Our second objective was to facilitate the implementation of the commitments made by states to benefit from the best economic policy. This was reiterated by several auditors, including the Commissioner. I think we need to be aware of what is at stake. I would therefore simply like to say that we must be careful not to turn the exercise here in this Parliament into a self-centred exercise in which each political group tries to add what is dear to its heart. The real challenge is to include in the national debates as broad an acceptance as possible that the single currency is a common good, that European prosperity is a common good, that the Commissioner works in the general interest of Europe, that he is not a schoolmaster who comes to teach us lessons and that he is content to do what he has been asked to do.  Therefore, Commissioner, go back to Brussels feeling that Members here are asking you to take responsibility - the Italian Presidency, I believe, is taking its own - to ensure that The Member States respect the commitments they have made and that European growth comes not from a sterile debate but from concrete actions in favour of our youth. Particular.  (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – I think we are all aware that the report is a compromise after all between the political groups. Sure, I'll vote on the report. My specific question to our colleague is this: Sure, we criticize. My question is whether you can come as a group, as a Member, with a concrete proposal for the democratic monitoring of the troika's programmes for the countries of the European Union?

name: Sylvie GOULARD
text: "blue card" answer. Mr President, you are doing me a great deal of honour, Madam, thinking that I alone will have the solution. I can give you my feeling, nothing more. My feeling is that this parliament has already done a lot. Firstly, it included the European semester in legislation and gave dialogue with national parliaments its importance. Second, in the previous Parliament we auditioned the members of the troika and put them under pressure, as far as the law allowed us. Third, we made a report, which allowed Members to travel to countries that were under the programme. Of course, all of this is not enough. Personally - and whatever Mr Terho says - I believe that if we had an effectively federal Europe, we could go much further. It is good because Europe is not at all federal and because it leaves the Member States - without them always assuming their responsibilities - considerable leeway, sometimes in defiance of common rules, that we are now experiencing these difficulties. Let's not caricature, let's all try together to be constructive. However, the compromise should not take us away from the idea that we have a huge responsibility towards European youth. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mrs Goulard, you have complained that the report has been so watered down that everyone has packed everything into a report that was originally largely clear and has a clear liberal handwriting that has also properly analysed problems. Now almost nothing is left of it. The solution to the eurozone's problems is essentially sought through large-scale state interventions. If that is the case, if this is no longer apparent from this original report, what is market economy and what is liberal, why is the Liberal Group still voting in favour of this report?

name: Sylvie GOULARD
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr Lucke, you do not seem to know me so well , not yet. The idea that I could really only say that the liberal ideas have been watered down is that this is sausage, if I may say so. It's really sausage. It's sausage to me, and it's nonsense. Excuse me! Because what we are trying to do here is really a report, where we outline the basic orientation of cooperation between the national and European levels. This goes far, far beyond these petty partisan political controversies.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, we know well how disastrous the Economic Policy of the European Union has been for the European Union as a whole, but in particular for the economies on the periphery of the euro area. And with the European Semester, which is part of the problem and not the solution, we were living up to problems of democracy and the ability of the peoples of countries to decide on their budgetary policies, but we also have been able to live up to this disastrous economic policy. There is talk of fiscal consolidation, we talk about proposals, but we never touch on the essentials. If we want real fiscal consolidation, the alternative is to tackle the real problem that we have, which is unemployment. There are suggestions about research, the environment and gender equality... I do not say that they are not important, they are important, but until we focus on the real problem that is unemployment, we will have no solution.  Unemployment is not only a side effect, it is not just a consequence, unemployment is the cause, it is the main cause of the unsustainability of public accounts. And what do the European institutions do about it? They continue to insist on deregulation of the labour market, while the periphery of the European Union is mired in unemployment and precariousness. But it's not just that. There are also goals that are never met. None of the objectives presented, either in economic policy or in the European Semester, have ever been achieved, and what do the European institutions do? They call it another name, they call it growth-friendly fiscal policy. In other words, a change of slogan to continue with the same policy that leads us to the destruction of the European economic fabric. We cannot support this proposal, we have already expressed against it, we cannot support a proposal that continues to sink the countries on the periphery more and more and which brings no solution that goes through what is essential. And I say again: the essential thing is employment. Do you want consistent public policy, consistent public accounts? Focus on your job.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I first would like to thank Mr Philippe De Backer for his collaboration in getting to a consensus report. I do not know whether this is a kiss of death, with a Green thanking a Liberal, and I do not know whether there will then be a kiss of death from him to me again.  But, of course, this is a hugely important discussion in our Group as well and for all the political groups. I mean, it is very clear there is a pro-European majority in this House which is stressing the importance of the Semester and I think that is also clear from the report. This is also a very clear call to the Council and the Member States to take this process more seriously. This is not something that you say ‘yes’ to in Brussels and then go home and say ‘well that was decided over there by strangers’. This is our policy, and if we want to survive together we have to take seriously the economic governance we do together. That is in the report and is very important.  However, at the same time we do know there is a huge political division on the direction of the different structural reforms. And here let me be very clear also to Mr Katainen, who until now agreed with me, but now I would really like to stress that our Group is very, very critical of the way the Commission has performed the structural reforms. It is a one-sided way on austerity, it is a one-sided way where reform is mainly flexibilisation of the labour market, and then assuming that will save all. That is not the case so we need a more balanced approach. Fortunately, of course, we would have liked to see more critical remarks on the current structural reforms being proposed.  However, in the report we see that there is more room for a balanced approach. There is more room for social indicators thanks to the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs also. There is more room for environmental reforms. There is more room for investments, and I think that all together is a good direction indicating that the course of Europe should be changing and therefore in the end, in this consensus, I subscribe to the consensus, but really let us work on it. Otherwise we will lose the support of the people.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: Mr President, once again I stand here before a committee that is committed to the European Union, to ever closer union, and fails to accept that the European Union has failed and failed dismally. It has failed the youth of Europe, where currently unemployment is at an average of 23.3%. It has failed the youth of Greece, where unemployment for youth is 57.7%. There is an average unemployment across the eurozone of 16.8%.  This is the success of the euro according to friends on the other side of the Chamber. We have GNP and GDP falling year on year; productivity levels lower; the highest suicide rates that nations across Europe have ever known. There is poverty, people living in the streets. This is the Europe that you regard as a dream. This is the Europe that you think is a success.  Well, tell the people who are losing their children by leaving their countries that it is a success. Tell the people who are unemployed that it is a success. There is nothing that this Chamber nor you as MEPs, nor the Commission or the Council can do that will help these people except one thing. That is allowing the European Union to break up, to remove the euro, to make sure that countries can run themselves and control themselves once more. Wake up and recognise the euro is a failure.

name: Burkhard BALZ
text: Mr. President! When we vote on the new Commission tomorrow, it will, of course, also involve the demand for more commitment for the European Semester. The track record in the implementation of the country-specific recommendations is far too weak. It is precisely if Europe now wants to launch an investment programme that strengthened economic and budgetary consolidation must be the prerequisite for this. Growth only thrives when the soil is already prepared. The report is very clear here, pointing out the various obstacles to growth. Thus, growth is currently being hampered above all by too many failures in the modernisation of many economies, by too little flexibility in labour markets, by the far too low level of investment, especially in private investment, and by the lack of access to sources of finance. It is clear that these obstacles must be reduced. Of course, it is above all the Member States that are in demand. They need to be much more consistent in this regard, so that reforms are not only an announcement, but also implemented in the end. More calls for more public money, which are often put forward by colleagues from other groups, do not help either. Public injections of money cannot replace or reduce the need for reform. Public budgets are now significantly over-indebted, and The contributions of European taxpayers are largely exhausted. That is why the focus must be on significantly more private sector. European companies are looking for investment targets, European banks and insurance companies need solid investment opportunities, especially at the current low interest rates. They should find these opportunities again in Europe, in a Europe that is also becoming more competitive and thus improving the investment climate. It is precisely the country-specific recommendations aimed at competitiveness and innovation that are important. We will listen carefully to when the Commission will report on compliance in the future and regularly.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Mr. President! It is important for us Social Democrats that our priorities, which we have incorporated into the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, also be reflected. We call for an end to the blind, unbalanced austerity policy in Europe. Europe must become more ambitious and more united. And Europe finally needs investment in the future. Because instead of lifting 20 million people out of poverty, we now have an increase of 7 million people in poverty. The number of people who cannot live on their work is also growing dramatically. Precarious working conditions have become the norm – that must not be the case! We need a European stability mechanism. The Green Paper on automatic stabilisers is therefore also a move in the right direction. The European Semester urgently needs a social dimension, with the same commitment of EU social and employment policies as for EU economic policy within the European Semester. The Commissioners have promised us many times in the hearings that there will be a binding step. The social and employment indicators are a good first step. But we need more indicators to better present the situation in the Member States. My appeal, too, is not to use crises as excuses to be less ambitious, but rather to implement the objectives of the EU 2020 strategy even more ambitiously precisely because of the crises we have.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: Mr President, it is disappointing that Member States have a poor uptake of the country-specific recommendations. However, the low uptake of CSRs should not result in measures which, if made binding recommendations, would effectively force Member States to follow a centralised plan for their country’s economic development.  We need to consider whether the fault lies with the Member States for failing to embrace helpful actions or whether the CSRs are less useful than the Commission implies. When you assess the ability of public bodies to forecast, compared to private forecasting for economic data, the Commission does not come out well. Neither does the IMF. They are typically ranked in the bottom quartile, while banks and fund analysts dominate the top. I, therefore – like many – need convincing that the indicators that the Commission is using are correct and are appropriately tailored to the specifics of each country. The European Semester should remain a plan of mutual respect and not a centralised plan that cannot take into account real economic activity.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Mr President, I should like to thank Mr De Backer for that comprehensive report. The European Semester is a helpful tool in providing input, international and economic decision-making, and it is a step towards fiscal and economic union, but we have just heard Mr Woolfe’s passionate plea, so the wolf pack is on our heels. We have to note what is going on. These people are ready to rip apart Europe. They are ready to destroy our future for their benefit, for their political short-term gains, so now is the time to unite, to work together to aim for the single market. I think that is our future. I do not think we can throw EUR 300 billion or EUR 400 billion at it and make a big change. It will be a very small dent and it will be gone in a year. We have to go for reforms. We have to bring Member States here and question them on why they are not implementing the suggestions that we send to them. This is the problem. They are not taking up the suggestions and we need more enforcement on this. I think all the guidelines are pretty good. I am reading the Council recommendations and so on. They are all great, it is smart people who are preparing them, but Member States have to take responsibility and we have to hold them responsible for this implementation and for the reforms. It is the only way forward. So I wish you all the best of luck. You have my support.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: Mr President, countries that needed a radical new economic policy have instead been subjected to what has been a disastrous agenda that has resulted in high levels of public debt and unemployment. Those jobs that are being created are, in many cases, low-paid and short-term. In countries like Ireland we have seen the devastating results of a government’s obsession with austerity policy. In my own constituency we have witnessed entire rural communities being left desolate, with no employment opportunities for the young, resulting in mass emigration from those areas. The Irish Government has now created a two-tier and two-speed recovery that has yet to reach those families which actually suffered most throughout the recession, and the European Commission, it appears to me, is cheerleading this approach to achieve any kind of sustainable fiscal adjustment, when the sole priority should be to achieve full employment. The Commission’s policy recommendations and the report before us this week add insult to injury. The failure of austerity policies and the ineffectiveness of the current monitoring policy is obvious to the citizens that we represent, but too many people here today are, I fear, blind to the need for a real stimulus package that would reinvigorate our domestic economies.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: Mr President, I think there are a lot of us in this House who consider that the real failure has not necessarily been that of the European Union, but governments’ failure to control financial institutions, and that action on that needs cross-border agreements. We have heard as well in this debate about the effect of the crisis on the future generations. I think that is why, for us, it is also important to integrate not only the social dimension, but also the ecological dimension in our response because otherwise we are not really dealing with the problem in the round. People have also talked in this debate about ownership. It is not just our Parliament and national parliaments. I think we also need to be looking much more at the engagement of social partners – and indeed civil society – within this process, given that the reforms are supposed to be for the benefit of the people. So is the Commission going to bring forward guidelines for the engagement of civil society in the Semester process?

name: Bernard MONOT
text: Mr President, first of all I would like to pay tribute to a great French boss who died last night, Mr Christophe de Margerie, President of Total, and to extend my condolences to his family. Regarding the European semester, what incantations throughout this report for growth, employment and structural reforms! However, did it take months of reflection on macroprudential criteria to reach such mundane and pre-run conclusions? Since 2011, the Aim of the European Semester has been to harmonize the economic policies of the EU countries, but for what results? A "eurodivergence" between Germany and most eurozone countries, a "eurodivergence" of the unemployment rate in the euro area countries, inflation rates and nominal borrowing rates that discredit your optimal utopian currency area. The only convergence: growth, still close to zero in the euro area before, alas, the next entry into a structural recession by 2015 or 2016. To top it all off, eleven out of twenty-eight countries are in the process of excessive deficit, not to mention the European Union budget. What solutions do the EPP and the S and D offer us in this document? More Europe, of course. If this does not work, it is because there is not enough federalist Europe, as in the past the politburo for communism. Your recipes are always the same, ultraliberal, but they will lead to the same result: social austerity for peoples. It is therefore a no-brainer: your European semester instrument is ultimately useless. None of your desperate attempts to coordinate the economic policies of the Economic and Monetary Union to restore growth and jobs will work. Worse, the troika's suicidal austerity policy will soon plunge us all into widespread bankruptcy.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on the great work he has done to try to agree on a common position. I agree with the rapporteur, Mr De Backer, that growth and job creation need to be boosted. But let us not deceive ourselves: sustainable growth will not be possible only with a Juncker plan, however ambitious; sustainable growth will not be possible with strong action by the European Central Bank, however ambitious it may be. To have sustainable growth, we need joint action by all stakeholders: European institutions and Member States; we need reforms: reforms in the Member States and reforms also in Europe. Spain is a benchmark: it is one of the most ambitious countries in terms of reforms, and it is one of the countries that has the most growth in the eurozone and that is creating the most jobs. And we also need expansive fiscal policies in those countries that can afford it. Therefore, ladies and gentlemen, we need joint action by Europe and the Member States to consolidate and achieve sustainable growth.

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this report has not been watered down. A political direction that is being formed, which is being defined with the help of the various groups supporting the new Commission. I see four key elements in this resolution: the first, the need to launch as soon as possible the EUR 300 billion investment plan announced by Juncker; secondly, it stresses the importance of make the best use of the flexibility already provided for in the Stability Pact; thirdly, the role of structural reforms in strengthening medium and long-term growth; fourthly, there is the need to strengthen the social dimension of European policies. And these four elements are closely linked. Public and private investment is an essential ingredient for the rapid recovery of the European economy.  At the same time, the use of the flexibility provided for by the rules, in the presence of exceptional circumstances, such as the prolonged recession, the expectation of inflation well below European targets. It is functional not only to get out of resignation but also to encourage and finance reforms. Investment and flexibility can help to encourage, create mechanisms to make recommendations more binding and, finally, social cohesion, it is also a factor of competitiveness and growth. So a broad consensus on a new economic policy line is emerging and this is the political fact, and it is to be hoped that the outgoing Commission, in assessing national stability laws, will not want to stand in the way of this new course.

name: Stanisław OŻÓG
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking The report on the European Semester takes up an important debate on the current state of the Economies of the European Union and their needs. I agree with many of the problems highlighted in the report, such as the issue of youth unemployment or the energy dependence of some European Union countries, including my homeland, on Russia, but I cannot support the call for such a far-reaching synchronisation of economic policies, which in the long term will be a threat to the sovereign budgetary policies of the Member States.  I am also concerned about the provisions on support for all three pillars of the Banking Union, of which I am opposed, and the call for uniform external representation of the euro area. I believe that we should leave greater decision-making independence to the Member States.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: Mr President, I thank, in particular, my ALDE colleague, Philippe De Backer, for a very good report, and I also thank my colleagues in the Committee on Employment, where, as shadow rapporteur, I had the opportunity to contribute to this report.  Yes, our priority must be to create the conditions for the creation of new jobs. We need more, but not at all costs. Above all, a healthy economy must be a prerequisite for job growth. Man-made jobs disappear as quickly as they were magically created. We are facing a strategic decision at national level in this area: change starts with an education system that responds to the real needs of the market and ends with a functional link between schools, universities and businesses. This is an urgent task for all Member States that responsibly manage their resources and want to encourage young people to work.  The report on the European Semester includes a number of important measures and proposals. Let us not take the path of cost reduction, but invest in research, education, innovation and new technologies. Let us eliminate unnecessary administrative burdens for entrepreneurs and small businesses and simplify the transition of school leavers into the working environment. We must increase competitiveness and structurally reform the labour market. The European Semester is therefore an important instrument. I will support the report on the European Semester.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Mr President, the European Semester is a tool that tries to achieve coordination in the implementation of a failed policy, which is graded in certain numbers. Investment in the euro area is 15% lower than in 2009. Youth unemployment is 25%, while in my country, Greece, it has reached 60%. The eurozone is at a standstill and threatened with recession, so your theory, Mr Katainen, that 'with tough one-sided austerity will come and invest' has failed.  And Mr Della Vedova, the Italian Presidency is about to end, we are at the end of October, and the very fine words that Mr Renzi told us here on 1 July about major changes are still waiting for them. What did you achieve at the milan unemployment summit? An absolute zero. Mr Katainen, you said that you still cannot tell us anything about the famous EUR 300 billion promised to us by Mr Juncker here in plenary on 1 July, because you were new. You were too old as a representative of a harsh neoliberal austerity. Your policy has failed.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: Mr President, despite some elements of criticism that we value in the report, we cannot support it, especially by paragraphs such as 5, 6 and in particular 8, which stresses the importance of maintaining the process of structural reforms.  We know that behind this expression we could have positive elements of change towards a fairer, more sustainable and equitable society, but the reality is precisely the opposite: 'structural reforms' is the euphemism that has been used to weaken public pension systems, to give greater market share to private systems, much less sustainable.  Structural reforms in the labour market have meant lowering redundancy, dynamiting collective bargaining, lowering often misery wages and, on top of that, for example in Spain, 400,000 fewer occupied than before 2012, and this can be extendable to many other countries. The Semester is now the lever used to force internal devaluation and this Parliament should be forceful in condemning such processes.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Mr President, the report on the European Semester supports unpopular measures to reduce popular income, abolish labour and insurance rights. It calls for the implementation of the Memorandums of Understanding, the financing of banks and monopolistic groups. The peoples pay dearly for the capitalist crisis and anemic development, although whenever it comes, it will be marked by a continuation of the unpopular attack.  A typical example is the dismissals of the multinational Coca-Cola in Greece, who are currently here in Parliament and who have been on strike for over a year, as the company closed its factories there because it found cheaper costs elsewhere, taking advantage of EU policy. The parties that present fiscal easing as a pro-grassroots recipe are mocking workers, they are the same carriers of this unpopular attack. It is imperative for the development now of the popular struggle to recover losses, to overturn the unpopular policy, to abolish exploitation.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by thanking Mr De Backer for his work in the ECON Committee. This excellent work has brought to light the great progress made by some States and the difficulties rather than others in complying with the recommendations that had also been issued. Just look at the percentages: 10% of the recommendations have been accepted by the Member States, 45% instead of these recommendations have made little or no progress. This shows that the issue of sanctions, probably against states that do not accept the recommendations, is an issue that will have to be addressed, because behind these recommendations there is a need to balance the books and to combine development with growth and, above all, with reducing the deficit. It is no coincidence that the states that have not adapted to the recommendations are those that have the most structural deficits; It is no coincidence that, unfortunately, Italy is also one of these states. Mr Barroso has recently asked the Italian Government to reduce the structural deficit by another half a point. We hope that the Italian Government will choose to do so, because behind a structural deficit there is a difficulty and an impossibility of growth and development.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: Mr President, I would like to bring to your attention points 122 and 123 of this resolution on the European semester and point 7 of the opinion of the Committee on Budgets, on the question of Member States' contributions to the EU budget. These contributions are integrated into state spending and add to their public deficit, even though we all know here that 95% of the European budget is investment-oriented. Corseted by an absurd rule that prevents them from generating investment margins, our States, our Union are plunging dangerously into recession. The European Parliament has repeatedly disagreed, regretting that Member States' participation in the EU budget is included in the calculation of the structural deficit. Ladies and gentlemen, we must restore budgetary margins to our European governments. Excluding national contributions from the calculation of the public deficit would be a first breath of fresh air. This will not exempt us from finding our own resources to make our Community budget an autonomous instrument, finally rid of national selfishness and destined for investment in growth and jobs.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Mr. President! Many Members of this House give the impression that weak investment in the eurozone is the reason for the eurozone's weak growth. That is wrong, ladies and gentlemen. The weakness in investment is not a cause of this weakness in growth, it is a symptom of the euro crisis. There is also a reason for the lack of investment. The weakness in investment is due to the lack of competitiveness of many eurozone countries. The lack of competitiveness is due to the problematic European currency: the euro. It is not possible to draw up a report on the competitive situation of the euro area without at least mentioning the problem of the single currency. But that is exactly what this report by Mr De Backer does. It is expressly avoided to talk about the euro at all. And that's a behavior that's short-sighted and stupid. For it is the behaviour of a child that closes his eyes to a danger that he perceives, because he believes that the danger does not then exist.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Mr. Vice-President, the European Semester is conceived as a comprehensive framework that will ensure better coordination of Member States' economic policies through refined criteria. It is therefore necessary that the first evaluation reports of the Semester for the new financial period clearly highlight weaknesses and opportunities to further this visionary framework.  It is essential to include the sustainable development settings in this framework, which aims to look at the performance of European economic policies, and therefore the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety has also expressed its opinion on the report in this direction.  It is essential to include evaluations and recommendations aimed at energy efficiency, increasing the share of renewables and reducing CO2 emissions by 2020 in member states. At the level of all portfolios, the Commission should recognise the importance of these objectives as key to achieving local jobs and sustainable green growth. Energy security and sustainable development are the only guarantors of the long-term and successful economic recovery of the Member States of the European Union. In this light, it is necessary to include the Ministers of the Environment, Environmental Policy and Awareness of the importance of the transition to a circular economy as a new paradigm of waste and energy management in this overriding economic debate.  We need to become more efficient in managing the resources we have and turn to energy connectivity and independence as guarantors of successful economic growth.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it seems to me that there is some confusion in this text: at the beginning, in fact, it is noted that, according to the European Commission itself, the policies adopted so far have failed with negative effects on economic growth and a devastating social impact. I would therefore have expected a series of criticisms and a proposal for substantial changes to European economic policies; Instead, there is still talk of building a genuine monetary union, strengthening economic governance and supporting the Troika.  I believe that my fellow Members may not have seen, pretending not to see what is happening now throughout Europe, with the absurd measures imposed on citizens who are already in exhaustion. I do not want this to happen again! All European economic and fiscal policies must be completely reviewed! Away from the Stability and Growth Pact, where has growth been? Away the six-pack, the two-pack, the fiscal compact before it's too late! Let us discuss everything again on the basis of greater sharing and solidarity, otherwise the economic and social disintegration of Europe will be inevitable.

name: Markus FERBER
text: Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues! Of course, what we are talking about today is primarily how we deal with the country-specific recommendations. So much has already been said about this that I do not want to say anything more about it. However, I would like to make a few basic comments and I very much regret that Mr Lucke has now left us. The euro is not the problem, but it is the catalyst that highlights problems, because the veil of currency fluctuating has been lost, behind which many Member States have long been able to hide by trying to artificially gain competitiveness by devaluation. That is precisely the success of the euro, that this veil has been taken away from the Member States and that the mistakes have become apparent. Secondly, I often hear now that money could solve problems. We can still put so much money into training young people if there are no companies that employ these young people. In other words, in addition to competitiveness, it is also a question of strengthening entrepreneurship in the European Union, of creating a strong small and medium-sized enterprise that builds up decentralised value chains, which is able to provide jobs for young people, but also for other people, which also manages to provide decentvice jobs in the various regions of the European Union. You don't solve that with money, but you solve it with boundary conditions. Young people are not employed by providing them with money, but by equipping companies with jobs. That is our shared responsibility, which we have to face up to.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: I would like to draw attention to one major problem in the European Union: the ever-increasing poverty, especially child poverty. As many as 27% of children in the European Union live in poverty or balance at the poverty line. Therefore, both the Commission and the Member States must take immediate measures to eradicate child poverty. The second problem I would like to draw attention to is female poverty, because women are currently the highest earners. I therefore call on both the Commission and the Member States to make specific recommendations in order to reduce the gender pay gap and, consequently, pensions. Member States must ensure that people are given the necessary social protection, access to health and social services, and that greater inclusion of vulnerable groups in the labour market, the reduction of poverty at work and the promotion of gender equality should be ensured, taking into account the recommendations of the European Parliament. Colleagues, social investment is essential to ensure the future of the Member States and the European Union as a whole.

name: Sander LOONES
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. Citizens, taxpayers, entrepreneurs, they are struggling in Europe today. We are therefore pleased that the report emphasises economic growth, competitiveness, jobs and the need to tackle poverty with an integrated approach. That is good. But the European Union will only be truly successful for us when it is close to its citizens and when it therefore focuses and intervenes in the areas where it can offer real added value. A Europe that is strong where necessary. And in this respect, the report might have shown a little more ambition. More fundamentally, as far as we are concerned, the fact is that the tax burden is already very high in many Member States today, but that this report nevertheless chooses to allocate additional fiscal capacity to the European Union. We as parties do not choose an irresponsible transfer union, but a union of responsible Member States. The time, ladies and gentlemen, of budgetary follies is behind us. Let us, therefore, frontload as much as possible the measures that strengthen competitiveness. And this idea is also in this report. This report provides a good starting point for this. We recognize that, too. Above all, however, let us try to shift a number of gears up and create jobs in practice.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: I'm sorry to have to disturb the fun and glory of your Semester party here. There is, moreover, a wise French wording that says 'Qui veut trop prouver, ne prouve rien'. If you want to prove too much, you won't prove anything in the end. I doubt that you, ladies and gentlemen of the European majority, are sufficiently aware of how meaningless your document is, how meaningless this improbable accumulation of meaningless platitudes actually is. However, as an EU critical Member of the European Parliament, I should be happy with so much non-committal meaninglessness, because this so-called Semester is much more than the coordination of economic policy and cooperation. It is a philosophy, above all an ode to your philosophy, the philosophy of far-reaching togetherness, the philosophy of stifling unification, the philosophy of the tasteless unity sausage and all of that, which is all overfused with your philosophy on immigration, when the Member States and the Peoples of Europe are in fact in need of autonomy, freedom and oxygen rather than this here.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: Mr President, it is quite interesting to see how very many of the Members of this Chamber always want to blame someone other than the Member States for their economic policy and their budget policy. There is no more rapid way to austerity than overspending, and where you have had overspending you have crashed into austerity without any choice.
