And still the Left here is defending overspending, at the same time as EU critics over there are blaming someone else. But let us see how things have worked. In the countries where there was overspending, there are big problems; when you turn the policies, with stability and reforms, we see growth coming and new jobs. This is the pattern and in some ways, in that perspective, we do not need any report. We can just take a look at the reality, because in the Member States where you are implementing the rules and where you are reforming we have turned away from the crisis – in the United Kingdom, in Spain, in Portugal – but where you proceed you see it in countries like France. We need to stick to the rules; that is what we have learned from reality. Let us stay with that.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Commissioner, Europe and, in particular, the euro area are facing a situation that is perfectly exceptional in terms of its scale, its duration and its isolation on a global scale, where the recovery is still waiting. The basic indicators of economic health are all in the red, regardless of the strategy applied by the Member States, dear colleague, Mr Hukmark. We see inflation approaching nullity, growth as soft as fragile and unemployment still as high, especially among the most fragile.  The reality is that we cannot dismiss with a flip of the observations and recommendations of all the experts but also of the IMF. In relation to this, Europe must implement this strategy of the 300 billion we want. But we cannot do it simply as a re-agency of the Structural Funds or as a proposal that is based solely on private investment or that is totally diluted over time.  That is why, Mr Katainen, we are counting on the next Commission to have a real mobilization, a variation on the ground so that this 300 billion allows a reorientation of Europe on the path of ecological and digital transition. In order to do this, we will also have to agree to move away from a logic of fair return and accept an asymmetrical approach that allows us to take into account the reality of the situation of the Member States and the economic situation of both the euro area and the European Union.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the European Semester for the coordination of economic policies is an undemocratic tool for monitoring the budgets of the Member States within German Europe. In fact, Greece will remain under continuous enhanced supervision until it repays 75% of its debt to the European Union, i.e. by today's standards until 2050.Greece can only exit enhanced supervision if it claims the repayment of Germany's debts to Greece, i.e. 108 billion euros without interest on German reparations and 54 billion euros without interest on the owner's loan. , i.e. EUR 162 billion without interest.  That is why we are once again calling on the Greek Government to include in the state budget all of Germany's debts to Greece, which are both overdue and due and interest-bearing, amounting to EUR 162 billion. Because Greece is the lender and Germany is the debtor. Only in this way will Greece be able to regain its national sovereignty and cease to be a German protectorate at the mercy of the troika and the memorandums.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen! ECB President Draghi has repeatedly said in recent months that europe can buy time through its monetary policy, but that the eurozone's problems cannot be overcome. The eurozone's problems can only be overcome through member-state economic policy efforts, namely growth-friendly fiscal consolidation and structural reform measures. These actions will be coordinated within the framework of the European Semester. The Annual Growth Survey for the 2014 European Semester foresees a total of five priorities: growth-friendly fiscal consolidation, which has already been mentioned. Minister Della Vedova spoke today of a consolidation of confidence in this context. I would say that the budget plan that Italy has submitted will be the litmus test for this. Let's see. I hope you can do that. Secondly, restoring normal lending to the economy. That is primarily the task of the ECB. Thirdly, the promotion of growth and competitiveness. Once again, this is a task primarily for the Member States. Fourthly, the fight against unemployment. In the first item on the agenda of the debate on the Milan Employment Summit, it has already been pointed out today that not much is happening in itself. My impression is that more and more money is being demanded, but in reality the measures are not being taken. Fifthly, the modernisation of administrations. We see in Europe that the implementation of the measures is not working. Only 10% of the country-specific recommendations have been implemented, 45% little or no. Nor does growth-friendly fiscal consolidation work, the budget plans have been announced. Similarly, growth in Europe is not gaining momentum. The OECD has lowered its forecast for 2014 by 0.4 percentage points to 0.8% growth. That is why I appeal to the Member States in their own sense: consolidate your budgets. Start the structural reforms! Only in this way can Europe overcome the crisis.

name: Georgios KYRTSOS
text: Mr President, I think the picture is not as black as some colleagues have presented it. In recent years serious progress has been made on the basis of the joint effort, a characteristic success is Ireland's exit from the Memorandum, and I would say 'excellent'. Our Portuguese friends, too, have been able to get out of the memorandum, our Cypriot friends are doing better than planned, and I am optimistic that my country, Greece, will finally succeed, as long as the government becomes bolder in the reforms, that it can reduce taxes by financing this reduction with a corresponding reduction in public spending. , and I would also say to my friends of the Greek opposition that they too should become more responsible, more creative.  I think we know what the general issues are, we need budgetary discipline - we do not do otherwise - we need structural changes, we understand that, and we also need to stimulate investment activity, whether this stimulus comes through public spending from countries - of course - that have the means, or from countries that can reduce current spending and make public investments. , of course we also need the Juncker plan or similar initiatives. So I am optimistic, as long as we can get along and move forward.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: Mr President, I would like to thank our colleague Philippe De Backer for his report, on which I can agree on certain aspects of the proposal which highlight the need for ambitious initiatives based on an investment plan to revive and support economic growth and, above all, of course, job creation. However, I think there are still important points missing. For example, there is no request for clarification from the European Commission on Mr Juncker's famous 300 billion investment plan, including whether this money would be fresh money or not and what the sharing would be between private and public investments and also, above all, what types of investments would be supported. The report also contains many references to administrative simplification for businesses, which is a good thing, but it does not mention any safeguards for the protection of workers, including health and safety rules at work or information and consultation of workers for social dialogue. Paragraph 23 highlights the economic macroconditionality of access to structural funds, which still amounts to twice punishing those who need it most. The report also mentions the reduction in labour costs, mainly offset by green taxation but says nothing at all about the taxation of capital. Of course, I find that these points are lacking in this report because, for me, it is not a few details that need to be changed, as has been said, but resolutely the course and the method. I think all of our unemployed young people need it.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Mr. President! Today we are talking about the De Backer report, the so-called European Semester. We will vote on it tomorrow at noon. Yesterday at 10 p.m., this report, in its final version, was not yet available in German and not yet in French. These are two of the three official languages of this House. I put that on the record. I take up the name of the report. It is called :The European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination'. Coordination is the central concept. Coordinating, centralising, harmonising – you want to abolish competition within the EU so that the EU becomes more internationally competitive. This is nonsense. In fact, i am only positive about paragraph 28 of the report. It notes that only 10% of all EU coordination and harmonisation orders are fully implemented in the Member States. In our common interest, for a better future for Europe, we should slowly take note of this reality and break new ground.

name: Marco VALLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am pleased that there is now what the future Commissioner Katainen will be here, who says that only with stability will there be growth. I want to ask him in these five years of stability policies, where is growth? The data is all against it! Germany is also now having a drop and we're going to see the data, the markets, what's coming out.  So I wonder, how can we also support the fiscal compact from next year, how can countries such as France, Italy, make policies in this way? That is to say, to fall into debt in this way, we are talking about tens of billions, we are talking about the destruction of welfare! We are talking about this in Europe at the moment. If we want to do something really useful, I call on all my colleagues here to reconsider the six-pack, the two-pack and, above all, to call the Heads of State to review this folly, which is the fiscal compact, because you are aware of what we are carrying out with this policy of rigour supported only by one state, which is Germany.

name: Danuta Maria HÜBNER
text: Mr President, alongside budgetary macroeconomic measures, structural reforms are at the heart of the European Semester, and the country-specific recommendations help identify the most pressing structural reform needs across Europe. But what we need today is a strong structural reform commitment catalyst and coordination technology that would guide the reforms from the commitment stage to reality. The European Commission enjoys as never before the legitimacy of both Parliament and the Council, and has the capacity and resources to coordinate and scrutinise structural reforms. So, unless the Commission assumes this double role of commitment catalyst and coordination mechanism, the European debate on structural reform will remain empty rhetoric. Markets will punish failure to act. Europe, of course, cannot afford to run such a risk.

name: Neena GILL
text: Mr President, for me it is clear. The focus of the EU Semester needs to be shifted if we are to come out of the crisis and create growth. We will not create jobs for millions of unemployed young people by implementing a purely austerity agenda. It is not just me who is saying this: many international institutions and well-known economists have stated that we need to move to smart investments. I welcome the Commission’s investment package but we also need to look at reforms to create jobs and tackle tax evasion, plus macroeconomic imbalances, through the country-specific reports in the future being more regionally oriented. The text adopted in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs is still difficult to accept because of an unnecessary reference to macroeconomic conditionality introduced into the EU structural funds. How does it help Member States that are suffering because of certain budgetary rules to lose their structural reform? I hope that the final text that we vote on tomorrow will therefore be more balanced, and that this reference will be taken away so that I can fully support it.

name: Werner LANGEN
text: Mr. President! If you listen to the contributions to the debate, you could get the impression that growth, jobs and investment will only arise if the Member States, or even Europe, continue to take on debt. It is clear when we talk about the De Backer report: a catalogue of department stores is of no use at all. The report is already a department store catalogue. We must make it clear that the responsibility for budgetary and structural reforms lies with the Member States and no one else. The EU must coordinate it – that is sensible and right. That is why my proposal goes far beyond what we have in the European Semester. I believe that we need a Monetary Commissioner who will be given rights similar to that of the Commissioner for Competition today. That would be the way for the states to comply with their own signed guidelines. The recipes I've heard here are all misguided. Mr Lucke says it is the euro that is to blame, not the investments. Everyone knows that it is not because of the money supply, it is solely because of investment, the lack of confidence in individual states, the fact that they have lived beyond their means. Fourteen out of 21 Greek colleagues have spoken here from Greece, and only my neighbour has made reasonable statements on this. As if we could solve the problems if local politics did not choose the right path. That is why the European Semester is important, but we should not overload it!

name: Siôn SIMON
text: Mr President, we do not just need more jobs, we need better jobs. Of course there is a jobs crisis in the EU, but there is also a skills crisis and a quality crisis. What there is not is a flexibility crisis or a price crisis. The sector of the economy with the worst unemployment is precisely the sector with the highest so-called flexibility and the worst conditions – the sector of zero hours contracts, of bogus self-employment and of perpetual part-time temporary agency contracts. So if these mechanisms are – as we are asked to believe – a necessary tool for employers to get people into the labour market and keep people in the labour market, then they do not work. In which case, can I ask the Commission why none of these issues are in the country-specific recommendations?

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Dear President, I congratulate my rapporteur colleague De Backer and all colleagues who have made a major contribution in the preparation of this summary and substantial report. A lot of activities and measures are being taken at European Union level on the monetary policy side. For progress, growth and development, we need strong activities and measures on the fiscal policy side. This is precisely the role of the European Semester, which encourages Member States to reform, strengthen competitiveness and through this to economic recovery.  The report underlines the importance of linking cohesion policy with the implementation of recommendations within the European Semester. Funds should focus on financing the reforms required by the recommendations. Investments in change and development projects, in research, innovation, education and skills acquisition are key to achieving the growth we all want, and this is exactly what this report highlights. That's why I fully support him.

name: Olle LUDVIGSSON
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul In order to boost growth and job creation in Europe, we need to build a better functioning labour market. It should become an increasingly central factor in the semester. It is a question of strengthening active labour market policies. With short-term training and another match, the unemployed are given the opportunity to take the vacancies available. It is a question of strengthening social dialogue. Where parties work closely together, stability is created, good working conditions and an ability to effectively solve problems. It is also a question of ensuring equal treatment. In order to promote mobility, those working in other EU countries must be sure that they will be spared dumped wages and conditions. There is enormous potential for improvement in the European labour market. It must now be taken seriously.

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: Mr. President, dear colleagues! I have listened to this debate for a relatively long time this morning. It has not really become clear to me what the role of the European Parliament in this European Semester is supposed to be. Because the competences, the points that have been called for here, all have nothing to do with what we as the European Parliament can do. That is why I would like to agree with Mr Langen and point out that we must not overburden the European Semester and that we should not comment too much, but should concentrate on our own tasks. One of these tasks – it was mentioned briefly a moment ago – is the implementation of the country-specific recommendations, particularly in the area of the European internal market, which, according to all the studies we have before us, is still predicted to have great growth potential, according to all the studies we have before us. It is interesting to note that often the states, which also suffer economically for other reasons, unfortunately do not actually fully follow these recommendations in order to better implement the conditions of internal market law. That is why I would be very pleased, ladies and gentlemen, if we in this House could use the European Semester above all to talk more about the implementation of the texts relevant to the internal market and, in individual cases, to encourage individual countries to make the implementation of these requirements more effective. In the end, everyone would benefit – the countries that are in economic difficulties, and everyone else, and we would achieve growth that does not need new debt.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: Mr President, I will not do an analysis of time lost under the ideological paradigm of austerity in recent years. I would like to focus, however, on this new speech which is beginning to emerge in Europe , as my colleague Gualtieri previously quoted, and which is present in this report of the European Semester thanks to the amendments of our group. That is why, looking to the future, I ask the European Commission, the new European Commission where Commissioner Katainen will be, for this Europeanisation of economic policy in the euro area, that banking union, that capital market union, that tax union. And I also believe, like Mr Balz, that Europe needs to have greater capacity to implement country-specific recommendations. And I believe that the new Commission will have to channel tensions between France, Italy and Germany, because it is so difficult for a country not to comply with the rules we have given us to have a current account surplus of more than 7% or 8% of GDP and the European Commission does nothing. That is why we believe that this European Semester takes the step from the vision of the 'euro pattern' we have suffered in recent years to a genuine economic union, and we believe that the new Commission must lead it with a clear commitment.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: Mr President, as Prime Minister, the Commissioner of course pioneered the Youth Guarantee at national level in his home country – a successful project which has now also been introduced at European level. This will not solve youth unemployment as a whole, but it clearly helps.  There are many good employment and youth unemployment policy ideas at national level which can be applied in other EU Member States as well, not necessarily one-to-one – not all of them – but obviously a country in which youth unemployment is 50% or above might want to implement some of the successful measures from countries in which youth unemployment is 10% or below. Therefore, I propose to establish a European mechanism for the exchange of best practices for job creation and especially for youth unemployment. Parliament’s report on the European Semester also contains my proposal to create such a European mechanism. I look forward to working with you, Commissioner, in your new capacity as Vice-President for Jobs, to transpose this into reality. The second point I would like to make is linked to labour mobility. We are, of course, working on making transnational European labour mobility a reality in Europe, but labour mobility is also too low within many EU Member States. We often see in the same Member States unemployment levels of below 5% and employers having a hard time filling vacancies, while in other regions in the same country unemployment is above 30%. Therefore, we need also to include this and highlight it in the country-specific recommendations and work together on basically making labour mobility work within Member States too.

name: Alfred SANT
text: Ir-realtà hi li r-rata tal-investimenti fl-Unjoni Ewropea ilha tonqos sa minn żmien sew qabel seťet il-kriżi tal-elfejn u tmienja. Warajha l-istaťnar kompla jiżdied. Ir-realtà hi li biex nilťqu kompetittività akbar ťalli noťolqu impjiegi żodda, ninsabu f'sistema fejn l-aqwa gťodda saret l-iżvalutar intern. Dawk li jipproponu t-tťaffif fis-swieq tax-xogťol u modernize tas-sistemi ta' sigurtà soèjali effettivament qed jippromwovu dan l-iżvalutar. Il-proèess qed jimmina bil-kbir il-mudell soèjali Ewropew fejn l-awtorità pubblika minn naťa tiggarantixxi σelsien sť iť lill-impriża privata u min-naťa l-oťra tassigura ťarsien sťiť lill-popli bťala ťaddiema u bťala Illum biex l-ekonomija Ewropea tirranka l-mira saret li l-mudell soèjali Ewropew jitnaqqar jekk mhux jinťatt. Il-popli Ewropej dan ma jriduhx. Fil-fatt fejn qed ikun abbandunat il-mudell soèjali Ewropew xorta mhix tissaťťať il-kompetitivity. Il-verità hi li l-ekonomija Ewropea mhux qed jirnexxielha taffaèja u timmaniżżja l-globalizzazzjoni. Kif qed titwettaq bťalissa, bla lqugť u bla adattazzjoni sostanzjali, din mhijiex kompatibbli mal-mudell soèjali Ewropew. Ir-riżoluzzjoni ta' quddiemna tinjora din id-dilemma. L-istrutturi li nbnew biex jassiguraw li l-Pajjiżi Members tal-Unjoni Ewropea jibqgťu kompetittivi huma wisq tqal, wisq burokratiżi u sa issa żgur ma rnexxewx. F'dan kollu, huwa inaʻettabbli jekk donna qed naqblu li l-mudell soèjali Ewropew jista' jiżi mèekken jew imwarrab. B'rażun, iè-eitttadini Ewropej mhux se jaqblu ma' dan.

name: Verónica LOPE FONTAGNÉ
text: Mr President, Commissioner, today we can see that, thanks to an improvement in the economic situation — especially in countries which, like mine, have made the necessary structural reforms — country-specific recommendations can focus more on social issues and what is fundamental. Our objectives can be growth and job creation focused on innovative sectors such as ICT, the green sector or the digital economy, as well as poverty reduction.  From the European Union we are talking about economic, social and territorial cohesion, and in order to achieve it we must, on the one hand, pay greater attention to the most vulnerable and remote groups of the labour market through active employment policies focused on improving education and employability and facilitating recycling and the transition of work, mainly through dual training and lifelong learning.  On the other hand, productive investments must be made and interconnections with rural areas and areas with permanent natural or demographic difficulties improved, as they generally have higher unemployment rates and higher costs for accessing public services such as education and health. Finally, I would like to stress the importance of SMEs regaining the leading role in the European Union.

name: Georgi PIRINSKI
text: Mr President, it is vitally important that flexibility should be provided in the criteria for excessive deficit targets for public investments, and in investment in educational expenditure. There is absolute agreement not only in part of the House, but throughout the House, that if we want to increase the competitiveness of the European Union economy it is of paramount importance to increase investment in innovation. Therefore, Commissioner, this is a test for the Commission to prove that what is being said concerning flexibility in the rules on the European recommendations and deficit reductions is being turned into actual fact by providing space for such investments.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the European Mr President for his Firstly, I would like to state in general that this debate on the part of my fellow Members has often tried to impose on the European Semester tasks which do not belong to it. Therefore, Mr De Backer is in an extremely difficult situation, because we have been involved in a general debate.  Allow me to focus more on the European Semester and highlight an area that is really important and can also be an opportunity for us. This is the strengthening of the pillar of the internal market, a number of pieces of legislation have been adopted within the internal market pillar, but they are quite convoluted and very difficult to come by. We should focus on correct compliance with these rules, which most studies believe could actually lead to an increase. This is particularly true in the digital internal market, where we have many opportunities.  I would like to highlight another important area that has been touched on by several of my fellow Members, this is the range of country-specific recommendations. I think that country-specific recommendations are currently too general. They should be much more specific, more country-specific, as it is in its name. Unfortunately, this report does not include any reference to the inputs that should be specified here, nor do I miss the indicators that would be suitable for measuring the recommendations. There are two other important topics that I would like to mention tangentially. One is the financing issue for the SME sector. It would have been good to present a more detailed proposal in the report. I am pleased that Mr De Backer's report touched on tax fraud as an important area and has raised the proposal that I have made in the IMCO opinion. Thank you for your work and I will vote in favour of this report.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Mr. President! Only 10% of the country-specific recommendations have been fully implemented, while 45% have only been partially implemented. It is therefore clear that there is a need for action in the European Semester. I believe that the implementation of the European Semester must become compulsory and not just voluntary. A common currency requires a common budget policy. Therefore, the coordination of budgetary policy on the ground of Community law and implementation is a duty for the Member States.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: If we are talking about this important subject, which is undeniably an economic semester, then we need to link the subject of the economic semester much more strongly to social policy in the future. We have many problems that are being shown in our countries, which are very closely linked, whether to our social systems, to high unemployment rates and to the impossibility of using employment-enhancing instruments, but also to phenomena that we have still not been able to eliminate until now, such as wage policy. Employees in the same businesses earn much better in those more economically advanced countries than, say, us in Slovakia, and they are often large enterprises that, I must say, still use the cheaper labour force in our countries, even though we have been a Member State of the European Union for 10 years. I would therefore ask that, in future, we also take much more account of these social aspects, which are important for the population and according to which the people in our countries often also assess the nature of the development of the European Union.

name: Emmanouil GLEZOS
text: Mr President, education, health and research must be the immediate priorities. Anyone who wants to really care about the people cannot avoid this rule. But in order to find the possibility of developing the primary sector, the rural economy, we have to deal with the issue on the axis, that money does not create values on its own, it exchanges values, it represents values, but only workers with their work can produce values.  This is the only way to deal with the consequences of the crisis, particularly unemployment. This requires socialisation of means of production, socialisation of money ownership is required. But in order to do this, the people themselves must decide their own fortunes. Soon, whether they want it or not, in Greece the people will come to power and set an example for the whole of Europe.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: Mr President, it is really good to see everyone coming in. They have missed an hour of the most undemocratic thing I have ever seen, where we have heard all this talk: socialist dreams about all the extra spending the EU is going to do; no one allowed to question; no debate in the Chamber; our voices silenced.  Our voices will not be silenced. They will only get louder and louder. I am glad you are all back from the bars or the tofu bar or wherever you have been, because now you can hear what is really going on. The British people do not stand by what is happening here. This is a disgrace, and your economic ideas are of the past – previous centuries. The future for our country lies free of your strange economic delusions; our country lies outside the EU and outside this farce.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. - Mr President, I would like to thank honourable Members very much for a very valuable debate and ideas. I will just take up a few issues which I would like to comment on briefly. One of the issues which we seem to more or less agree on is the implementation of country-specific recommendations. We can recognise that this has not happened as efficiently as it should have done and there we all must carry our own responsibility. The issues are, of course, in the hands of Member States and governments and national parliaments, but we can also encourage them to do what they had promised to do and what is good for the countries themselves as well as for Europe as a whole. My second point: Mr Cofferati and Ms Gall-Pelcz mentioned the internal market and the country-specific recommendations concerning the single-market-related issues. We all know that there are also lots of shortages in this field. For instance, in the implementation of the Services Directive there are lots of shortages. This is quite amazing because we – the Parliament, Commission and Council – have already decided on the Services Directive, for instance, and it has not been implemented yet. So we are lacking economic growth because of poor performance in various Member States in this field as well, so we need to pay more attention there in the future. The third point is about the structural reforms. Mr Eickhout said that the Commission has historically represented structural reforms that are too one-sided and our idea has been just to use structural reforms as a tool to reform austerity policy. Of course, it depends on the country as to what the problems are, but I would just like to raise a few issues and a few examples of non-austerity structural reforms. The first one is tax reform, for instance lowering labour tax and raising environmental tax, or raising dividend tax and at the same time lowering corporate income tax. Another issue is pension reform, which is necessary in many countries because the population is ageing – municipality reform, labour reform and things like that. So it is not only about austerity, but a change to society so that it is stronger and more sustainable.  The next point is gender equality. Many Members also raised this issue. I am very happy about this because it is a question both of equality and labour supply. So at the same time as we are reforming our societies to be more sustainable, they can be more growth-oriented. Gender equality – the Finnish Labour Party is based on this – is very crucial in this sense. My final point: Mr Pirinski and Mr Cofferati mentioned the role of research and development. This is one of the issues on which we have to concentrate more during the next European Semester – what we could do in order to strengthen R&D activities in our Member States because this is the way to improve the potential growth of the Member States. There are good examples in various Member States where the universities and small- and medium-sized entrepreneurship have been combined in a very fascinating way and the universities have become a hub of entrepreneurship. So in something like this we could learn from each other, and they could be added to country-specific recommendations.

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, just two final lines, after thanking all the speakers and having found a debate that is also passionate here, with many common visions, although certainly not one. The weeks and months ahead are in many respects crucial and we hope to be able to examine soon the first annual growth survey to be presented by the new Commission. We need to review the economic governance provisions of the six-pack and two-pack review. And we must conclude the mid-term review of Europe 2020 to ensure that the strategy and its implementing instruments remain valid and effective. Cooperation between all the institutions of these processes will be essential to achieving positive results. While we are working for these reviews at European level, we are well aware that what matters to citizens is the result at national or regional or local level and their need to see improvements in everyday life. We have identified the policies that can make these improvements and implementing them is our common challenge.

name: Philippe DE BACKER
text: rapporteur. - Mr President, colleagues, thank you for your input during the debate. In the final conclusion I cannot go into all the remarks, but just let me say this: in the end it is very clear that every part of the European institutions, be it Parliament, be it the Commission or be it also the Member States, have to promise and follow through on what they have promised in the past.  Let me begin with the Member States. If you come to Brussels and within the European Semester you agree to implement certain structural reforms to make sure that your deficits are being reduced, that you implement the necessary reforms to modernise your economies, a 10% success rate is not enough. You will have to perform better. Also we, as a Parliament, will have to make sure that the scrutiny we apply through the process of the European Semester is stronger. Also at European level there is still a lot to be done. Mr Katainen has made a good point on completion of the single market, but also completion of the capital market, of the Energy Union and of the digital market will be a high priority for the next Commission.  It is also necessary to say that, with all these structural reforms, we do not have to do them because we are told to by Brussels; we are doing them because our citizens want them, because they understand that modernising our economies, making them more competitive, attracting private and public investment to make our economies grow and to create employment is the essence of the European project. I urge you all tomorrow during the vote to think very deeply about the road that Europe is taking and to support the report that I have presented here today. I hope that we can have full support for this report and that we can continue like this in the future.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Wednesday. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: - Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. It is very important to monitor and improve the regulation and processes in the internal market, as well as to the debate on country-specific indicators, in which I fully support the professional position of the Hungarian Vice-President of the EP. At the same time, allow me to explain, in the context of wage catch-up and the creation of new jobs, that balanced and prudent steps are needed. It is known that many new jobs have been created in the eastern half of Europe since accession to the EU, and it is also true that these secure jobs were created partly because of lower wages. At the same time, the 'equal opportunities' and equalisation of wages in the Eastern and Western Member States cannot be imagined with the mass and rapid loss of existing hard-earned and retained jobs in the eastern half of Europe. Just a reminder: in Hungary, in 2002-2010, the reported and large-scale collective redundancies were higher each year than in any of the last four years of the second Orban government. This result must be taken care of and full employment, which is also stated in the EU's Founding Treaty, should be pursued in order to ensure that as many people as possible have jobs and thus the economy, and thus living standards, are increased.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. – The European Semester, the economic semester, gives an assessment of member states' economic policies on the basis of objective criteria, irrespective of the current majority of governments. In contrast to the government's success propaganda, the Autumn Hungary is breaking away from its regional rivals. Rising public debt could cause us to fall back into the excessive deficit procedure, which is a closer EU budgetary observation. As a result of luxury investments and a senseless freedom struggle, next year we will face austerity of up to HUF 1 700 billion, which fidesz is taking from the pockets of the Hungarian people. It is telling that before the municipal elections, the current government did not dare to say this to the Hungarian people. The Hungarian government continues to austerity, withdraw resources from higher education and health care, and puts those on modest incomes in a hopeless position. One in three Young Hungarians is unemployed. As a result of the misguided economic policy, more than half a million Hungarians, most of them young Hungarians, are now working abroad. Instead of vegling civilians and excessive internet taxation, it would be necessary to introduce the euro immediately and to change the single-rate tax system for the poor and disproportionately rewarding the rich. It is useful for the European Commission to look at governments. EU control can be a guarantee for Hungarian citizens against the irresponsible economic policies of the Fidesz government.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: Dear Mr President, the Specific Recommendations that the European Commission has made in the framework of the European Semester in recent years have produced many positive results and helped to accelerate the crisis and restore economic growth. Unfortunately, the weakening reform pressures associated with this unstable improvement of the economic situation in some Member States lead to a refusal to carry out the severe reforms necessary to stabilise public finances and thus threatens to erase the progress made. The Commission's analysis shows that these recommendations are not sufficiently taken into account at national level and we need to create stronger safeguards for their implementation if we are to accelerate growth and improve the living standards of our citizens. Particular attention should be paid to the need to continue reforms in countries that mark negative demographic trends threatening the sustainability of their health and pension systems. In the absence of decisive action, instability in these systems will put increasing pressure to deviate from sound budgetary policy and hinder economic growth. The only approach responsible for European citizens and future generations is to go down the path of reforms and stop wasting valuable time in lutting and political experimentation.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Writing. – The time of saving must end. Europe needs investment, both public and private. This is the only way to stimulate growth and, at the same time, to stimulate employment and demand. This must be an absolute priority and should be included in the European Semester. Outgoing Commission President Barroso said he did not see a risk of recession in the euro area, despite zero growth in the second quarter and a bleak outlook for 2015. Investment in some Member States has fallen by 30-40 percent since the crisis erupted. A crucial point, therefore, will be to exclude sustainable investment from deficit calculations, so that states return to the growth path while not neglecting necessary investments. Mr Juncker's €300 billion investment plan is a glimmer of hope. Of course, it is important that social indicators have been taken into account for the first time in the European Semester. However, it is incomprehensible why employment and social objectives are not treated on an equal footing – i.e. binding – as macroeconomic targets. Finally, a point of great importance that I have raised: wealth and income inequality has risen sharply in recent years, jeopardising purchasing power, demand and investment in the real economy. Member States should therefore include measures in their national reform programmes to reduce these inequalities.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. – The main objective of the European Semester is to maintain an up-and-coming process of economic recovery and to achieve a balanced budget. It is therefore essential that the coordination of the EU's economic policies is subject to democratic control by the European Parliament. In addition, greater involvement of national parliaments in improving democratic control would also be welcome. It is also crucial for the EU economy to maintain and support a balanced and sustainable strategy for growth and jobs. I would like to stress the importance of the correct implementation of the recommendations by the Member States, as well as the need for greater transparency in the decision-making process. If we look at the implementation of the 2013 recommendations, we find that only 10-15% of the recommendations in 2013 have been fully implemented. In view of this, I would like to draw attention to the need to ensure greater discipline in the implementation of the recommendations in order to mobilise sufficient political capital in favour of reforms in the Member States. In particular, it is the Member States that should push for increased competitiveness, growth and modernisation of the social security system and the labour market.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: The European Semester has become an effective tool of the European Union and the Member States for the coordination of economic policies. The experience gained in recent years in using this tool is beginning to bear fruit. However, I believe that two still visible problems must be removed, which affect the effectiveness of the European Semester. Firstly, in some Member States, draft national reform programmes and those of convergence programmes or, where appropriate, stability programmes are not submitted to national parliaments before being submitted to the European Commission. Secondly, the recommendations made to each Member State by the European Commission and appropriated by the Council are not translated into programmes and measures at national level so as to ensure that reported problems are removed and trends are corrected.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. – The European Semester for economic policy coordination is essential for the proper functioning of the Economic Union. However, it is also worth emphasising that it has a significant impact on social stability and on the lives of every resident of an EU Member State. This fact is particularly evident in the European Union, which has experienced an economic crisis which has severely worsened living conditions for many European citizens, including the Lithuanian population. The crisis has also led to an increase in inequalities and poverty levels, limiting people's access to good quality public services, which in the 21st century have been reduced. Europe should be the norm. The debate on the EU Semester provides an excellent opportunity to encourage Member States to act more intensively in areas where citizens are at risk of social exclusion. The phenomenon of social exclusion is worrying and is increasingly occurring among young people. For this reason, the European Union, like its Member States, must start to tackle unemployment more actively, especially among young people who are taking the first steps in the labour market. In addition, coordinated economic policies must take into account support at all levels in order to create more jobs. It is therefore worth considering a proposal that encourages the Commission to increase the focus on reforms needed to support the provision of high-quality public services, with a particular focus on health systems in the Member States. In order for the strategy in question to be effective, it must be based on development-oriented investments, better use of human resources, in order to make the labour markets more flexible and to respond more quickly to economic change.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the vote. (Results and other voting details: see minutes)

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to point out that, on 25 April, France submitted a request for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund following the restructuring plan of PSA, particularly at the Rennes and Aulnay sites.  I would also like to point out that to date, more than 2,300 workers have not found work and remain unemployed, and that this plan is designed to help them find a job. Therefore, I thank parliamentarians for approving it.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I hereby close the vote.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. Whilst in Brussels last week, SF’s Martin McGuinness had very positive discussions with both the Chair of the European Parliament’s Committee on the Budget and the Head of Operations at the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. I was pleased to hear from European officials that they are ‘open’ to the prospects of Ballymena’s JTI Gallagher plant in the North of Ireland benefiting from the Globalization Adjustment Fund to assist workers facing redundancy. Martin McGuinness dFM strongly made the case that Gallagher’s clearly falls into the remit of this fund, which aims to help people who lose their jobs as a direct result of global market trends. What we were told was that the onus is on the British Government to submit a bid for assistance or to delegate responsibility to the Northern Executive to do so. Martin McGuiness will work with his colleague Peter Robinson in an effort to get a joint approach to the British Government so that the delegated authority is secured. This is an opportunity to do something tangible to help workers at Gallagher’s, and the goodwill expressed by key decision-makers in Europe must be pursued.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. - The principle of subsidiarity dictates that decisions should be taken at the closest possible level to the citizen – in this case at regional or national level. Therefore, these projects should not be funded by the European Union.  It is absurd that the arbiters of whether this funding should, or should not, be given are Members of the European Parliament with no detailed knowledge of the situation. This project may well be of benefit to the people in the Comunidad Valenciana, but I am not best placed to judge. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be scrapped, which would give money back to the Member States to decide for themselves about the appropriateness of such funding. Consequently, I had no option but to vote against – even though this may be a worthwhile project.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. - I am pleased that a project is being set up to support the reintegration into the labour market of 633 workers made redundant, due to the global economic and financial crisis, in 142 companies active in the metal products manufacturing sector in Spain.  The economic crisis has weighed heavily on these different sectors throughout the European Union. Indeed, the decline in production in the industry has had consequences for employment. Nearly 600,000 jobs were lost in Spanish industry between 2008 and 2012, including 150,000 in the manufactured metal products sector. These job losses account for 24% of total employment in industry and 35% of total employment in the metal industry, respectively. Job losses in the metal products sector were even greater in Comunidad Valenciana. Indeed, the number of jobs in the metallurgical sector in this region rose from 35,868 in 2008 to 20,873 in 2012, representing a decline of 43%, eight percentage points higher than at the national level.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. - The European Globalisation Adjustment Funds are a key tool to support thousands of workers affected by major structural changes in our economy. I vote in favour of mobilizing EUR 1 019 184 which will give 300 metal workers in the Valencian Community a new opportunity to recycle their training, create companies, or receive occupational advice, i.e. adapt their skills and skills to existing demand. A sector in crisis that accounted for 25.4% of employment in the Valencian industrial sector, and which has now lost a third of its turnover and almost half of jobs. I consider it essential to support such employment revival policies, with the confidence that the European Commission and the Spanish authorities will take the necessary measures to verify that the funds we approve today are managed in accordance with the principles of transparency and efficiency.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. - This request for intervention under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Spain concerns the reintegration into the labour market of laid-off workers in 142 companies in the metal products manufacturing sector in the autonomous community of Valencia (Communidad Valenciana), Spain.   This application concerns 633 dismissed workers, including 300 beneficiaries. It aims to mobilise EUR 1,019,184.  Faced with a global economic and financial crisis, Spain is hard hit by the decline in demand and production of metals. In this region alone, the number of jobs in the metallurgical sector fell by 43%, from 35,868 in 2008 to 20,873 in 2012.  In the face of this situation, I have spoken out in favour of this request.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. - (IT) I supported this report authorising the mobilisation of the EGF, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in favour of 142 Spanish companies in the metallurgical sector. The EGF is the European instrument which, more than any other at the moment, can help workers in companies affected by the crisis by treating the symptoms but not the causes of their malaise. That is why I will certainly continue to support what you have done, but also to fight for Europe to tackle the real causes of this unprecedented economic and financial crisis: I am referring to the wrong currency, the fixed and ines demanding budgetary parameters imposed by the European Treaties and a worldview that helps immigrants and not European citizens.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. - (C) Has voted in favour of this report today. I therefore do so to provide workers in the cases in question with financial support for retraining and/or other measures to find new jobs. However, I would like to stress that the high level of unemployment in europe could be effectively combated if the austerity policies of the European Commission and the governments of the Member States have long been pursued could be stopped. Creating new jobs in Europe requires a new economic policy with massive public and environmentally friendly investments. Public investment is needed in schools, health and social care, but also in infrastructure, rail, public transport, energy-efficient housing and sustainable energy systems.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 1 019 184 of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 633 workers who have lost their jobs in the metal products manufacturing sector in the Valencian Community as a result of structural changes in world trade due to globalisation and the impact of the economic and financial crisis. The personalized services to be financed from the FEAG include training activities, vocational guidance, placement, promotion of entrepreneurship and incentives for the creation of a company. While these aids alone are not capable of alleviating the drama of unemployment in the Valencian Community, they do constitute good assistance and training for the reintegration of the workers concerned.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report because it supported the granting of support from the European Globalisation Fund in the Valencia region of Spain. This support was decided to be granted to employees of companies active in the manufacture of metal products, who were made redundant in the reference period from 1 April 2013 to 31 December 2013 from 142 companies operating in the region , of which 300 employees were eligible for support under the egf measures. The application submitted by Spain met the criteria for financial assistance laid down in the EGF Regulation. The Commission and Parliament also assessed the fact that the metal products sector is also a major supplier of raw materials to various manufacturing industries, in particular the shipbuilding, construction and automotive sectors, which have been severely affected by the economic crisis throughout the Union. The egf will provide redundant workers with a coordinated but tailored service package covering vocational guidance, recruitment, training, entrepreneurship promotion, business start-up support, job search allowance, cost-related travel and employment promotion.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the resolution on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in the redundancy sector in Comunidad Valenciana, driven by similar problems in Romania, where the metallurgical sector has lost more than 200,000 jobs in the last 20 years.  Some of the combined plants have been privatised, but in most cases they have disappeared altogether, being privatised by liquidation.  Metallurgy has become an unemployment-generating industry. And it will remain so for a while, as the big combined plants continue to cut their spending.  The clearest example is that of the Russian group Mechel, which in 2013 sold the four metallurgical compounds it owned in Romania, which was heavily indebted, with most of the employees of these combined being subsequently made redundant. I believe that through the measures stipulated, as well as through the financial support provided, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an effective instrument for employment in the EU, as well as an indispensable measure for the retraining of redundant employees. Through such programmes, the European Union once again demonstrates its support for the workforce.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of mobilising the adjustment fund to protect 142 companies in the metallurgical sector. We must defend work and not finance!

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. - Parliament has decided to accept the Request for Intervention of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund from Comunidad Valenciana metal manufacturing companies in Spain to help employees of this company, which is heavily affected by the employment consequences of globalisation. Dismissed employees will receive training aimed at reintegrating into the labour market and finding a job. I voted in favour of this report, which shows the Union's solidarity in the face of certain negative consequences of globalisation on employment.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - (IT) Today I voted in favour of this report in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of 633 workers working in the metal products manufacturing sector in Spain, as a result of the economic and financial crisis.  The metal products sector is crucial for a wide range of manufacturing industries such as shipbuilding, construction and the automotive sector. In the European Union, the economic crisis has hit all these sectors hard. Between 2000 and 2007, i.e. before the economic and financial crisis, the eu industrial production index recorded an average annual growth of approximately 1.7%. Subsequently, between April 2008 and April 2009, industrial production in the EU fell by more than 22%. In Particular, in Spain, between April 2008 and April 2009, industrial production fell by almost 27% (i.e. five points higher than the EU level) and has not recovered since, experiencing a relatively regular decline.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. - (IT) Unfortunately, the metallurgical sector has been hit not only by the structural change in world trade but also because the Spanish economy itself has suffered greatly as a result of the crisis. The 5-Star Movement supports any call for mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund that is fully justified and that gives relief to those people who have no fault, but only the misfortune of being working in industrial sectors that suffer the ruthless competition of countries that do not have the same legal feeling with regard to workers' rights. That is why we want to safeguard, as far as possible, the fate of those who are fighting hard to keep their jobs and feed their families.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the application, the tenth within the framework of the 2014 budget, for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) for a total amount of EUR 1,019,184 for Spain.  The EGF was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. The application in question was submitted by the Spanish authorities following redundancies and terminations of activity in 142 undertakings manufacturing metal products, excluding machinery and equipment in the NUTS 2 level region of the Valencian Community.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was established in 2006 to provide additional assistance to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of international trade and to help them reintegrate into the labour market.  From 1 May 2009, the scope of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been extended to include support for workers made redundant as a direct result of the economic, financial and social crisis.  At a time when Europe is in the face of a financial, economic and social crisis, with unemployment being one of the main consequences, the European Union should use all means at its service to react, in particular, to the support to be provided to people who have been left without a job.  I therefore supported this report on the mobilisation of EUR 1 019 184 in favour of Spain with the aim of supporting the 633 workers made redundant in 142 factories in the Comunidad Valenciana region.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - Spain is among the Member States hardest hit by the financial and economic crisis, with the consequent fall in industrial production which has had obvious consequences for employment, particularly in the manufacture of metal products, raising the unemployment rate. That is why I supported this report because I believe that intervention by the EGF in favour of the Comunidad Valenciana in the production of metals and metal products, which is important for a wide range of manufacturing activities such as shipbuilding, construction and automotive, sectors all heavily affected by the EU economic crisis, is of common interest to all Member States.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. - The European Union has set up legislative and budgetary instruments in order to provide additional support to workers who have been affected by the consequences of major structural shifts in world trade patterns and to support the re-integration of the same workers back into the labour market. The report confirms that 300 workers previously operating in the manufacture of fabricated metal products in Spain will be targeted by the EGF co-funded measures. Personalised services for the redundant workers will include occupational guidance, promotion of entrepreneurship, vocational training and up skilling to build on skills and competences gained in the metal industry. I therefore voted in favour of this report as it will provide additional opportunities and support to the workers (and their families) affected by these redundancies.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. - In favour of mobilising the EGF for Spain, with several metallurgical companies in the Comunidad Valenciana in crisis: a total of 142 companies and over 600 workers are involved, amounting to around EUR 1 million. The redundancies of workers in companies manufacturing metal products in Spain are linked to the global economic and financial crisis; Spain is one of the Member States hardest hit by the crisis, which has led to a decrease in demand, and therefore in production, of metals and metal products;  in Spain, the manufacture of metal products decreased by 23.3% in 2009 compared to the previous year, and by 36.6% between 2008 and 2013; notes that the sector's turnover fell by 38.5% in the period 2008-2012 and that the number of jobs lost corresponds to 43% of total employment in the metallurgical sector. The objective of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is to facilitate the rapid reintegration into working life of these redundant workers through tailor-made accompanying actions, such as assistance in job search, vocational guidance, training and retraining, promotion of self-employment and entrepreneurship.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of resources for 300 of the 633 laid-off workers from 142 companies engaged in the manufacture of metal products in order to implement measures co-financed by the EGF during the period from 1 April 2013 to 31 December 2013. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of high unemployment in Spain, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. - I supported this EU action because the EGAF funding of EUR 1 019 184 will contribute to the costs of measures for the reintegration of approximately 300 redundant workers into employment. I note that this application by Spain relates to 633 redundancies in 142 enterprises operating in the manufacture of fabricated metal products in Comunidad Valenciana, linked to the global financial and economic crisis, during the reference period from 1 April 2013 to 31 December 2013. The Commission has concluded that the application meets the conditions for deploying the EGAF.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. - Thanks to this text, employees of the Spanish steel industry who have been made redundant will be able to benefit from a range of services that can help them return to their jobs. Not only will they be offered vocational training but also incentives to start their own business.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. - The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) aims to help workers who have lost their jobs as a result of changes in world trade as well as the victims of the financial crisis. This application, submitted by Spain, is for layoffs in the steel sector. Spain is one of the Member States most severely affected by the crisis. The latter has, among other things, led to a decline in demand and production of metals and metal products. Metal products were manufactured by 23.3% in 2009 compared to the previous year and by 36.6% between 2008 and 2013; the sector's turnover decreased by 38.5% over the 2008 to 2012 period and job losses accounted for 43% of total employment in the metallurgical sector. The aim is to help 300 sacked employees out of 633 in 142 companies located in the Comunidad Valenciana region. The assistance will amount to EUR 1,019,184 and will help to co-finance active labour market measures focused on career guidance, placement and training,... This request has my support as well as that of the European Parliament.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. - The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. Spain has requested assistance from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant in 142 Companies in Spain as a result of the global financial and economic crisis, with the exception of workers made redundant in machinery and equipment sectors. Spain thus lost around 600 000 industrial jobs between 2008 and 2012, of which 150 000 were in the metal processing products sector. Lost jobs amounted to 24% of total industrial employment and 35% of all jobs in the metal products sector. A coordinated package of personalised services for redundant workers includes the following actions: career guidance advice, job mediation, training (vocational training, further training, development of transversal skills, on-the-job training), support for entrepreneurship, support for start-ups, job search allowance, contribution to the cost of commuting to work (commuting) and employment promotion. According to the Commission, the measures described above constitute an active labour market measure within the scope of Article 7 of the EGF Regulation and may benefit from a financial contribution of EUR 1 019 184 at the request of Spain. I supported the report in the plenary vote.

name: Pablo ECHENIQUE
text: in writing. - The delegation of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilizing this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. This aid is partial, as only 300 workers would benefit, and it seems insufficient as the amount of investment per capita to support their training and labour insertion processes through self-employment would not reach EUR 3400. We consider this EGF to be a simple hot cloth over the bleeding that is charged each month, in terms of mass layoffs, this Europe of Markets and Capitals. It is urgent to formulate policies aimed at the distribution of wage labour and a real disengagement between access to work and the right of access to fundamental public goods and services.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. - The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. I voted in favour of this report because it is a means by which the EU can give valuable help to local economies hard hit by company closures. I regret that the government has not taken advantage of this fund in Wales.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. - (C) Our belief is that prosperity is created through free trade and fair competition. That is why we are opposed in principle to the European Globalisation Fund, which we believe is an expression of protectionism. We can possibly accept that the Fund is being used as a mere emergency measure at a time when europe is in a deep economic crisis – especially in view of people's sense of hopelessness and exclusion that has followed the wake of the crisis- and which risks further reinforcing the wave of nationalism and xenophobia that is spreading today in europe. However, we believe that the Fund is unfounded on the day the crisis is over.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - The EGF was created to provide additional support to redundant workers following major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation or financial crisis and helping them find new jobs. Between 2014 and 2020, the fund's annual ceiling is EUR 150 million. Redundant workers are offered measures such as support for business creation, job search assistance, vocational guidance and various types of training. Spain submitted its application to the EGF following 633 redundancies in 142 companies in the metal manufacturing sector during the reference period from 1 April 2013 to 31 December 2013, which are related to the global financial and economic crisis which resulted in a lower demand for metal and metal products and lower production of them down 23.3% , in 2009 compared to the previous year, and 36.6% between 2008 and 2013.Turnover decreased by 38.5 % during the period 2008-2012, and redundancies account for 43% of total employment in the metallurgical sector. In this mobilization of the EGF in favour of the Spanish region of Comunidad Valenciana, EUR 1.019 million was granted. I voted in favour.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - In this plenary session we are called upon to decide on the allocation of financial assistance from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) – the Fund set up to be mobilised in the event of massive redundancies and thus perhaps alleviate the poor conscience of those responsible for the policies promoting them – following 8204 redundancies by 155 companies based in Spain, Belgium and France. It's brutal and shameful. An accusatory libel to this European Union and its policies. This report focuses on the application of Comunidad Valenciana Metal, following 633 redundancies in 142 companies in the metal products manufacturing sector in Spain. The justification for further these redundancies is the global economic crisis, with Spain being one of the most severely affected Member States, which resulted in lower demand for metal and metal products and lower production of these redundancies - production fell by 37% between 2008 and 2013, turnover decreased by 39% between 2008 and 2013 and redundancies account for 43% of total employment in the metallurgical sector.  This is the eu's response to the crisis: massive capital destruction, redundancies, falling wages, settlement of rights, dismantling of the welfare state, increased exploitation. It is urgent to break with this path.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of this intervention to make up for the redundancies of 142 Spanish companies in the metal sector for a figure of just over one million Euros.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. - While it seems a proposal for real support for the dismissed and even in such a difficult economic period, it hides the negative fact that in the hands of the workers almost nothing will reach, since all the funding will be passed on by intermediaries. That is why my vote is against.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. - I voted against this application for mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. I support measures that create growth and jobs, but the Globalisation Adjustment Fund is simply a waste of taxpayers’ money. There is no evidence that it offers value for money in terms of reintegrating redundant workers back into the labour market.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. - The delegation of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilizing this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. This aid is partial, as only 300 workers would benefit, and it seems insufficient as the amount of investment per capita to support their training and labour insertion processes through self-employment would not reach EUR 3400. We consider this EGF to be a simple patch that is charged every month, in terms of mass layoffs, in this Europe where the interests of large companies are above the interests of citizens. It is urgent to formulate policies aimed at the distribution of wage labour and a real disengagement between access to work and the right of access to fundamental public goods and services.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: in writing. We must face reality and tell citizens that these huge amounts of money, devoted solely to subsidies, generate no wealth, no productivity, no hope. All they generate are economies destined for failure and societies that are letharged by the excessive protection of States.  I don't object to people being helped, but I do object to people being treated like cattle, who are fed and not disturbed. We must foster creativity and creation, not the European paternalism of 'money everything is fixed', because this way we will not be able to create the right frameworks so that these people can create a new life.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. - I support the need to have a European instrument to assist redundant workers. I am glad that Parliament fully supported the setting up of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) as part of the Multiannual Financial Framework for 2014 to 2020. I supported this application for Comunidad Valenciana metal workers following 633 redundancies in 142 enterprises in the fabricated metal products industry. Assistance to this region is essential, particularly given the fact that in the period 2008-2009 industrial production in Spain declined by almost five points more than in the EU-28 and has yet to recover and still faces continuing decline. I would also like to congratulate the Spanish authorities for their support for the workers in their decision to begin the early implementation of personalised services to those made redundant.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - The delegation of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilizing this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. This aid is partial, as only 300 workers would benefit, and it seems insufficient as the amount of investment per capita to support their training and labour insertion processes through self-employment would not reach EUR 3400. We consider this EGF to be a mere patch in terms of mass layoffs, in this Europe where the interests of large companies are above the interests of citizens. It is urgent to formulate policies aimed at the distribution of wage labour and a real disengagement between access to work and the right of access to fundamental public goods and services.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. - I voted for the motion for a resolution as the financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund will help laid-off workers in the Valencian Community, of which there are 633 and who are in a state of uncertainty and in difficult life moments.  I also support the rather swift reaction of the European Commission, which reacted promptly to the request of the Spanish authorities in the form of their re-entry into the labour market, as the finished metal products sector is one of the main suppliers of important EU branches of the economy (e.g. construction, shipbuilding).  UNEMPLOYMENT rates in the EU have reached historic levels as a result of the economic crisis, so concrete measures (such as vocational training) need to be implemented, in addition to the EGF, which represents emergency assistance, in order to contribute strongly to the economies of the affected regions.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. - It is important to support employees who lose their jobs suddenly due to a global financial and economic crisis. We need to help them get back on their way to employment. This aid of 1.02 million will help the many employees in the production of metal products in the municipality of Valencia in Spain to return to the labour market and find a job that is in line with their skills, while from 2008 to 2013 43% of jobs were lost in the region.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. - I supported the resolution on the request to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund introduced by Spain concerning redundancies in metal products companies located in the province of Valencia. The Fund was created to promote the reintegration into the labour market of workers who are victims of changes in the structure of international trade resulting from globalization, or the financial crisis. I am the the the city, the for example of the adoption of this financial aid amounting to just over eur 1 million.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of mobilisation of the Fund, as I support providing assistance for the reintegration into employment of around 300 redundant workers who lost their jobs due to the global financial and economic crisis.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of Mr De Clercq's report. Mr Šulin, as I see the decision on the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Spain as an undisputed opportunity for the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant in 142 companies operating in the metalworking sector. In a context of economic crisis such as the one we are experiencing, we have repeatedly stressed the importance and effectiveness of an instrument such as the EGF. By using the most appropriate destination criteria, Europe is once again demonstrating its mission of solidarity and its concreteness in helping the people most affected by a devastating economic crisis.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of resources for 300 of the 633 laid-off workers from 142 companies engaged in the manufacture of metal products in order to implement measures co-financed by the EGF during the period from 1 April 2013 to 31 December 2013. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of high unemployment in Spain, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. - This fund has been established by the EU with the aim of helping workers who have suffered the consequences of major structural changes in global trade patterns or the continuation of the global financial and economic crisis to return to the labour market. In this context, Spain submitted an application for the mobilisation of this fund on the occasion of the dismissal of 633 workers in 142 companies engaged in the manufacture of metal products in the Valencian Community as a result of the economic crisis that has hit the EU and especially Spain in this sector.
