The proposal adopted by the Commission consists of an aid of EUR 1,019,184 affecting 300 workers, for the implementation of active measures for the labour market: vocational guidance services, placement, training activities, promotion of entrepreneurship, incentives for the creation of an undertaking, job-seeking allocations, contribution to travel expenses and incentives for job creation. Considering that the granting of this measure meets the requirements and is of significant aid, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. - I decided to support the Mobilisation Report of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help the Comunidad Valenciana region, which laid off 633 workers from 142 companies operating in the metal finished products manufacturing sector.  The European Globalisation Fund was created to provide additional support to workers made redundant by the effects of the global financial and economic crisis, in order to support reintestment into the labour market. This Report aims to mobilise €1 million for affected workers to provide them with professional orientation, employment mediation, education and training for new jobs, promotions of entrepreneurship, incentives for entrepreneurship and employment, job search allowances and commuting costs, all for the purpose of restoring to the labour market and increasing employment levels.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. - I voted in favour, because that was also the position of the socialist political group. The Spanish proposal is in line with my political convictions and policy of action in the context of globalisation.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. - I supported this proposal as a legitimate use of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The Spanish authorities argue that the metal products sector is a key provider of inputs to a wide range of manufacturing activities, in particular the shipbuilding, construction and automotive sectors. All of these were significantly impacted across the European Union by the economic crisis, as previously recognised by the Commission and its services.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, concerning spain's application for financial assistance from the EGF, following the 600 redundancies in 142 companies operating in the metal products manufacturing sector in that country. I believe it is essential and of the utmost importance that measures be applied to assist redundant workers in terms of: placement, training and safeguarding jobs.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. - (IT) I believe that the principle of solidarity between the Member States of the European Union must be an essential point of reference for the work of the Community institutions.  It is on this basis that I have decided to express my agreement with mrs Šulin's report, which supports the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in favour of a large number of Spanish workers made redundant in companies operating in the manufacture of metal products.  Spain is one of the countries most affected by the economic crisis in recent years, and we have a duty to help each of our Member States in times of greatest difficulty.  In order to promote the harmonious reintegration into the labour market of as many as 633 workers made redundant from 142 different Spanish companies operating in the metallurgical sector.  Yes, because, if we want to continue to be accredited as an institutional point of reference to our citizens, we have a moral duty to act to ensure that they are guaranteed fundamental rights, including those at work. Yes, finally, to show how much the European Parliament cares about the dignity of each of the Community's workers, regardless of their national affiliation, and the political colour of their members.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. - The redundancies at the 142 companies of the Comunidad Valenciana are linked to far-reaching structural changes in world trade patterns as a result of globalisation. The losses in the metal finished product production sector illustrate the rapid decline in the European market share in steel production and the simultaneous increase in the market share of countries such as China. This makes it all the more important to adopt an effective Union strategy for the steel-producing industry in order to maintain competitiveness. For these reasons, I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF in this case.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The globalization aid fund fulfils its harmful role. Instead of helping workers, it encourages shareholders and states to submit to forced liberalism. The application concerns 633 workers laid off in 142 companies in the manufacture of metal products located in the Spanish region "Comunidad Valenciana". The Spanish authorities argue that the economic crisis has weighed heavily on the manufacturing sector throughout the European Union: between April 2008 and April 2009, industrial production in the EU fell by more than 22 percentage points. But without questioning the economic model that is the cause of the deindutrialisation of Europe and without promoting the only effective remedy: solidarity protectionism. Both the Spanish government and the EU treat the symptoms without ever addressing the causes of the disease. I abstain so as not to deprive Spanish workers of this fund.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. - The EU is an area of solidarity and is part of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This support is essential to help the unemployed and the victims of relocations in a globalised context. More and more companies are relocating, taking advantage of the low labour prices that are practised in several countries, notably China and India, with harmful effects on countries that respect workers' rights. The EGF is intended to help workers who are victims of business relocation and is key to facilitating access to new employment. The EGF has already been used in the past by other EU countries, and it is now up to Spain to give this aid, who submitted the EGF/2014/004 ES/Comunidad Valenciana Metal application to a financial contribution from the EGF, following 633 redundancies in 142 companies in the metal manufacturing sector in Spain (300 potential workers receiving the measures co-financed by the EGF) during the reference period from 1 April 2013 to 31 December 2013.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. - The European Union has set up legislative and budgetary instruments in order to provide additional support to workers who have been affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns and to assist the reintegration of the same workers back into the labour market. The report notes that between 2008 and 2012, Spain lost almost 600 000 jobs in the metal industry. The Comunidad Valenciana metal application aims to support Spain in reintegrating into the labour market workers from 142 enterprises manufacturing fabricated metal products who were made redundant due to the global financial and economic crises. Therefore, I have voted in favour of this report, which will aid affected workers.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. - I am fully supporting the Report giving the green light for the mobilisation of the European Globalization Adjustment Fund (EGAF) in Spain in relation to 633 redundancies in 142 enterprises operating in in the manufacture of fabricated metal products due to the global financial and economic crisis. The fund will help workers made redundant with occupational guidance, job placement, trainings (vocational training and upskilling, training in transversal skills, on-the-job training), promotion of entrepreneurship, incentives for setting up a business, job-search allowance, contribution to commuting expenses and employment incentives.

name: Giulia MOI
text: in writing. - The Spanish authorities submitted the application EGF/2014/004 ES/Comunidad Valenciana Metal for financial assistance from the EGF following redundancies and terminations of operations in 142 companies operating in the manufacture of metal products in the Comunidad Valenciana. As the contribution is intended to be additional support for the 633 redundant workers and aims to facilitate their reintegration into the labour market, I voted in favour.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. Spain has applied to the Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) to the tune of EUR 1,019,184 to support the reintegration into the labour market and the training of 300 of the 633 workers laid off in 142 companies in the metal products manufacturing sector in the Valencian Community. These layoffs only exacerbate the fragility of the labour market in this part of Spain. It should be remembered that the production of metal products in Spain fell by 36.6% between 2008 and 2013 as a result of the decline in demand from shipbuilding and the automotive industry. It should also be noted that the unemployment rate in this country is very high and that that of young people is one of the highest in the euro area. Spain and its people, permanently affected by the crisis, must not only face the social damage caused by the ultraliberal dogma put in place by the European Union but also suffer the austerity measures imposed by Brussels. For these reasons, I voted to grant this aid to Spanish workers.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. - I voted for the mobilization of 1,019,184 euros which will benefit 300 former employees of the steel sector in the region of Valencia (Spain). Elected from a steel region that has not been spared by the crisis, I am very familiar with the economic situation of the sector and the dramatic social consequences. Gross steel production in the EU increased from 206.9 million tonnes in 2006 to 177.6 million tonnes in 2011. This corresponds to the decline in European market share in the sector from 16.6% in 2006 to 11.7% in 2011. At the same time, the Chinese market share rose from 33.7% to 45%.  I stress that the mobilization of these funds is a one-off and necessary response, but we must quickly implement structural measures to remedy the decline in European production.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report in view of the importance, in these times of economic crisis, of EU support for workers whose businesses have suffered particularly. The metal products sector in Comunidad Valenciana has been hit hard and it is absolutely necessary to give the population the means to retrain.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. - Spain submitted the EGF/2014/004 ES/Comunidad Valenciana metal application for a financial contribution from the EGF following the 633 redundancies that took place in Spain between April and December 2013 in the framework of 142 companies operating in the manufacture of metal products. I stress that the redundancies of the 142 metal products companies are linked to the global economic and financial crisis. In Spain, production of metal products decreased by 23.3% in 2009 compared to the previous year and by 36.6% between 2008 and 2013, and the number of jobs in the metal products sector decreased by 43%. The processed metal products sector is a major supplier of raw materials for a whole range of manufacturing industries, in particular the shipbuilding, construction and motor vehicles sectors, all of which are significantly affected by the economic crisis in the Union. As the S&D coordinator for industry, research and energy, I stress the need for a Union strategy on European industry. Viable solutions are needed for both the steel industry and the metal products sector in order to maintain competitiveness and jobs across the EU.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. - The redundancies at the 142 companies of the Comunidad Valenciana are linked to far-reaching structural changes in world trade patterns as a result of globalisation. The losses in the metal finished product production sector illustrate the rapid decline in the European market share in steel production and the simultaneous increase in the market share of countries such as China, India and Korea. We must show solidarity here and stress the importance of steel-producing industry for the whole of the European Economic Area. This makes it all the more important to adopt an effective Union strategy for the steel-producing industry in order to maintain competitiveness. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the mobilisation of the Fund by the Comunidad Valenciana in this case.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. - Whereas the proposal for a decision mobilising EGF funds in favour of Spain is aimed at assisting the reintegration of workers in the metallurgical sector, who are suffering as a result of structural changes in world trade; Whereas, not only because of increasing global competition, industrial production in Europe has fallen considerably; Agreeing that the decline in industrial production has had a major impact on the employment of the metallurgical sector in the Valencian community, I voted in favour.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. I regret this perverse system by which the European Union, on the one hand, destroys the economic environment and, on the other hand, pays some subsidies which do not compensate for the difficulties that its policy has generated.  If I do not hesitate to support job creators, I regret that the Union is putting them in a position to have to ask for help in order to survive. When is a rational policy that would protect businesses and workers through controlled borders? Taking a few steps to reduce the effects when you keep making the causes worse makes no sense.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - As rapporteur for the mobilisation of EGF funds for valencia's construction sector last year, I supported my colleague Shulin's report on the allocation of €1,019,184 to Spain. I supported the entire European Union initiative to create a European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. I also welcomed the European Commission's decision to allocate funds to Spain, to enable the retraining of metal factory workers and their reintegration into the labour market.  I consider it extremely important to stimulate the labour market in this way, because due to the financial and economic crisis many people have become operational surpluses. The issue of unemployment is one of the most important issues of today and a major problem faced by the Countries of the European Union, which I am extremely aware of especially because of the number of unemployed persons in my country, the Republic of Croatia.  In order to overcome the crisis and start the economy, we need to work on reducing unemployment and I think this can be achieved through initiatives of this type. I hope that the measures provided by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund will in this case be implemented as soon as possible based on the principle of equality and equity.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. - In this period of global economic and financial crisis, it is right to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, following the request of the Comunidad Valenciana Metal, to help some of the workers in companies operating in the metal products manufacturing sector (companies heavily affected by the crisis) to facilitate them by direct action and a package of personalised services to relocate more effectively to the labour market.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Writing. - I voted against this motion because, once again, funds from the Globalisation Fund are being misused for labour market measures. Here, the nation states would be required to take possible measures on labour market policy where necessary and desired. The EU has no competence in this particular case and, once again, is exceeding its competences.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. - Large variations in the metallurgical sector on the international market combined with the financial crisis have led to massive redundancy measures. I therefore vote in favour of mobilising the European globalisation adjustment fund required by the Valencian Community, in the hope of increasing the retraining of laid-off workers.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. - The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund aims to provide assistance to people who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes. I voted in favour of granting it to the Valencian Community. The metallurgical sector of this autonomous community has been hit hard by the crisis: between 2008 and 2012, it suffered a 43% drop in its jobs (14,995 jobs), 8 percentage points higher than the national average for this type of activity. More than one million euros will be paid to finance training and to promote entrepreneurship and job search for 300 ex-employees in the sector, and I welcome this.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 1 019 184 of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) for 633 workers who have lost their jobs in the metal products manufacturing sector in the Valencian Community, as a result of structural changes in world trade due to globalisation and the impact of the economic and financial crisis.   The personalized services to be financed from the FEAG include training activities, vocational guidance, placement, promotion of entrepreneurship and incentives for the creation of a company. While these aids are insufficient to alleviate the drama of unemployment in the Valencian Community, they can help the reintegration of the workers concerned into work. In any event, it would be desirable to improve the financial endowment of these aid on a forthcoming occasion.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I welcome the vote of this report which will enable the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to be mobilised for the 633 redundancies at Comunidad Valenciana/Metal. These layoffs will only worsen the unemployment situation in a region that is already particularly vulnerable, as the metal products sector accounts for 25.4% of regional industrial employment. The number of jobs in the metallurgical sector rose from 35,868 in 2008 to 20,873 in 2012... this represents a decline of 43%. While European financial aid to laid-off workers should be more dynamic and delivered with all the speed and efficiency possible, there should also be a European strategy on the steel industry. It is vital today.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. - Following 633 redundancies in 142 companies in the metal manufacturing sector (during the reference period from 1 April 2013 to 31 December 2013), Spain submitted an application to the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (FEAG). The metallurgical sector accounts for 1/4 of the Jobs of the Valencian Community and between 2008 and 2012 the level of employment in this sector decreased by around 43 % in the region. I could therefore not agree more with this decision (the tenth application of the EFSA in the 2014 budget year), so I voted in favour of this report, which will allow the mobilisation of EUR 1.019 million geared towards the retraining of 300 workers in training and vocational training activities.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: Writing. - Ladies and gentlemen, the neoliberal policies you insist on pursuing have closed thousands of businesses and created millions of unemployed people in the EU. Today's four cases, in Spain, Belgium and France with over 7000 dismissed, are neither the first nor will they be the last. You cause misery and despair that you try to overlap with crumbs of charity. The $150 million. The European Adjustment Fund for the new programming period is an affront to our intelligence and the dignity of these people. This amount is not sufficient to cover, even to a minimum, the cost of projects to assist redundant persons in order to find a new job or set up their own business. Continued austerity does not lead to growth, but leads to padlocks and the unemployed. It needs to be broken and changed in this policy.  I call for an immediate comprehensive strategy and the availability of sufficient financial instruments from the Community budget to revitalise the European economy. Only in this way can we hope for a decent standard of living for workers and professionals in the EU.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. - This application, the tenth in the 2014 budget, relates to the mobilisation of the EGF for a total amount of EUR 1,019,184 for Spain. The application relates to redundancies and terminations of activity in 142 companies operating in NACE Division 25 Revision 2 (Manufacture of metal products, excluding machinery and equipment) in the NUTS 2 level region of the Valencian Municipality (ES52). I voted in favour of defending the work of the companies concerned and supporting the growth of the region.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour because this is an intervention following the redundancies and the cessation of activity of as many as 142 Spanish companies in the metal sector for a figure of just over one million Euros.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. - The delegation of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilizing this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. This aid is partial, as only 300 workers would benefit, and it seems insufficient as the amount of investment per capita to support their training and labour insertion processes through self-employment would not reach EUR 3400. We consider this EGF to be a simple hot cloth over the bleeding that is charged each month, in terms of mass layoffs, this Europe of Markets and Capitals. It is urgent to formulate policies aimed at the distribution of wage labour and a real disengagement between access to work and the right of access to fundamental public goods and services.

name: Jordi Vicent SEBASTIA TALAVERA
text: in writing. - As a Valencian Member I am voting in favour of this resolution and I express the importance of this aid in order to alleviate the effects of my country's brutal deind industrialisation. However, I would like to make it clear that what we are urging is a re-industrialization plan so that the competitiveness that our companies had before the bursting of the housing bubble recovers and creates the jobs we urgently need.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of resources for 300 of the 633 laid-off workers from 142 companies engaged in the manufacture of metal products in order to implement measures co-financed by the EGF during the period from 1 April 2013 to 31 December 2013. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of workers in this sector in the context of high unemployment in the Spanish State, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of the human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. – I welcome the fact that Parliament today approved EU aid to help 300 Spanish workers made redundant.  The EUR 1 019 184 in EGF aid approved by Parliament will support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant in 142 enterprises operating in the manufacture of fabricated metal products, except machinery and equipment. The UK has never made an application under this fund. UK workers receive none of this support therefore.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. - As Spain is one of the European countries affected by the crisis and has a hard time coping, I welcome this decision in which the EU has put in place legislative and budgetary instruments to provide further support to workers affected by the effects of major structural changes in global trade flows and to help them re-enter the labour market. Layoffs at 142 companies operating in Spain's finished metal products manufacturing sector have been linked to a global financial and economic crisis that has hit all of Europe and caused social caratur problems. Employment in the region has been severely affected by the impact of the crisis on traditional sectors. I support the decision to prevent the redundancies of 633 workers, as any additional redundancies at Communidad Valenciana will exacerbate the already difficult situation that has arisen as a result of the unemployment problem. I welcome any proposal that could allow the economy to start and re-employment, such as the intention to allocate €3,000 to 20 beneficiaries, which could greatly help their return to the labour market by starting their own businesses, as well as a proposal for vocational training, higher qualifications, learning additional skills that can adapt workers to the future needs of the metal industry.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: in writing - I voted against the proposal because it addresses the problems of low competitiveness through redistribution, which further reduces competitiveness. Moreover, EUR 1 019 184 for 300 Spaniards means that taxpayers will pay up to around EUR 34 000 for each of these beneficiaries.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. - I voted against this report today, I am opposed in principle to the use of this European Globalisation Adjustment Fund and as a result I cannot support this proposal to mobilise it.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. - I am voting against this report because instead of ending up with the laid-off staff who are in dire need, they will be allocated to companies or organisations (private or state) that are supposed to re-draw up these staff or help them find work. That is, they will either create skilled unemployed people or prolong their agony.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - I support the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund - EGF/2014/004 ES/Comunidad Valenciana metal from Spain. The report we received from the rapporteur clearly shows that the dismissals of 142 Spanish companies involved in the production of metal products are linked to the global financial crisis.  Between 2008 and 2012, Spain lost more than 600,000 jobs, more than 150,000 of them in the metal products sector. Spain is one of the Member States most affected by the crisis, leading to a drop in demand and thus a decline in the production of metal products. As an important indicator, it should be noted that in 2008 35 868 people worked in the metallur industry in the comunidad valencian area. By 2012, the number of jobs in the industry fell to 20,873, a decline of 43%, which is eight percentage points higher than at the national level.  I believe that mobilising this fund will help reduce the difficulties caused by the redundancies of 633 workers from 142 companies in Comunidad Valenciana. For this reason, I support this report.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. - I voted against the proposal for a decision to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund based on spain's request (EGF/2014/004 ES/Comunidad Valenciana metal) for a financial contribution €1,019,184 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF), following the redundancies of 633 workers in 142 companies operating in the metal finished products manufacturing sector.  I believe that such packages of measures represent only firefighting measures that offer no long-term solution for laid-off workers on the one hand and for the poor economic situation in crisis-affected sectors. In my view, Member States must provide their companies with a healthy business framework that will enable them to be competitive on the global market, which presupposes a tax burden and the removal of bureaucratic barriers holding back investment and business. In the case of Spain's request, I welcome the fact that the proposed package of tailor-made services includes, inter alia, the promotion of entrepreneurship and incentives to set up a business.  Here, however, questions arise about the prosperity of emerging small businesses in a sector that has long faced difficulties. On the other hand, measures to encourage entrepreneurship must be one of the pillars of any economic recovery and employment policy, not just one of the services offered to workers following their dismissal.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. - I welcome any incentive that gives the tools to fight the big malaise that affects so many people in the País Valencià. We are aware that this economic turmoil that is affecting different economic sectors is more acute in the metal industry as some important commercial partners in emerging economies are subsidising them. Adapted training and the recognition of skills and competences gained throughout a worker’s professional career is one of the keys to regain competitiveness in the labour market. I also welcome the fact that the package has been drawn up with the stakeholders.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. - This European fund is essential for ensuring the continuity of industry in peripheral countries and the employability of workers in this sector. That's why I voted for it.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund because it is necessary to support the reintegration of all those workers who have suffered the opening up of economies to international competition. In the most vulnerable sectors, it is essential to address the consequences of the intensification of trade flows by implementing tangible and functional measures, such as outplacement, assistance in active research, contributions for the recruitment of disadvantaged workers and retraining. It is essential to improve the opportunities for all workers to seek employment through appropriate training, through the recognition of skills and competences acquired during their professional career, while always respecting the principles of non-discrimination and equal opportunities. It is therefore necessary to provide timely assistance to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade due to globalisation (such as the closure of a company or the relocation of production to a non-EU country), thus demonstrating concretely the solidarity of the many who benefit from the opening up of markets to those facing the sudden shock of unemployment.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of resources for 300 of the 633 laid-off workers from 142 companies engaged in the manufacture of metal products in order to implement measures co-financed by the EGF during the period from 1 April 2013 to 31 December 2013. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of high unemployment in Spain, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - This report focuses on 633 redundancies in 142 companies in the metal manufacturing sector in Spain. Since the beginning of the financial and economic crisis (August 2007), the response to the crisis, especially on the part of the EU, has been through redundancies, falling wages, settlement of rights, dismantling of the social state, privatisation. Austerity has continued to aggravate not only the social situation but also the economic and financial situation. All austerity plans have in common pass the bill on to taxpayers and workers, fuel the recession and overbook future revenues. Another policy is needed to increase production, increase wages and pensions, strengthen public services, in short, the right of each State to promote socio-economic development, intervening in defence and promoting national productive sectors and employment with rights.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. - The steel industry in Europe is in great trouble due to constant globalisation and strong competitive pressure against countries such as the People's Republic of China. As can be seen from the example of the dismissal of the 142 workers of the Comunidad Valeciana company, only an effective EU strategy for the steel-producing industry can in the long term help to create new opportunities and investments. As the competitiveness of the European steel industry must be maintained, I voted in favour of the motion which provides for the mobilisation of the EGF.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. - The Globalisation Fund was set up to help with short-term emergencies caused by mismanagement, globalisation or the financial and moral crisis in the Member States. Support includes training, business start-up grants, coaching and outplacement of redundant workers. The Globalisation Fund co-finances these job creation measures at 50% or 65%, with the remainder provided by the Member State concerned. This makes the EU Commission a gigantic labour market agency. Nevertheless, the European Court of Auditors said in a special audit report that this "globalisation fund" provides only limited EU added value and should be replaced by a more efficient regime. It was explicitly stated that this Globalisation Fund is not the best way to provide much-needed specific support. And yet the EU is continuing the policy, which has been shown to be inefficient. I cannot agree with that.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. - In this plenary session alone we are called upon to decide on the allocation of eGF financial assistance, following 8204 redundancies by 155 companies based in Spain (1), Belgium (2) and France (1). This report focuses on the application of Comunidad Valenciana Metal, following 633 redundancies in 142 companies in the metal products manufacturing sector in Spain. The justification for further redundancies is the global economic crisis, with Spain being one of the most severely affected Member States, which has resulted in lower demand for metal and metal products and lower production thereof. Seven years since the start of the financial and economic crisis (August 2007), the EU's response to the crisis has been through redundancies, falling wages, settlement of rights, dismantling of the Social State, privatisation. The absolutisation of deficit reduction by reducing wages, pensions and social benefits has continued to aggravate not only the social situation, but also the economic and financial situation. This is not the solution. Another policy is needed to increase production, increase wages and pensions, strengthen public services, in the meantime, the right of each State to promote socio-economic development.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. I welcome the granting of a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which the Belgian authorities had requested from the EU in the wake of the redundancies at the assembly plant and suppliers of Ford Genk.  This fund was set up to provide additional support to workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns. The Fund finances individually adapted measures for the reintegration of jobseekers, promotes self-employment and business start-ups, and grants mobility allowances and allowances for disadvantaged or older workers. The redundancies that have taken place so far and are expected to continue to be expected will have a serious impact not only on the labour market in the province of Limburg but also on the entire region of Flanders.  It is therefore gratifying that the EU has accepted Belgium's request and is providing funds to support the redundant workers, in the hope of helping them to achieve lasting, long-term and therefore stable employment through the measures taken.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. - The principle of subsidiarity dictates that decisions should be taken at the closest possible level to the citizen - in this case, at regional or national level. Therefore these projects should not be funded by the European Union.  It is absurd that the arbiters of whether this funding should or should not be given are members of the European Parliament with no detailed knowledge of the situation. This project may well be of benefit to the people in Genk, but I am not best placed to judge. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be scrapped, which would give money back to the Member States to decide for themselves about the appropriateness of such funding.  Consequently, I had no option but to vote against – even though this may be a worthwhile project.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. - Ford Genk has been hit hard by industrial rationalisation measures caused by the 2008 banking and liberal crisis. Its workers have been hit hard by the waves of layoffs due to the overproduction of the automotive industry in relation to demand and it is therefore quite logical that the EGF should be mobilised to help them with socio-professional reintegration.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. - As part of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, Belgium has submitted the EGF/2013/012 application following the dismissal of 512 people, 479 of whom are covered by the measures relating to the Ford-Werke site in Genk and 10 suppliers of Ford Genk.  As Ford is the largest employer in the province of Limburg, these layoffs will have serious consequences on the local economic fabric. In addition, the closure of the Ford site is likely to lead to two further waves of layoffs (650 and 4,000 jobs lost according to the Belgian authorities).  In the face of savage globalisation and unfair competition from low-cost countries, the European automotive industry is facing serious difficulties. Moreover, in addition to the reduction in the EU's market share in car production, the number of new cars sold in the Union is also falling, as our manufacturers are doubly penalised. This sad observation is only the result of successive European policies, but the mobilization of EUR 570,945 under the EGF will help laid-off workers to train and reintegrate into the labour market, which is why I voted in favour of the demand.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the report authorising the mobilisation of the EGF, the Ruropeo Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in favour of 512 Belgian workers and 10 companies operating in the automotive sector. If it wants a future, this Europe must go beyond the good and superficial propaganda with which it has dealt to date with the problems of its citizens. That is why I hope that the EGF, which is intended as a very important instrument of support for citizens who have lost their jobs, will soon be accompanied by new resources to finance the revival of competitiveness and growth.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. - (C) Has voted in favour of this report today. I therefore do so to provide workers in the cases in question with financial support for retraining and/or other measures to find new jobs.  However, I would like to stress that the high level of unemployment in europe could be effectively combated if the austerity policies of the European Commission and the governments of the Member States have long been pursued could be stopped.   Creating new jobs in Europe requires a new economic policy with massive public and environmentally friendly investments. Public investment is needed in schools, health and social care, but also in infrastructure, rail, public transport, energy-efficient housing and sustainable energy systems.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 570 945 of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 512 workers who have lost their jobs at the Ford-Werke GmbH assembly plant in Genk, as a result of structural changes in world trade resulting from globalisation and the impact of the economic and financial crisis. The customized services to be financed from the FEAG include training, vocational guidance and recycling activities. These aids constitute good assistance and training for the reintegration of the workers concerned.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report because it supported the granting of support from the European Globalisation Fund in the Belgian city of Genk. Parliament has found that the application fulfils the criteria for granting financial assistance laid down in the EGF Regulation, although the conditions for the minimum number of redundancies during the reporting period are fulfilled only partially because less than 500 redundancies have been made. The EGF Regulation provides that an application for financial assistance from the EGF can be considered admissible where redundancies have a significant impact on employment levels and the local economy. Two more redundancies are expected in the Frandria region of Belgium in 2014, with more than 11,000 jobs expected to be lost. Parliament therefore decided that, if concrete measures to assist the first group of redundant workers were implemented as soon as possible, their chances of finding new jobs would increase and equal opportunities would be guaranteed to all redundant workers.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of mobilising the Globalisation Adjustment Fund. You have to defend the 512 redundancies of the Ford Genk. I am on the side of work and workers and not on the side of finance.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. It is clear that car production in Europe has fallen significantly. For example, under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF), Belgium introduced the EGF/2013/012 application after the dismissal of 479 people. Thus the layoffs of Ford-Genk and ten suppliers symbolize the decline of the European Union's market share in car production burdened by the unfair production costs of competition and before which the European institutions remain hopelessly powerless. Concern is mounting in the industrial world, where European workers are increasingly affected by savage globalisation and are struggling to find jobs. Thus, the mobilization of 570,945 euros under the EGF will help those made redundant to integrate into appropriate training courses, which will facilitate their reintegration into the labour market. So I voted to do that.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. - The European Parliament has decided to approve the request to mobilise the globalisation adjustment fund in favour of Belgium in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant at the Ford Genk assembly site and at ten Ford Genk suppliers in Belgium. I voted in favour of this mobilization, which shows the Union's solidarity in the face of certain negative consequences of globalisation on employment.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - (IT) Today I voted in favour of this report in order to provide support to 512 laid-off workers working at Ford's assembly plant based in Genk. The difficult economic situation of the automotive sector in the EU is mainly due to a substantial decline in sales of new cars in the EU due to the economic crisis and structural problems due to overcapacity faced by some manufacturers in several Member States, which has negatively affected the international competitiveness of the EU car industry as a whole. These factors have led various car manufacturers and their suppliers to close factories and carry out renovations which have led to a large number of job losses in the automotive manufacturing sector in recent years.  The aim is to facilitate the rapid reintegration into working life of these redundant workers through tailor-made accompanying measures, such as assistance in job search, vocational guidance, training and retraining, promotion of self-employment and entrepreneurship.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. - The mobilizations of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund are necessary protective measures against those who have no hope of being able to continue working in industrial and commercial sectors affected by the radical change in the structure of world trade, the automotive industry is a clear example of this.  The economic scenario is changing faster and faster and creating real social tragedies in many sectors of civil, industrial and commercial life: many workers are denied guarantees that should not be affected over time, but are objectively rendered null and void by a situation of global crisis and abrupt change in the exchange dynamics of many goods throughout the globe.  We do not want those who have worked hard to be suddenly left without protection.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the application, the eleventh within the framework of the 2014 budget for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) for a total amount of EUR 570 945 for Belgium.  The EGF was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. Belgium's application relates to redundancies at the Ford-Werke GmbH assembly plant, based in Genk, and at ten Suppliers of Ford Genk, for a total of 512 redundancies in eleven companies operating in the car manufacturing sector.  The Belgian authorities stated that the redundancies were due to major structural changes in world trade flows due to globalisation, which caused a significant loss of EU market share on world markets.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was established in 2006 to provide additional assistance to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of international trade and to help them reintegrate into the labour market.  From 1 May 2009, the scope of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been extended to include support for workers made redundant as a direct result of the economic, financial and social crisis.  At a time when Europe is in the face of a financial, economic and social crisis, with unemployment being one of the main consequences, the European Union should use all means at its service to react, in particular, to the support to be provided to people who have been left without a job.  I therefore supported this report on the mobilisation of EUR 570 945 in favour of Belgium with the aim of supporting the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant in the assembly plant of Ford-Werke GmbH (Ford Genk) and ten of its suppliers, resulting from major structural changes in world trade standards due to globalisation.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - (IT) I support the report on the mobilisation of the EGF in relation to Belgium's request to make a financial contribution to Ford Genk as the company's car production sector has suffered serious economic disruption, in particular a sharp decline in the EU's market share. In particular, due to the difficult economic situation of the car manufacturing sector in the EU, with sales of new cars falling significantly, some car manufacturers and their suppliers have been forced to close factories and carry out restructurings that have led to a large number of job losses in the automotive production sector in recent years. I hope that today's vote will allow employees to be reintegrated into the labour market and will help the entrepreneurs affected by the crisis.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. - The redundancies in the assembly plant of Ford-Werke GmbH and in 10 suppliers of Ford Genk in Belgium are linked to major structural changes in world trade patterns and a  consistent decline in sales of new cars in the European Union. 479 redundant workers are expected to participate in the EGF co-funded measures (including job-search assistance and training) aiming for the reintegration of redundant workers in the labour market. I have therefore voted in favour of this report since the measure not only addresses loss of jobs but also reintegration into the labour market.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. - (IT) Today I voted in favour of the request for mobilisation of the EGF with regard to Belgium, which applied for financial assistance following 512 redundancies at the Ford-Werke GmbH assembly plant, based in Genk and at 10 Suppliers of Ford Genk in Belgium. The redundancies are linked to major changes in the structure of world trade due to globalisation, a rapid decline in the EU's market share in global car production and a substantial decline in sales of new cars in the Union. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF), which provides support to those who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade due to globalisation, is becoming essential, given that more and more European companies are being forced to close down.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of resources for redundancies 479 of the 512 dismissed at the Ford-Werke GmbH assembly plant in the town of Genk and ten ford Genk suppliers in Belgium during the reference period from 1 July 2013 to 1 November 2013. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of high unemployment in Belgium, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of the human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. - I note that this application by Belgium relates to 512 redundancies in the assembly plant of Ford-Werke GmbH located in Genk and in 10 suppliers of Ford Genk in Belgium, operating in the car manufacturing sector, between 1 July 2013 to 1 November 2013. The redundancies were caused by major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation and a rapid decline of the EU’s market share in the production of passenger cars. The Commission has concluded that the application meets the conditions for deploying the EGAF. The EGAF funding of EUR 570 945 will provide assistance for the reintegration of 479 redundant workers into employment. Hence, I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. - With the mobilization of the EGF, sacked employees of the Belgian automotive industry will be able to benefit in particular from job search assistance and personalised support. These measures are particularly useful in accelerating their reintegration into the labour market.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. - Created in 2006, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) aims to help reintegrate workers who have lost their jobs as a result of changes in world trade. In 2009, its scope was expanded to include victims of the financial crisis. This application, submitted by Belgium, is for redundancies in the automotive sector; redundancies at Ford Genk's assembly site, and at 10 of its suppliers in Belgium. The aim is to help 479 sacked employees. The assistance will amount to approximately EUR 570,945 and will help to co-finance active labour market measures focusing on job search assistance, training and retraining. I regret, however, that 33 sacked employees have been left behind and have not also been able to benefit from this aid for purely democratic reasons. This request has received my support and the support of the European Parliament.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. - The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. Belgium has requested assistance from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, as 512 redundancies at Ford-Werke GmbH's assembly plant in Genk and ford genk's 10 suppliers in Belgium during the reference period 1 July to 1 November 2013, of which 479 workers are expected to participate, have caused significant local labour market tensions. The request from the EGF is for a total of EUR 570 945 for Belgium. The Commission found that the application complies with the requirements for the use of the EGF laid down in Regulation (EC) No 1927/2006 and that the measures taken by the Belgian authorities constitute a coordinated personalised package of services and active labour market measures aimed at reintegration of workers into the labour market and will help some 479 redundant workers to re-enter the labour market. I supported the report in the plenary vote.

name: Pablo ECHENIQUE
text: in writing. - The delegation of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilizing this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider this Globalisation Adjustment Fund to be a simple hot cloth on the haemorrhage that is charged each month, in terms of mass layoffs, this Europe of Markets and Capitals. The processes of industrial conversion, labour flexibility and production technology characteristic of the Third Industrial Revolution make it increasingly difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. - The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. I voted in favour of this report because it is a means by which the EU can give valuable help to local economies hard hit by company closures. I regret that the government has not taken advantage of this fund in Wales.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - The EGF was created to provide additional support to redundant workers following major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation or financial crisis and helping them find new jobs. Between 2014 and 2020, the fund's annual ceiling is EUR 150 million. Redundant workers are offered measures such as support for business creation, job search assistance, vocational guidance and various types of training. Belgium applied for the EGF following the dismissal of 512 redundancies at Ford east-Belgium in Genk and ten supplier companies in Belgium during the reference period from 1 July 2013 to 1 November 2013. Redundancies at the Ford-Werke GmbH assembly plant and ten Ford Genk suppliers are related to major structural changes in world trade standards due to globalisation, an accelerated decline in EU market share in the global passenger car production sector and a progressive decline in new car sales in the Union. In this mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Genk in Belgium, EUR 911,934 was granted. I voted in favour.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - Belgium submitted the application under consideration, following redundancies at FORD/Genk and ten other supplier companies, totaling 512 workers made redundant. The rapporteur attests that the conditions laid down in the EGF Regulation are met and took into account two other redundancies, which are expected to occur this year - 4 340 at FORD Genk and 2 280 in its suppliers located in the same geographical area, Flanders. The automotive industry has been the subject of 17 eGF mobilisation decisions since the start of the EGF in 2007. A consequence of the crisis of capitalism. Interestingly, it was Mr. Ford that, in the mid-twentieth century, a trade unionist recalled that machines do not buy cars, a maxim that would become famous. Capitalist globalisation, to which this Fund aims to promote adjustment, is synonymous with increasing asymmetric integration and interdependence, strong capital liberalisation – especially of the financial – and trade at the global level, which in turn is synonymous with inequalities, unemployment, increased poverty and intensification of labour exploitation. The EU's response to the crisis was in line with the Budgetary Treaty and Economic Governance. More of the same, therefore: seeds of new and greater crises.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the intervention for 512 redundancies at Ford in Genk (Belgium) and for 10 of its suppliers for € 570 945.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. - I am voting against the report with the proposal for a decision, because these measures are insufficient to tackle unemployment. Also the money, for the most part, does not end up with the made-up workers in need, but in various consulting and career guidance companies. In the end, these measures are a mockery of those who are made redundant by the austerity policy imposed by the European Union itself.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. - I voted against this application for mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. I support measures that create growth and jobs, but the Globalisation Adjustment Fund is simply a waste of taxpayers’ money. There is no evidence that it offers value for money in terms of reintegrating redundant workers back into the labour market.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. - The delegation of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilizing this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider this Globalisation Adjustment Fund to be a simple patch that is charged every month, in terms of mass layoffs, in this Europe where the interests of large companies are above the interests of citizens. The processes of industrial conversion, labour flexibility and production technology characteristic of the Third Industrial Revolution make it increasingly difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. - I support the need to have a European instrument to assist redundant workers. I am glad that Parliament fully supported the setting up of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) as part of the Multiannual Financial Framework for 2014 to 2020. I supported the Ford Genk application for the mobilisation of EUR 570 945 following the redundancies of 512 workers from the Ford plant in Genk as well as ten Belgian suppliers to the plant. Over the last number of years we have seen a large number of EGF applications on behalf of those working in the automotive industry. Given that another 7 160 redundancies approximately are due to impact the region this year, and the inevitable knock-on effects of this on the local and regional economies, the use of the EGF in the region will be essential for these workers to retrain and build upon their existing skills in order to re-enter the labour market.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: Written. I do not think that people should be the victims of failing European socio-economic policies. That is why I voted in favour of the mobilisation of funds from the European Fund for Adaptation to Globalisation, but I think this is a wipe for the bleeding. In fact, I believe that companies, and the Member States themselves, should come up with appropriate aid measures themselves, because now we are actually just pumping money from the Member States around. Large multinationals such as Ford and PSA (Peugeot-Citroën) put their employees on the streets after years of loyal service, because they are moving their production to places where they can find cheaper labour. I strongly reject these degrading practices, and with the resources from the European Fund, we are at least ensuring that the workers who have been sent away are not left out in the cold.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - The delegation of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilizing this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider this Globalisation Adjustment Fund to be a mere patch, in terms of mass layoffs, in this Europe where the interests of large companies are above the interests of citizens. The processes of industrial conversion, labour flexibility and production technology characteristic of the Third Industrial Revolution make it increasingly difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. - I voted for this motion for a resolution because it supports the labour market of the province in Flanders, where Ford Genk is the largest employer, which will have significant consequences on the unemployment rate following the additional two waves of redundancies foreseen.  It is of utmost importance to provide effective and concrete assistance from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, as as many as 98.1% of redundante workers are aged between 25 and 54, and as the EU's market share in passenger car production is declining.  It is also significant that the local economy is protected and growth is encouraged in the best possible way. I also support the fact that the Flemish Government, in the case of Ford Genk, has taken targeted measures to address this issue, such as the establishment of a specific working group and the consultation and participation of social partners in the established committee to monitor applications submitted to the EGF.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. - It is important to support employees who lose their jobs suddenly due to a global financial and economic crisis. We need to help them get back on their way to employment. This assistance of 570,945 euros will support the 479 Ford Genk employees who were made redundant in Belgium in their return to work.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. - I supported the resolution on belgium's request to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for redundancies at the assembly site, as well as from Ford-Genk suppliers. The Fund was created to promote the reintegration into the labour market of workers who are victims of changes in the structure of international trade resulting from globalization, or the financial crisis. I am the the fore, the most pleased, for the adoption of this financial aid, amounting to more than EUR 570,000.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of mobilisation of the Fund, as I support giving assistance for the reintegration into employment of 479 redundant workers who lost their jobs due to globalisation and a rapid decline of the EUʼs market share in the production of passenger cars.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) I support Mr Rübig's report. It provides for the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant at the Ford-Werke GmbH assembly plant, based in Genk ("Ford Genk"), and 10 suppliers of Ford Genk in Belgium. With today's vote, we are trying to guarantee a system of reintegration into the labour market for employees affected by the economic crisis, highlighting, once again, the role that Europe has and must continue to play in this time of crisis: the engine for supporting growth and development.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of resources for redundancies 479 of the 512 dismissed at the Ford-Werke GmbH assembly plant in the town of Genk and ten ford Genk suppliers in Belgium during the reference period from 1 July 2013 to 1 November 2013. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of high unemployment in Belgium, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of the human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. - This fund has been established by the EU to provide additional assistance to workers who have suffered the consequences of major structural changes in global trade patterns or the continuation of the global financial and economic crisis. Belgium submitted a request for the mobilization of this fund to support the reintegration of workers laid off due to structural changes in global trade patterns as a result of globalization at the Ford-Werke GmbH assembly plant and other globalisation companies.  The proposal adopted by the Commission consists of a total of EUR 570 945 for aid for labour insertion for the benefit of a total of 479 workers. For these reasons I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. - Due to the unfavourable situation of the automotive sector in the European Union and the constant decline in passenger car sales affected by the economic crisis and the decline in production as a result of structural changes in global trade flows, I supported the Report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to assist Belgium in the dismissal of workers at the Ford-Werke GmbH plant located in Genk ('Ford Genk') and the redundancies of workers at 10 suppliers.  The European Globalisation Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the effects of structural changes due to globalisation. This Report aims to mobilise €580,000 to help redundant workers, allowing workers to be reintegrated more quickly through assistance in seeking new employment and training and retraining.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. - I voted in favour, because that was also the position of our Socialist Group.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. - I support this proposal. The Belgian authorities argue that the closure of the Ford plant in Genk will, apart from this first wave of redundancies, cause two other waves of redundancies expected to occur in 2014 of 650 and 4 000 dismissals. These redundancies will have a serious impact on employment and the local economy  The coordinated package of personalised services to be co-funded includes the following measures for the reintegration of 479 redundant workers into employment (grouped by category): (1) job-search assistance (key account manager, social intervention advisor, information on vocational education and training options, active job-oriented guidance), and (2) training and re-training (vocational training courses, employment through individual vocational training, application training)

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. - (IT) I supported the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, relating to the demand made by Belgium, for the protection of redundant personnel, following the closure of one of the Ford chain plants in the country. We must ensure that the Fund supports the stable reintegration into the labour market of redundant workers.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the Rübig report, which supports the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in favour of 512 Belgian workers made redundant from eleven companies operating in the car manufacturing sector, because I believe that the handing out of almost EUR 600 000 to finance measures to reintegrate them into the world of work will contribute to the creation of new jobs. , albeit marginally, to alleviate the penalties that the economic crisis is inflicting on European workers.  As the report states, the reasons for the dismissal of such a large number of employees by the Ford company in Genk would lie not only in the structural changes in world trade due to globalisation, but also in a clear narrowing of the European Union's market share in car production on a global scale.  While it is true that the main objective of the EGF is precisely to offer support to European workers who have lost their jobs as a result of significant changes in the market, then I believe that the planned intervention in favour of the workers of the Belgian car plant is absolutely necessary, as well as necessary.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. - The redundancies at the Ford-Werke GmbH assembly plant and at ten of its suppliers are leading to far-reaching and, above all, serious structural changes in world trade patterns and a rapid decline in the EU market share in the car production sector. In a local labour market, which is already characterised by high unemployment, low levels of skills and skills and less developed education, the waves of redundancies that have already taken place and the future waves of redundancies have serious consequences. Specific measures must therefore be taken as soon as possible in favour of workers who have already been made redundant, in order to ensure rapid reintegration into the labour market. It should be stressed that training measures should take into account and build on the specific knowledge and skills acquired by the workers concerned in the automotive and subcontracting industries. The first priority should therefore be the ability of all workers to provide adequate training. I therefore voted in favour of mobilising the EGF in this case.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The fund for aid to globalization is well within its destructive role. Instead of helping workers, it encourages shareholders and states to submit to forced liberalism.  The request relates to 512 redundancies at Ford-Werke GmbH's Assembly site in Genk and ten Ford Genk suppliers in Belgium. According to the Belgian authorities, the difficult economic situation of the car manufacturing sector in the European Union is mainly due to a steady decline in the sale of new cars in the EU as a result of the economic crisis and structural problems of overcapacity encountered by some manufacturers in several Member States. These factors have led to plant closures and restructurings at several automakers and their suppliers, resulting in a large number of job losses in the automotive sector in recent years. Indeed, the global automotive sector has already undergone several years of strong capital restructuring, thousands of employees have already suffered the consequences of plans to cut jobs and reduce activity, while the groups were making considerable profits. For fiscal 2013, Ford reported net income of $7.15 billion, up 26%.  I am voting against this request for a redundancy bonus for shareholders.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. - The EU is an area of solidarity and is part of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This support is essential to help the unemployed and the victims of relocations in a globalised context. More and more companies are relocating, taking advantage of the low labour prices that are practised in several countries, notably China and India, with harmful effects on countries that respect workers' rights. The EGF is intended to help workers who are victims of business relocation and is key to facilitating access to new employment. The EGF has already been used in the past by other EU countries, and it is now up to Belgium to give this aid to the EGF/2013/012 BE/Ford Genk application for a financial contribution from the EGF, following 512 redundancies, with 479 persons expected to take part in the measures, at the assembly plant of Ford - Werke GmbH (4), located in Genk ('Ford Genk') and ten supplier companies in Belgium during the reference period from 1 July 2013 to 1 November 2013.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. - The European Union has set up legislative and budgetary instruments in order to provide additional support to workers who have been affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation and to assist the reintegration of the same workers back into the labour market. The report notes that closure of Ford Genk in Belgium will cause two more waves of redundancies expected to occur in 2014 of 650 and 4 000 dismissals. The Ford Genk application aims to support Belgium in reintegrating workers who have been made redundant in the assembly plant of Ford-Werke GmbH located in Genk and in 10 suppliers of Ford Genk in Belgium as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation, back into the labour market. Therefore, I have voted in favour of this report.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. It is no secret that the automotive industry is going through difficult years in Europe. The closure of Ford Genk will have serious consequences not only for Flanders, but also for the whole of Belgium. More than 11,000 jobs will be lost in the next two years and the province of Limburg will lose its largest employer. European aid will be decisive for our workers. In the case of Ford Genk, EUR 57.0945 will be mobilised to help workers find work or to enable them to undergo training in order to re-enter the labour market.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. - I am in favour of the Report on the Mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in Genk, Belgium. The Report will give the green light for the mobilisation of the European Globalization Adjustment Fund (EGAF) in Belgium in relation to the redundancies of 512 workers in the assembly plant of Ford-Werke GmbH located in Genk. The EGAF funding will providing assistance for the reintegration of 479 redundant workers into employment.

name: Giulia MOI
text: in writing. - In 2013, Belgium submitted an application for mobilisation of the EGF amounting to EUR 570 945 in relation to the 512 redundancies in eleven companies operating in the car manufacturing sector at the assembly plant of Ford-Werke GmbH, based in Genk. As financial support goes to 479 redundant workers and aims to facilitate their reintegration into the labour market, I voted in favour.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The steady fall in new vehicle sales in the EU has led the entire automotive sector in Europe to a sustainable economic slump. Automakers have responded to this crisis by intensifying the establishment of new factories in countries with low-cost labour, resulting in the closure of many production sites in Western Europe and plans for mass layoffs. It is in this particularly tense context that Belgium has requested the Globalization Adjustment Fund (EMF) to the tune of 570,945 euros to help retrain and train 479 people who have been laid off at Ford-Werke GmbH's Genk assembly site. These layoffs have a serious impact on employment in the province of Limburg, which is already affected by high unemployment and low levels of qualifications. In addition, two new waves of layoffs are coming due to the planned closure of the Ford Genk site. Added to this is the impact of this closure on direct suppliers (for every 100 jobs lost at Ford Genk, 65 will disappear from direct and indirect suppliers in Limburg). I voted to grant that fund.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. - I voted in favour of this text, which will mobilise 570,945 euros for 512 former Ford employees and former employees of 10 of its suppliers. This assistance is intended for the retraining of those made redundant. Europe has experienced an overall decline in car production since the beginning of the crisis. As proof, the WEF has been mobilized 17 times since 2007 to intervene in the automotive sector.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report in view of the importance, in these times of economic crisis, of EU support for workers whose businesses have suffered particularly. The automotive sector has been hit hard and continues to restructure widely around the world. The reintegration of employees in this sector is absolutely necessary but difficult given the specialization. The EU had to give the people the means to retrain.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. - I have voted for this EGF project because as a shadow rapporteur from the S&D Group I have contributed to the elaboration of the report and I support the need for an EGF contribution. I believe that the European Globalization Adjustment Fund is an excellent instrument capable in offering the support needed by the redundant persons but also in directly creating new jobs.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. - I voted for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for the egf/2013/012 BE/Ford Genk - Belgium application. Belgium requested a financial contribution from the EGF following the dismissal of 512 workers, 479 of whom were targeted for participation in the measures in question, from the Ford-Werke assembly plant in Genk and from 10 Ford Genk suppliers between July and November 2013. The redundancies relate to major changes in the structure of world trade, as well as the rapid reduction of the EU's share on the world passenger vehicle production market and the steady decline in sales of new cars in the Union. Since there have been fewer than 500 redundancies during the reference period, the requirements laid down in the Regulation are partially met in terms of the minimum number of redundancies. The Commission declared the EGF's request for contribution admissible as redundancies have a strong impact on employment and the local economy. In the present case, two other waves of redundancies expected in 2014 (approximately 4,340 redundancies at Ford Genk and 2,820 redundancies at suppliers located in the same geographical area) are taken into account. They will have a strong impact on the entire Flemish Region, with 11,000 jobs expected to be lost.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. - The redundancies at the Ford-Werke GmbH assembly plant and its suppliers lead to far-reaching and, above all, serious structural changes in world trade patterns and a rapid decline in the market share of European manufacturers in the global market. In a local labour market, which is already suffering from the structural weakness of the area, the waves of redundancies that have already taken place and the waves of redundancies that are still to be feared have serious consequences. Specific measures must therefore be taken as soon as possible in favour of workers who have already been made redundant, in order to ensure rapid reintegration into the labour market. It should be stressed that training measures should take into account and build on the specific knowledge and skills acquired by the workers concerned in the automotive and subcontracting industries. The first priority should therefore be the ability of all workers to provide adequate training. I therefore voted in favour of mobilising this fund in this case.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. - Whereas the proposal for a decision mobilising EGF funds in favour of Belgium is aimed at supporting the reintegration of redundant workers in the Ford-Werke GmbH industrial district, which is in difficulty as a result of structural changes in world trade;  Whereas the automotive sector in the European Union has fallen considerably as a result of the economic crisis and growing global competition; By agreeing that the increase in the number of redundant workers could have serious repercussions on the unemployment rate and the local economy, I voted in favour.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. I regret this perverse system by which the European Union, on the one hand, destroys the economic environment and, on the other hand, pays some subsidies that do not compensate for the difficulties that its policy has generated.
