While I do not hesitate to support job creators, I regret that the Union is putting them in a position to have to ask for help in order to survive. When is a rational policy that would protect businesses and workers through controlled borders? Taking a few steps to reduce the effects when you keep making the causes worse makes no sense.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - I supported rapporteur Paul Rübig's report. In today's world of clean market economies and globalisation, many companies, including their workers, are affected by structural reforms aimed at eliminating unprofitableness and poor resource allocation.  I support the Proposal of the European Commission and the Council to issue financial assistance to laid-off workers of the Ford Genk factory of €570,945. The process of assisting people who have been dismissed in the form of counselling and job search is very useful, as are the proposed retraining measures. The data showing the level of seriousness is the fact that 100 redundancy workers of the Ford Genk factory are associated with the redundancies of another 137 workers of related companies.  I welcome the belgian authorities' initiative to implement the services carried out even before a final decision on support is taken. In the face of the difficult economic situation in the field of manufacturing and placing new cars, we need to shift our focus to mitigating the crisis.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. - (IT) At this time of global economic and financial crisis, it is right to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help workers made redundant by companies operating in productive sectors suffering from the downturn. In this case, they are workers at the Ford Genk assembly plant in Belgium and 10 suppliers from ford genk(Belgium) who will benefit from the measures cofinanced by the EGF for reintegration into the labour market.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Writing. - I voted against this motion because, once again, funds from the Globalisation Fund are being misused for labour market measures. Regardless of globalisation, Europe has overcapacity in the field of automobile production. In this particular case, it would be up to the Belgian Government to take concrete labour market measures. The EU is not responsible for this and, once again, is exceeding its competences.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. - The European Union's efforts in the face of mass redundancies must not be faded and must provide quick and concrete solutions. Thus, I am voting in favour of mobilizing the globalization adjustment fund required by Genk, because of the layoffs in Ford, then one of the largest employers in the province.  However, I believe that, in view of the growing difficulties in the automotive sector, it is becoming urgent to opt for a European industrial policy that creates stable jobs. To do this, Europe must rely on automotive products for which it has an undeniable technological advance.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 570 945 of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 512 workers who have lost their jobs at the Ford-Werke GmbH assembly plant in Genk, as a result of structural changes in world trade resulting from globalisation and the impact of the economic and financial crisis. The customized services to be financed from the FEAG include training, vocational guidance and recycling activities. These aids constitute good assistance and training for the reintegration of the workers concerned.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) for Ford Genk workers. The use of this envelope will provide individual assistance to these workers and help them return to work. If the importance of this fund for the support of workers is no longer to be demonstrated, I remain critical on two points. First of all, the fact that the WEF can only intervene when more than 500 workers have been laid off by a single company (including downstream suppliers and producers) seems to me to be too reductive. Many workers have seen their smaller businesses close and have not been able to benefit from this fund. I therefore hope that the 500-worker threshold will be lowered. In addition, effective fundraising takes far too long when it is at the time they lose their jobs that workers need support. I therefore call for an expedited decision-making process to mobilize the WEF.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. - Structural changes in world trade patterns resulting from globalisation are now an unavoidable reality. As such, the European Commission has established a legislative instrument capable of providing additional support to workers affected by the consequences of the economic crisis and globalisation. In view of the consideration that Belgium has submitted an application for assistance in respect of 512 redundancies in Genk and that Union financial assistance to redundant workers should be characterised by financial support as a direct result of the economic and social crisis, and should also be provided as quickly and efficiently as possible in order to assist in the reintegration into the labour market , I voted in favour of this report which I hope will minimise the effects of unemployment in the Genk region.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. - This application, the eleventh in the 2014 budget, relates to the mobilisation of the EGF totalling EUR 570 945 for Belgium. The application relates to redundancies at the assembly plant at Ford-Werke GmbH, based in Genk ("Ford Genk") and at 10 suppliers of Ford Genk in Belgium. I voted in favour of defending the work of the companies concerned and supporting the growth of the region.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour because it is an economic intervention, for a figure of around six hundred thousand euros, following 512 redundancies at Ford in Genk and the cessation of the activity of ten of its suppliers

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. - The delegation of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilizing this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider this Globalisation Adjustment Fund to be a simple hot cloth on the haemorrhage that is charged each month, in terms of mass layoffs, this Europe of Markets and Capitals. The processes of industrial conversion, labour flexibility and production technology characteristic of the Third Industrial Revolution make it increasingly difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of resources for redundancies 479 of the 512 dismissed at the Ford-Werke GmbH assembly plant in the town of Genk and ten ford Genk suppliers in Belgium during the reference period from 1 July 2013 to 1 November 2013. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve workers' problems in the context of high unemployment in Belgium, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. - Thanks to today’s vote Belgium was granted EGF aid to support the reintegration in the labour market of workers made redundant in the assembly plant of Ford-Werke GmbH located in Genk (‘Ford Genk’) and in 10 suppliers of Ford Genk in Belgium due to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation. The €570 945 in aid will pay for job search assistance and training and re-training to help 479 workers get back into employment.  The UK has never made an application under this fund. UK workers therefore receive none of this support.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. - I support the decision to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in accordance with point 13. Interinstitutional agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, cooperation on budgetary matters and good financial management. In the conditions of high unemployment and low economic growth faced by the European Union, I particularly welcome the efforts of the Belgian authorities to initiate the implementation of services tailored to the needs of affected workers on 1 July 2014, long before the final decision on the approval of EGF funds for the proposed harmonised package. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide additional support to workers laid off as a result of major structural changes in the passenger car manufacturing sector that have affected the labour market. I also support co-financing of service packages tailored to the needs of reintegrated 479 redundant workers into the labour market, including retraining, employment through individual vocational education, vocational training course. I think it is important that the specific skills and abilities acquired by redundant workers working in the automotive industry or working for its suppliers are recognised and upgraded when implementing training and retraining measures. Institutions should also make greater efforts to improve procedural measures to accelerate the mobilisation of European Globalisation Adjustment Fund funds.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: in writing - I did not support the proposal, as it amplifies precisely the problems it is trying to solve. Subsidies for workers made redundant as a result of the loss of competitiveness of firms are paid out of taxes by other firms and workers and therefore logically reduce their competitiveness. The only real aid for firms losing competitiveness is thus reducing taxes and reducing regulatory burdens, so that they can compete much more effectively with firms outside the European Union.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. - I voted against this report today, as I am opposed in principle to the use of this European Globalisation Adjustment Fund and, as a result, I cannot support this proposal to mobilise it.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. - I am voting against this report because instead of ending up with the laid-off staff who are in dire need, they will be allocated to companies or organisations (private or state) that are supposed to re-draw up these staff or help them find work. That is, they will either create skilled unemployed people or prolong their agony.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - The change in globalisation trade routes and the decline in new car sales within the European Union have led to the loss of 512 jobs, with two more redundancies expected due to the closure of Ford's factory in Genk. This will have a bad effect on the local labour market in the Flemish region, which already has a high unemployment rate and low education and working qualifications.  For every 100 jobs lost within Ford Genk, an additional 65 jobs are lost to linsburg suppliers, and another 72 to suppliers in the rest of the Flemish region. In order to avoid many of the problems that have arisen in the layoffs so far due to the closure of Ford's factory in Genk (strikes, social discontent and more), I consider it extremely useful to use the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, as this will alleviate many of the social problems caused by the redundancies.  This will give workers time to adapt to the new situation and allow them to transition more seamlessly into the labour market. For the above reasons, I support the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund – EGF/2013/012 BE/Ford Genk from Belgium.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. - This lunchtime, the PS delegation of the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilising more than 1.4 million euros to support the workers of Ford Genk and the Carsid metallurgical plant in Charleroi. The aim of this assistance is to reorient professionally and train the 1231 workers who are victims of restructuring and redundancies in their companies. This Fund is a symbol of a Europe that can be more united. The EGF makes EUR 150 million available each year to support workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in international trade as a result of globalisation. The funds are used for training, retraining of workers, programs to help start their own businesses, etc.  That's great news. The Fund gives rise to a hope that the construction of a social Europe will finally begin. It is important to understand that the precariousness and competition of European employees among themselves is not the norm. It is up to Europe to guarantee the protection of employees. Social Europe is the only one that can today reconcile citizens with their institutions.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. - I voted against the proposal for a decision to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund based on Belgium's application under EGF/2013/012 BE/Ford Genk to finance an EGF contribution of EUR 570 945, after the dismissal of 512 persons, of which 479 should be affected by the measures, at the Ford-Werke GmbH assembly plant.  I believe that such packages of measures represent only firefighting measures that offer no long-term solution for laid-off workers on the one hand and for the poor economic situation in crisis-affected sectors. In my view, Member States must provide their companies with a healthy business framework that will enable them to be competitors in the global market, which assumes a tax burden and the removal of bureaucratic barriers holding back investment and business.  In the case of Belgium's request for a Ford Genk, I particularly oppose the proposed package of services, as Belgium did not use the possibility of financing incentives to set up its own businesses, i.e. did not include measures in its package to encourage entrepreneurship, which should be one of the pillars of Member States' employment policy.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. - Globalisation has good and bad aspects and it is important to find quick solutions when citizens are affected by that, especially the ones that are losing their jobs. We are conscious that the problems in Ford Genk will also affect its suppliers located in the same geographical area and that it will have a serious impact on the whole Flemish region. I supported this report today in order to give these people a second chance and to assist them with their reintegration into the labour market. This should be dynamic and made available as quickly and efficiently as possible in order to minimise the impact on employment and the local economy.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. - This European fund is essential for ensuring the continuity of industry in peripheral countries and the employability of workers in this sector. That's why I voted for it.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of resources for redundancies 479 of the 512 dismissed at the Ford-Werke GmbH assembly plant in the town of Genk and ten ford Genk suppliers in Belgium during the reference period from 1 July 2013 to 1 November 2013. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of high unemployment in Belgium, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of the human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - The rapporteur attests that, in the application under analysis in Belgium, the conditions laid down in the EGF Regulation are met, and has taken into account two other vacancies of redundancies, which are expected to occur this year – 4 340 in FORD Genk and 2 280 in its suppliers located in the same geographical area, Flanders. The automotive industry has been the subject of 17 eGF mobilisation decisions since the start of the EGF in 2007; in particular, the decline in THE EU's market share in passenger car production has already been mentioned in eight previous decisions. Globalisation which essentially has the growing integration and economic interdependence of strong capital liberalisation – especially financial – and global trade, which is synonymous with inequalities, unemployment, increased poverty and intensified labour exploitation. As evidenced by the dozens of applications for mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund approved over the past seven years, the millions of unemployed in the EU and the exponential increase in poverty levels, the solution is not the measures taken so far, but the break with these policies, which opens the door to a Europe of sovereign states.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. - The redundancies at the Ford-Werke GmbH assembly plant and at ten of its suppliers confirm the crisis in the European car production sector. The increasing decline in this sector is having a serious impact on the European economy, which is in one of the most serious crises. It is therefore essential to take effective and, above all, specific measures to enable those affected to be reintegrated quickly, by creating, in particular, training places for these specific workers and by trying to place them as workers in the European car industry. Training is therefore a top priority. In this sense, I voted in favour of the motion which provides for the use of the EGF.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. - The Globalisation Fund was set up to help with short-term emergencies caused by mismanagement, globalisation or the financial and moral crisis in the Member States. Support includes training, business start-up grants, coaching and outplacement of redundant workers. The Globalisation Fund co-finances these job creation measures at 50% or 65%, with the remainder provided by the Member State concerned. This makes the EU Commission a gigantic labour market agency. Nevertheless, the European Court of Auditors said in a special audit report that this "globalisation fund" provides only limited EU added value and should be replaced by a more efficient regime. It was explicitly stated that this Globalisation Fund is not the best way to provide much-needed specific support. And yet the EU is continuing the policy, which has been shown to be inefficient. I cannot agree with that.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. - Belgium submitted the application under consideration, following redundancies at FORD/Genk and ten other supplier companies, totaling 512 workers made redundant. The rapporteur attests that the conditions laid down in the EGF Regulation are met and took into account two other redundancies, which are expected to occur this year - 4 340 at FORD Genk and 2 280 in their suppliers located in the same geographical area, Flanders . The automotive industry has been the subject of 17 eGF mobilisation decisions since the start of the EGF in 2007; in particular, the decline in THE EU's market share in passenger car production has already been mentioned in eight previous EGF decisions as well as the major structural changes in global trade patterns arising from globalisation. Globalisation that essentially has the growing integration and economic interdependence, of strong liberalisation of capital – especially of the financial – and of trade at the global level; which is synonymous with inequalities, unemployment, increased poverty and intensified exploitation of work. The EU's response to the crisis has been consolidated in the Euro, the Stability Pact and the Lisbon Strategy – price stability, fiscal consolidation and market deregulation, and this is the result of these policies.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. I welcome the granting of a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which the Belgian authorities had requested from the EU in the wake of the redundancies at the steel producer Carsid S.A.  This fund was set up as an expression of EU solidarity to provide additional support to workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns.  The rapid decline in the EU's share of the global steel market for crude steel, a fall in steel demand from the automotive and construction sectors as a result of the economic crisis, and an increase in production costs have in recent years particularly affected many regions where employment is heavily dependent on traditional heavy industry. The redundancies at the Carsid production plant near Charleroi therefore unfortunately hit an area which was already characterised by a high proportion of long-term unemployed. Extensive labour market policies and sufficient financial support are essential here. The measures co-financed by the Fund include job-search assistance, active job-oriented counselling and various retraining and training measures and are therefore more than welcome. However, it would have been desirable if the examination of the application had been carried out a little more quickly, since the Fund's support should be provided as soon as possible.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. - The principle of subsidiarity dictates that decisions should be taken at the closest possible level to the citizen – in this case, at regional or national level. Therefore these projects should not be funded by the European Union.  It is absurd that the arbiters of whether this funding should or should not be given are members of the European Parliament with no detailed knowledge of the situation. This project may well be of benefit to the people in Belgium, but I am not best placed to judge. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be scrapped, which would give money back to the Member States to decide for themselves about the appropriateness of such funding. Consequently, I had no option but to vote against – even though this may be a worthwhile project.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. - As Carolo, it is obviously with satisfaction that I have seen a broad consensus emerging in the European Parliament to approve the EUR 911,000 granted by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help the socio-professional reintegration of Carsid workers. This European aid has enabled, through regional pre-financing, individualised support for workers with a satisfactory result, since 500 of them have found a job, 1.9 billion, barely precarious, in this period of economic crisis. Nevertheless, 177 people have not returned to work following the closure of a blast furnace, which was the victim of the demand crisis and the rise in raw materials created by the 2008 economic and banking crisis. Unfortunately, the Charleroi region has been hit hard by this liberal crisis. I will also, of course, remain extremely attentive to the requests made to the Fund for mass layoffs that took place in Caterpillar, St Gobain or Duferco by a management much more concerned with a financial than social logic.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. - This request is aimed at mobilizing EUR 911,934 for Belgium following the dismissal of 939 people at the Carsid S.A. production site in Marcinelle (one of the charleroi sections).  The measure particularly affects 752 workers, with a view to reintegrating them into the labour market through training, retraining and individual support for support and job search.  Following a decline in the EU's share of raw steel production (from 17.1% in 2006 to 11.9% in 2011), some 280,000 workers lost their jobs in the metallurgical sector between 2008 and 2013 (-20%).  The steel sector is therefore hard hit in Europe and unfair competition from countries such as China (over the same period, its share in crude steel production rose from 35.5% to 46.8%, an increase of 32%) has serious employment consequences in some regions.  I have therefore spoken in favour of this text in support of these workers who are victims of globalisation.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the report authorising the mobilisation of the EGF, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in favour of 939 Belgian workers and 10 companies operating in the steel sector. In a difficult scenario for doing business like the current one, every form of aid, every opportunity is a very important strategic resource that cannot be ignored or so much worse overlooked. From this point of view, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund must be regarded as one of the most useful instruments provided for by the EU, which makes it possible to give a concrete hand to all those workers who have lost their jobs as a result of the economic crisis.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. - (C) Has voted in favour of this report today. I therefore do so to provide workers in the cases in question with financial support for retraining and/or other measures to find new jobs.  However, I would like to stress that the high level of unemployment in europe could be effectively combated if the austerity policies of the European Commission and the governments of the Member States have long been pursued could be stopped.   Creating new jobs in Europe requires a new economic policy with massive public and environmentally friendly investments. Public investment is needed in schools, health and social care, but also in infrastructure, rail, public transport, energy-efficient housing and sustainable energy systems.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 911 934 of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 939 workers who have lost their jobs at the Carsid assembly plant in the Charleroi region, for the production of continuous raw cast steel, as a result of structural changes in world trade resulting from globalisation and the impact of the economic and financial crisis. The customized services to be financed from the FEAG include training, vocational guidance and recycling activities. While these aids alone are unable to alleviate the drama of unemployment in the Charleroi region, they do constitute good assistance and training for the reintegration of workers affected.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report because it supported the granting of support from the European Globalisation Fund to the retraining of redundancies at a factory in charleroi in the Belgian city. Workers from carsid SA (Carsid) were made redundant as a result of major structural changes in the world's trade system caused by globalisation and the rapid decline in the Union market share in the continuous casting sector, as well as the steady decline in casting production of untreated steel in the Union. This is due to the decrease in steel demand in the automotive and construction sectors. The dismissal of Carsid is projected to lead to a significant increase in the unemployment rate in the Charleroi district (a former coal mining and steel production area where employment is heavily dependent on traditional heavy industry), as the area is already characterised by the fact that a large proportion of the unemployed are made up of long-term jobseekers and those with low-level qualifications and skills. In 2012, the unemployment rate in the Charleroi district was 21.6%, compared with 15.8% in the Walloon region and 11.2% of the unemployment rate across the country.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of mobilising the Globalisation Adjustment Fund. I am on the side of the 939 workers made redundant by Carsid, an induced by the Italian duferco group.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. - Parliament has decided to accept the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund's request for intervention from Belgium's metal-making companies to help employees of this company, which is heavily affected by the employment consequences of globalisation. The layoffs of many Carsid employees in Belgium are due to increased global competition in the steel sector. Dismissed employees will receive training aimed at reintegrating into the labour market and finding a job. I voted in favour of this report, which shows the Union's solidarity in the face of certain negative consequences of globalisation on employment.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted today in favour of this report in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of 752 steel workers who have been made redundant from carsid's production plant based in Marcinelle, near Charleroi in Belgium, as a result of major changes in the structure of world trade due to globalisation. The contraction in demand for steel in the EU automotive and construction sector as a result of the economic crisis and a relative increase in production costs (raw materials, energy, environmental constraints, etc.) have harmed the competitiveness of the EU steel industry and have led to the loss of a large number of steel jobs in recent years due to the closure and restructuring of plants by various steel producers in Europe. For example, between 2008 and 2013 the number of employees in the metallurgical industry in the EU decreased by around 280 000, from 1.44 to 1.16 million (-19.4 %). The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF), which provides support to those who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade due to globalisation, becomes essential as more and more European companies are forced to close down.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. - The rights of many workers are crushed by a global crisis situation in which the substantial difference between different economies leads to impoverishment and crisis in entire commercial and industrial sectors, the steel sector in Europe is one of the victims of this crisis. The generation that grew up after the Second World War has struggled for greater guarantees in the workplace, these guarantees are now devoid of substantial content and the fates of so many people are crushed by a sudden and sudden historical change in global dynamics, the intervention of states is necessary and due to those who are not to blame for what is happening but only the misfortune to work in sectors that suffer this change.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the application, the twelfth in the framework of the 2014 budget, for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) for a total amount of EUR 911 934 for Belgium.  The EGF was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. The application was made following 939 redundancies linked to the closure of Carsid SA's production plant in Marcinelle, near Charleroi.  The redundancies are due to major changes in the structure of world trade due to globalisation.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was established in 2006 to provide additional assistance to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of international trade and to help them reintegrate into the labour market.  From 1 May 2009, the scope of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been extended to include support for workers made redundant as a direct result of the economic, financial and social crisis.  At a time when Europe is in the face of a financial, economic and social crisis, with unemployment being one of the main consequences, the European Union should use all means at its service to react, in particular, to the support to be provided to people who have been left without a job.  I therefore supported this report on the mobilisation of EUR 911 934 for Belgium with the aim of supporting the reintegration into the labour market of the 752 workers and potential beneficiaries of the 939 workers made redundant in Carsid SA.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of Mr Sarvamaa's request for the mobilisation of the EGF totalling EUR 911 934 for Belgium. I agree with the allocation of these funds to remedy the redundancies linked to the closure of carsid SA's production plant in Marcinelle, near Charleroi. The Union shall provide instruments to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of world trade and to facilitate their reintegration into the labour market. It is essential, especially at times of difficulty such as today's, when Europe is facing, among other issues, a serious employment crisis, that every contribution and support in this area is dynamic and is made available quickly and efficiently; it must be able to pursue a policy of solidarity with all European citizens. They are courageously fighting the crisis, and that is why the institutions are increasingly committed to any new difficulties.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. - The EGF co-funded measures will include individual job-search assistance and training. Such measures will support the reintegration of the workers back into the labour market. I have therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. - (IT) Today I voted in favour of this report in order to provide additional support to the workers at the Carsid SA production plant. 939 lost their jobs as a result of major changes in the structure of world trade due to globalisation and the rapid decline in the Union's market share in world continuous casting crude steel production and a substantial decline in crude steel production in the Union due to a decrease in demand for steel in the automotive and construction sectors. It is expected that 752 people will benefit from measures from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources for the 752 redundancies that occurred at the Carsid SA assembly plant in the town of Marcinelle, near Charleroi, Belgium, during the reference period from 28 September 2012 to 28 January 2013. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of high unemployment in Belgium, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of the human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. - I note that this application by Belgium relates to over 900 redundancies at the production plant of Carsid SA (‘Carsid’) located in Marcinelle near Charleroi in Belgium due to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation between 28 September 2012 to 28 January 2013. The Commission has concluded that the application meets the conditions for deploying the EGF. The coordinated package of personalised services to be co-funded includes the following measures for the reintegration of 752 redundant workers into employment. In order to mobilise the Fund, the Commission has submitted a transfer request to the Budget Authority for a global amount of EUR 911 934. Hence I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. - Faced with layoffs in the steel industry, Belgium has called on the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The funds released must constitute effective and concrete supplementary assistance for laid-off workers. Personalised services must provide them with real added value in order to support them in their efforts to reintegrate into the labour market.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. - Created in 2006, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) aims to help reintegrate workers who have lost their jobs as a result of changes in world trade. In 2009, its scope was expanded to include victims of the financial crisis. This application, submitted by Belgium, is for redundancies in the steel sector. The aim is to help 752 employees who lost their jobs as a result of the dismissal of 939 people following the closure of the Carsid SA site in Marcinelle. The aid will amount to EUR 911,934 and will enable active labour market measures such as individual job search assistance, training and retraining to be co-financed,... This aid is certainly not up to the tragedy experienced by the laid-off workers, but it is a sign that Europe, if not prevented it, is sensitive to their plight. However, I deplore the length of the Commission's review of this matter. This request has received my support and the support of the European Parliament.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. - The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. The Belgian authorities have made a request to the European Commission for redundancies at the Carsid SA plant, which are linked to significant structural changes as a result of globalisation and are linked to a rapid decline in the UNION's share of the world market and a steady decline in the production of cast crude steel in the Union, as demand for steel in the automotive and construction sectors has decreased; Commission proposal includes the use of EUR 911 934 from the Fund for technical support. According to the Belgian authorities, the measures started on 1 October 2013 constitute a coordinated, personalised package of services and active labour market measures aimed at reintegration of workers into the labour market. I supported the report in the plenary vote.

name: Pablo ECHENIQUE
text: in writing. - The delegation of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilizing this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series.  However, we consider this Globalisation Adjustment Fund to be a simple hot cloth on the haemorrhage that is charged each month, in terms of mass layoffs, this Europe of Markets and Capitals. The processes of industrial conversion, labour flexibility and production technology characteristic of the Third Industrial Revolution make it increasingly difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. - The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. I voted in favour of this report because it is a means by which the EU can give valuable help to local economies hard hit by company closures. I regret that the government has not taken advantage of this fund in Wales.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - The EGF was created to provide additional support to redundant workers following major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation or financial crisis and helping them find new jobs. Between 2014 and 2020, the fund's annual ceiling is EUR 150 million. Redundant workers are offered measures such as support for business creation, job search assistance, vocational guidance and various types of training. Belgium submitted the Application EGF/2013/02 BE/Carsid following 939 redundancies, with 752 people expected to take part in the measures in the context of the closure of the production unit of Carsid SA, located in Marcinelle, near Charleroi, during the reference period from 28.09.2012 to 28.01.2013. The redundancies at carsid SA's production unit are related to major structural changes in global trade patterns resulting from globalisation, the accelerated decline in the Union's market share in the continuous leaking crude steel production sector worldwide and a significant decrease in the production of leaking crude steel in the Union due to a decline in demand for steel products in the automotive and construction sectors. Eur 911 934 was granted in this eGF mobilisation. I voted in favour.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - This is the second application from Belgium that we are considering in this plenary session. It refers to the dismissal of 939 workers, related to the closure of the production unit of Carsid SA, located in the vicinity of Charleroi. This company produced steel brames used in the production of products used in construction, transportation equipment and the automotive sector. The justification for this dismissal does not differ from what we have seen so often: the important structural changes in global trade patterns arising from globalisation, with the rapid decline in market share. This redundancy significantly aggravated the unemployment situation in the Charleroi area (a former coal mining and steel production area, where employment is heavily dependent on traditional heavy industry), which is characterised by a high percentage of long-term unemployment. This is the consequence of deindustrialization, the result of policies of destruction of the productive fabric and the financialization of capital, having as first and only objective the easiest and fastest profit. The solution lies not in the measures taken so far, but in the rupture with these policies, which open doors to a Europe of progress and social justice, of workers and peoples.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of 939 redundancies at Carsid (steel plate producers) in Charleroi for EUR 911 934.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. - I am voting against the report in the motion for a resolution, because these measures are insufficient to tackle unemployment. The money also, for the most part, does not end up with the laid-offs in need, but with various counselling and career guidance companies. In the end, these measures are a mockery of those who are made redundant by the austerity policy imposed by the European Union itself.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. - I voted against this application for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. I support measures that create growth and jobs, but the Globalisation Adjustment Fund is simply a waste of taxpayers’ money. There is no evidence that it offers value for money in terms of reintegrating redundant workers back into the labour market.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. - The delegation of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilizing this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider this Globalisation Adjustment Fund to be a simple patch that is charged every month, in terms of mass layoffs, in this Europe where the interests of large companies are above the interests of citizens. The processes of industrial conversion, labour flexibility and production technology characteristic of the Third Industrial Revolution make it increasingly difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. - I support the need to have a European instrument to assist redundant workers. I am glad that Parliament fully supported the setting up of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) as part of the MFF for 2014 to 2020. I voted in favour of the Carsid application for EUR 911 934 for the 939 steel workers made redundant due to the closure of the Carsid SA production plant. The Charleroi area´s high reliance on the steel production industry, which has in turn been severely impacted by a decline in the construction and automotive sectors as a result of the crisis, requires a fast response and measures to combat long-term unemployment and encourage reintegration into employment. I hope that this will be achieved by the personalised measures to be implemented for the workers.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - The delegation of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilizing this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider this Globalisation Adjustment Fund to be a mere patch, in terms of mass layoffs, in this Europe where the interests of large companies are above the interests of citizens. The processes of industrial conversion, labour flexibility and production technology characteristic of the Third Industrial Revolution make it increasingly difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. - I voted for the motion for a resolution because the dismissal of 939 Carsid SA workers will have a significant impact on unemployment in the Belgian city of Charleroi (near which the company is located) whose long-term unemployment rate has passed 20%.  Tmis workers are also exposed to a decline in cast steel production in the Union, further jeopardising their labour market situation. Redundancy at the Carsida production facility poses a major problem for locals, and financial assistance from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an adequate measure towards mitigating this situation.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. - It is important to support employees who lose their jobs suddenly due to a global financial and economic crisis. We need to help them get back on their way to employment. This assistance of 911,934 euros will enable sacked employees at Carsid's crude steel production site in Belgium to benefit from personalized training programmes to facilitate their return to work.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. - I supported the resolution on the request to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund introduced by Belgium concerning layoffs at the carsid S.A. crude steel company near the town of Charleroi. The Fund was created to promote the reintegration into the labour market of workers who are victims of changes in the structure of international trade resulting from globalization, or the financial crisis. I am the the fore, the most pleased to say that this financial aid of almost EUR 912,000 has been adopted.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of mobilisation of the Fund, as I support providing assistance for the reintegration into the labour market of redundant workers who lost their jobs as a result of globalisation and a rapid decline of the Union’s market share in the production sector for continuously-cast crude steel.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. - The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been set up to provide additional support to workers affected by changes in world trade. It has a budget of EUR 150 million. So far, the Hungary has not benefited from this framework, even though there has been very high unemployment in my country as a result of the crisis artificially generated by the EU's central countries and the US. Only support for a country that is suffering from the crisis process can be accepted. A Belgian company has applied for support here, so I voted against, because Belgium is one of the causes of the crisis and the beneficiary of the colonisation of the new EU Member States.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of Mr De Clercq's report. Petri Sarvamaa, which provides support for some Belgian companies active in the production of crude steel. Specifically, the report provides for the allocation of resources necessary for the reintegration into the labour market of redundancies at the Carsid SA production plant ("Carsid") based in Marcinelle. This report is in addition to three others adopted today, all aimed at the same aim: to support workers in difficulty as a result of the crisis.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources for the 752 redundancies that occurred at the Carsid SA assembly plant in the town of Marcinelle, near Charleroi, Belgium, during the reference period from 28 September 2012 to 28 January 2013. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of high unemployment in Belgium, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of the human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. - The effects of globalization on automotive sectors have been extrapolated to related sectors such as steel. This, coupled with the crisis that has particularly affected steel demanding sectors such as construction, has caused a major recession in this sector.  On 5 September 2014, the Commission approved Belgium's application for mobilisation of the EGF to support the reintegration into the labour market of dismissed workers at the Carsid SA assembly plant.  This is aid of EUR 911 934 for the provision of services to assist in the reintegration of 752 of the laid-off workers at the plant.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. - Due to significant structural changes in world trade flows and the growing trend of decreasing union market share in the continuously cast crude steel sector and reduced cast steel production, a Report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been adopted to help workers who have lost their jobs as a result of the closure of the Carsid SA production facility located in Marincelle near the town of Charleroi. The European Globalisation Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the effects of structural changes due to globalisation. This Report aims to provide €900,000 to assist redundant workers in the form of individual job search assistance and training and retraining for new jobs and I have supported it.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. - I voted in favour, because that was also the position of the Socialist Political Group of the EP.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. - I supported this package. Decrease in demand in steel in the automotive and construction sectors in the EU as a consequence of the economic crisis and a relative increase of production costs (raw materials, energy, environmental constraints, etc.) – these factors have harmed the competiveness of the EU’s steel industry and have led to a high number of job losses in the steel sector in recent years due to plant closures and restructuring by several steel manufacturers in Europe. For instance, between 2008 and 2013, the number of persons employed in the metallurgic industry (NACE Rev. 2 division 24 ‘Manufacture of basic metals’) in the EU-27 decreased by around 280 000 from 1.44 million to 1.16 million (− 19.4 %).

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the report on the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for the reinstatement of the 939 employees made redundant following the closure of carsid's production plant in Belgium. The EGF must be seen as a key EU instrument for all workers who have lost their jobs as a result of the economic and financial crisis.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of Mr Sarvamaa's report in order to express once again my closeness and support for workers affected by major changes in the structure of world trade. In view of the 939 redundancies at the Carsid SA production plant, I believe it is essential to reintegrate these workers and give them the opportunity to develop new skills and re-enter the labour market.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. - The numerous redundancies resulting from the closure of the Carsid SA production plant are linked to major structural changes in world trade patterns as a result of globalisation. The losses in this sector illustrate the rapid decline in The European market share in steel production and the simultaneous increase in the market share of countries such as China. This makes it all the more important to adopt an effective Union strategy for the steel-producing industry in order to maintain competitiveness. For these reasons, I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF in this case.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The globalization aid fund plays its destructive role. Instead of helping workers, it encourages shareholders and states to adhere to the social irresponsibility of forced liberalism. The application relates to 939 layoffs at carsid SA's ("Carsid") crude steel production site in Belgium, including 752 workers covered by the measures co-financed by the EGF. The Belgian authorities argue that the economic crisis has weighed heavily on the manufacturing sector throughout the European Union: in the EU-27, between 2008 and 2013, for example, some 280,000 workers lost their jobs in the metallurgical industry. But without questioning the economic model that is the cause of the deindutrialisation of Europe, and it does not propose the only effective remedy: solidarity protectionism. Both the Belgian government and the EU treat the symptoms without ever addressing the causes of the disease. I abstain so as not to deprive Belgian workers of this fund.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. - The EU is an area of solidarity and is part of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This support is essential to help the unemployed and the victims of relocations in a globalised context. There is an increasing number of companies relocating, taking advantage of the low labour prices, which are practised in several countries, notably China and India, with harmful effects on countries that respect workers' rights. The EGF is intended to help workers who are victims of business relocation and is key to facilitating access to new employment. The EGF has already been used in the past by other EU countries, and it is now up to Belgium to give this aid to the EGF/2013/02 BE/Carsid application for a financial contribution from the EGF, following 939 redundancies, with 752 people expected to take part in the measures in the context of the closure of the production unit of Carsid SA (Carsid), located in Marcinelle, near Charleroi, Belgium, during the reference period from 28 September 2012 to 28 January 2013.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. - The European Union has set up legislative and budgetary instruments in order to provide additional support to workers who have been affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation and to assist the reintegration of the same workers back into the labour market. The report cites how the number of jobs in southern Hainaut of Belgium has declined by 15.3% between 2007 and 2012, particularly in sectors where companies often employ a large number of workers. Additionally, these workers will likely have to retrain to find alternative employment. Therefore, I have voted in favour of the Carsid application.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. The steel sector is facing serious economic difficulties in Europe. The S.A.Carsid is not spared and suffers from the general decline in demand for steel in the automotive and construction sectors. By deciding, through the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, to provide financial assistance to laid-off workers from the Belgian company CARSID S.A., Europe is demonstrating its real potential to help reintegrate workers into the labour market. It is essential to help our workers, to ensure them stable and sustainable jobs in the long term.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the Report on the Mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for the mobilisation of the EGF in Belgium for the support and reintegration in the labour market of workers made redundant in the production plant of Carsid SA (‘Carsid’). The fund will help 752 redundant workers to get back into employment through job-search assistance, training and retraining programmes.

name: Giulia MOI
text: in writing. - Belgium submitted its APPLICATION EGF/2013/02 BE/Carsid for a financial contribution requested under the EGF amounting to EUR 911 934 following 939 redundancies linked to the closure of carsid SA's production plant based in Marcinelle. As financial support goes to 752 redundant workers and aims to facilitate their reintegration into the labour market, I voted in favour.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. Belgium has requested assistance under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 752 of the 939 people made redundant after the closure of carsid S.A.'s production site in Marcinelle (one of the charleroi sections).  These layoffs are the concrete result of significant structural changes in the steel sector in Europe. Thus, the decrease in European production of raw steel resulting from the casting (-13.4% between 2006 and 2011) is directly related to a decrease in demand from the automotive sector or the construction sector. Faced with direct competition from low-cost countries (e.g. China and India), some 280,000 people lost their jobs in the European metallurgical industry between 2008 and 2013.  It should also be noted that the southern Hainaut (Charleroi region) and neighbouring regions are particularly affected by the decline in manufacturing activities, a phenomenon that makes the retraining of laid-off persons essential to hope to find a job. As this aid was used to co-finance individual training and retraining measures, I voted in favour of not depriving these victims of the benefits of globalization and ultraliberalism on this merit.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. - I voted in favour of this text, which provides for the mobilization of EUR 911,934 for former Carsid employees in Belgium. Carsid produced steel slabs for processing at sites belonging to the Duferco Group in Belgium.  Production was mainly used in the construction, transportation, automotive and equipment industries. All of these sectors were hit hard by the crisis in Europe and the company was unable to cope with the drop in orders. I hope that the European Parliament will quickly decide on a package of measures that will enable European companies to regain competitiveness with foreign companies.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report in view of the importance, in these times of economic crisis, of EU support for workers whose businesses have suffered particularly. The metallurgical sector is a symbol of the major changes at work in the organization of world trade; we know that too much in France. It is therefore logical for the EU to help and empower the population to retrain.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. - I voted for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: for the request of EGF/2013/002 BE/Carsid – Belgium. Belgium requested the financial contribution from the EGF following the dismissal of 939 workers, of whom 752 workers were targeted to participate in the measures in question. The redundancies occurred after the closure of the Carsid S.A. production plant during the reference period September 2012 and January 2013. The redundancies at the Carsid plant are linked to major global structural changes as a result of globalisation, the rapid decline in the Union's global market share in the production sector of raw steel obtained by continuous casting, and the steady decline in production of raw cast steel at Union level as a result of the reduction in demand for steel in the automotive and construction sectors. Production of raw steel from continuous casting in the EU-27 decreased by 13.4% between 2006 and 2011, and the EU-27 market share in the same time period decreased by 30.7%. Unfortunately, Europe's steel sector is exposed to serious economic difficulties and, as s&D coordinator for industry, research and energy, I stress the need for investment in this sector to relaunch steel production in the EU.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. - The mobilisation of the Fund is intended to restore room for manoeuvre for a steel industry company. The numerous redundancies resulting from the closure of the Carsid SA production plant are linked to far-reaching structural changes in world trade patterns as a result of globalisation. The losses in this sector illustrate the rapid decline in The European market share in steel production and the simultaneous increase in the market share of countries such as China. However, the steel industry has always been the backbone of our industrial production. It is therefore crucial to adopt an effective Union strategy for the steel-producing industry – not least in order to maintain competitiveness. For these reasons, I voted in favour of mobilising this fund in this case.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. - Whereas the proposal for a Decision on the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Belgium is intended to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from the Carsid SA production plant as a result of structural changes in international trade; Whereas the contraction in steel demand in the EU automotive and construction sector has adversely affected the competitiveness of the European steel industries; Agreeing that the loss of a large number of steel jobs could have a major impact on the unemployment rate in the local economy, I voted in favour.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. I regret this perverse system by which the European Union, on the one hand, destroys the economic environment and, on the other hand, pays some subsidies that do not compensate for the difficulties that its policy has generated.  While I do not hesitate to support job creators, I regret that the Union is putting them in a position to have to ask for help in order to survive. When is a rational policy that would protect businesses and workers through controlled borders? Taking a few steps to reduce the effects when you keep making the causes worse makes no sense.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - I supported my colleague Petri Sarvamaae's report. Due to structural reforms covering the metalworking industry sector, the number of dismissals is unfortunately increasing on a daily basis. This proposal to mobilise €911,934 from the EGF aims to repair the damage caused by the redundancies of 752 workers. This package is planned to subsidize the retraining process of persons employed in the metalworking industry and individually assist each worker in finding new employment.  I support the process of speeding up the withdrawal of funds from the EGF. It has been several years to grant assistance to this company. Unfortunately, this crisis is caused by a crisis in the sale of new vehicles. The main exporter of Tmisda are large automotive factories. They are currently in decline in demand for cast steel. Between 2006-2011, the European Union saw a 13.4% drop in demand for cast steel. The world steel market did not experience a decline, but grew by 25.1%. The competitiveness of the European Union has been greatly reduced.  I support close cooperation between social partners and european institutions. The role of trade unions in negotiations is very important in order to find common ground on the way to helping laid-off workers. The city of Charleroi leads to an unemployment rate of 21.6% with these layoffs. This is well above the national unemployment average of 11.2%.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. - The Aim of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is to provide further support to workers in companies suffering from the negative economic situation and major structural changes in world trade. For this reason, the action in favour of workers who have been made redundant by Carsid SA (steel companies have suffered particularly from a fall in steel demand in recent years) is valid and will enable a large group of workers to better re-enter the labour market with measures aimed at retraining.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: in writing. - I also supported today's resolution on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. However, I have some doubts about the fact that most of the funds go to the old Member States, even though globalisation affects the new Member States in the same way. I believe that the further distribution of funds from this fund will convince me that the distribution is carried out in a balanced way.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Writing. - I voted against this motion because, once again, funds from the Globalisation Fund are being misused for labour market measures. Here, the nation states would be required to take possible measures on labour market policy where necessary and desired. The EU has no competence in this particular case and, once again, is exceeding its competences.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. - The steel sector is a sector severely affected by a large drop in demand in the EU, and the change in its prices internationally. The consequences are therefore very serious for employees, especially when, as in the Charleroi region, the optics of conversion are difficult. I therefore vote in favour of mobilising the globalization adjustment fund in order, in particular, to encourage the creation of businesses.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 911 934 of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 939 workers who have lost their jobs at the Carsid assembly plant in the Charleroi region, for the production of continuous raw cast steel, as a result of structural changes in world trade resulting from globalisation and the impact of the economic and financial crisis. The customized services to be financed from the FEAG include training, vocational guidance and recycling activities. While these aids alone are unable to alleviate the drama of unemployment in the Charleroi region, they do constitute good assistance and training for the reintegration of workers affected. In any event, it would be desirable to improve the financial endowment of these aid on a forthcoming occasion.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. - I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) for Carsid workers whose situation I know all too well. The use of this envelope will provide individual assistance to these workers and help them return to work. Having said that, if the importance of this fund for the support of workers is no longer to be demonstrated, I remain critical on two points. First of all, the fact that the WEF can only intervene when more than 500 workers have been laid off by a single company (including downstream suppliers and producers) seems to me to be too reductive. Many workers have seen their smaller businesses close and have not been able to benefit from this fund. I therefore hope that the 500-worker threshold will be lowered. In addition, effective fundraising takes far too long when it is at the time they lose their jobs that workers need support. I therefore call for an expedited decision-making process to mobilize the WEF.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. - This application, the twelfth in the framework of the 2014 budget, relates to the mobilisation of the EGF for a total amount of EUR 911,934 for Belgium. The question relates to redundancies linked to the closure of carsid sa's production plant ("Carsid") based in Marcinelle, near Charleroi. I voted in favour of defending the work of the companies concerned and supporting the growth of the region.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour because it is an economic intervention, amounting to nine hundred eleven thousand euros, following 939 redundancies made by carsid in Charleroi

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. - The delegation of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilizing this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider this Globalisation Adjustment Fund to be a simple hot cloth on the haemorrhage that is charged each month, in terms of mass layoffs, this Europe of Markets and Capitals. The processes of industrial conversion, labour flexibility and production technology characteristic of the Third Industrial Revolution make it increasingly difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources for the 752 redundancies that occurred at the Carsid SA assembly plant in the town of Marcinelle, near Charleroi, Belgium, during the reference period from 28 September 2012 to 28 January 2013. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of workers in the context of high unemployment in Belgium, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. - I welcome today’s vote on the mobilisation of the EGAF to support the reintegration in the labour market of Belgian workers made redundant in the production plant of Carsid SA (‘Carsid’). It concerns 939 redundancies in Carsid SA, located at Marcinelle near Charleroi in Belgium. A total amount of EUR 911 934 in EGAF aid will support 752 workers targeted for EGAF co-funded measures during the reference period from 28 September 2012 to 28 January 2013. The UK has never made an application under this fund. UK workers therefore receive none of this support.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. - The EU has set up legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers affected by major changes in global trade flows, but also to help them re-enter the labour market. The financial assistance provided by the Union to redundant workers should be more dynamic and accessible as quickly as possible, all in line with the Joint Declaration of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission adopted on 17 July 2008. I support the proposal because it reflects the agreement reached between parliament and the Council on the reintroduction of criteria for mobilising the fund in the event of a crisis, but also because it is also about increasing efficiency in dealing with mobilisation requirements. Belgium applied for financial assistance from the EGF following the redundancies of 939 workers, with 752 expected to be covered by the measures, in connection with the closure of Carsid SA's production facility. Please note, there is a risk that due to layoffs in Carsid, unemployment in the city area will increase significantly. I therefore support the proposal under the EGF Regulation and agree with the Commission that the conditions set out in the EGF Regulation have been met and that Belgium is entitled to financial assistance under this Regulation.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: in writing - I voted against this proposal as it is detrimental to the European Union's economy and its competitiveness. I have no doubt that EUR 911 934 939 can help redundant workers. However, all european Union taxpayers will have to put together to do this, which will reduce their competitiveness accordingly. And that is the exact opposite of what the European Union is trying to achieve with this contribution.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. - I voted against this report today, as I am opposed in principle to the use of this European Globalisation Adjustment Fund and, as a result, I cannot support this proposal to mobilise it.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. - I am voting against this report because instead of ending up with the laid-off staff who are in dire need, they will be allocated to companies or organisations (private or state) that are supposed to re-draw up these staff or help them find work. That is, they will either create skilled unemployed people or prolong their agony.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - As Belgium has applied for financial assistance from the EGF following the redundancies of 939 workers and 752 people are expected to be covered by measures related to the closure of the Carsid SA production company, I consider it necessary to reduce the duration of the introductory period in order for the EGF to act as quickly as possible.  However, it is important to note that the EGF was established to support workers dismissed as surplus due to structural changes in world trade flows resulting from globalisation, and that its funds can only co-finance active labour market measures leading to long-term employment, and must not replace activities for which companies are responsible under national law or collective agreements , or restructuring measures.  For all of the above, I support the proposal and egf funds should be mobilised to provide a financial contribution in relation to the application submitted by Belgium.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. - This lunchtime, the PS delegation of the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilising more than 1.4 million euros to support the workers of Ford Genk and the Carsid metallurgical plant in Charleroi. The aim of this assistance is to reorient professionally and train the 1231 workers who are victims of restructuring and redundancies in their companies. This Fund is a symbol of a Europe that can be more united. The EGF makes EUR 150 million available each year to support workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in international trade as a result of globalisation. The funds are used for training, retraining of workers, programs to help start their own businesses, etc.  That's great news. The Fund gives rise to a hope that the construction of a social Europe will finally begin. It is important to understand that the precariousness and competition of European employees among themselves is not the norm. It is up to Europe to guarantee the protection of employees. Social Europe is the only one that can today reconcile citizens with their institutions.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. - I voted against the proposal for a decision to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund based on Belgium's EGF/2013/02 BE/Carsid proposal for financial assistance from the EGF following the redundancies of 939 workers, with 752 expected to be covered by the measures, in relation to the closure of carsid SA ('Carsid') production facility located in Marcinelle.  I believe that such packages of measures represent only firefighting measures that offer no long-term solution for laid-off workers on the one hand and for the poor economic situation in crisis-affected sectors. In my view, Member States must provide their companies with a healthy business framework that will enable them to be competitors in the global market, which presupposes tax relief and the removal of bureaucratic barriers holding back investment and business. In the case of Belgium's request for Carsid, I am particularly opposed to the proposed service package, which does not include measures to encourage entrepreneurship in redundante workers, which should be a pillar of any economic policy.  It would also be desirable to condition the financing of such packages by adopting long-term measures that will enable growth in sectors affected by the crisis, as we cannot blindly finance the retraining of workers laid off due to poorly managed economic policy and the inability of states to provide their companies with conditions that will enable them to perform effectively on the global market.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. - This European fund is essential for ensuring the continuity of industry in peripheral countries and the employability of workers in this sector. That's why I voted for it.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources for the 752 redundancies that occurred at the Carsid SA assembly plant in the town of Marcinelle, near Charleroi, Belgium, during the reference period from 28 September 2012 to 28 January 2013. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of high unemployment in Belgium, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of the human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - This is the second Belgian application that we are considering in this plenary session. This company produced steel brames used in the production of hot and cold rolled products used in construction, transportation equipment and the automotive sector. The justification for this dismissal at carsid SA's production unit (Carsid) is related to the major structural changes in global trade patterns arising from globalisation, with the accelerated decline in the Union's market share in the continuous leaking crude steel production sector. This redundancy has increased unemployment in the Charleroi area (a former coal mining and steel production area, where employment is heavily dependent on traditional heavy industry) which is characterised by a high percentage of long-term unemployment. The mobilisation of the amount of EUR 911 934 is only a palliative which, if necessary, is not the solution. There is a need for another direction for Europe, a course that has social justice and the well-being of peoples at the heart of its policies and the right to work with decent rights, wages and pensions.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. - The steel industry in Europe is in great trouble due to constant globalisation and strong competitive pressure against countries such as the People's Republic of China. As can be seen from the example of the closure of the Carsid SA production plant, only an effective EU strategy for the steel-producing industry in Europe can, in the long term, help to create new opportunities and investments. As the competitiveness of the European steel industry must be maintained, I voted in favour of the motion which provides for the mobilisation of the EGF.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. - The Globalisation Fund was set up to help with short-term emergencies caused by mismanagement, globalisation or the financial and moral crisis in the Member States. Support includes training, business start-up grants, coaching and outplacement of redundant workers. The Globalisation Fund co-finances these job creation measures at 50% or 65%, with the remainder provided by the Member State concerned. This makes the EU Commission a gigantic labour market agency. Nevertheless, the European Court of Auditors said in a special audit report that this "globalisation fund" provides only limited EU added value and should be replaced by a more efficient regime. It was explicitly stated that this Globalisation Fund is not the best way to provide much-needed specific support. And yet the EU is continuing the policy, which has been shown to be inefficient. I cannot agree with that.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
