text: in writing. - This application refers to the dismissal of 939 workers, related to the closure of the production unit of Carsid SA in Belgium, which produced steel brames used in the production of hot and cold rolled products used in construction, transport equipment and the automotive sector. The justification for this dismissal in the production unit of Carsid SA (Carsid) is related to the major structural changes in global trade patterns resulting from globalisation, the accelerated decline in the Union's market share in the continuous leaking crude steel production sector worldwide and a significant decrease in the production of leaking crude steel due to a decline in demand for steel products in the automotive and construction sectors. This is the consequence of deindustrialization, the result of policies of destruction of the productive fabric and the financing of capital, having as first and only objective the easiest and fastest profit. The mobilisation of the amount of EUR 911 934 is only a palliative which, if necessary, is not the solution. There is a new direction for Europe, a course that has social justice and the well-being of peoples at the heart of its policies.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. - The principle of subsidiarity dictates that decisions should be taken at the closest possible level to the citizen - in this case, at regional or national level. Therefore these projects should not be funded by the European Union.  It is absurd that the arbiters of whether this funding should or should not be given are members of the European Parliament with no detailed knowledge of the situation. This project may well be of benefit to the people of France, but I am not best placed to judge. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be scrapped, which would give money back to the Member States to decide for themselves about the appropriateness of such funding.  Consequently, I had no option but to vote against – even though this may be a worthwhile project.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. - This support will support the reintegration into the labour market of 2,357 of the 6,120 workers laid off at Peugeot Citroen Automobiles. The massive layoff within this company risks undermining the entire economy of a region. I welcome the implementation of a plan to re-hire PSA workers, victims of liberal austerity policies.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. - The request here concerns the mobilization of EUR 12,704,605 under the EGF to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant at Peugeot Citroen Automobiles (PSA). It affects 2,357 workers out of the 6,120 licensees at the Aulnay site (now closed) but also at the Rennes site.  While between 2000 and 2012, world vehicle production increased by 44%, production in Western Europe fell by 25%. The share held by third countries such as China and Turkey now stands at 47% of world production, up from 15% in 2000. With the European market becoming saturated and unfair competition from these third countries increasing, our manufacturers are the first victims of this situation. Worse, within the Union itself, the share of manufacturers in these third countries continues to grow.  In the face of this, economic patriotism should prevail with, for example, the introduction of targeted tariffs in the face of unfair international competition.  Nevertheless, I have spoken out in favour of this request in order to support workers who are victims of globalisation and ultra-liberal policies and to give them a chance to retrain.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. - (IT) I supported this report authorising the mobilisation of the EGF, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in favour of 6 000 French workers in the metallurgical sector. The hope is that the European Union will soon adopt a more effective trade policy, finally dedicated to protecting our labour market. Pending a radical change in Community policies, the best, only, instrument we can rely on is precisely the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. - (C) Has voted in favour of this report today. I therefore do so to provide workers in the cases in question with financial support for retraining and/or other measures to find new jobs.  However, I would like to stress that the high level of unemployment in europe could be effectively combated if the austerity policies of the European Commission and the governments of the Member States have long been pursued could be stopped.   Creating new jobs in Europe requires a new economic policy with massive public and environmentally friendly investments. Public investment is needed in schools, health and social care, but also in infrastructure, rail, public transport, energy-efficient housing and sustainable energy systems.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 12 704 605 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 6120 workers who have lost their jobs at Peugeot Citroen Automobiles (PSA) in France, as a result of structural changes in world trade resulting from globalisation and the impact of the economic and financial crisis. The customized services to be financed from the EGF include training activities, vocational guidance, recycling and incentives for the creation of companies. While these aids alone are unable to alleviate the drama of unemployment in the Charleroi region, they do constitute good assistance and training for the reintegration of workers affected.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report because it supported the granting of support from the European Globalisation Fund to workers made redundant by the French car factory, Peugeot Citroën Automobiles. 6 120 workers were dismissed from the company producing motor vehicles, trailers and semi-trailers. The workers were mainly made redundant in the Ile de France (One plant) and brittany (Reno plant) regions. For the reference period from 1 October 2013 to 31 January 2014, support under measures co-financed by the EGF is foreseen to be granted to 2 357 staff. Parliament found that the redundancies would further increase unemployment in the Ile-de-France and Brittany regions, where the two plants in question were located, as One was the 8th largest employer and the redundancies reduced employment in the region by 13.6%. Parliament also noted that global trends in the western European car industry are of great concern, as it is estimated that global vehicle production increased by 44% between 2000 and 2012, with a 25% decrease in production in Western Europe during the same period. In addition, production in third countries (South Korea, China, Turkey, Indonesia, Iran, Malaysia, Thailand and South America) has increased significantly and currently accounts for 47 % of world vehicle production (15 % in 2000).

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of mobilising the Globalisation Adjustment Fund. They are on the side of the 6 000 workers declared redundant by Peugeot Citroen.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. - The European Parliament has approved assistance for PSA employees who have been dismissed at the Aulnay sites in Ile-de-France and Rennes in Brittany. This financial assistance will enable them to undergo training in order to re-enter the labour market and find a job. I voted in favour of this mobilization of the Globalization Adjustment Fund. The European and particularly French automotive sector is heavily affected by both the economic crisis and global competition. Financial assistance from the European Union was therefore completely justified and necessary.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - (IT) Today I voted in favour of this report in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of 2 357 workers operating in the automotive manufacturing sector who have been made redundant from the Peugeot Citroën Automobiles (PSA) plant. It should be noted that the EU manufactured 16.2 million vehicles in 2013, out of a worldwide total of 87.3 million (18.54%), while in 2000 the EU-15 manufactured 17.1 million vehicles, out of a worldwide total of 58.3 million (29.41%). On the demand side, the EU has now become a very slow-growing market. Consumers avoid buying by finding themselves in difficult economic conditions. The objective of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is to facilitate the rapid reintegration into working life of these redundant workers through personalized accompanying actions, such as assistance in finding employment, vocational guidance, training and retraining, promoting self-employment and entrepreneurship.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. - (IT) The changes in the structure of world trade are a change that unfortunately cannot be stopped, but because of the speed of the phenomenon, many workers and entrepreneurs are deprived of their livelihoods without fault, in the automotive sector this is a harsh reality that cannot be denied. Many have found themselves in an unfavourable economic situation, leading to the impossibility of providing for their own needs and those of their families.  The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is a fair instrument for limiting the consequences of an economic change that has affected and still affects many areas of our lives.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the application, the thirteenth in the framework of the 2014 budget, for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) for a total amount of EUR 12 704 605 for France.  The EGF was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. The application in question, submitted by the French authorities, concerns 6120 workers made redundant by PSA. This undertaking operates in the economic sector of "Manufacture of motor vehicles, trailers and semi-trailers" and the redundancy of workers has mainly concerned the Aulnay and Rennes plants.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was established in 2006 to provide additional assistance to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of international trade and to help them reintegrate into the labour market.  From 1 May 2009, the scope of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been extended to include support for workers made redundant as a direct result of the economic, financial and social crisis.  At a time when Europe is in the face of a financial, economic and social crisis, with unemployment being one of the main consequences, the European Union should use all means at its service to react, in particular, to the support to be provided to people who have been left without a job.  I therefore supported this report on the mobilisation of EUR 12 704 605 for France with the aim of supporting the reintegration into the labour market of the 2357 workers and potential beneficiaries of the 6120 workers made redundant at Peugeot Citroën Automobiles.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of Citroen. This Fund is set up to provide additional support to workers affected by major changes in the structure of world trade in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of redundant workers. I am therefore in favour of the peugeot citroën automobiles case, i.e. granting France a total amount of EUR 12 704 605, in order to protect 6,120 workers made redundant by PSA, mainly from the Aulnay plant, which was decided to close, located in the NUTS 24 Île de France (FR10) region and the Rennes plant (redundancy of a significant number of workers) in the Bretagne region (FR52).

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. - I have voted in favour of this report as it will improve the employability of the workers affected  by these redundancies and support their reintegration into the French labour market. Moreover, the financial assistance will provide support to workers made redundant as well as self-employed persons whose activity ceased as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. - The EGF, which offers support to those who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade due to globalisation, becomes essential, given the fact that more and more European companies are being forced to close down. In view of the problem of unemployment in the Ile de France and Brittany regions, I can only vote in favour of EGF intervention in relation to the redundancy of 6120 workers from Peugeot Citroën Automobiles operating in the NACE classified sector. The redundancies mainly affect the ile de France and Brittany regions, with 2,357 workers receiving measures co-financed by the EGF, in the reference period from 1 October 2013 to 31 January 2014.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of resources for the redundancies 6,120 redundancies made at Peugeot Citroen Automobiles, which operates in division 29 of NACE Rev. 2 ('Manufacturing motor vehicles, trailers and semi-trailers'), redundancies which have been made mainly in the Isle of France region (the Aulnay plant) and in Brittany (the plant) , with 2,357 workers benefiting from the measures co-financed by the EGF during the reference period from 1 October 2013 to 31 January 2014. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of high unemployment in France, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. – This application by France refers to 2 357 out of 6 120 workers made redundant at the Peugeot Citroën Automobiles Aulnay and Rennes plant. The French authorities state that according to OICA statistics, the EU-27 manufactured 16.2 million vehicles in 2013, out of a world total of 87.3 million (18.54 %), down from the EU-15 producing 17.1 million vehicles in 2000, out of a world total of 58.3 million (29.41 %). The Commission has concluded that the application meets the conditions for deploying the EGF. The Commission has submitted a transfer request to the Budget Authority for a global amount of EUR 12 704 605 for personalised services to be provided to workers made redundant. These include external experts guidance, thematic workshops, training, training allowances and grants for business creation. Hence I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. - Almost a year ago to the day, the last vehicle was coming out of the PSA factory in Aulnay. Affected by declining sales in Europe and the lack of competitiveness of the French automotive industry, thousands of employees of the "PSA" factories in Aulnay and Rennes were laid off. To cope with such an economic and social tragedy, these employees will benefit from the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the tune of 12.7 million euros. I welcome the vote of this text which will enable the thousands of employees made redundant from PSA to be better supported in their job search. The EPP, and in particular the French delegation, was right to fight for the maintenance of this Fund, which the States at one time wanted to abolish.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. - Created in 2006, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) aims to help reintegrate workers who have lost their jobs as a result of changes in world trade. In 2009, its scope was expanded to include victims of the financial crisis. This application, submitted by France, is for redundancies in the automotive sector. The aim is to help 2,357 sacked employees at Peugeot Citroen Automobiles in Ile-de-France and Brittany. The aid will amount to EUR 12,704,605 and will help to co-finance active labour market measures such as individual job search assistance, training and retraining,... I regret, however, that more laid-off workers could not be helped, knowing that in total Peugeot Citroen Automobiles had to part with 6120 workers.  This request has received my support and the support of the European Parliament.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. - The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. France has requested assistance from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund because, following the redundancies of 6 120 workers at Peugeot Citroën Automobiles, mainly in the Ile-de-France (Aulnay site) and Brittany (rennes site), a significant industrial change is taking place at the sites concerned, and measures are needed to help the local workforce to re-position. According to the Commission, the conditions laid down in Article 1(a) of the EGF Regulation are fulfilled and, therefore, France is entitled to make a financial contribution under that Regulation and constitute an active labour market measure within the scope of the eligible activities under Article 7 of the EGF Regulation.  On the basis of the request submitted by France, it is appropriate to make use of the financial contribution of EUR 12 704 605, which it will use for personalised assistance to redundant workers: reception structure and case management, external expert advice, thematic workshops, training, training grants, start-up grants. I supported the report in the plenary vote.

name: Pablo ECHENIQUE
text: in writing. - The delegation of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilizing this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series.  However, we consider this Globalisation Adjustment Fund to be a simple hot cloth on the haemorrhage that is charged each month, in terms of mass layoffs, this Europe of Markets and Capitals. The processes of industrial conversion, labour flexibility and production technology characteristic of the Third Industrial Revolution make it increasingly difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. - The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. I voted in favour of this report because it is a means by which the EU can give valuable help to local economies hard hit by company closures. I regret that the government has not taken advantage of this fund in Wales.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - The EGF was created to provide additional support to redundant workers following major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation or financial crisis and helping them find new jobs. Between 2014 and 2020, the annual ceiling of the fund is EUR 150 million. Redundant workers are offered measures such as support for business creation, job search assistance, vocational guidance and various types of training. France submitted this application following 6 120 redundancies at Peugeot Citroën Automobiles, mainly in the isle of France (Aulnay plant) and Brittany (Rennes plant) during the reference period from 1.10.2013 to 31.01.2014. The redundancies in psa are related to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation and refer to the observation made by France (L'industrie Automobile Française, Analyse et statistiques 2013) according to which, between 2000 and 2012, world vehicle production increased by 44 % while, in the same period, in Western Europe, it fell by 25 % and, at the same time, in third countries , recorded a significant increase, currently accounting for 47% of the world's vehicle production. In this mobilisation of the EGF for the region of Brittany and the Isle of France, EUR 12 704 605 was granted. I voted in favour.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - Another bid from the automotive sector, submitted by France, following 6120 redundancies at Peugeot Citroën Automobiles. The justification for this attack on the right to work is repeated: important structural changes in the patterns of world trade due to globalization. It should be noted that between 2000 and 2012, world vehicle production increased by 44%, while in the same period western European production fell by 25% and, at the same time, production in third countries (South Korea, China, Turkey, Indonesia, Iran, Malaysia, Thailand and South America) has increased significantly, now accounting for 47% of world vehicle production (up from 15% in 2000). It is clear that the automotive industry is moving to countries with lower wages, thus ensuring higher and easier profits. We are approving palliatives which, as the present case shows, do not apply to all workers made redundant: of the 6120 redundancies, only 2357 are covered by this fund. We need to face this avalanche of collective redundancies head-on and give it the real reason: it is the fastest and easiest profit that is speaking louder. And it is always the workers who pay for the crises that capitalism generates and that will never be able to solve.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the intervention requested by the French authorities to manage the approximately 6000 redundancies of the Peugeot Citroën group - the measures will affect more than 2000 workers.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. - I am voting against the report with the proposal for a decision, because these measures are insufficient to tackle unemployment. Moreover, the money, for the most part, does not end up among the dismissed who need it, but in various consultancy and career guidance companies. In the end, these measures are a mockery of those made redundant by the austerity policy imposed by the European Union itself.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. - I voted against this application for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. I support measures that create growth and jobs, but the Globalisation Adjustment Fund is simply a waste of taxpayers’ money. There is no evidence that it offers value for money in terms of reintegrating redundant workers back into the labour market.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. - The delegation of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilizing this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider this Globalisation Adjustment Fund to be a simple patch that is charged every month, in terms of mass layoffs, in this Europe where the interests of large companies are above the interests of citizens. The processes of industrial conversion, labour flexibility and production technology characteristic of the Third Industrial Revolution make it increasingly difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers.

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: In writing. On 25 April, following PSA's restructuring plan, France submitted a request to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which the European Parliament approved this week. I voted in favour of this request to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which targets 2,357 laid-off workers. FEAM helps workers laid off due to the global financial and economic crisis; it is a key tool through which the European Union intervenes to help European citizens and a fine example of European solidarity. Elected from the Grand-Est constituency in France, I approved this request all the more because it concerned not only employees of the Rennes and Aulnay sites, but also 89 workers at the Tremery site and 48 people at the Metz site (in Lorraine), 202 people at the Mulhouse site (in Alsace) and 608 people at the Sochaux site (in Franche County) : 4 sites in my riding.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: Written. I do not think that people should be the victims of failing European socio-economic policies. That is why I voted in favour of the mobilisation of funds from the European Fund for Adaptation to Globalisation, but I think this is a wipe for the bleeding. In fact, I believe that companies, and the Member States themselves, should come up with appropriate aid measures themselves, because now we are actually just pumping money from the Member States around. Large multinationals such as Ford and PSA (Peugeot-Citroën) put their employees on the streets after years of loyal service, because they are moving their production to places where they can find cheaper labour. I strongly reject these degrading practices, and with the resources from the European Fund, we are at least ensuring that the workers who have been sent away are not left out in the cold.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. - In times of crisis, we must be the first supporters of employees who find themselves brutally unemployed. The answers are not just financial. They also go through a quality training offer adapted to the profiles of employees. In this area, France must redouble its efforts. However, I can only rejoice that the European Union has shown solidarity by mobilising EUR 12.7 million for the 2,357 employees of PSA Peugeot Citroen. I now hope that this funding will enable a personalised training programme for each PSA employee so that everyone can find a job in line with their skills and that none of them are deprived of the opportunity to look to the future with serenity.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - The delegation of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilizing this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider this Globalisation Adjustment Fund to be a mere patch, in terms of mass layoffs, in this Europe where the interests of large companies are above the interests of citizens. The processes of industrial conversion, labour flexibility and production technology characteristic of the Third Industrial Revolution make it increasingly difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. - I voted for this motion for a resolution to approve resources from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for the benefit of laid-off Peugeot Citroen Automobiles workers, whose redundancies are compounded by unemployment in regions where the two affected plants are located, namely Île-de-Francei Brittany.  The decline in vehicle production in France, as a result of fundamental changes in the world market, has significantly affected the 6120 Peugeot Citroen Automobiles workers who need to reintegrate into the labour market through EGF funds with the help of start-up grants. It is therefore necessary to ensure that redundang workers and the self-employed across Europe can count on EU support in similar cases through support measures such as the EGF.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. - It is important to support employees who lose their jobs suddenly due to a global financial and economic crisis. We need to help them get back on their way to employment. This assistance of 12.7 million euros will enable the 2,357 PSA Peugeot Citroen employees who have been made redundant in Aulnay and Rennes to benefit from personalized training programmes in order to return to the labour market and find a job that is in line with their skills.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. - I supported the resolution on the european Globalisation Adjustment Fund's request for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund introduced by France on the redundancies at Peugeot Citroen Automobiles (PSA). The Fund was created to promote the reintegration into the labour market of workers who are victims of changes in the structure of international trade resulting from globalization, or the financial crisis. Thus, this European Union aid of 12.7 million euros will allow more than 2,300 French employees dismissed from PSA to be supported and accompanied in the search for a new job. I welcome the adoption of this financial assistance.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of mobilisation of the Fund, as I support providing assistance for the reintegration into the labour market of redundant workers who lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of Mr De Clercq's report. Isabelle Thomas. As in the other cases put to the vote today, it is a question of allocating resources to ensure that some redundant workers are reintegrated into the labour market. In this particular case, these are the workers of Peugeot Citroën Automobiles, operating in the manufacture of motor vehicles, trailers and semi-trailers who have lost their jobs in France as a result of the global economic and financial crisis. In this respect, our vote on the activation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund will be able to make a positive and concrete contribution.

name: Jérôme LAVRILLEUX
text: In writing. - After supporting it in the Parliamentary Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I voted in favour of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund (F.E.M.) to help former employees of the PSA automotive industry at the Aulnay and Rennes sites, as part of their reintegration into the workforce.  The funded project proposes the creation of mobility and professional development spaces, the provision of external experts and advisors, the organisation of thematic and information workshops, access to a large offer of training, as well as the granting of grants for the creation of companies.  The European Union will contribute 60% of the EU (12,704,605 euros) to a project of 21,174,342 euros.  This is an example of concrete action by the European Union in favour of employment.  I must regret, however, that France does not make sufficient use of these European funds.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: In writing. - The European Union has a Globalisation Adjustment Fund, EGF, which aims to mitigate the effects of relocations and the crisis by funding training and retraining aid. The request to mobilise this fund concerns former employees of the PSA sites in Rennes and Aulnay. An envelope of 12.7 million euros is to finance up to 60% of reclassification programmes, personalised aid, training, business start-up aids and training leave beyond the 4 months paid by the company for 2,357 former employees. As a member of the Social Affairs Committee, I am speaking on every request from the WEF. In this review, I make sure that the aid we provide goes only to workers so as not to disempower companies of their social obligations.  Psa's legal obligations and commitments with the social partners are not included in this application, so this is a plus that is granted to former PSA workers. So I voted for this additional aid, but I remain in demand for tighter controls on the use of these funds to ensure that they only benefit workers.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of resources for the 6,120 redundancies made at Peugeot Citroen Automobiles, which operates in division 29 of NACE Rev. 2 ('Manufacturing motor vehicles, trailers and semi-trailers'), redundancies which have been made mainly in the Isle of France region (the Aulnay plant) and in Brittany (the plant) , with 2,357 workers benefiting from the measures co-financed by the EGF during the reference period from 1 October 2013 to 31 January 2014. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of high unemployment in France, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. - On 10 September 2014 the Commission approved a decision mobilizing this fund in favour of France. The reason for the application was the dismissal of 6,120 workers from the Peugeot Citroen Automobiles company. The automotive sector in Europe has been severely affected by structural changes due to globalisation and has in place other requests for mobilisation of this fund as we can see in the previous report.  The aid shall consist of EUR 12 704 605 intended to provide services to facilitate the employment of EUR 2 357 of the dismissed workers. These are the reasons why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. - I support the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to assist France in the dismissal of peugeot citroën automobiles workers. Redundancies are linked to structural changes caused by the growing trend of globalisation.  The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund aims to provide additional assistance to redundary workers and the self-employed who have had to cease their activities as a result of globalisation.  This report allocates €12.7 million to provide measures for redundant workers such as reception centres and social work with individuals, the engagement of external experts in worker guidance, thematic workshops, training, training fees and start-up grants, and that is why I supported it.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. - I voted in favour today, because that was also the position of the socialist political group, and it is also a demonstration of solidarity.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. - I welcome this application. The French authorities argue that the redundancies have a significant adverse impact on the local and regional economy in the affected areas. In agreement with the relevant public authorities, the company has carried out regional impact studies for the areas around the Aulnay and Rennes plants. In its commune, the Aulnay plant was the 8th largest employer, and the redundancies reduce the numbers employed in the area by 13.6 %. The reduction is less steep in Rennes, but it must be noted that this area has already been affected by a general economic decline, with the number of unemployed in Brittany as a whole doubling within the past five years

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. - (IT) I supported the EGF report on france's application for a financial contribution in connection with the dismissal of the 6120 workers of Peugeot Citroën. This fund is set up to support the reintegration of redundant employees into the labour market, who are affected by the consequences of company structural changes, with the aim of improving the employment opportunities of all workers through appropriate training. I am therefore strongly in favour of giving France the amount of EUR 12 704.605 in order to protect and guarantee 6000 workers made redundant by PSA.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. - (IT) I believe that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is a necessary and additional support for workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of world trade. As the third demand linked to the car industry French which exceeds EUR 10 million, I stress the importance of making adjustments in good time and carefully identifying skills, so as to create retraining opportunities and exploit the skills of workers in other sectors. On the basis of this, I have decided to express my agreement with mrs Thomas' report, which also recalls the importance of improving the employment opportunities of all workers through appropriate training and recognition of the skills and competences acquired during the worker's professional career. I welcome the fact that it is estimated that the number of participants eligible for business start-up grants is high.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. - The redundancies at PPE are linked to far-reaching structural changes in world trade patterns as a result of globalisation. The losses in the automotive manufacturing sector in Western Europe illustrate the rapid decline in European market share and the simultaneous increase in the market share of third countries. This makes it all the more important to adopt an effective strategy to maintain competitiveness. For these reasons, I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF in this case.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The globalization aid fund is a redundancy bonus. Instead of helping workers, it encourages shareholders and states in their social irresponsibility. The application concerns 2357 of the 6120 workers made redundant at PSA for a total amount of 12,704,605 euros from the Fund to France. The plant closures in Aulnay-sous-Bois or Rennes are not justified by the lack of profitability or by the decline of the French automotive industry, which has been experiencing a resurgence over the past 18 months. PSA reported a profit of $477 million for the first half of 2014. They have been the result of years of the shameless search for ever greater rates of profitability by the main shareholders of the Peugeot family who emigrated to Switzerland. Their economic irresponsibility leads to capital restructuring at the expense of PSA's industrial development, and in particular its sustainable ecological conversion. The aim is to make taxpayers pay the consequences of the financial decisions of irresponsible and annuity shareholders. Instead of randomly distributing a few funds to employees, it would be better to pursue ambitious industrial policies that allow for the resumption of activity and ecological planning. I'm voting against this request for a redundancy bonus.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. - The EU is an area of solidarity and is part of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This support is essential to help the unemployed and the victims of relocations in a globalised context. More and more companies are relocating, taking advantage of the low labour prices that are practised in several countries, notably China and India, with harmful effects on countries that respect workers' rights. The EGF is intended to help workers who are victims of business relocation and is key to facilitating access to new employment. The EGF has already been used in the past by other EU countries, and it is now up to France to give this aid to France, which submitted the EGF/2014/006 FR/PSA application for a financial contribution from the EGF, following 6 120 redundancies at NACE Rev's Citroën Automobiles (PSA). 2, Division 29 (Manufacture of motor vehicles, trailers and semi-trailers), saying the redundancies relate essentially to the regions of the Isle of France (Aulnay plant) and Brittany (Rennes plant), with 2 357 of the potential workers benefiting from the measures co-financed by the EGF during the reference period from 1 October 2013 to 31 January 2014.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. - The European Union has set up legislative and budgetary instruments in order to provide additional support to workers who have been affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation and to assist the re-integration of the same workers back into the labour market. The report articulates how redundancies in the Aulnay plant of France have reduced the number of employees therein by 13.6%. In Rennes and Brittany, numbers are less steep but are, nonetheless, still very significant. Redundancies in the European automobile industry have been drastic overall. Thus, the Peugeot Citroën Automobiles application aims to help France reintegrate these workers, who have been made redundant in their industry as a result of globalisation, back into the labour market. Therefore, I have voted in favour of this report.

name: Giulia MOI
text: in writing. - France submitted the EGF/2014/006 FR/PSA application for a financial contribution from the EGF amounting to a total amount of EUR 12 704 605. It concerns 2 357 out of 6 120 workers made redundant at Peugeot Citroën Automobiles - Manufacture of motor vehicles, trailers and semi-trailers. As the contribution is intended to be additional support for the 2 357 redundant workers and aims to facilitate their reintegration into the labour market, I voted in favour.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) was set up by the EU to enable the retraining of workers who are victims of relocation and/or economic crisis. Last April, France applied for 2,357 PSA Group employees for EGF assistance, the amount of which was set at EUR 12,704,605. This solicitation of co-financing follows the closure of the Aulnay site and the restructuring of the Rennes site, which resulted in the dismissals of 6,120 people. The French automotive industry is bearing the brunt of the economic consequences of ultraliberal dogma and the free and undistorted competition demanded by Brussels and applied with submission by successive governments of the right and left in France. For example, between 2000 and 2012, French car manufacturers saw their sales of new vehicles fall significantly in Europe, resulting in a significant decline in production and restructuring plans in France. Although I believe that this WEF demonstrates all the cynicism of the EU, I voted for this report, considering that it is a way to recover some of the 20 billion euros that France pays to Europe each year.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. - I voted in favour of this text, which will mobilise more than 12 million euros for some of PSA's laid-off workers in Brittany and the Ile de France. The French automotive industry has experienced a significant decline since the 2008 crisis. The government to which I belonged in France had taken a series of measures to support the sector. Since the alternation, no major structural reform has been taken and the social consequences have been severe. I regret that the French Socialist rapporteur is taking advantage of this important text to launch controversies. In addition, I denounce the rapporteur's desire to increase the process of mobilising the EGF. The strength of this fund is to enable a relatively rapid mobilization of aid for those made redundant. The rapporteur wants to increase the number of consultations before the fund is submitted, which will inevitably lead to a slowing down of the procedure. This idea is antisocial and does not take into account the emergency situation experienced by those who are made redundant.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the Report on the Mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in France, which will mobilise the EGF in favour of France to support the reintegration in the labour market of workers made redundant in Peugeot Citroën Automobiles. The Report concerns 2 357 out of 6 120 workers made redundant in Peugeot Citroën Automobiles. The personalised services which are to be provided to workers made redundant consist of training and training allowances, among others.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. - I voted in favour of this report, which mobilises just over 12 million euros for the 2,300 workers laid off at PSA. The automotive sector, and in particular the French sector, is still suffering from the crisis and it is necessary to help workers in the sector to retrain. Faced with the social consequences of the crisis, it was unthinkable that the EU would not mobilise: it is done!

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. - I voted for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for the application submitted by France following the 6120 redundancies made at Peugeot Citroën Automobiles. The undertaking operates in the manufacturing of motor vehicles, trailers and semi-trailers. Of the total redundancies made, 2357 workers are targeted by measures co-financed by the EGF during the reference period October to January 2014. Between 2000 and 2012 world car production increased by 44%, although production in Western Europe decreased by 25% and, in addition, production from third countries (South Korea, China, Turkey, Indonesia, Iran, Malaysia, Thailand and South America) has increased considerably, currently accounting for 47% of world car production (compared to 15% in 2000). To date, the automotive sector has been the subject of 21 requests for assistance from the EGF, 12 of which are based on trade issues related to globalisation and 9 on the global economic and financial crisis.  As the S&D coordinator for industry, research and energy, I stress the need to identify solutions that strengthen the competitiveness of the automotive sector. In view of the significant difficulties faced by the European automotive industry, these solutions must take into account economic, social and environmental aspects.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. - For some time now, the PSA Group has been suffering from increasing competitive pressure, especially in the small car sector. The mobilisation of the fund is intended to help the Group to restore its competitiveness. The recent redundancies at PPE are linked to far-reaching structural changes in world trade patterns as a result of globalisation. The losses in the automotive manufacturing sector in Western Europe illustrate the rapid decline in European market share and the simultaneous increase in the market share of third countries. This makes it all the more important to adopt an effective strategy to maintain competitiveness. On the other part of these considerations, I voted in favour of mobilising the Fund.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. - Whereas the Commission has approved a proposal for a Decision on the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of France in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant by Peugeot Citroën Automobiles; Whereas, despite the slow growth of the EU market on the demand side, manufacturers are finding it difficult to maintain their market share, which is increasingly being intercepted by third countries; Agreeing that redundancies have a considerable negative impact on the local and regional economy of the areas concerned, I voted in favour.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. I regret this perverse system by which the European Union, on the one hand, destroys the economic environment and, on the other hand, pays some subsidies that do not compensate for the difficulties that its policy has generated. While I do not hesitate to support job creators, I regret that the Union is putting them in a position to have to ask for help in order to survive. When is a rational policy that would protect businesses and workers through controlled borders? Taking a few steps to reduce the effects when you keep making the causes worse makes no sense.  Peugeot is in fact suffering from refusing to carry out massive relocations and trying to preserve jobs in France. It is unacceptable that this choice ultimately harms him. This is proof that Europe's economic directives are absurd and unfavourable to the citizens of European countries.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - Unemployment is one of the worst consequences of the economic, social and financial crisis that the whole world has faced for years. The European Union's initiative to mobilise funds from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is one of the projects that can help countries take care of workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes.  I supported the European Commission's decision to allocate funds to the French automotive industry, Peugeot Citroën Automobiles, especially as these measures will benefit more than 2 000 workers. Given that, according to a french government report, the largest number of people dismissed as a result of the new situation belongs to the older age group, aged 55-64, it is of utmost importance to support their reintegration into the labour market.  Measures such as retraining, career guidance, career management skills development, additional education and training are a way to give older workers who are not considered an attractive workforce to be recruited. Consequently, I supported the Commission's proposal to allocate €12,704,605 from the European Globalisation Fund to France.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. - The targeted support that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund gives to workers who, despite themselves, suffer from the crisis and structural changes in world trade, allows them to enjoy personalized services with a package of actions that will help them retrain in the labour market. That is why the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of measures to reintegrate workers made redundant by Peugeot Citroën Automobiles is absolutely necessary and effective.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Writing. - I voted against this motion because, once again, funds from the Globalisation Fund are being misused for labour market measures. Here, the nation states would be required to take possible measures on labour market policy where necessary and desired. The EU has no competence in this particular case and, once again, is exceeding its competences.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. - Various sites of the COMPANY PSA in France have been affected by massive layoffs I therefore vote in favour of the mobilization of this fund of adjustment to globalization, which must be recalled the aims that are training and retraining. Nevertheless, prevention is better than cure, so I expect EU governments to adopt common industrial policies in order to confront the distortion of competition and the flight of our industries.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: In writing. - The European automotive sector is going through a deep crisis, which is not new, but whose effects on employment are increasingly devastating. It is our duty as European elected officials to do what we can to help hard-hit workers bounce back from their dismissal, sometimes even the outright closure of the factory where they worked for years. That is why I accompanied my colleague Isabelle Thomas in the drafting of her report on the mobilization of the WEF for former PSA employees, and I obviously voted for it. The Ile-de-France and Brittany regions have been impacted by the thousands of job cuts, and now is the time to retrain as many people as possible. The Aulnay-sous-Bois site in particular represents a very strong potential for industrial activity, and thus job creation for former PSA workers.  These are tough times, so European funds are all the more important to implement European solidarity and provide concrete and effective help for our citizens.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. - I voted in favour of providing 12.7 million euros in aid to people formerly employed by PSA Peugeot Citroen. This aid comes from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which is aimed specifically at workers in the sectors most affected by the crisis. It will be intended to co-finance measures to support job search, training, or initiation into entrepreneurship for more than 2,000 former employees of the psa Peugeot Citroen company, and this is a project that deserves our support.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 12 704 605 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 6 120 workers who have lost their jobs at Peugeot Citroen Automobiles (PSA) in France, as a result of structural changes in world trade resulting from globalisation and the impact of the economic and financial crisis. The customized services to be financed from the EGF include training activities, vocational guidance, recycling and incentives for the creation of companies. These aids constitute good assistance and training for the reintegration of the workers concerned. However, it would be desirable to improve the financial endowment of these aids on a forthcoming occasion.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. - I welcome the vote of this report which will enable the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to be mobilised for some of the 6120 workers laid off at Peugeot Citroen Automobiles at the Aulnay-sous-Bois and Rennes site in France. But there is reason to wonder: between 2000 and 2012, global vehicle production increased by 44% while over the same period production fell by 25% in Western Europe and third-country production (South Korea, China, Indonesia, etc.) increased significantly to 47% of world vehicle production (up from 15% in 2000)!

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. - I voted in favour of this report to provide financial and professional assistance to the 2,357 PSA Peugeot Citroen employees who have been made redundant across France. The EUR 12.7 million provided by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund will enable graduates to benefit from appropriate training programmes and then return to work in line with their skills. I would like to point out that the French EPP delegation and I have always supported the continuation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund and have clearly defended it when it was called into question. The PSA case clearly shows that we must continue our fight for a fairer Europe closer to the citizens.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. - This application, the thirteenth in the 2014 budget, relates to the mobilisation of the EGF for a total amount of EUR 12,704,605 for France. The application concerns 6,120 workers made redundant by psa. This undertaking operates in the economic sector classified in Division 29 of NACE Rev. 2 ("Manufacture of motor vehicles, trailers and semi-trailers"). The redundancy of workers mainly concerns the Aulnay plant (which is to be closed) in nuts 24 Île de France (FR10) region and the Rennes plant (redundancy of a significant number of workers) in the Bretagne region (FR52). I voted in favour of defending the work of the companies concerned and supporting the growth of the region.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. - (IT) I have decided to vote in favour because this is the important intervention, requested by the French authorities, to manage the approximately 6000 redundancies of the Peugeot Citroen group. The measures will affect more than 2000 workers who, among other things, will be accompanied by training courses aimed at relocation. The total amount made available for this mobilisation of the EGF is EUR 12 704 605.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. - The delegation of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilizing this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider this Globalisation Adjustment Fund to be a simple hot cloth on the haemorrhage that is charged each month, in terms of mass layoffs, this Europe of Markets and Capitals. The processes of industrial conversion, labour flexibility and production technology characteristic of the Third Industrial Revolution make it increasingly difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of resources for the redundancies 6,120 redundancies made at Peugeot Citroen Automobiles, which operates in division 29 of NACE Rev. 2 ('Manufacturing motor vehicles, trailers and semi-trailers'), redundancies which have been made mainly in the Isle of France region (the Aulnay plant) and in Brittany (the plant) , with 2,357 workers benefiting from the measures co-financed by the EGF during the reference period from 1 October 2013 to 31 January 2014. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of workers in the context of high unemployment in France, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of the human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. - I welcome that today the European Parliament approved EU aid to help support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant in Peugeot Citroën Automobiles. The EUR 12 704 605 of EGF aid concerns 2 357 out of 6 120 workers made redundant in Peugeot Citroën Automobiles, with the redundancies mainly occurring in the Rennes and Aulnay plants.  The UK has never made an application under this fund. UK workers therefore receive none of this support.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. - Given the situation of major structural changes in global trade flows in which workers of the French automotive industry are directly affected, I believe that EU financial assistance should be dynamic and made available as soon as possible to help workers get into the labour market as soon as possible. The terms of the EGF Regulation have been met and I believe that France is entitled to a financial contribution under that Regulation.  To date, 21 applications for EGF funding related to the automotive sector have been received, 12 of which are based on the effects of globalisation on trade and 9 on the effects of the global financial and economic crisis. This package of services, adapted to the needs for which co-financing is requested, includes measures for redundacy workers. I support a plan to provide interest-based loans for setting up new businesses that could help participants set up sustainable businesses.  I recall the importance of increasing the employment rate of all workers through tailor-made training programmes and recognising the abilities and skills adopted by the worker during his professional career. I welcome this decision as the coordinated package of personalised services was designed in consultation with the national representatives of the intended beneficiaries and social partners, and with the social policy of equality between women and men and with the principle of non-discrimination.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: in writing - I did not support this proposal, as I believe that it is wrong to combat declining competitiveness by allocating subsidies. The proposal concerns EUR 12 704 605 for 2357 redundancies of Peugeot Citroën Automobiles. This thus accounts for almost EUR 5400 for each of the workers concerned. However, this money will ultimately be paid only from the taxes of other workers and firms, which will be able to employ fewer employees as a result of this support. Thus, in order to combat the negative consequences of unemployment, the European Union itself is contributing to the increase in unemployment, and this is certainly not accepted.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. - I voted against this report today as I am opposed in principle to the use of this European Globalisation Adjustment Fund and, as a result, I cannot support this proposal to mobilise it.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. - I am voting against this report because instead of ending up with the laid-off staff who are in dire need, they will be allocated to companies or organisations (private or state) that are supposed to re-draw up these staff or help them find work. That is, they will either create skilled unemployed people or prolong their agony.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - Given that France has applied for financial assistance from the EGF following the redundancies of 6 120 workers and 2 357 people are expected to be covered by measures related to the operations of the Peugeot automobiles production company, I consider it necessary to reduce the duration of the introductory period in order for the EGF to act as quickly as possible.  However, it is important to note that the EGF was established to support workers dismissed as surplus due to structural changes in world trade flows resulting from globalisation, and that its funds can only co-finance active labour market measures leading to long-term employment, and must not replace activities for which companies are responsible under national law or collective agreements , or restructuring measures.  The installations concerned may undergo significant industrial repurmission, which could trigger a stronger redistribution of workers if they use their potential for multimodal transport. For all of the above, I support the proposal and egf funds should be mobilised to provide a financial contribution in relation to the application submitted by France.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. - The European Parliament has adopted by a large majority Isabelle Thomas' report calling for the mobilisation of the globalisation adjustment fund to the tune of 12.7 million euros for 2,357 of the 6,120 workers laid off at PSA, announced in July 2012. I voted against this report because it funds the dismissal of thousands of employees of a company that has obtained a guarantee of 4 billion from the French government, the European car industry having also been massively supported by the EU following the crisis of 2007-2008.  I also voted against it because the reasons given are the company's losses, the deterioration of the European car market while car registrations have been rising steadily for 13 months and France is the second largest European beneficiary of this increase; according to the former boss of PSA, the highest psa boss in Europe, the "cost of labour" is said to have provided several million euros for his retirement-hat, which he was forced to give up in the face of the scandal of thousands of layoffs. I think that large companies have other means of financing redundancy plans than by using public funds.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - We are looking at another application from the automotive sector, a sector that to date has been the subject of 21 applications for EGF intervention, 12 of which related to the globalisation of trade and 9 to the global financial and economic crisis.  Between 2000 and 2012, world vehicle production increased by 44 %, while in the same period western European production fell by 25 % and at the same time production in third countries (South Korea, China, Turkey, Indonesia, Iran, Malaysia, Thailand and South America) has now increased significantly, now accounting for 47 % of world vehicle production (up from 15% in 2000). It is clear that the automotive industry is moving to countries with lower wages, thus ensuring higher and easier profits. We are approving palliatives which, as the present case shows, do not apply to all workers made redundant: of the 6120 redundancies only 2357 are covered by this fund.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. - The automotive industry in Europe is in great trouble due to constant globalisation and strong global competitive pressure. As can be seen from the example of the redundancies at PSA, only an effective EU strategy for the automotive industry can help to create new opportunities and investments in the long term. As the competitiveness of the European car industry must be maintained, I voted in favour of the motion which provides for the mobilisation of the EGF.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. - The Globalisation Fund was set up to help with short-term emergencies caused by mismanagement, globalisation or the financial and moral crisis in the Member States. Support includes training, business start-up grants, coaching and outplacement of redundant workers. The Globalisation Fund co-finances these job creation measures at 50% or 65%, with the remainder provided by the Member State concerned. This makes the EU Commission a gigantic labour market agency. Nevertheless, the European Court of Auditors said in a special audit report that this "globalisation fund" provides only limited EU added value and should be replaced by a more efficient regime. It was explicitly stated that this Globalisation Fund is not the best way to provide much-needed specific support. And yet the EU is continuing the policy, which has been shown to be inefficient. I cannot agree with that.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. - We are looking at another application from the automotive sector, a sector that has so far been the subject of 21 applications for EGF intervention. This application is submitted by France following 6120 redundancies at Peugeot Citroën Automobiles, saying the redundancies relate mainly to the regions of the Isle of France (Aulnay plant) and Brittany (Rennes factory).  It should be noted that between 2000 and 2012 world vehicle production increased by 44 %, while in the same period production in Western Europe fell by 25 % and at the same time production in third countries increased significantly, now accounting for 47 % of world vehicle production. It is clear that the automotive industry is moving to countries with lower wages, thus ensuring higher and easier profits. We are approving palliatives which, as the present case shows, do not apply to all workers made redundant: of the 6120 redundancies only 2 357 are covered by this fund. We need to face this avalanche of collective redundancies head-on and give it the real reason: it is the fastest and easiest profit that is speaking louder. And it is always the workers who pay for the crises that capitalism generates and that will never be able to solve.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. - I voted against the proposal for a decision to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund based on Spain's application for an EGF financial contribution following 6 120 redundancies at Peugeot Citroën Automobiles, with a projected 2 357 workers to be treated with measures to be co-financed by the EGF of EUR 12 704 605.  I believe that such packages of measures represent only firefighting measures that offer no long-term solution for laid-off workers on the one hand and for the poor economic situation in crisis-affected sectors. In my view, Member States must provide their companies with a healthy business framework that will enable them to be competitors in the global market, which presupposes a tax burden and the removal of bureaucratic barriers holding back investment and business.  In the case of France's request, I welcome the inclusion within the service of measures to grant start-up grants, as well as a plan for granting interest-based loans for setting up a business. Such measures should base any plan adopted after mass redundancies, rather than on unspecid and unsafe training measures. However, measures to encourage entrepreneurship must be one of the pillars of any economic recovery and employment policy, not just one of the services offered to workers after their dismissal.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. - This European fund is essential for ensuring the continuity of industry in peripheral countries and the employability of workers in this sector. That's why I voted for it.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of resources for the redundancies 6,120 redundancies made at Peugeot Citroen Automobiles, which operates in division 29 of NACE Rev. 2 ('Manufacturing motor vehicles, trailers and semi-trailers'), redundancies which have been made mainly in the Isle of France region (the Aulnay plant) and in Brittany (the plant) , with 2,357 workers benefiting from the measures co-financed by the EGF during the reference period from 1 October 2013 to 31 January 2014. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of high unemployment in France, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. – The Globalisation Fund does not want and cannot tackle the huge problem of unemployment. It is used to cover up the unpopular policy, the exploitative nature of capitalist enterprises and the EU itself, by funding unemployment recycling programmes and fund-gnawing fake training mechanisms. The cases of Peugeot and FORD are typical.  Monopoly groups are exploiting the capitalist crisis to reduce wages and throw thousands of workers into unemployment, moving factories that close to countries with cheaper labour. Increasing the exploitation of workers is a necessary condition for monopolies to maintain their profitability, even in the crisis, and to strengthen their position in the raging global monopoly competition. Peugeot workers, Ford, the working class as a whole must not limit their claims to the crumbs of extreme poverty that the EU and civil governments throw at it. It is necessary to organize its struggle for the reconstitution and counter-attack of the labour movement, targeting the very exploitative system that breeds unemployment and poverty, to claim to be the owner of the wealth it produces, taking in its own hands the keys to the economy and power.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the President of the Commission on the Barroso II Commission's balance sheet (2014/2812(RSP)). I would point out to Members that there is no catch-the-eye procedure in this debate and that I will not adopt blue cards. First of all, I would like to warmly welcome the President of the Commission and his members of the previous Commission to this House. (Applause) Mr President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has This is the last sitting today at which this Parliament will meet with you as the Current Commission. I assume it is the last one. We will know better tomorrow at noon. But from the present point of view, I would assume that there is a slight tendency to be able to say that this is the last meeting of this College. I therefore take this opportunity to welcome you once again and to tell you that cooperation between a Parliament and an executive is always marked by great tensions. That must be the case. However, as a College, I would like to express the thanks of the European Parliament in advance for the cooperation that is certainly not always easy, but it is based on a common spirit. Thank you, ladies and gentlemen. Before giving the floor to the President of the European Commission, Mr Lucke has come forward – I assume on a point of order.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Mr. President! The final report of the Second Barroso Commission is on the agenda. Under this item, the Commission will certainly give some kind of account to its conduct over the last five years. I would like to draw your attention to Article 17(1) of the TREATY of the EU, which essentially states that the Commission is the guardian of the Treaties. However, the Commission has come under massive criticism for having tolerated and even encouraged the breach of Article 125 of the FEU Treaty – the non-assistance clause – and Article 21 of the FEU Treaty – the prohibition of monetary public debt. Given the importance of these matters, it is totally inappropriate to allow only the group chairmen to speak today. The European Parliament must take seriously the inviolability of the Treaties and must therefore be able to hold a detailed debate on them. I would therefore ask that the debate be so that ordinary Members can also take a position on it, because they too are the elected representatives of their people.

name: José Manuel Barroso
text: President of the Commission. - Mr President, first of all I would like to thank you for the invitation to address this Parliament at what I think will be the last time I have this opportunity. In fact, now we are coming to the end of my second mandate as President of the Commission, and I am very happy to be here with you and my colleagues, to present to you our bilan, and of course, since this is my second Commission, I think I can also refer to the last 10 years. This time I did not bring a written speech. There will be a testimony online, a text I have prepared, and that is going to be distributed to all those of you who would like a copy, together with the main documents of the Commission over these last 10 years. I thought that instead of reading a speech to you, I would share with you my feelings, my emotions, on what I think about the way the European Union has responded to these very challenging times and what I think are the most important challenges for the future. First of all, I think you can agree that these have been exceptional and challenging times. Ten years: ten years of crises and the response of the European Union to those crises. Not only the financial and sovereign debt crisis, but let us not forget that at the beginning of my first mandate we had the constitutional crisis, when two founding Members of the European Union rejected, in referenda, the Constitutional Treaty. So we had a constitutional crisis, we had a sovereign debt and financial crisis and we had several geopolitical crises – but in most acute terms now with the crisis between Russia and Ukraine.  The constitutional crisis we had was in fact solved through the Lisbon Treaty. The reality is that at that time many people, some of whom we know, were saying that it would be impossible for the European Union to find a new institutional setting, and there were moments of ambiguity and doubt; but basically we were able to keep most of the acquis of the European Union, including most of the new elements of the Constitutional Treaty, with the Lisbon Treaty that was ratified by all Member States, including those that today seem to have forgotten that they have ratified the Lisbon Treaty. More recently – because I want to leave to the end the economic issues, because they are still with us – we had the very serious challenge and threat to our stability, stability in Europe, coming from the unacceptable behaviour of Russia regarding Ukraine. We took a principled position. We offered Ukraine an association agreement and a free trade agreement and in fact I am happy that, despite all the difficulties, Ukraine was there signing and ratifying the association agreement. I want to congratulate this Parliament, because on the same day, at the same hour, that the parliament in Ukraine was ratifying this agreement you were also ratifying the agreement, showing that you can offer hope to Ukraine as part of the European family of nations. Now as I am speaking to you, this crisis is not yet solved. We know that, but I think we can be proud that we have kept a position of principle, that we have condemned in the most unequivocal terms the actions of Russia, and that in fact there was an association agreement ratified; not only in Ukraine but also with Georgia and Moldova. I believe we have a duty to those countries that are looking to Europe with the hope of sharing with us the same future and also because they want to share with us the same values. At this moment we are still mediating – today in Brussels there is a meeting mediated by the Commission on Energy – with the Russian Government and the Ukrainian Government. We believe a politically-negotiated solution is possible, we are working for that, we believe it is in the interests of all the parties to have a political agreement, but a political agreement that respects the principles of international law, that respects the right of a country that is our neighbour to decide its own future and that respects the sovereignty and independence of that country. I think we should be proud of what we have been doing in this very challenging geopolitical crisis. We also had the financial and sovereign debt crisis. The reality is that the crisis was not born in Europe, but the fact is that because we were not prepared, because the euro area did not yet have the instruments, we were very much affected by it, not only in financial terms but in economic terms, in social terms and I would say also in political terms. I think this crisis was probably the biggest since the beginning of the European integration process in the 1950s.  Let us now put things in perspective. Let us remind ourselves what was the main opinion of most analysts in the economic and financial media, or even in many of our countries or outside of Europe, as to what could happen. Everybody was predicting a Greek exit, Greece exiting the euro, and of course that Greece exiting the euro would have immediate cascading effects on other countries, a domino effect that was indeed already felt in countries like Ireland or Portugal. But let us not forget. Spain was also under very heavy pressure and Italy too. We were on the edge of the abyss. I remember well what happened in discussions in the margins of the G20 in Cannes in 2011. I remember well when the analysts were almost unanimously predicting a Greek exit and at least 50% of them were predicting the implosion of the euro. And what happened? Not only was there no exit from the euro: now we are going to welcome the 19th member of the euro and Lithuania will join us on 1 January 2015. Not only did Greece not leave the euro: the euro area has enlarged and the European Union has been enlarging as well. That is a point which I think is very much underestimated in our analysis. In 2004, the year I had the pleasure and the honour of assuming the leadership of the Commission, do you remember how many we were? We were 15. Today we are 28 countries, so we have almost doubled the membership of the European Union during all these crises. Is there a better proof of our Union’s resilience and capacity to adapt? I think the fact that we were able to remain united and open during the crisis confirms the extraordinary resilience and strength of the European Union. This should not be underestimated. I know that for some this does not count for much. In a way they are idealising the past. They probably dream of a cosy Europe. They think Europe was better when half of Europe was under totalitarian Communism. I do not think that. I think Europe today is better than when half of Europe was under Communism. (Applause) I think that the fact that, even during all these crises, the European Union was able to open, consolidate and unite on a continental scale almost the whole of Europe around the values of peace, freedom and justice is a great thing. We should commemorate it and not be ashamed of it as some seem to be. I think this is also a reason to commemorate. Many people predicted – like those of you who were following these issues at that time – that the Commission would not be able to function and that it would be impossible. They were saying that at 25, 27 or 28 the European Union would be blocked. The reality is that the European Union was not blocked by the enlargement. I can share the reality with you now. Sometimes it was more difficult to put together some of the core members of the Union than all the 28 countries of Europe. So I think we should be proud of that as well – collectively – because the European Union was able to remain united and open during the crisis.
