When I say open I mean it in all senses, including having an open attitude towards the world. For instance, after the failure of the Doha Development Round and the global trade talks, we promoted a proactive trade agenda and we are now leading in that sense. I believe that trade can be one of the best ways to support growth globally and in the European Union. We – because it was the initiative of the European Union – went to the United States, to the former President of the United States of America, inviting him – indeed, convincing him – to organise the first G20 meeting at Head of State and Government level because that was a means of taking a cooperative global approach and avoiding a return to ugly and nasty protectionism, which could be a temptation in times of crisis. We were able to keep Europe not only united and in fact enlarging its membership, but also open to the rest of the world.  But now we can ask, are we stronger or weaker? I know that most people today, on the critical side, will say that we are weaker. But are we really? In fact, when the crisis erupted, we had almost no instruments with which to respond to it. We were facing – as was said at that time – an unprecedented crisis. For instance, we had no mechanisms to support the countries facing the immediate threat of default. What did we do? We collectively – the Commission and Member States, and always with the strong support of the Parliament, I have to say – created a new system of governance. Today we have a much stronger governance system than before, including with unprecedented powers for the Community institutions. We have done everything to keep the Community method at the centre of our integration. For instance, the Commission today has more powers, in terms of governance of the eurozone, than before the crisis. The European Central Bank today has the possibility to directly supervise the banks in Europe, something that would have been considered impossible, almost unimaginable, before the crisis. I remember, when we spoke about banking union and when I gave an interview saying that we need a banking union, I received some phone calls from capitals asking ‘why are you speaking about banking union? This is not in the Treaties’. I responded that it was not in the Treaties, but that we needed it if we wanted to fulfil the objectives of the Treaties, namely the objective of stability for growth – and today we have a banking union.  So, if we look at things in perspective and we think where we were ten years ago compared to where we are now, we can say with full rigour and in complete observance of the truth that today the European Union, at least in the euro area, is more integrated, has reinforced its competence and that we now have, through the Community method, more ways to tackle crises, particularly in the eurozone. Not only the system of governance in the banking union, but  legislation on financial stability, financial regulation and financial supervision that we have presented – around 30 new pieces of legislation that were all approved by the Parliament. Once again I want to thank you, because in almost all those debates Parliament and the Commission were on the same side of the debate for more ambition – not less – for Europe. So today I can say that we are stronger because we have a more integrated system of governance, we have legislation to tackle abuses in the financial markets and we have a much clearer system of supervision and regulation.  I think we are now better prepared than we were before to face crisis, if crises like the ones we have seen come in the future. Of course you can say, ‘but there are still many difficulties’. Yes, and I am going to say a word about this in a moment, regarding the prospects for growth, but please do not forget where we were. We were very close to the default – a less polite word would be bankruptcy – of some of our Member States, and look at where we are now. Out of the countries that had to ask for adjustment programmes, Portugal and Ireland have exited the problem successfully – Ireland is now one of the fastest growing countries in Europe – and in fact all the others that were under the imminent threat of collapsing are now in a much more stable mood. Spain has asked for a programme for its banks to also exit the programme successfully. So in fact only two countries out of all those – because we should not forget that the Central and Eastern European countries also had adjustment programmes even if they were not yet in the EU area – are still completing their adjustment programmes. On average, the deficits now in the eurozone are 2.5. This is much less than in the United States or Japan. In terms of stability, we are much better now than before.  The eurozone has a trade surplus. In the European Union in general we now we have a surplus in goods, in services and, for the first time in many years, in agriculture. I am saying that because very often the opinion in some political sectors is that we are losing with globalisation. This is not the case. Some countries in our Union are in fact not winning that battle but, on average, you can say that Europe is winning the global battle in terms of competition, namely in terms of trade and investment.  Of course, growth is still timid. I think that basically we cannot say that it is completely done, because threats remain. But we have won the battle of stability. Today nobody in the world will honestly bet on the end of the euro. The euro has shown that it is a very strong, credible and indeed stable currency. The reality is that our growth is still timid and clearly below expectations.  So what can we do for growth? This is the important question. For that I need to make a reminder, once again. I know very well that very often European Union policy, and mainly Commission policy, has been presented as completely focussed on austerity. I think this is a caricature. We have constantly asked at least for three important lines: fiscal consolidation, certainly, for the countries that were feeling the pressure of the markets – and it would be completely irresponsible if they could not frontload a programme of rigour to correct their poor finances – but we have always insisted with equal vigour, although probably some would not like to listen, on the need for structural reforms, for competitiveness, because the reality is that even before the crisis we were growing beneath our potential.  That is the reality: there were serious problems of lack of competitiveness in some of our countries, so that is why we did more ambitious structural reforms, but we have always argued in favour of investment. I have always said that what we need for Europe is more investment – public and private investment. Private investment will come, the more we can show that we have competitive economies and that we can attract private investment. Indeed, I am very happy to see that most of our countries, certainly at different paces, are pursuing ambitious structural reforms; strict reforms which would have been considered completely impossible before the crisis. The reality is, if we want to be honest in terms of analysis, that the countries that have suffered the most during the financial crisis were precisely those which had lost in terms of cost competitiveness before the crisis.  For instance, the reforms that have been made by Spain, by Ireland, by Portugal and by Greece are impressive and confidence is coming back precisely because of that. Apart from the fiscal consolidation and the structural reforms, we have always signalled the need for more investment: private investment, but public investment as well. You remember the debate about the MFF? President Schulz remembers, certainly. We were together in many meetings, asking the Member States to do more in terms of investment and the most important instrument we have had at European level for investment is the Multiannual Financial Framework, which is around one trillion euros. If there is not more ambitious investment, it was not because of the lack of ambition of this Commission or lack of ambition of this Parliament, it was because of the opposition of some capitals.  This is the reality: we are for solid investment, targeting investment for growth. This is the reality. Not only with the MFF. Remember the proposals that, for instance, I put forward here in the State of the Union speeches with you, the increase of capital for the EIB that was finally agreed? The project bonds that the Member States accepted but, oh yes, as pilot project bonds; the facility that we have created for SMEs with loans from the EIB and structural funds from our budget – unfortunately only two countries wanted to go along those lines. Or, for instance, the programme for a Youth Guarantee that we proposed and the Member States agreed on, but now with the Youth Employment Initiative only two countries have accepted a dedicated programme for youth employment. So, my dear colleagues, let us be clear that we are for investment. I wish all the best to the new Commission and to my friend and colleague, Jean-Claude Juncker, that they may have the support of the Member States for a more ambitious investment programme over the next years. I believe it is possible now. I believe there is much greater awareness today on this matter. But once again, this is part of a comprehensive strategy combining fiscal consolidation with structural reforms and investment and, of course, all the measures taken by us in terms of banking union and financial regulation for stability. This is the way, and I am saying that with vigour because I think it will be our mistake, after everything we have done, to give up, to show less determination, to abandon the road of structural reforms.  I think basically we have done a part of the job: stability is broadly there, so is growth, even if it is lower than we would have liked, but now we need the determination to complete the reforms, so that we have sustainable growth, not growth fuelled by debt, excessive public debt or excessive private debt, because this debt is artificial. It is a fictional debt and sooner or later we are going to pay the price. But sustainable growth: that I believe is possible, if we continue the courageous path of reforms and stronger governance for the European Union. I have not the time, because I respect this Parliament very much and certainly I admire your patience, to now go into all the other policies we have been developing over the years. But just let me now highlight one or two, because I think they are very much at the point of decision now, and this is important. I am extremely proud that it was my Commission in my first mandate in 2007 that put forward the most ambitious programme for climate protection in the world and that we are still leading in the world in terms of the climate agenda. In fact, we were able to join the climate agenda with the energy security agenda. I am saying this because this week we are going to have an important discussion in Brussels at Heads of State and Government level and I hope that the European Union will keep its leadership role. Not, of course, to be isolated but to be with others, because we have a responsibility towards our planet. Certainly, one of the great advances of these years is that the European Union was able to make the most important bold steps in terms of fighting climate change.  Another area where I think we could be very proud is that, in spite of all the restrictions because of the financial situation, it was possible in the MFF to get 30% more for Horizon 2020 for research and technology. I think there is a great situation now, with great opportunities for us to do more in that area, and also on the cultural side with our programme Europe Creative. So the reality is that in some areas it was possible, in spite of the economic and financial crisis, to increase investment at European level.  I am also very proud that in spite of the pressures of our budgets, we could always be there in terms of development aid and a policy for our neighbourhood. Whenever there was a big tragedy in the world, from the tsunami in Indonesia and now to the Ebola crisis, from the Syrian refugee crisis to Darfur, we were there. We were among the first.  I think we Europeans should also be proud of that, because together with our Member States, the European Union is still the most important donor for development aid in the world. That is something that corresponds very much to our values and I am happy that in spite of all the crises we did not abandon our obligations in terms of development cooperation.  I have already said a word about trade. I think it is very important to keep an ambitious trade agenda, an open Europe, but for free and fair trade. The Commission has concluded a record number of agreements, with South Korea, Singapore, Central America – the first region to reach an agreement – Peru, Ecuador, recently with Canada, recently with Western Africa, Eastern Africa and Southern Africa, and I could also mention some others that are not progressing like Japan, United States and an investment agreement with China. So we are the most important trade bloc in the world. We are the biggest economy in the world. I am saying that because today I know it is very fashionable to be pessimistic and defeatist about Europe – what I call the intellectual glimmer of pessimism – but I believe that we have a good record to show and I believe that together, collectively, we are much stronger and we can better defend our interests and protect our values. Dear colleagues – I call you colleagues because I believe we have sometimes been through discussions but we have been colleagues in this great enterprise, this European project – I think politically we have some lessons to draw. One is that we have shown great resilience. I think we can say that the forces of integration are stronger than the forces of disintegration. I believe that, day and night, sometimes in very dramatic moments, sometimes when I have to make dramatic appeals to some capitals, to the richer countries, asking them to show more solidarity, or to the poorer countries asking them to show more responsibility. Sometimes we have done it very discreetly, it is true. The European Commission is probably more discreet than others. I did not want the Commission to be part of the cacophony of different voices during the most acute moments of the crisis. It was extremely market-sensitive, that situation. But I can tell you, in my full conscience, that we have done everything we could with existing instruments to avoid the fragmentation of the euro and to avoid division in the European Union. I very often had to call on my colleagues in the European Council, Heads of State and Government, to show the ethics of European responsibility. But one of the lessons I draw from this is that, in the end, it was possible to come to decisions. It is true that it was sometimes extremely painful and difficult and took time, and we have also said – and I think it is something we can all agree on – that democracy is slower than the markets. So the Commission would have preferred, and I am sure this Parliament as well, for decisions to be bolder, more comprehensive and faster, but we are a union of democratic states, we are not a super-state, and we have to respect different sensitivities. One of the conclusions I draw from these 10 years of experience is the need to cooperate between institutions. I know sometimes it is more popular to put forward impossible ideas and criticise others, but I firmly believe that we need to engage with different institutions and that it is not a solution to put countries in opposition to the European Union. On the contrary, we have to show our countries that they are stronger if they are part of the European Union; that we are not diluting their national identity but on the contrary that we are asking them to share their sovereignty so that they can better project their interests globally. I am fully convinced of this. I am saying this to you now. I am leaving in some days, and my only interest is that these lessons be learned, so that we do not repeat the same mistakes in the future. At the same time I think we can say that it is not through confrontation, but through cooperation that we can attain the objectives. At the moment I am preparing to hand over this very challenging and interesting job to my good friend, Jean-Claude Juncker. I want to say here, on behalf of myself and all my colleagues at the Commission, that we wish the new Commission all the best. They have, of course, a great challenge ahead of them, but they can also count on our support and I am sure on the support that this Parliament is going to give to them.  Mr President, relations were not always perfect but I think you can agree that we were able to establish a cooperative relationship between Parliament and the Commission. I have been to this Parliament over 100 times. No Commission was ever so often in Parliament as my two Commissions. We have established this cooperation and I am so grateful, because this Parliament sometimes has very – shall we say – strong demands, but it has always supported the Community method. It always supported the Community institutions and I believe this is very important for the future of Europe. My dear colleagues of the European project, the way to solve the problems we have in Europe is not through revolution and even less through counter revolution. It is by compromise, it is by reform: evolution and reform. We have to reform to adapt to new challenges, but not with new clashes between the institutions, not with clashes amongst our countries. I believe that if this idea of strong cooperation, of putting the European common good first, is pursued, then my colleague and friend, Jean-Claude Juncker, and his new Commission will have success – based, of course, on the support that I am sure you are going to give them. Because – and this is my last time and also my last comment – the European Union is a Union of values. In these last days I have had to face many journalists and they have asked me, ‘What was your most emotional moment? Which moment did you prefer?’ I have many. I also had very difficult ones, to be honest. But one of my most emotional moments was when, on behalf of the European Union, together with Martin Schulz and with the President of the European Council, Herman Van Rompuy, we received the Nobel Peace Prize for the European Union. (Applause) I think this was a powerful reminder, sent to us from the global community, that we count in the world and that what we do is very important; that the values that were at the origin of the creation of our Union, namely the values of peace, are still of the essence today and that we have to fight for them. This is the moment I really said I want to share with all those in the different institutions, including this Parliament, who have been working for a united, open and stronger Europe. When I leave this office, with all my colleagues from the Commission, I can tell you we have not achieved everything we could or everything we would have liked to have achieved, but I think we have worked with the right conscience, putting the global interests of the European Union above specific interests, and I believe that now there are conditions to continue working for a united, open and stronger Europe.  Thank you for your attention. Auf wiedersehen! Goodbye! Au revoir! Adeus, muito obrigado! (Sustained applause)

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, President of the Commission, Commissioners, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioners for their excellent work and for the work she has done. It is a week of decisions for the European Union: tomorrow a new Commission and today the day of farewell to the members with whom we, as parliamentarians, have been able to work for the last few years. That is why I am pleased that my group is present and that we are celebrating this day with dignity today. As chairman of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, I would like to thank the President of the Commission, but also all the other Commissioners who have contributed their work, their convictions and their enthusiasm for our common cause over the last five years. Thank you very much! (Applause) José Manuel Barroso has looked back on 10 years. If I may start in person, I would like to point out that ten years ago I was a newly elected Member of this Parliament. In these years, I have come to know the then newly elected President of the Commission as a convinced, strong European who puts his full effort into his cause, who is the driving force, who is the driving force, who has respect for us, the European Chamber, the European Parliament, and who, above all, is a human being, who talks to everyone, who is approached by everyone, whether officials or not. In this respect, we have had a good President of the Commission who has done his job. The record is impressive. We have heard some data today from José Manuel Barroso. The start at the beginning, the chance, the question of whether this will work with the enlargement to the east, with the reunification of Europe, will work in everyday life – it has worked. The constitutional debate that has made Europe more democratic. This year, we were able to implement the concept of the leading candidates on the basis of the Treaty of Lisbon, to make Europe even more democratic. Europe is at the forefront of climate protection. We do not need to hide at a global level. Then, in the second period of the Barroso term of office, the euro and financial crisis. Before the crisis, the eurozone states were alone in a storm of markets. Today we have the solidarity of the ESM. Before the crisis, debt-based growth was the center of this continent, and today we have more sustainable budgets. Before the crisis, unregulated financial markets were active, today we have a banking union and a strong European banking supervision. I would like to state explicitly that these crises that we have experienced were not, in fact, crises of the European Union, but mainly crises of the Member States, because mistakes have been made there at national level. The framework described by José Manuel Barroso was to solve the problem: stop making debt, instead strengthening competitiveness and investing more. The rescue route was right. This must be emphasised time and again. Ireland, Spain, Portugal are back in the markets, governance has been strengthened, and with Slovenia 2007, Cyprus 2008, Malta 2008, Slovakia 2009, Estonia 2011 and 2014 Latvia have adopted many new Member States as their currency. This shows, God knows, success. Some might sometimes have wished for a louder, more aggressive, more pointed President of the Commission in the public debate, even when it came to calling the national Member States to the rafters. I say to these critics: dear friends, in the most existential crisis that we as Europeans have experienced since the Second World War, the better way to work together, to make honest work, to approach each other, to work out the team approach, is probably the better way. Maybe less showmaster and a little more substantial work, that's, I think, the right approach. There are many other areas that could be mentioned that are important. I am thinking only of police cooperation, because I myself was allowed to work in this area. In recent years, we have made Europe safer for the citizens of this continent – and many other points. The coronation was certainly the Nobel Peace Prize in 2012, the speech in Oslo in which our President of the Commission described the history of our continent since the Second World War, and I quote it: 'Peace is not the absence of war, but peace is a virtue and a state of mind!' Barroso reminded us all of the minds of Europeans. We can also be grateful for that. The record is impressive, and if I were to conclude by summarising it, I would summarise the main message that Barroso and his term of office leave us with the message: we Europeans can do it. We Europeans can do that. If we have the courage, if we are creative, if we stick together, then we can use the storms of fate that the future will also give us. Serenity and courage. I would like to express my sincere thanks on behalf of the entire Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats. (Applause)

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: On behalf of the Group of the Party of European People's Party (S&D). – Mr Barroso, I am sure you will appreciate the frankness with which I address you today. Mine will not be a form intervention, it would not deserve his intelligence, nor the correctness and seriousness that he has always shown. I will tell you quite frankly that my group's assessment of your Commission is a critical one. In this very House, ten years ago, you rightly called on us – and I will use your words – not to lower our guard in the face of the apathy and scepticism that affect European democracy. We share together, he said, an awareness of populist threats, we must not give them new arguments. Ten years later, our continent is plunged into unemployment, and I am sorry that you did not mention this word, which indicates the worst scourge we are experiencing today, the lack of work, and deflation will fade hope into the European dream, and the anti-European movements have never been as strong as they are today. Of course, I am well aware that there are internal and external causal factors that do not take account of your choice. I am well aware of this, but we must be honest in admitting that there have also been serious mistakes in economic policy. The original sin is called austerity, in the name of an ideological vision, investment has been reduced, productive expenditure has been cut, thus preventing Member States from betting on their future, from completing the necessary transition to the knowledge society, and now we are sick. Let's face it! Paradigmatic is the story of Greece, a country that is all too often forgotten, but which is the mirror of European unease. Greece suddenly realised in 2010 that Greece's accounts were not reliable. No one wants to deny the responsibilities of that country, but an attempt has been made to force the Greeks to put the accounts in order and this has not been achieved, but on the other hand Greek society has been debunked.  And also on the Stability Pact: stability and never growth have been insisted on, whereas this is a stability and growth pact. The two pillars must be kept together. I agree with Mr Weber that we must not give up budgetary discipline but at the same time increase growth and create new jobs, whereas in recent years we have focused only on the first pillar.  I do not want to underestimate the important things that your Commission has done: I am thinking, for example, of the fight against climate change, I am thinking of financial regulation, I am thinking of trade policy, I am thinking of the launch of an industrial policy, I am thinking of the rigour of competition, competition policy, and the boost to the European internal market. I would like to reiterate to you, Mr Barroso, to all your Commissioners, our esteem and recognition of the personal commitment that you and your fellow Commissioners have made. Unfortunately, this was not enough, and now we need a change of pace to save Europe before it is too late.

name: Syed KAMALL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. –  Mr President, the European Conservative Reformists are a Group that prefers to look forward, not back to the past. While my Group has not always seen eye-to-eye with Mr Barroso on a number of different issues, with his Commission there have been times when we have been able to find common ground. So, Mr Barroso, as you look forward to your next role may I, on behalf of our Group, wish you all the best and your Commissioners all the best for the future.   As you yourself said, your Commission has been a Commission of crises, not all of them your fault. Your first term began with an institutional crisis, after the French and the Dutch voted to reject the European Constitution. But instead of listening to the very real concerns expressed by voters in two of the founding Member States, instead of lifting your eyes from the institutional navel gazing, the Commission resurrected and repackaged the Constitution as the Lisbon Treaty, under a new guise. Your second term was marked by a financial crisis and a banking crisis and then a currency crisis and a debt crisis. These changed the political agenda and consumed much time and energy. But despite a slew of financial regulation over the last five years, we are still in a position where some banks are considered too big to fail and we have not ended taxpayer bailouts. Given the scale of the eurozone crisis at times, it would have been better if you have could have been more open.  We know you can be open. After all, you have been very open with the British people in the last few days, and in the same way that you have said what you think about freedom of movement, in the same way that you have been clear what membership of the EU entails, will you now be open with the taxpayers of Germany, the Netherlands, Finland and other richer eurozone countries about what euro membership entails?  Will you be open that the only way to sustain the eurozone in the long-term is fiscal transfers from the richer countries to the poorer economies of the eurozone, probably forever? These crises are enormous and are not over and we will have long-term consequences for years to come, but these crises are a symptom of a larger crisis, and that is dealing with global competitiveness. But there are people who are deeply worried about being left behind; left behind as leaders come to Brussels to pursue political integration; left behind as our share of the world economy shrinks; left behind as too many of the political elite look back to the past rather than forward to the future.  At times we have agreed with you on the Services Directive, free trade agreements and measures to pursue the completion of the Single Market. But it is time that we look at how we help businesses grow. Instead of creating more red tape, ask entrepreneurs what stops them from creating new jobs. Instead of environmental targets, ask companies what makes them greener and more environmentally friendly. Instead of rules which ban investors from investing outside the EU, ask them what encourages them to invest in start-ups.  So while I think it is fair to say that your Commission has not always had the chance to look forward, I also think it is fair to say that we hope that the next Commission will be in a position to sometimes take a step back, focus on the bigger picture and face the challenges of the future.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, first of all let me both personally and on behalf of the ALDE Group start by thanking the President of the Commission for all the efforts that he and his colleagues have put in throughout the years.  Mr Barroso, you have described to us today the track record of your Commission – in fact of your two Commissions – and, while it primarily focused on the successes with very little on the self-critical side, I would say that in general on many of the issues one would agree with you. So, once again, I offer you my thanks and appreciation. Let me also say a few words about what might have been missing during the past two periods. It is not easy to evaluate someone from the outside. One cannot fully comprehend and understand some of the bottlenecks and difficulties you are facing – some of the information that an outsider might not have – but it is equally not easy probably for the Commission, and even for the Commission President, to comprehend the serious aspects of the issues that daily life brings to our citizens and the difficulties that we sometimes face.  In this respect, one thing that I would like to highlight – something that I really missed – is a real lack of leadership. You have mentioned a number of issues where you took the lead and where you were in contact with the Member States, but the fact is that the Commission did not always use the power of initiative sufficiently in difficult times. Sometimes the initiatives were insufficient, weak or too late. I would even say that sometimes I felt that the right of initiative lay with the capitals. Sometimes we had the feeling that it was Paris and Berlin highlighting the issues and tabling them, and the Commission was somehow in the shadows. This is one thing that we surely have missed. Secondly, you have said rightly that we succeeded in stabilisation. That is absolutely true. You have contributed to stabilisation, but what we have not sufficiently achieved is that we did not come with growth, with structural reforms and with something that takes courage immediately after the stabilisation. We were weak on some of the policies. You mentioned climate-change policy. I could not agree more: that is important. But on industry, on energy, on the administrative burden – on some of these policies we should have done much more. That is where I would have expected the Commission to take the lead and for the rest to follow, really. I will finish by saying that we did win the battle on stability, but we did not win the battle on reforms, growth, competitiveness or recovery. Sometimes we need less regulation, better regulation, but we need more common policies. This is where I would have expected the Commission to take a much stronger lead.  Having said that, clearly there are policies where you have succeeded. Transport is definitely one of them. I think you had a very strict and very good record on competition policy and on some others. But, all in all, these would be the critical remarks that I would have to make on behalf of the ALDE Group. We could have been more advanced and we could have dealt with some of the challenges that we face in a better way.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, Mr Barroso, to hear you be satisfied with your ten-year record, it is difficult to understand why so many Europeans do not realize that they live in the best of worlds and why they now refuse to vote. In your plea, you talk about yourself, constantly about yourself, but very few of those millions of hard-working people, those who are overwhelmed by unemployment, poverty and austerity every day. In ten years, you have succeeded in making the European idea itself hate, as you have worked hard to deliver the major public sectors to the private sector, to deregulate rail, energy and the post office, and to bring the management of the single currency to the quasi-exclusive service of speculation instead of giving priority to work and productive and ecological investment. Not content with this, you have, together with the States, succeeded in turning private debts into public debts and pushed the audacity to call upon, to settle them, the International Monetary Fund and its shock therapies, whose youths and peoples of Greece, Portugal, Ireland, Spain and now Italy and France are now suffering the consequences with unheard of violence. We were told that the Lisbon Strategy was a resounding failure; Europe 2020 is also. You have refused to include any criteria for social progress and ecological progress in major European decisions. Only recently, you rejected the european minimum income project, the extension of the Maternity Leave Directive and a real positive change in the detached workers directive. Not content with the savage competition of workers and businesses within Europe, you have proposed to expand the field of exploitation with the activation of the project of a large transatlantic market. The future depends on the exit of these austere and regressive choices that lead any European project to a dead end. On the contrary, we must invent a humanist Europe. We must now imagine a policy of social recovery, replacing the relentlessness to bring down the cost of labour by a hunt for the waste of capital and attacks on the environment. To the rigidity of the European Central Bank we should oppose what we have stopped defending here: a new fund for social, human and ecological development and a great cooperative investment plan, otherwise there will be no future for our European project.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, Mr Barroso, you are often portrayed as someone who follows rather than leads. I believe, on the contrary, that you are someone who is capable of deciding and making choices. The first choice I remember seeing you make was in 2003, before you bed president of the Commission. It was when you made the resolute choice to stand with Mr. Bush, Mr. Aznar and Mr. Blair to support the invasion of Iraq, but let's move on! It's ancient history. In your ten years in office, you have made a series of choices and I will point out three. The first was to respond to the crisis, on the one hand, mainly through the troika and, on the other hand, by revising the economic governance of the European Union of modes of action which are both deaf to inequalities, completely insensitive to ecological challenges and completely blind to the demand for democratic legitimacy, all while placing the rights of creditors at a supreme level.  You have also made the choice to refuse to make the bet that the European Union will regain its competitiveness and its ability to create value by deliberately choosing to be, on the planet, the continent that becomes the world champion of sobriety in resources and energy, the only way for us to conquer our strategic autonomy but also our competitiveness in a sustainable way.  Finally, you have chosen not to put an end to the permanent blackmail to which our democracies are subjected, blackmail by financial markets, by financial companies deemed too big to fail and by multinationals to which, through trade agreements, you want to give them rights that would give them legitimacy and sovereignty superior to those of our democracies.  The result of the races: today, 25% of Europeans , a figure I have often mentioned here- or one in four Europeans, are at risk of poverty and social exclusion. That's 4% more than five years ago. Twenty-seven million Europeans are unemployed, unemployed, and I am not talking about the working poor and the underemployment. That's three million more unemployed than five years ago. By the way, where is the growth? If anyone saw her, let him tell me, I did not see her. If someone has also seen a reduction in the public debt, let them tell me, it has eluded me. The result of the races: today, less than a third of our citizens still have confidence in the process of European integration, up from almost half five years ago. This is the result of the races! So it would be a bad trial to tell you that it is your responsibility and your sole responsibility. Everyone knows that this is not true. Nevertheless, Mr Barroso, I would have expected you to show a much stronger initiative to defend this article of the Treaty of the European Union, which reminds us that the Union places solidarity, especially between generations, and social justice at the heart of its project. That is why our citizens today no longer trust Europe, because this part of the treaties has been forgotten.  I would have relied on you as the guardian of the treaties to remind it, including to the heads of state or government and, including, from time to time, to the majority of this Parliament.

name: Nigel FARAGE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President. Well, Mr Barroso, for ten years we have been trading blows in this Parliament, and indeed I am the only person on today’s list of speakers who was involved ten years ago. I have found you – I have to say for the vast majority of that time – to be very civil, but often bemused by what I have had to say and by events in Europe as they have unfolded. In fact, I remember the first speech I gave. You presented your new Commission, and I pointed out to you that your nominee from France, Monsieur Jacques Barrot, was a convicted embezzler who had received a two-year suspended prison sentence and had been barred from public office. To my shock, at that moment you simply showed in your face that you had no idea that it was true, but of course it was. Perhaps that comes from your early days as an active student Maoist, when you believed in big ideas but did not perhaps have much to do with practical reality.  I have enjoyed much of what you have said over the years. Indeed, I particularly enjoyed you the day after Ireland – the only country indeed that had a referendum on the Lisbon Treaty – had voted ‘no’ to Lisbon. You stood up and said that the Irish did not really mean ‘no’. I particularly enjoyed that. I also enjoyed you saying that the European Union was the first ever non-imperial empire, because in that you showed so much of what this project has now become. I do not think that anybody doubts that those who got together in the 1950s after two ruinous world wars with the genuine intention of getting the French and Germans to sit around a table in order to talk together and to trade together were doing the right thing. But it has morphed and changed into something else, and it is your analogy to an empire that has led to the current failure. It is the expansion to allow in more and more countries; it is the expansion of the eurozone to let in Mediterranean countries which should have never have joined in the first place and which are now suffering so horribly. So I view you as a fantasist, but at no point have I ever, ever implied that you were dishonest. You are not. You are very honest indeed. I remember you telling Martin Callanan, who led the Conservative Group here for some time while the Conservative Party under David Cameron’s leadership became more Eurosceptic with each British parliamentary by-election, not to try to be like UKIP because the voters will go for the real thing. And you were right. We won the European elections. But thank you for last Sunday, thank you for appearing on British television, thank you for confirming that the real fantasist is not you – it is David Cameron. The British Prime Minister who pretends that we can restrict free movement and remain members of the European Union. You made it clear that he was wrong and that he was deceiving the British people. You made it clear that you were the boss and not him, and for that I thank you and wish you a very happy retirement indeed.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Barroso, I have heard your speech, I do not want to speak to you as an MEP, but I am speaking to you as mayor. I have a son who is about ten years old; Ten years ago I could tell him that Europe was the future, that Europe could combat unemployment, that Europe could fight the increase in taxes, of expenditure, which was against illegal immigrants, which was for work. What came up? I want to be your report card, because it is your last day as President of the Commission: unemployment has increased, taxes have risen, expenses have increased, the poor have increased, there is no work! Illegal immigrants are everywhere! Diseases have increased! Europe in the world matters less and less! The euro is a currency that, instead of bringing prosperity, is bringing poverty. Is this the result of your Commission?  What do I have to tell my son? That Europe has been a good thing over the last ten years, or do I have to tell it the truth? That is to say, Europe has been a disaster! This is what's happening and I'm mayor, and meeting people, more and more, out of work, without money, not even the money to live, to give something to their children, what should I tell them as mayor? That Europe is helping us? I live in a country, Italy, which is made up of a government in some respects also of invertebrates. I just have to say one thing to thank you for one story: the marò affair, this one, where there are two Italian soldiers hostage to India: you defended them by saying that they should not have the death penalty; I thank you, but if they had been two soldiers from Kiev at this hour they would still be in India? Or would they have already been brought to Europe? I ask you to defend the Europe that must defend our soldiers, because if the Italian Government is unable to do so, Europe must do so. These are two heroes! One is now home for serious health reasons, but the other has been held hostage by the Indians for three years. Let us not be teased, because Europe must pull our balls out, otherwise the world will crush us.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: Mr President, I have a point of order under the Rules of Procedure. The procedure is Chapter 2, Rule 123 in relation to statements by the Commission. It relates to part of paragraph 1 and all of paragraph 2. If the President of the Commission makes a statement, when that statement is placed on the agenda before a debate, it is an option for the Parliament to have a wind-up debate on a resolution. I have such a resolution in my hand. In that resolution, if Parliament decides to wind up a debate with a resolution, there must be a committee or a political group of at least 40 names. I have the signatures of 56 names of Members of this Parliament to present in terms of that resolution. (Applause from certain quarters on the right) The resolution will state that under the presidency of Barroso, the euro has initiated or contributed to the crisis in Europe and contributed with misguided austerity policies ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr Woolfe, I would like to thank Mr Woolfe for his You do not need to read it aloud, that has been understood. (Interjections) What you are asking for here is a change in the agenda. Amendments to the agenda must be submitted by 4 p.m. on Mondays. Furthermore, if I had to vote on a resolution, I would have to set a deadline for amendments, which is obviously impossible. In this respect, your request is inadmissible. I'm sorry. (Interjections)

name: José Manuel Barroso
text: Member of the Commission. Mr President, you have already listened to me with great patience and I will not repeat my arguments. I would just like to answer a few questions from the speakers who have gone before me. First of all, I believe that the proof that the Commission that I had the honour of chairing was on the right track is that the criticisms come from the two extremes of the room and, very often, with the same tone which reveals a refusal to see, categorically, the difficulties and extraordinary challenges we have faced, and the same tendency to give , of course, no coherent response. The truth is that we have probably experienced the greatest economic and financial crisis since the beginning of our European integration, and that it was not the European Union that caused it. It is this truth that some "sovereignists" - to use their expression - do not understand or do not want to understand. Indeed, it is not Europe that has been at the root of excessive private debt and the lack of financial responsibility. On the contrary, it all happened under national supervision - or lack of supervision. Europe is the answer. Now we have one of the most ambitious, if not the most ambitious, regulatory and supervisory systems in the world. To say that Europe is worse because of the European Union is a lie. It is an absolute lack of respect and intellectual rigour. It was not Europe that caused the financial crisis, it was born in the United States. Of course, Europe was vulnerable, but the European Union only reacted, it was not the cause. And all of us who share the European ideal, whether we are from the right, the left or the centre, we must have the courage to say so, otherwise we will strengthen - and this is an opinion I give you when I leave office - the populisms of the extreme left or the extreme right. I have listened attentively to some of you saying "populism is now stronger" and blaming the European Union. My dear friends, this is not true. Populism and xenophobia exist very clearly outside the European Union. Look at what happened in Switzerland, against immigrants; look at what happened in Norway, with this terrorist - a demented man - who killed I don't know how many young people because he is against a multicultural Europe; look at the Tea Party in the United States. Is it Europe's fault, the existence of the Tea Party in the United States? In today's world, there is aggressive populism, sometimes with left-wing arguments, sometimes right-wing arguments, and it is difficult, I must admit, to tell the difference.  Therefore, to say that this is the result of the European Union is a lack of intellectual rigour as well as a lack of political honesty.  What we as Europeans need to do is to show precisely that it was not Europe that created the crisis, or even the public debts of the Member States. Europe cannot do much when a Member State, for example, falsifies its accounts. Europe has had to deal with that. The first initiative of my second Commission was to ask the Member States to give us more supervisory power over national statistics, because in the first Commission I chaired, this was refused. This was not refused by Greece, it was rejected by the large Member States who did not want to give more responsibility to the European Union. Therefore, if we really want to debate, let us be precise and be rigorous in terms of intellectual honesty and political rigour.  That's why, dear friends, I'm not going to waste your time. However, I would like to say something with great conviction. The team that I have had the honour of chairing has worked - and I now see some of you in this Parliament, and they know this well - with great dedication and rigour, always making the European interest a priority and I want to tell you, since we are an assembly of different political forces, always making the idea of the European common good the priority.  It was not colleagues from the EPP group, socialists or liberals who made up my Commission, they were men and women who worked for Europe. You know what my party is: it is the party of the EPP and I am proud of it. But as President of the Commission, my party has been Europe. This is a message that I would like to share with you, especially with the great forces of the pro-European centre-left and centre-right. Of course, differences must be expressed, but they must not weaken the European camp. Don't give more gifts to the far right and the far left. The pro-European forces must unite. They must have the courage to defend Europe. They must also do so in the capitals and not simply here in Strasbourg. We must be able to have this grand coalition for Europe because I believe that we have the energy to win the battles of the present and the battle of the future.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Thank you, President Barroso. Ladies and gentlemen! Before we conclude the debate, allow me to say a word to you, Mr President, and to the Members of the Commission. Mr Barroso, first of all to you personally. As chairman of a parliamentary group, I have been with you for seven and a half years, with more emphasis on beatings. I was president of a European institution with you for two and a half years. At the end of this debate, on behalf of this institution, without prejudice to all the differences that logically exist between Parliament and the Commission, I would like to say one thing to you, regardless of what is going on in terms of content: anyone who invests ten years of his life in European politics in the form you have done – I have seen it closely – can only be thanked for the enormous amount of effort that has been put into European policy. , which you have also personally put into your idea of Europe. As President of the other institution, I would like to say this explicitly with great respect and great recognition. (Applause) This also applies to the members of your Commission, who are here in large numbers, almost entirely, I believe. I would also like to thank you for your work, without prejudice to any differences that exist on the substance. A job that is not easy, a work that is often unfairly reviled. This is also a piece of responsibility for the policies of others, because the scapegoating function in the European Union works relatively well. Success is national, and failure is often assigned to the European institutions, including you as the Commission. That is not fair. However, it is therefore fair to thank you from the heart for your commitment at the end of your term of office. I would also like to do this on behalf of our institution. (Applause) Perhaps a point of order. The ladies and gentlemen who have now left the Chamber should perhaps know one thing for the future: the agenda will be set on Mondays. The motion that has been tabled here was a request to amend the agenda. It is also possible to table amendments to the agenda at nine o'clock in the morning on the day of the sitting. But then the President's approval is needed. As a rule, I give my assent to such requests. You cannot change the agenda in the middle of the agenda. I believe that this is understandable for anyone who has a minimum of parliamentary understanding. In that respect, that request was visibly inadmissible and also unfounded. Incidentally, the Conference of Presidents decides first of all on changes in the agenda and on the conduct of the meetings themselves. The heated process here was determined by the Conference of Presidents, by the way, unanimously. In this respect, this request was surprising.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Mr. President! You have misrepresented the intentions of the applicants. The resolution that has been tabled was a resolution on the existing item on the agenda. And that is a right provided for in Parliament's Rules of Procedure. (The President: When was the resolution tabled?) This resolution is signed. Mr Woolfe had it in his hand. You could have had it available, and he told you exactly what provision of Parliament's rules he was referring to. You cannot iron that out by saying that it is a change in the agenda. No amendment to the agenda has been requested, but a resolution should be tabled on this item. The right to do so is enshrined in Parliament's rules. You have violated these rules here, Mr President!

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Honourable Member, thank you very much. You are a new Member of this House. That is why, as I have already told you, I am looking at your mistakes. (Laughter) The agenda is set and it is decided when the agenda is set whether there is a debate with a resolution or without a resolution. This debate was explicitly without a resolution. In this respect, the request for debate with a resolution could have been tabled either last Monday or this morning. Incidentally, I believe that this is a minimum of understanding: if you hand-write a resolution during an ongoing debate, which you then submit here, I myself am not in a position to make it available to all Members within such a short period of time, but that is a minimum right of a Parliament that all Members can look at a resolution in advance. I actually assumed that they would have known. The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. – During Mr Barroso’s term of office yet more powers have been transferred from nation states to the EU. I would like to highlight one particular area which is both topical and highly dangerous and concerns Europol, the EU's emergent police force. In a recent BBC radio interview, Mr Troels Oerting, the head of Europol’s Cybercrime Centre, revealed that ‘most of the world’s cybercrime originates from Russia’, that he is ‘increasingly happy’ with Europol’s ‘cooperation’ with Russia’s ‘law-enforcement authorities’, and that he recently visited Moscow and agreed to share information with them on a number of ‘interesting cases’. This is an extraordinary statement given that in Russia it is impossible to distinguish between organised crime and the so-called law enforcement agencies. Meanwhile, a respected internet security company iSIGHT has uncovered a massive Russian cyber-espionage campaign against Western governments and NATO. This is at a time when the British Parliament is on the verge of voting to permanently transfer yet more powers to the EU on policing and criminal justice matters. It is utter madness to share sensitive information with Russia, which is a gangster state, and seriously puts at risk our security and the protection of our citizens.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. – The balance sheet of the last legislature cannot be more negative. For a majority of citizens, Europe has gone from identifying with the idea of solidarity, to doing so with sacrifice. The conservative majority has imposed an ideological approach to the crisis by prioritizing debt reduction and the fiscal deficit over growth and employment. The European Union is the world's economic zone with the greatest impact of the employment crisis. It has cost us the loss of more than 2.5 million jobs. Inequality, poverty and social exclusion have been triggered. Austerity has failed in Europe. While Obama bet on stimulus policies. The United States grows and creates more than 8 million jobs. Now, we face the threat of a third recession. But the promoters of austerity continue to bet on suffering in the face of growth. As a result, citizens move away from Europe because Europe has moved away from them. And populism grows by threatening Europe's very idea. The new Commission has the opportunity and the obligation to correct course. There probably won't be another one.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. – Mr Barroso may claim, in his defence, that he had to weather the worst crisis in the history of the European Union, but he never acknowledged that the financial crisis was brought about by the same kind of policies he spearheaded, and which in turn made it escalate into a destructive economic crisis across the continent. Acting at the behest of the majority of the conservative governments that appointed him, Mr Barroso consistently let selfish national interests and priorities run over the common interests of European citizens. Incredibly, he claims to have increased the power of the Commission. Mr Barroso chose to run to the virtually unconditional rescue of the financial sector and its creditors, at the expense of the needs of their victims. He chose to ignore how the architecture of the common currency facilitated and exacerbated the crisis, especially in smaller, peripheral countries. Even when he took the first steps to address those flaws, he went down a moralising path that served conservative interests and divided Member States, punishing vulnerable citizens with loss of disposable income, public services and welfare entitlements. Mr Barroso’s sorry legacy should be repudiated.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. –  When I look back at the Barroso II Commission there are notable positive features such as efforts in combatting child abuse and child pornography online. Another positive was the introduction of incentives to increase the number of women in the IT industry.  Others, however, are too negative to counterbalance these. Tragedies in the Mediterranean led the EU to create task forces, adopt packages and organise countless debates – but regardless of all this we had more immigrants dying in the Mediterranean, and more EU citizens feeling disproportionate pressures. We still live in a Union were 75% of asylum applications are processed in only 6 out of 28 Member States.  The Barroso II Commission owed an obligation to its citizens to prepare itself for when the recession hit – but it did not. Millions, particularly young people, are still unemployed while rising austerity measures and an increase in financial debt have left 120 million Europeans at risk of poverty and social exclusion. Most worrying of all is that during the last Commission’s mandate the EU failed to connect to its citizens. I sincerely hope that the new Commission manages to learn from these mistakes and makes a true difference for our citizens.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. – Barroso's ten years as President of the European Commission are the most disaved from the statements made ten years ago – and repeated five years ago – about the importance for Portugal of having a Portuguese in the presidency of the European Commission. All the decisions, all the nuclear policies adopted during this period, all the most relevant legislative proposals of the European Commission have proved negative for our country and our people – as well as for the peoples of the other countries of the European Union. Legislation on Economic and Monetary Union - economic governance, European semester; common policies - CAP, trade policy, fisheries policy; Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020: in all this Portugal lost and lost a lot. The EU-ECB-IMF troika's intervention programme is of particular emphasis. A programme which – as we warned then – has not solved any of the country's problems, on the contrary, has aggravated them all. Portugal is today a poorer, more unfair, more unequal, more dependent and less sovereign country. It also owes it to this European Commission. Unsustainable levels of inequality; dismantling of the social functions of the State; degradation of living and working conditions, unemployment, poverty; favouring the major powers and their major economic groups. This is, in three lines, the balance sheet of the Barroso Commission.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. Barroso violated democracy by imposing the Lisbon Treaty on the French people; the law by saving the euro in defiance of the treaties; and our values by starving people. Terrible oligarch's record.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: , in writing. – The outgoing President of the European Commission, José Manuel Duro Barroso, has made his balance sheet and farewell speech at the Eurochamber without even mentioning the unemployment that now affects Europe, especially countries such as Greece and Spain. This is the main reflection of a decade in which a European Commission, which should have devoted its main efforts to creating occupation and combating the crisis through public growth and investment policies, has been often missed. However, in recent years, the European Commission has focused its efforts on implementing the prescriptions that States and heads of government were imposing from the European Council, blurring the European Commission's capacity for action and reaction. Today, we are faced with an EU that must urgently change course to restore hope to a European dream that has been abducted by the rise of populism and the far right and because of the devastating effects of the crisis and austericide policies that have led to the high level of unemployment and the impoverishment of European families.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: in writing. – The Barroso Commission's mandate has been through a constitutional, geo-political and financial crisis. The constitutional crisis was resolved by the Treaty of Lisbon. The geo-political crisis remains to be resolved. An important step was taken by ratifying the association treaty with Ukraine, but the next Commission will have to finalize the agreement with Moldova. The financial crisis has been a difficult time for Member States: the Barroso Commission has proposed several legislative packages to achieve a balance of fiscal responsibility, to gain access to the European Single Market and has initiated deep structural reform in the countries concerned. A banking union has been created. As a result, the financial sector is equipped to supervise banks.  The Barroso Commission has drawn up a long-term plan for modernising the European economy. Multiannual programmes will aim to improve competitiveness by focusing on research, innovation and infrastructure development. It has ensured that Horizon 2020 is Europe's largest research programme and has been provided with an EU budget 30% higher than the previous programme. It is wanted to connect Europe in transport, energy and the digital sectors. All these 2020 targets, agreed by the previous Commission, will establish a framework for competitiveness, sustainability and security in the EU.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: , written.- Five years of Barroso's II Commission have passed primarily in the sign of the economic and financial crisis. This resulted, inter alia, in an increased concentration of power in the hands of the Commission, which has largely followed the corporate agenda. Some of the key legislative proposals have been abolished, without adequate explanation of the reasons for their withdrawal.  European policy remained one-sided and continued to emphasise the market and left social and employment policies behind. You started your second term with an economic downturn and you end it with economic stagnation, record low inflation and announcements of another downturn. The mandate was certainly marked by transparency issues.  The Commission's absence from the transparency report in the EU institutions and the fact that almost 2/3 of the lobby groups concerning the financial sector are not registered undermine the already low trust of citizens. Transparent entry into an EU institution's building does not guarantee both transparency and protection against abuse of office. I hope that a poor assessment of your economic and political "results" will be a good signpost to the new Commission not to repeat the same mistakes.

text: in writing. –  During Mr Barroso’s term of office yet more power has been transferred from nation states to the EU. name: Richard SULÍK
text: , in writing.– I consider the Second European Commission, led by José Manuel Barroso, to be a major failure. The failures of this Commission could be seen from the outset. About a week after the official launch of the second Barroso Commission, on 1 December 2009, the Treaty of Lisbon was approved. However, already at the beginning of May 2010, just half a year later, aid was approved to Greece, in direct breach of the newly approved Treaty of Lisbon. Shortly afterwards, the violation of the Treaty of Lisbon reached systemic level, as it was first created temporary euro (EFSF) and later permanent euro (ESM). Systematic violations of the rules by the Barroso-led European Union were not the only negative of this European Commission. Of the 27 Euro-Commissioners at the beginning of her term of office, at least 10 had a communist past, or communist ideas are not rejected at present. Similarly, the response of the second Barroso Commission to the crisis was very unfortunate. The European Union has continued to push for more of the same, which has caused the current crisis – the redistribution of taxpayers' money and the issuing of a number of harmful regulations. As a result, too, today Barroso leaves the European Union budget in a state where up to 4/5 of this budget is used for payments to farmers and cohesion funds, with no prospect of fundamental change.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. — Annex II to Barroso is amended as follows: In difficult circumstances, unlike its original intentions, the Commission operated almost exclusively as a single issue Commission, which was forced to deal with various aspects of economic crisis management. It should be appreciated that it has also taken important and partly effective initiatives that are worthwhile to continue in crisis management (such as tackling youth unemployment). Nevertheless, the serious shortcomings of the approach on which the measures are based and the European economic policy practice that we are experiencing today are the growth and genuinely efficient, quality job creation, as well as the marginalization of european solidarity in the social field. A valuable lesson of recent times is that, if necessary, especially in difficult times of European integration, the Commission should also be able to take more effective action against Member State governments that threaten the community and European construction economically and/or politically.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. Mr Barroso, you did not deserve an honourable farewell. They headed the authority, which, as the "guardian of the Treaties", was not supposed to break EU law. This good intention is now history. Under your leadership, the EU Commission has tolerated the violation of the non-assistance clause and the prohibition of monetary public debt by the ECB and the Member States. This is a clear violation of EU law. Now you have also buckled in the budget dispute with France and Italy. Both national draft budgets for 2015 are seriously in breach of the Euro Stability Pact, either because the deficit is too large (France) or because the debt level is one of the highest in Europe (Italy). In doing so, you have proved that there is either no political will to deal with the euro crisis or that the European Commission has nothing to report. They said: 'EU countries must remain on the reform path with strict union control'. It is good to know how seriously the EU Commission takes this 'strict governance'. The fact that the EU Commission does not, of course, have the right to govern in the budgets of the nation states is completely different.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: (in writing)– Resistance against the wave of anti-European populism in many Member States is the most important achievement of the Barosso Commission in its second term. I believe that this committee has succeeded, despite the hesitations coming from the leaders of the Member States and the syncopes generated by the economic and financial crisis, in avoiding the many trends that have manifested themselves in favour of strengthening the intergovernmental method in the coordination of the EU. In these extremely difficult years, the European Commission has demonstrated its capacity for initiative and leadership, laying new foundations on its collaboration with the EP whose political role and responsibility have increased significantly. If we assess the work of the Barosso Commission, we must look at the whole decade that has passed. Without exhausting the list of results achieved during this period, it should be noted that the EU has gone from 15 members to 28, that the adoption of the Treaty of Lisbon has been successful, and as a result of intense turmoil, another step has been taken towards integration - from the European Single Market, one of the pillars of united Europe, has moved to implementing economic governance. The new EC will have a difficult task, but I am convinced that Jean-Claude Juncker will go further on the path of integrated Europe.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The next item on the agenda are the statements by the Council and the Commission on the preparation of the European Council (23-24 October 2014) (2013/2705 (RSP)).

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Meeting of the European Council scheduled for the end of this week will be exceptional in several respects: it will be the last meeting of the European Council of the first permanent President of the European Council, Mr Van Rompuy. And assuming that Parliament approves the new Commission tomorrow, it will also be the last of the current President of the Commission, Mr Barroso. But it will also be exceptional from the point of view of substance: firstly, the European Council is called upon to reach agreement on the 2030 framework for the European Union's climate and energy policies. I do not need to remind the House of the importance of this issue. It is in the interests of all of us to develop a coherent European climate and energy policy that ensures affordable energy prices, industrial competitiveness, security of supply and the achievement of climate and environmental objectives. It is certainly not an easy goal, if our overall objective is clear, the individual Member States each have their own vision, which reflects a number of factors such as the accessibility of energy sources, their industrial capacity and energy demand and also the different environmental cultures.  This means that the negotiations currently under way to prepare for this week's meeting are complex and represent an important challenge, but we all know how essential it is to ensure an ambitious outcome, not least in view of the role that the European Union wants and must play on the international stage as a world leader. The agreement should be global and the essential point is the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions. The proposal under discussion is an internal emission reduction target of 40% by 2030 compared to 1990 levels. To achieve this, six main chapters have been defined covering the EU-ETS – Emission Trade System – and non-ETS sectors, renewable energy sources and energy efficiency, the creation of a fully functioning internal energy market, energy security and governance.  I will not go into too much detail, as negotiations are still ongoing, while I am speaking to you, the General Affairs Council is discussing these issues as part of the process of preparing for the European Council meeting. The Presidency has worked hard to ensure that an agreement is reached.  A successful outcome of this European Council would allow the European Union to submit a contribution that meets the UNEFCCC's agreed timetable in Warsaw for the conclusion of a comprehensive climate agreement by the first quarter of 2015. The step that our leaders must take is therefore extremely important.  In addition to energy and climate issues, the European Council is called upon to discuss the economic situation. We know that it is fragile and the most recent forecasts remind us that we cannot afford any delay. We managed to overcome the difficulties immediately following the crisis, but now we need to relaunch growth, create jobs and develop competitiveness. Only in this way can we rebuild an adequate level of confidence in our economies. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, let me conclude by mentioning another extremely important issue: the deadly spread of the Ebola virus. You discussed this yesterday in the presence of the Commission. I do not need to tell you that we are in the midst of a serious crisis. We need a global response both internally and externally, which is why it was agreed that the European Council should take stock of the situation and, above all, highlight the strategic actions needed to bring this deadly virus under control.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. - Mr President, I am honoured to be here today to present to you the views of the Commission on the European Council meeting this week. The summit will seek to agree on the 2030 climate and energy framework and discuss the economy and external developments, including Ukraine, and we will also address the Ebola epidemic. Let me start with a few remarks on the economy. This week’s meeting is not one for decisions in this regard. It will be for the new Commission to initiate the new European Semester in a few weeks from now. Throughout the crisis, yes, our comprehensive response has always been built upon the three pillars of fiscal consolidation, structural reforms and targeted investments. This is still valid today. While economic recovery in the EU is still fragile and uneven, we are seeing that the efforts are paying off. Those countries which downturned the most are now better off than those which are lagging behind in addressing the root causes of the crisis.  The reforms to European economic governance have been instrumental in making this progress possible. Together, we have changed the way that Europe’s economies and financial sector are legislated, supervised and regulated. The framework for that has been created. Now we need to stick to it and to fully implement it. This is very important for restoring confidence. Agreeing a new framework on energy and climate policies for the period up to 2030 at this European Council will show how credible we are in transforming our economies and societies towards a low-carbon future. The proposals in our current 2020 framework have been of strategic importance. They have put our Union firmly into a position of global leadership and were widely recognised as a key contributor in the global fight against climate change. Importantly, we came to these agreements by finding the right mix of ambition and realism. By combining two strands – environment and energy – consensus was possible.  There are economic advantages to climate-friendly innovation and investment and an economic case for cost-effective decarbonisation is clearer than ever. We also broadened the scope to include energy security. Recent challenges to our security and the strategic dimension have given energy security concerns even more impetus. Energy security must therefore be part of the climate agenda.  Yet sadly our European climate ambition is far from being matched by the two most important polluters globally – the United States and China. Public opinion in Europe accepted the targets of 20-20-20 by 2020, even if they were aware of the difficulties in implementing them. The EU felt let down when a comprehensive global deal did not happen, despite pressing others to follow suit. But developments afterwards have shown that the Union was and remains on the right side of the argument.  There is now a renewed momentum towards a global, binding climate treaty to be agreed in Paris next year. Agreeing on our own 2030 framework now will set the tone; it would provide our Union with key leverage in a crucial phase of the international negotiations. The Commission’s 2030 proposal from January is the frame of reference for this EU debate. Our proposals are clear, ambitious and balanced, with a 40% emission reduction target at their heart.  The ball is now in the court of the European Council. Leaders must assume their responsibility; we expect difficult discussions but we are confident that a decisive deal is within reach now. The third issue to be discussed at the European Council is the external situation, in particular the conflict between Ukraine and Russia. With the unsettled conflict in Ukraine we realise more than ever that to defend our values and protect our interests, Europe needs to take the lead and be active. We need to continue contributing to a political solution. At the same time, we need to demonstrate that unlawful and uncooperative behaviour brings with it heavy consequences. The situation in Ukraine is a clash of world views that touches the very heart of the European Union, its principles, its values and what it symbolises: freedom, democracy and rule of law. This is why the EU from the start took a principled position against Russia’s illegal annexation of Crimea and the destabilisation in Ukraine’s eastern region. Since then we have done all we could to make the most of a bad situation. The political and peaceful solution of the conflict has always remained our first priority.
