Not any solution, but one that guaranteed the sovereignty, independence and unity of Ukraine. Our relations with our eastern neighbours are not detrimental to relations with the other neighbours. We never sought exclusivity in our relations. In fact, the European Union has invested a lot in the strategic partnership with the Russian Federation, convinced that it is in our common interest to cooperate. Developments are still unfolding. The European Union continues to work for a politically negotiated solution. The Commission has made every effort in this regard by taking the lead in promoting trilateral talks on sensitive issues such as trade and energy. Just today, the Commission is mediating another round of talks on the gas issue.  On the security front, priority needs to be given to full implementation of the Minsk Agreements. This is the basis for restoring and consolidating trust. The ceasefire needs to be respected and verified. Elections in the Donbas need to be held in accordance with Ukrainian law and the border needs to be controlled and monitored. We cannot give up on Ukraine. We cannot give up on reaching a solution. If we do not reach a solution, what would be at risk would be both Ukraine’s independence and also the security, stability and unity of the European continent. We must defend the credibility of a multilateral order based on values, equality and the rule of law.  At the same time, we are greatly concerned by the humanitarian and security situation in Syria and Iraq. It is deteriorating dramatically day by day. The rapid progression of ISIL is alarming. Military action in line with international law is necessary, but it is not enough. It needs to be part of the wider effort, comprising measures in the political and diplomatic, counter-terrorism and terrorism funding, humanitarian and communication fields.  The Commission has been active on the humanitarian part. To date, around EUR 2.9 billion has been mobilised to those in need in Syria and Iraq, but the security situation impacts negatively the delivery of aid. While military intervention will be the key to defeating ISIL, it is imperative not to link the delivery of humanitarian aid to military objectives. Humanitarian access should not be put at risk. Unfortunately, there is yet another crisis which the European Council will have to address, and this is Ebola. The Ebola outbreak is not just a problem for West Africa; it is a challenge for the international community as a whole and Europe has a responsibility to do its part.  The Commission and the Member States have provided assistance to the countries affected and to the humanitarian effort on the ground – more than EUR 600 million already, and it is not just money. Twelve Member States are providing medical and other equipment through the EU civil protection mechanism. But we need to do more to help the affected African countries and also protect our own citizens. The Commission discussed this issue at todayʼs College, and will feed into a discussion at the European Council. This week’s European Council will cover very telling issues as far as the need for European Union unity is concerned: what the European Union is for; what it should do and what challenges it faces. I look forward to hearing your views here today on how we can work together to tackle these challenges. It is with this spirit of cooperation and with the crucial support of this House that Europe must be successful in coping with today’s and tomorrow’s challenges.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, Mr President of the Council, Commissioner, as you have said, the Council which will meet on 23 and 24 October will have to deal with important and highly topical issues. It will decide, among other things, on the objectives to be set for the new climate and energy framework, and it will address the key issues of strengthening energy security, Europe and interconnection needs. Let us make no mistake: our goal is not to wage an ideological war against climate change, which would leave the bruised bodies of our companies and their employees on the battlefield. It is really a question - and I say this forcefully - that Europe is committed to the fight against climate change while maintaining its competitiveness and ensuring its security of supply. The situation in Ukraine is a sufficient reminder of the importance of ensuring the security of our energy sources. Europe faces major challenges: energy prices are high - in some sectors account for up to 40% of production costs - national policies are not sufficiently coherent and the internal energy market is still fragmented. Finally, we have an obligation to move towards a decarbonized economy. In order to respond, we must diversify our sources of supply: renewable energies must be supported until they reach technological maturity. We also need to strengthen energy infrastructure. The interconnection between the Member States will be the key to building a genuine common European energy policy, an energy union, so dear to the new President Jean-Claude Juncker, who has made it one of his priorities. The objectives set by the European Council will be important in informing and guiding the investments of our companies. We need to provide them with a stable environment and visibility. Let's stop constantly changing our goals. I take here the example of the list of sectors exposed to carbon leakage: it should not have led to procrastination and our group, the EPP, has also been able to show its unity on this essential subject. The support of companies, in order to evolve their production method and the use of their resources, must not be a word in the air but a concrete act and a promise to keep. Today, many European industrial sectors are world champions of energy efficiency and emissions reduction. In building construction and transport, the potential for efficiency gains is enormous. On the other hand, carbon capture and storage technologies have not really taken off. Electricity storage must also mobilize us. It alone will make the development of renewable energy credible. Europe cannot lag behind in these key areas. The European Union must therefore strongly and first and foremost support our companies in their research and development efforts. This will enable them to use ever more innovative and less polluting technologies to meet the challenges of sustainable development. In December, at the Lima conference, we will have to engage with our partners with frankness, seriousness and pragmatism. We must not impose our objectives on others because acting unilaterally is not the answer. While the EU is now responsible for only 11% of global CO2 emissions, a share that will fall in the coming years, it cannot take the necessary decisions on its own. Europe must not be the great naiveness of climate negotiations. The Lima conference must therefore be a real preparation phase for the major conference in Paris. In 2015, we do have a good chance of reaching a concerted international agreement that is therefore strong and respected by all. You have mentioned many challenges, Commissioner, and there is an urgent need to solve the Ukrainian problem. There is an urgent need to fight terrorism. There is an urgent need to stem the spread of Ebola. We all need to be determined. As Jean Monnet said, and I conclude, "what is important is not to be optimistic or to be pessimistic, but to be determined." And in the EPP group, on all these issues, we are.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Mr Della Vedova, Mr Katainen, my group would like the next Council not to be a routine five-year end-of-stage council, but to be the beginning of a new stage that would turn european Union policy around. But if we want to take that turn, we have to look at the reality data and not stay blind to all the alarms that are going on. We would have to listen to the avalanche of analysis and recommendations from experts and think tanks and not remain deaf to this analytical coincidence, and we would have to abandon insensitivity about the social consequences of the policies that have been put in place. Looking at the data, we see that the latest OECD and International Monetary Fund reports agree that the growth outlook in the European Union in 2014 and 2015 is not at all optimistic; any perspective is worse than what has occurred before. We also see that, at best, we are in an economic relapse and, at worst, we are entering a third recession. But the intermediate scenario is stagnation, which the Monetary Fund has called "secular stagnation." If we talk about inflation, we see that the best hypothesis is low deflation, and the worst, clear deflation, and that either limits our chances of reducing the deficit and increasing growth. At the same time, we have also not been able to reduce the level of unemployment. In view of this situation, the analyses, the Monetary Fund, the OECD, the think tanks, the German Institute for Economic Studies itself point out that what is happening to us is a consequence of the policies we have been putting in place. What to do about this situation? In view of this situation, the new Commission must be used to launch the 'fresh' and private public 300 billion euro programme, which encourages growth and employment. Where to do it? Taking advantage of the importance of climate change, mainly in infrastructure and in everything that means reducing emissions, supporting renewable energy, energy savings and also connecting between the different countries of the Union. Parliament has always been more ambitious than the Commission to this effect, and the Socialist Group has been more than Parliament as a whole. I therefore encourage the new Commission! Try to implement a new, environmental, sustainable economic policy in the European Union.

name: Syed KAMALL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, we welcome the fact that the European Council will consider climate and energy policies alongside economic recovery. It is nonsensical to consider them separately. A healthy economy needs low-cost energy. Europe does not have it. Since 2005, energy prices in Europe have risen by 38%. In the USA, they have fallen by 4%, creating tough decisions for households, but also for companies, and stalling economic growth.  Climate and energy policy must be for the long term. It should not be based on short-term reactions. We need long-term thinking, and we need to work with industry, not against it. If we are to achieve a workable policy, it is time to put aside this ideological debate between whether or not you agree with one group of climate scientists or another group of climate scientists. Surely it is time to find common ground. Surely it is time that we find those areas on which we agree. Surely this is the sort of Chamber where different groups can come together. Surely we can agree on less pollution. Surely we can agree on less waste in landfill. Surely we can agree on less dependence on unpleasant regimes, whether in Russia or in the Middle East. But we can also agree on more. We can agree on more renewable energy. We can agree on more energy efficiency and more conservation, and we can agree on more energy security. So let us put aside those differences and work together. But we have to take a step back and ask the fundamental question: in a modern, digital economy, with high-speed rail and electric cars, what will provide that energy? Wind? Yes. Solar? Of course. Wave energy? Yes. But is that truly enough? Therefore the question – and my question particularly to your group, my green friends – is what fills in the gaps? Some people will say nuclear, but the Greens say no. Some say clean coal. The Greens say no. Some say shale, but the Greens say no. So we have to answer this fundamental question. Blue card me if you have an answer. If not, we will have an energy policy that might emit less CO2, but we will also have power cuts, companies moving production outside the EU  and even higher levels of unemployment. So surely here the key is pragmatism, not setting climate targets which are unreachable and which drive industry out of the EU. Let us not forget that the EU by 2030 will only account for 4.5% of global emissions. We cannot have a ‘little European’ mentality. We have to work with the rest of the world. A solution will not necessarily be from a multinational. It might well be found in someone’s garage by the Bill Gates or the Steve Jobs of the energy world. That is why we need to be pro-market, not necessarily pro-big business. Let us cut the red tape and arbitrary targets that crush these start-up companies at the start. Otherwise, we will never solve this challenge. It is time to reclaim the green agenda for those who believe that being green and pro-growth are two sides of the same coin. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: blue-card question. – That is right, you invited it. So basically, you know what the answer is. I mean if we want to balance a primarily renewables-driven energy mix, we need conventional gas; that is one thing.  But would you not agree, when you talk about cheap energy, that if you want to transition our energy mix from where it is today to where it needs to be, that requires investment, and while you invest, that increases your costs temporarily.  So back to you, as a financial person:  how do you manage the financial transition to make sure that you can afford the investments now to get to cheap energy tomorrow?

name: Syed KAMALL
text: blue-card answer. – I am very pleased that you asked me that question. We might actually get some sense and common ground in this debate.  It is quite clear. Instead of politicians, the Commission or national governments trying to pick winners, leave it to the market. The market will decide which will provide us with the sustainable energy for the future. Yes, I agree with you; let us not subsidise nuclear. I agree with you; let us not subsidise solar or wind. Let the innovators come forward and meet those challenges, and you and I might find ourselves on the same side in the debate.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, Mr Della Vedova, on behalf of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, the next meeting of the European Council will take place at an important political moment: a new Constitution of the European Parliament and a new European Commission. It faces enormous challenges with regard to economic growth, the reindustrialisation of Europe and its complaceble with climate objectives.  Energy policy is of undeniable importance for both terms of this equation. If there are over-energy costs to be tackled, we cannot distort reality and focus only on mature renewable energies. We must have the courage to look equally at the aid provided to the fossil energy sector. If we want to focus on energy efficiency, security of supply and counterour dependence on the outside world, we must ensure a stable environment for investment in these areas.  As the Commissioner said, the ball is on our side. We must set ambitious targets for limiting greenhouse gas emissions and binding and ambitious targets for renewable energy penetration and energy efficiency.  I therefore call on the next European Council to respect Parliament's position and to establish a 2030 energy and climate framework that will provide green growth, which is less important to the European trade balance and reduces air pollution. Finally, I would like to point out that the Single European Energy Market is not possible without the cross-border infrastructure necessary for the transit of energy flows. It is unacceptable that geographical areas almost isolated from the European energy system continue to exist and that otherwise much could contribute to lower costs and security of supply. A fourth binding target for a minimum level of interconnection between Member States is therefore absolutely essential in this energy and climate framework.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, the need to strengthen energy security stems primarily from the fact that energy is a basic human good, to which we must all have equal access. Therefore, it must not be a question of competition that develops into economic or military wars, but must serve the peace and the peoples of Europe. To this end, the forthcoming European Council will have to ratify the obvious.  The European Council must also denounce Turkey's provocative actions and prevent the illegal directive of the Turkish Ministry of Foreign Affairs that came into force on 20 October, in which it illegally detains areas south of Cyprus, thus violating the sovereign rights of the Republic of Cyprus, as well as the rights of the European company, EDI, which is currently conducting research drilling within the Cypriot EEZ.  We recall that these are sovereign rights of a Member State of the United Nations and of the European Union, which are enshrined in the Treaty on the Law of the Sea and demarcated by neighbouring states. We call on the European Council to show its solidarity with a Member State under threat. What is the value of the solidarity clause when people are deaf to threats from a country on an accession path with the European Union? When this country is responsible for suspending the dialogue to solve the Cyprus problem, a problem from which the entire people of Cyprus, Greek Cypriots and Turkish Cypriots suffer.  Let me also stress that it is unacceptable that Parliament is not currently discussing Turkey's aggressive and illegal attitude towards the Member State, despite the efforts made by my group, GUE/NGL.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, I must be a big naïve or a little optimistic on the edges from time to time, but I remember that in March 2011, after the Fukushima disaster, the very pro-nuclear Chancellor Merkel said to herself: "Sapristi, the energy transition is an environmental requirement and an economic opportunity for Germany." And she went right into it. I was thinking that after the Ukraine crisis, it is all the European leaders who have come to the conclusion that this is not only an environmental requirement and an economic opportunity, but also a strategic imperative. I therefore expected that the Council, which will soon meet, would very easily adopt the position of the European Parliament.  I remind you of the Delvaux report, adopted at the end of the previous Parliament, which stresses the need for a three-way objective, both ambitious and binding. Because, as you know - I didn't find the equivalent French expression - "What gets measured, gets done." And conversely, what is not measured is not done. We had binding targets for CO2 reductions and for the share of renewable energy, and we are meeting them.  We had a non-binding target for energy efficiency. And guess what's next? We don't reach it! Therefore, the only way for Europe to achieve what it thinks it needs to achieve is to set a three-way binding target. This is, as I recall, an environmental requirement. Climate change is already affecting the European Union; it concerns not only the Pacific Ocean, but also Italy or France. So soon you won't know the Bordeaux wines as you know them today. So it's an environmental requirement.  Of course, it is also a geostrategic requirement if we want to achieve energy independence. It is not by replacing dependence on Putin or the sheikhs of the Gulf with dependence on the United States or Africa that we will be independent. If we want to be independent, we have to turn to renewable energy.  Finally, it is an economic opportunity. As I said to José Manuel Barroso, if Europe wants to have something to offer in the world of the 21st century, if it wants to be ahead not only of technology but also of the business model and the model of social organisation, it must achieve an energy revolution. Therefore, I would like to urge the Council to do so with full heart. (The speaker agrees to answer two "blue card" questions (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – I come from an area in the West Midlands called Dudley, and there are pensioners there who, last year, told me they could not afford to have the heating on. They were struggling, having to sit with blankets on them. They were desperate. I have noted what you were saying about the triple lock, and your agenda going further for CO2 emissions reduction, etc., but what would you say to those pensioners, who this winter will be so cold that many of them might even die?

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to ask my colleague how he sees the fourth objective, which is so important for us in Europe for new employment, namely the 20% reindustrialisation that we have set ourselves for 2020, and whether he considers it probable that we can also achieve a binding target for a reindustrialisation rate of 30%, so that we can finally combat unemployment in many countries in Europe. , and what priorities he would set here.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: "blue card" answer. Mr President, I believe that these are two absolutely crucial and well-founded questions. The first question, by Mr. R-big, concerns the industrial dimension. The construction of the energy transition is first and foremost an industrial project. It is an industrial modernization project, but the production of equipment is also an industrial site. The question, then, is whether we want to foster an industrial infrastructure inherited from the 19th and 20th centuries or build the industrial infrastructure of the 21st century. I agree with you that some sectors, which are in extremely limited numbers, would indeed be very exposed because of a transition that is too rapid and that these sectors need to be protected. We agree. But we must not put all industrial sectors in the same bag. As for the social question, it is again extremely well-founded. This is a real problem and it is true that, during the investment phase of the energy transition, we have an increase in the cost of energy which, in fact, affects the weakest. How are we going to do that? In any case, there must be a means to be used: the progressive pricing of energy, i.e. energy pricing, which favours the poorest households - fiscally. We wanted to experience it in Belgium and in some places where we Greens are in power. This would eliminate the impact of the energy transition on these people, but it also means increasing energy for households that can afford to pay. That's the first part. The second part is based on the long-term financing of the energy transition, which will save money in the future. There are enough financiers in this house to answer this question: how do we anticipate the benefits of the energy transition and use these anticipated benefits to finance the transition?

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, only those who are blind do not see that the world is facing momentous changes today and that all the certainties of past years are collapsing like pins, one after another. We have just entered a perfect storm, which includes a climate, energy and economic crisis at the same time, which no country, not even the one with the largest army in the world, has so far managed to counter in an effective and above all lasting way, because these three crises are an absolute novelty in terms of magnitude and their interconnection in a planet that we wanted to globalise. Even when economic parameters in Europe have formally appeared to improve with austerity, the effects on the real economy and on the well-being of the people have been detrimental. You die because you no longer have health care, because you lose your job and you commit suicide. You die from floods or because you have nothing more to eat. It is the very European political and social fabric which is disintegrating before our very eyes and with it the original idea of a European Community, which is becoming increasingly adverse among the populations. So who are the anti-Europeans? Who has been responsible for this so far, or who is suffering the effects?  We need new instruments and forward-looking policies that do not just square the budgets on an Excel sheet. We cannot tackle new and gigantic problems with the same mentality, the same calculations, the same tools as a century that has been behind us for 14 years. If there is one certainty, only one is that this will certainly not be the century of business as usual as the European Community is taking.  We are calling for the treaties to be re-examined, the fiscal compact immediately, for monetary budgetary policies to be reviewed, for the union's own decision-making structure to be reviewed, and for more space to be given to direct elected institutions such as this Parliament. Let it be a new course for Europe, supported in the transition from a European citizenship income, where the transition to the regularization of production activities and the transition to complete independence from fossil fuels is a priority.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Mr. President! If the Council now wants to set the course for energy policy in October, it could become a fateful day for Europe's energy-intensive industry. Even though our industry has reduced emissions since 1980, companies are now expected to continue to reduce their CO2 emissions by up to 40%. We already have the world's highest energy prices for electricity with Japan, twice the cost of gas in the UNITED States, three to four times that of Canada and the United States. The planned reduction commitments would also be unrealistic from these points of view and above all unfair, as can be explained by the example of the Austrian voestalpine Group. Thanks to good development, increasing production, the voestalpine Group is penalised – and this is a must be said – with the lowest CO2 emissions in Europe, and is being asked to pay for emissions trading as a net contributor and thus vigorously. An additional purchase requirement with additional costs of 800 million euros is expected by 2020, possibly even from 2.3 billion by 2030. This is how we kill our leading companies! In this way, we are forcing our industry to move abroad, to go to third countries. What we need are intelligent solutions, an allocation of free allowances based on current benchmarks and not on the 2008 or 2007 figures. We need a distribution according to emission intensity. Our companies need planning certainty and, above all, the reduction targets must be comparable worldwide and therefore harmonize accordingly.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: We are ahead of the key decisions of the European Council on the future of climate, energy and future policies of our economic policy in the European Union. The Presidency presents six climate policy targets, but at the same time, as MEMBERS, we are asked: is it possible to reduce emissions by 40% while preserving economic growth? Will the new reduction targets allow m.in to rebuild jobs: the 5 million that we are talking about in the Europe 2020 strategy? Will they also allow industry to achieve GDP growth of between 16% and 20% through reindustrialisation? This is the aim of the new Commission. Will the new reduction targets not result in carbon leakage – the relocation of production and also emissions outside the Union, and thus perhaps also a reduction in the capacity of individual Member States and their economies? How will we meet the competition under the new free trade agreement with the United States, given that energy prices in the Union are higher, that the United States is experiencing a more than 4% increase and energy prices are lower there, if only because of shale gas prices? How to solve energy supply issues (gas is supposed to be one of the elements of emission reductions, including import gas) when energy has become a field and a condui point of confrontation, as evidenced by Russia's conflict with Ukraine?  I would like to say that we have different objectives. We want to achieve reductions, increase renewables, efficiency, and image success in cop21, but we also want to maintain energy prices and the amount of emission allowances, if only because of the crisis that has taken place. The general dispute is the level of reduction targets and the division between states. Perhaps more will be done by countries that can reduce more, and others by economic and social opportunities. The Member States – this is my last statement, Mr President – should have the right to choose the path to reduce, the amount of RES and the implementation of energy efficiency. The "one size fits all" approach should not be pushed.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: Mr President, the next European Council is supposed to approve the upcoming European Commission, but it should also be able to deliver a real turning point for Europe. We need this turning point. Markets, as we know, are afraid of deflation risks. But much more than that, the European citizens who elected us are waiting for this turning point. From my perspective, this means to choose from now on as the central priority of Europe, no longer fiscal consolidation, but growth, investment and job creation. This means that we should have, from now on, more time to reduce public deficits; we should have more room to make public and private investments; we should have better coordination of economic policies to sustain demand, and we should adopt another approach to reforms.  Yes, we need reforms, but not just to reduce costs. We need reforms to create more added values, to create more and better jobs, and to create a new kind of global competitiveness for Europe. These are the kind of reforms we need, so I really hope that this new approach will be taken on board by the new Commission – as well as the Italian Presidency – as we prepare for the next phase of Europe 2020 strategy. So far the strategy has not been working; we need to recognise this. We need to bring a new light, a new inspiration to this strategy, which is there precisely to deliver growth and jobs but with a future perspective.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking There is a lot of talk in this Parliament about justice, about equal opportunities, about supporting the weak. In achieving its climate objectives too, the Union should not forget these principles. This should be taken into account at the forthcoming summit, which is expected in Poland with great interest, but also with great concern. In this case, it is about inequality between countries, between rich and poor societies, about the right to economic development. Some countries have built up their economic position for many years, accumulating wealth by polluting the environment. There are also countries in Europe that have undergone a painful political transition and which are still making up for the effects of finding themselves not of their own volition in the Soviet zone of influence.  Poles expect the European Union to help modernise its coal-fired power plants, not further deindustrialise and weaken the economy as a result of the adoption of stringent environmental standards, especially as countries such as Germany emit more carbon dioxide per capita than Poland, build new coal-based power plants, increase lignite mining. I would remind you that around 45% of germany's electricity comes from coal and that four new power plants have been built in germany in recent years. The burden of climate targets must take greater account of the different levels of development and prosperity of the Member States than before.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Mr President, the issue of the economy will also dominate the next summit. Because we have 3 million more unemployed, because we have 25% of Europeans living in poverty, because the euro area is threatened with recession and deflation. Mr Katainen and Mr Della Vedova, instead of general questions and routine placements, tell us what you are discussing behind closed doors.  Mr Katainen, a few days ago you made a statement on the Greek economy. Will this new line of credit, preventive, be accompanied by conditions, i.e. a new memorandum? Will the International Monetary Fund also participate in the new programme? What about France's budget? Does the Commission have a proposal or are you waiting to see what mr. Schaeuble decides before he discusses it yesterday with Mr. Sapin? When are you going to tell us about when, how and where about the EUR 300 billion that Mr Younger has promised us for months? How long before the Commission and the Council do not dogmatically follow what the Merkel government allows? When will you make your own suggestions?  Austerity, unemployment, recession, inequality produce Euro indifference and anti-Europeanism. You are the anti-Europeans and not the European left that claims a europe of democratic, social, strong social state and growth.

name: Peter ERIKSSON
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul I would like to address the Prime Ministers of Europe, who are now meeting to agree on the objectives of climate policy. I want you to stand up for knowledge, science and rationality. Don't bow to short-term interests and ignorance. It is possible to negotiate the targets and postpone the decisions. You can look away, but the problems don't go away. They're getting worse. They are hitting more and more people and costing more. Because climate change is real and we all know the cause and we all know about it. It is about burning up fossil fuels, oil, coal and gas. But the solutions are already here. Look at the countries that have invested in renewable fuels. They still have their industry. They have lower energy prices. That is why I appeal to you the Heads of Government of Europe: stand up as adults. Show that you are worthy leaders and take the responsibility necessary to meet the climate challenge.

name: Robert Jarosław IWASZKIEWICZ
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking The eu's climate policy has been repeatedly highlighted in public debate about how harmful EU climate policy is to European industry. On the altar of a blown ideology of global warming consists of real interests of entrepreneurs, including Polish entrepreneurs.  The summit will be attended by a Polish delegation with a new Prime Minister. I Polish the government to veto the findings of this summit! Instead of increasing energy Polish, a trader needs low taxes, limited administration and simple business rules. For Polish adoption of new proposals from the European Commission or even the continuation of the EU's existing climate policy means an economic disaster. If currently the price of a megawatt-hour in Poland is about PLN 160, then in the near future it will be 320 PLN. So the electricity expenditure of the average Polish family will increase many times. I call once again for the findings of this summit to be vetoed!

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Undersecretary Benedetto della Vedova for the Council spoke of growth, jobs and competitiveness. Commissioner Katainen says that we were realistic because we combined climate and energy. Well, I believe that this is the synthesis that we must find is our realism.  The elements relating to competitiveness must be key elements: we are slowly emerging from the crisis, too slowly, and that is why we must first promote growth, development and job creation, in all our policies. And here I would like to remind you of the objective set by communication for a European industrial renaissance. The goal is the reindustrialization of 20% by 2020 and this is a goal that we must always remember when we talk about all our agendas. You said that in Paris – you were optimistic – there is the possibility of an agreement. Here I have been following the coops from Copenhagen and I am not that optimistic, but today I want to make an effort, I want to be as optimistic as you are. But do we go to Paris having already made unilateral commitments? We will go there to Paris having already made commitments! So, I say, all right we want to push, we want to put these commitments on the table to get the rest of the world to come together, to sign this agreement. Are we sure we're going to have it? I want to be optimistic. We know that it is much easier when we talk about renewables, technologies, research and innovation, bilateral, multilateral agreements, but when we talk about the global agreement everything is much more difficult.  So, I want to collect here, asking you to maintain the current system of guarantees for sectors most at risk of carbon leakage because we are asking them to make a further effort, to maintain or strengthen it and to close with Barroso's words. We maintain leadership but let's not isolate ourselves, because that's the risk we sometimes run. I want to be optimistic, but let's keep the leadership without isolating ourselves!

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is essential that the Heads of Government take their responsibility next Friday when they take decisions. And let us hope that they make decisions in the field of energy and climate, of the energy climate package 2030. Because if Europe and the Council get rid of that responsibility on Friday, then we have a very big problem in Lima or Paris. Then Europe cannot say, we take responsibility, and ask other parts of the world – I am thinking of China and the United States – to take that responsibility as well. So now that responsibility has to be taken. We set out important lines in the European Parliament last year, February this year. It is not about the line of one group, because our group could be even more ambitious. It is the line of a large majority in the European Parliament. And it deals with three enforceable objectives at European level. You know them: the 40% reduction in CO2 emissions, the 40% energy efficiency and the renewable energy. And on Friday in the Council – we have heard that say – about half of the Member States would be prepared to move to a reduction of at least 40% emissions. And that 40% and at least 40% is extremely important – because that is also what the European Parliament wants – and that gives us some flexibility if we want to remind others of their responsibility on the international stage. So please let's go down that road. But of course it doesn't stop there. It's a total package. In Europe, too, we must not continue to subsidise fossil fuels and unconventional fossil fuels, and we must also meet these two other objectives. Oxfam recently calculated – and this is an important source – that a target of 40% energy efficiency, 40% energy efficiency, every family, every family in the European Union will result in a cost saving of EUR 300. So to say that there is a contradiction between energy efficiency and clear objectives, and the future, is not true at all. I call on the Heads of Government to take responsibility next Friday.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Mr. President! I have listened to some of the Commissioners-designate in Brussels, including Mr Katainen. What I have missed most of them are new ideas and strategies on how to deal with the problems in the EU in the future. Although the results of the European elections have spoken clearly, there is no response to citizens' demands to move away from centralism, paternalism and over-regulation. It continues to refuse to address the real causes of the crisis, such as the procrastination of important reforms. Instead, they continue to pursue redistributive policies and shift the problems into the future. Mr Draghi has been trying for years to save the euro with dubious measures, to buy time, and you are now trying to do the same with a banking union, with a future European unemployment insurance scheme. You are beautiful your balance sheets by now counting into GDP also turnover from prostitution and drug trafficking. And now you also want to pursue a common energy policy, as if we did not have more pressing problems to solve. What will be left of our continent when you finish it?

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, new growth, energy security and climate are the subjects discussed at the next European Council. I hope that they will be dealt with together, because each depends on the other two. This interdependence is barely mentioned in the Juncker plan, there is a mention of the green economy in it, but it is not enough. A real new deal is needed to revive European economies after years of destructive austerity. I am thinking of the new deal for Europe, a city initiative that should be taken up by the Eu ropean Union, even if the million signatures required may be missing. It is the horizon that allows us to keep together dangerously disjointed objectives, climate protection, employment, investment in alternative energy and secure supplies. The plan depends on national contributions to the Structural Funds and the EIB. So the most indebted states will not be able to contribute. The new deal by proposing real EU own resources, a tax on financial transactions, a carbon tax can give growth an ecological dimension and tax not increasingly precarious work, but financial rents. Unfortunately, instead of taxing financial rents, the Ecofin Council decided to postpone the implementation of the directive on combating large evaders.

name: Yannick JADOT
text: Mr President, in 2008 the European institutions adopted the first climate-energy package and, indeed, Europe took a leading role in energy, climate and industrial matters.  Unfortunately, this ambition has run out of steam and the package proposed by the European Commission, on which our European leaders will work, considerably reduces this ambition. With a 30% efficiency target, this is a one-third reduction in ambition between the decade 2010 and the decade 2020. With a target of 27% renewable energy, this is an ambition cut in half. So how can this new Commission consider that with such a package we are going to be the world leaders in climate and energy?  We talk a lot about economy and realism, but the realism is that with 40% efficiency, we don't need Russian gas. Economic realism is that two thirds of the new electricity capacity installed in Europe is renewable energy sources. That's economic realism, that's climate realism.  Let us have ambition to be pragmatic, to save the climate, to save European industry and to create jobs!

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in order to have a viable economic development policy, we must have the problem of integrating the various factors that we have also heard about today. However, there is one point I would like to make, because we often feel obliged to make the climate targets binding – as Mr Rübig said earlier clearly. But it seems that no one has the courage to assume as binding the objectives linked to the reindustrialization of our continent and our countries.  So, the strong question that I am asking for is taken up by the Council, but that it should become the climate in which we are also thinking in this House, the question is: who do we believe can restore hope to Europeans? Who do we think will give hope and work to our fellow citizens? On the basis of what model of economic development we believe we can give a real signal of confidence to all those who have historically taken responsibility for giving jobs, jobs and generating value. I believe that when we set ourselves the goal, by 2020, of generating a GDP that at least 20% sees the presence of the great manufacturing tradition of our continent and our nations, well, at that moment we set ourselves a binding target. If we fail to comply with it, we will have failed and all the other objectives will come accordingly. I do not believe in the possibility of economic development that neglects the educational value of corporate culture. Corporate culture is what someone else has said before me, wondering what he can tell his children. I have three children and I tell my children that without the ability to undertake there is no future: risk means giving everyone a chance of hope. All energy and climate objectives must be sub-achieving this general objective!

name: Matthias GROOTE
text: Mr. President! If you listen to some of your colleagues here who are promoting the market, you have to say that this is right. The market needs a stable framework. But what Mr Kamall from the ECR has said here is almost knocking the barrel out. It is the British Government that is giving EUR 43 billion over 35 years to a planned economy where nuclear power stations guarantee a fixed feed-in tariff. To promote the free market here, but to do the opposite at home, which, I must say, is truly brazen and untruthful. What is it all about? The market, industry and climate protection can be combined. I am firmly convinced of this. We need investment security in Europe so that companies can take money into their hands to invest in low carbon industry to invest in renewable energy. For this we need a functioning emissions trading system. For this we need a working framework. That can work. In the field of renewable energies in particular, we have growth rates, and as far as jobs are concerned, we are actually only dreaming of this in other areas. We must continue to move forward consistently along this path. However, this can only be done with strong emissions trading. We currently have a price of EUR 6.15, EUR 30 was estimated. Incidentally, the European Commission, Mr Katainen, has calculated EUR 30 for the carbon list. EUR 6.15 to EUR 30. The difference will now be paid by the European taxpayer. We will not get popular support for this. We need to make a change. We have to get on with it, and then something can become of it.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: Mr President, Commissioner, today we are once again discussing the issue of the so-called climate package. The whole negotiation process here in Parliament, when a compromise between the Commission and Parliament was hard to find, also shows that this problem is very complicated. Even the vote itself a few months ago was far from easy and, as a result, rather surprising.  As a long-time member of the ITRE Committee and after many interesting discussions in committee, I would very much appeal to prudness in adopting so-called ambitious commitments and objectives for the future. Environmental protection is important for any sensible politician. We are also well aware that excessive interference with environmental protection can often do the opposite. The exorbitant regulatory objectives of the climate package may jeopardise the competitiveness of the Member States, worsening the economic performance of the entire European Union and, consequently, worsening the environment, which is certainly not in our interest.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: Mr President, the geopolitical climate at our eastern border is still frozen in limbo and, as the approaching winter becomes the main negotiation tool for our eastern supplier, pragmatism appears to be the word on everyone’s lips. But I beg to differ and this is why. For the completion of the single energy market we need to fill in the missing links in the infrastructure. We need to get smart and we need direct access to the global energy market through multiple entry points. A fully functioning internal energy market connected to the global market is the key to security of supply and to the long-term competitiveness of our industry.  The resources we need for infrastructure cannot be covered by public money. We need to attract private investment, making better use of the financial instruments we have put in place. Focussing on a CO2 emissions reduction target that will keep our air clean is good, but we must also allow Member States to decide themselves how they want to streamline their efforts on renewables and energy efficiency because each competitiveness pole in Europe needs different policy tuning and a different energy mix. That is why a general emissions reduction target with flexible implementation is the choice to make.  Keeping our industry competitive and creating a real European market in energy with low prices and numerous supply sources is not a pragmatic choice; it is a choice for growth and this is what should be in our leadersʼ minds at this upcoming Summit.

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the macroeconomic data so objectively negative and worrying should discourage the self-contradictory attitude that I have now heard in the Commission's words. I hope that these are the words of the Barroso Commission and not those of the Juncker Commission. We need a breakthrough, because the situation is really serious and worrying. A new policy mix that works on supply and demand and does not leave the ECB alone. That is why today's investment, today's demand and tomorrow's supply are particularly decisive.  We expect the European Council to help the Commission to draw up an ambitious investment plan. Of course, private investment must be mobilised, but to do so we need public resources to leverage. They say: there are no such resources, there are procedural problems. I do not think so, the resources are there, the procedural problems can be overcome, what is needed is political will. We hope that this political will will emerge at the next European Council.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking In three days' time, the Council is due to take key decisions setting out a framework for energy and climate policies by 2030. The previous framework for 2020 was taken 12 years before the target date. Today we do it 16 years in advance. What is the reason for this haste? All the more so because the negotiating strategy for the Paris climate summit, which assumes that the whole world expects our leadership in climate rescue, is all the more questionable. This is probably not possible once again, and at the same time we will be in serious trouble, especially when setting a 40% greenhouse gas emission reduction target. We will reduce our energy security by limiting the use of domestic raw materials, and at the same time we will put our economies at a competitive level against countries that do not bear similar costs. All this at a time when the European Commission is considering how to revitalise the industry and increase its share of GDP from 16% to 20%. For Polish, the introduction of an EU plan would entail disproportionate costs, resulting in economic and social degradation in my homeland. There will be no permission for this.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. It is a good decision for two reasons to put security of supply on the European Council's agenda. On the one hand, the Russian-Ukrainian situation gives the matter a clear topicality, and on the other hand it is the Member States that have a lot of work to do in this area.  In recent years, thanks to the work of the Commission and Parliament, all existing instruments, measures and action plans have been named, which can serve to increase security of supply in Europe. Many of these have now been realised. In many cases, however, Member States are behind in implementing and enforcing legislation. For example, mandatory physical bidirectionalisation or the development of simplified infrastructure licensing processes are progressing slowly. As a consequence, the focus should be on much more effective implementation in the coming period. Two areas would be highlighted separately. One of the most important previous Commission initiatives was to take coordinated action against external strategic partners and suppliers. That is why it is welcome that the High Representative candidate for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy has set a goal of creating the conditions for proper coordination between Member States. The other priority medium-term measure, accelerating the implementation of projects of common interest, has also been under dialogue for some time. I support the proposal for the Commission to play a greater role in project coordination. Ladies and gentlemen, let me conclude by stressing once again that the ball is now bouncing in the hands of the Member States. Parliament has done its part of the work. The success of a higher level of security of supply now depends primarily on the Council and the Member States.

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking The Council is to discuss and adopt new proposals for reducing CO2, which would be extremely dangerous for the economies of central and eastern European countries, including Polish, as well as for the European economy as a whole. Believing in the supposed decisive human impact on climate change, the European Union wants to be a leader in reducing global carbon emissions. This policy will undoubtedly lead to a reduction in the competitiveness of our economy and, in some Member States, will completely destroy it. Agreeing to the adoption of new proposals will automatically lead to drastic increases in energy prices and, consequently, an economic disaster, for example in Poland. Many European plants, for example, flee to Asia, emitting CO2 from there. Instead of wading into nonsense solutions, it is better to bet on modern coal-fired power plants. Therefore, responsible Heads of Government should veto the proposed proposal at the Council meeting.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Thank you for your word, Mr President-in-Office. The achievements of the Baros Commission II are exceptional and I believe that the European Council will also give them a positive assessment. President Barosso mentioned in his closing speech today that some mechanisms and measures, such as the European rescue mechanism, the European Semester, the sixth package, the double package, etc. have made a decisive contribution to making Europe almost out of crisis today and making it, most importantly, even more resilient to such stress, because we have set up appropriate firewalls. That is why we have a safer banking sector and a stronger euro. In addition, we have introduced several additional incentives for small and medium-sized enterprises, which are the backbone of the European economy. But despite the crisis, we have increased investment in culture, education and youth. let me just mention Erasmus.  However, if the European Union has focused more on inward consolidation in the barossa II, we are particularly in the process of positioning in the international environment in this Juncker mandate. The Russian invasion of Ukraine has devastated the forces' relationship to the detriment of Europe. One of the European Union's priorities must be to establish a trade agreement with the US as soon as possible. However, we need to open the door more to the enlargement process, to the Balkan countries, as well as Moldova, Georgia and Ukraine. Energy independence from Russia must also be one of the priorities.  Last but not least, the new Juncker Commission will also need to monitor more closely the enforcement of the rule of law in the Member States so that no more political prisoners appear on its soil, such as the case of Janez Janše in Slovenia. Thanks.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: Il-Kunsill Ewropew u l-Gumsjoni għandhom sfida quddiemhom, dik li jagħmlu politika li tassigura enerġija affordabbli, sigura u sostenibbli. U dan huwa l-bilan大 li rridu nilħqu, imma biex nagħmlu dan irid irid ikollna netwerk Ewropew tal-gass u l-elettriku sħiħ u komplet, li jgħaqd flimkien flower-Istati Membri kollha. Teżisti ħtieġa urġenti li ntemmu l-iżolament li ħerti Stati Membri bħal Malta jbatu minnu fil-qasam tal-enerġija. Il-proġetti ta' interess komuni ddiżinjati biex itemmu dan l-iżolament għandhom ikunu meqjusa bħala prijorità ewlenija għall-Unjoni Ewropea. Fi sforz biex ikunu diversifikati sorsi, rotot u anki suppliers, il-European Energy Security Strategy tappella għal hub tal-gass fil-Mediterran. U iva, nemmen li l-Mediterran għandu rwol kru大jali f'dan kollu. Għalhekk nappella lill-Kunsill Ewropew biex ikollu r-rieda politika li jagħmel politika ta' klima u l-enerġija għas-sena 2030 li tkun ambizzjuża u realistics u li tiffoka fuq is-Sigurtà tal-enerġija u miżuri biex ikollna l-interconnections ne大essarji fil-Mediterranħalli tispi大a s-sitwazzjoni ta' Stati Membri li huma iżolati u maqtugħa mill-grid Ewropew.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: Mr President, four points that are important. First of all, a clear line versus Russia and its war in Ukraine. This is the most fundamental task for the European Union: to preserve and defend peace. The aggression we see today from Russia is a threat to the peace order of today. This needs the support of all Member States and it must be clear and consistent.  Secondly, we need to attract investment into the European Union. That means that we need to fight red tape, to use the new opportunities of having a Vice-President of the Commission responsible for better regulation and fighting bureaucracy. We can only attract investment if there is an opportunity for companies to profit, for companies to develop. We need capital markets that are liquid all over the European Union. So we need to ensure that our regulation and legislation is not hindering liquidity-making and investment. Thirdly, we need to secure credibility and the stability of public finances in the European Union. How we face developments in those countries which are not living up to the Stability Pact will be crucial and decisive for the future. If we make new derogations for some countries just because they are big, we are making a big mistake. We did it in 2003; we must not do it now because it will damage the credibility of the whole of the European Union. Fourthly, the ambitions, the targets for reducing carbon dioxide emissions, are more important than the number of very many different targets. We need to focus and give priority to reducing carbon dioxide emissions, not try to steer the Member States to where they can do things better.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: "blue card" question. Mr. Parliamentarian, we are all a little tired of your problems with Russia. Russia is a stable partner and a great nation, and wanting to put Russia in all the sauces only inflames our relations with this great country of Europe. My question is this: do you not think that today, at the dawn of all European projects, Russia also represents our energy security?

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: blue-card answer. – To be honest, I do not know on what planet you are living. We have seen for more than a decade that Russia is a threat to European energy security, blocking energy distribution and using its energy resources for political blackmail. Can you not see the fact that one country is invading another country in Europe? If you are defending that, you are defending aggression. You are defending disrespect for sovereign countries, and you are defending those who are threatening Europe’s peaceful order. You can do that because you are living in a free Europe, but people like you are undermining our freedom. (Applause)

name: Paul TANG
text: Mr President, the Energy Union is on the agenda for the next few years, starting this week with the European Council. The energy union cannot do without ambition. And that ambition is not very high in some governments and in some members of this House, often under the guise of the economic consequences. But don't forget that it is precisely many companies, an important part of the business community that does not know fear, sees the need for change and sees many opportunities. For example, 49 companies are calling for a 40% improvement in energy efficiency. European leaders are in danger of being overtaken by European companies, and this is an important signal that I would like to see loudly echoed in this House. The European Parliament calls for 40-30-40 binding targets and has also shown the necessary ambition. It is now up to the leaders, this weekend at this Council, to show the same ambitions, so that the Energy Union is indeed a tool for achieving those ambitions.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: Mr President, tomorrow at the same time, we will hopefully have a new Commission with Vice-President Katainen in office. However, the Member States will remain the same. The most worrying aspect of the dramatically changed security situation is the still insufficient and very often fragile unity in the Council.  As for energy, three years ago the EU Heads of Government decided to set the current year, 2014, as a clear deadline for the completion of an internal energy market. By the next year, they planned to leave no isolated areas which depended only on supplies from third countries. This applies in particular to the Baltic States and Finland. Well, all is on track. The Commission action plans have been published and updated. However, the end of the year is close, while we are still talking and preparing plans. Therefore, I call on the next Council to face the new realities. Any delay in completion of the internal energy market will directly undermine our common security.  As for security, Russia’s systematic military provocations in the Baltic Sea area have to be addressed efficiently and with convincing determination. Sanctions remain the most reliable means to stop and prevent further Russian expansion. Therefore, it would be most counter-productive to cherish any illusions about relaxing sanctions. The fragile Minsk ceasefire agreement is not the only criterion. Sanctions can be eased only if the Kremlin is able and willing to fully withdraw from the occupied territories and to fully respect the sovereignty of its neighbours.

name: Elisa FERREIRA
text: The European Economic Agenda must change urgently. Today, the world identifies Europe as the major problem of the global economy. Six years after the start of the financial crisis, the dogma of austerity did not solve any problem. The European economy is probably stagnating for a long time. Average inflation in euro countries fell to 0.3%, with some areas in deflation. There are 25 million unemployed Europeans, the euro zone has lost 10% of its wealth, some countries have lost a quarter of GDP, internal imbalances in countries and between countries have exploded, the public debt of peripheral countries continues to grow and there are very worrying signs in the markets. Medium-term solutions have been identified since 2012.They need to be implemented, but there is an absolute emergency agenda: a strong growth initiative, ecologically balanced, job-creating and re-converging economies between the centre and the periphery of Europe, is needed. The European Central Bank cannot remain the only institution to act. In the face of this emergency situation, we must stop with the cover speeches and the promises that do not solve, only disguise the problems. This change has to be made now. It is a matter of weeks and not months and this has to be the central issue of the agenda of the next European Council.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Mr President, colleagues, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur, As the Ukrainian crisis worsens, energy security policy is becoming vital, not only for Ukraine, but for the whole of Europe. In Europe, we depend on Russian energy supplies, especially gas supplies. But we see that Russia is using these supplies as a political weapon in Ukraine. This unfortunately means that Russia is no longer a stable and reliable partner of the European Union on this issue. It is therefore vital that the European Council raises Europe's energy security policy to the highest level. Firstly, the improvement of the European Union's energy networks needs to be accelerated, so that Member States are safer, that energy supply can flow between Member States, thereby also freeing the Baltic States and Finland from this energy issuan. Secondly, there is a need to move rapidly towards an energy union so that the European Union can speak with one voice with Russia as a supplier. We must put an end to Russia's ability to use the 'split and rule' policy. We must understand that the Member States of the European Union must stop thinking separately and start thinking together. It is time to actively build the European Union's energy union. Thanks for the attention!

name: Jo LEINEN
text: Mr. President! We must be careful that the climate change summit does not lead to an anti-climate summit. I say this because there is a risk that the objectives on the table will also be watered down by generous allocation of allowances, which in the past were not used for climate protection, but for other purposes. The objectives we know are neither ambitious nor sufficient. In part, business is business as usual. This is really a small common denominator, measured by what is possible in Europe and what we can do. The biggest weakness is the non-binding nature of the renewable energy and energy efficiency target. We know that it is precisely with these two objectives that we can solve several problems with one stone. This famous investment programme must go right into this domain. This will enable us to become more independent and, of course, to create many jobs. I therefore hope that the Energy Union will really bring us to a sustainable Europe and that we will not continue along the path as we have done in the past.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: Mr President! President Juncker wants to make the EU a world leader in renewable energy, writing in black and white that a binding 30% energy efficiency target is a minimum if we are to maintain our credibility. At the same time, we see investment falling in the field of renewable energy in particular: 20% worldwide over the last two years, 55% in Germany and 75% in Italy alone. But excuse me: on this basis, we are not and will not be the world leader in renewable energy and energy efficiency. We need binding national, ambitious targets in the fight against climate change, and the European Parliament has led the way. We must have at least 40% in CO2 reduction, 40% in energy efficiency and 30% in renewable energy. We know that we can save money and become more competitive; we know that we can create jobs, and we know that we can become independent of Russian gas and Middle Eastern oil if we raise climate ambitions. So dear governments: when you meet on Thursday and Friday, you must show that Europe is not just the frontrunner for the climate fight, but is ambitious on behalf of all of us.

name: Linda McAVAN
text: Mr President, I would like to address my remarks to the Council Presidency about the summit and Ebola. It is good that you want to show leadership on this issue, but we now need to turn the pledges into action – into beds and specialised medical personnel on the ground. Every Member State needs to play its part and I hope you will be asking on Thursday and Friday for pledges from Member States and that you will keep a grid of who is doing what and when things are getting done. We must all be coordinated through the EU and that has to really happen this time because on the ground the NGOs are telling us – I am the Chair of the Committee on Development – that they are not feeling the effects on the ground. We have to break the logjam on the Medevac. It needs to be sorted out by the leaders of the EU.  Finally, everything that you have heard on climate change is extremely important. We are going to Paris next year. The whole world is watching. I met the American Ambassador today. We talked about this. We need to get a deal on Thursday that is credible, with a binding target. Otherwise we are not going to be leaders in the world. So please, show leadership, make sure we get a deal, make sure we tackle the real underlying issues on Ebola and then the citizens of Europe will believe that the EU can tackle the big problems facing our societies.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Mr. President, I expect that of the announced €300 billion of investment in the reindustrialisation of Europe, a significant part will be for the energy sector, and of course I support the creation of a common Energy Union. I also support the efforts of the Baltic countries, Finland and the efforts malta is exhibiting here, and I want to make it clear that we need to take care of our environment as well.  That is why I call for a good reflection on whether to build a thermal power plant on Ugljan in Croatia, when we can build an LNG terminal that would be far better for the environment. What I want to emphasize in particular here are the large reserves of renewable energy sources in the Balkans in countries that are not yet members of the European Union, and I believe that there needs to be a commonal union, because in this way we can come up with much cheaper energy and renewable sources, and maybe solve the problem of floods and other problems that these countries have.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Mr President, we are discussing energy security for the European Union on the basis of events such as these in Ukraine and Russia. As we speak in the eastern Mediterranean, a potentially new conflict is developing. And I am speaking to you as a European Member who is interested in the interests of the European Union and its energy security.  Turkey, a state that wants to join the European Union, has sent to the region its own warships challenging the Exclusive Economic Zone of the Republic of Cyprus, which has been established under the Law of the Sea. There's a model for the whole world. Four states, Lebanon, Israel, Egypt and Cyprus have regulated their Exclusive Economic Zone and this can be a model for the rest of the world. I therefore think that we should discuss this issue and see it in the context of our common interests and the solidarity and principles that unite us.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Good policy requires leadership, decisiveness, but it also requires the ability to critically withdraw, to have a critical opinion on its actions, to critically review its actions. I am thinking, first of all, of the part of the summit that will concern the climate package. I firmly believe that the climate package as it stands will place an undue burden on the European economy, and especially on the economies of those countries that have not had the chance to modernise, those countries that use traditional energy sources. I am, frankly, very surprised that Commissioner Katainen has not put forward precise views in this area and has not demonstrated the ability to make a real compromise. I am afraid that this is the real compromise that is needed at the summit because Europe cannot take on too much ballast of emission charges. He can't take on that burden because he has to think about his development. I hope that the summit will bring rational decisions on this matter. I say openly – I have lacked precise words on this issue in the speech of the President of the Council and Commissioner Katainen.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. - Mr President, I wish to thank everyone very much for this debate. It was very wide ranging, touching upon various issues on the agenda of the European Council. Many speakers paid attention to climate and energy policy, which is an extremely important thing for Europe but also for the rest of the world. I do not know whether I should say too much about it, because Commissioner-designate Cañete would be a better specialist in this field. But, if I just mention that this area is, if I should mention one, probably one of the biggest source of competitiveness – if we just manage to deal with climate policy and energy policy together and the most effective way. First or all there is an endless demand for clean technology solutions; there is also endless demand for non-food biofuels, renewables and, if we manage to regulate right things instead of wrong things, we could create incentives for the private sector to innovate and create new solutions to save energy, but also produce cleaner energy and cheaper energy. So, at the end of the day, here in Europe we would have better energy for a better price and also technology to sell to other parts of the world. So, basically, as Commissioner-designate Cañete said in his hearings, we need a better energy market, fewer subsidies but a more unified market and we need better energy connections in order to allow energy to flow across the borders in order to maximise the efficiency of energy production. We also need better regulations for renewables in order to let them come into the market. Unfortunately, at the moment we are suffering, for instance, some trade barriers within the European Union, meaning that not all the Member States allow the best and newest technology to come into their market because they want to protect their own market. I am sure that this House will not accept this kind of behaviour and it is surely one of the issues which will be on the agenda of the next Commission.  But before there is a next Commission there is a European Council meeting. I would just like to stop here and say that I will pass these messages from the Members on to the current President of the Commission, and I am sure we can come back to the industrial renaissance, which is very important for the Speaker of the Parliament who is the father of this concept in Europe, and it is also one part of the climate and energy policy with which we are going to deal in the next Commission.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr Vice-President, thank you and good luck in your job, which is not an easy one.

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have listened carefully to the debate we have had with a view to the Council of 23 and 24, particularly with regard not only to the energy dossier, which will be at the heart of the assessments of almost all the people, almost all the Honourable Members who have spoken. The various aspects that are related have been taken into account, those of energy security in the own sense, competitiveness, innovation and growth linked to the energy issue, as well as the environment and climate and geopolitical issues related to supply. Just as I have listened to the reflections on the crisis and the recovery of the economy and even if more marginally in the debate, the Ebola affair. I have listened and what I can say is that I will ensure that the issues and points raised in the debate are forwarded to President van Rompuy for this Council scheduled for the weekend.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The debate is over. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Ivo BELET
text: Tomorrow, the proposals for European energy and climate policy for 2030 will be on the table for nine months. In order to win the fight against global warming, we need to step up our efforts considerably. Moreover, it is essential that Europe now sends this signal in the run-up to the UN climate conference in Paris next year. A new global climate agreement must be concluded there. The ETS system must remain the cornerstone of our climate policy, but we must strengthen it in the short term so that it can once again provide effective incentives for our companies to continue to focus on energy-saving and therefore climate-friendly innovations. That we ensure that this does not lead to carbon leakage is in the interests of our companies and of the climate. Climate and the economy, including for energy-intensive companies, do not have to be enemies of each other. Contrary. We are therefore counting on an ambitious and comprehensive agreement to be reached on Thursday and Friday, so that we can quickly work on the concrete legislative proposals.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. – The EC will make a decision on the climate and energy targets by 2030. Juncker advocated "Green Europe, a leader in renewable energy" and now it needs to be materialized. The EP set its position in February 2014 and, although the S$D group was more ambitious, we must not lower the approved claims of the EP (30% renewables, binding on member states; savings and efficiency -40% binding and -40% emissions) to improve the competitiveness of the European economy, to preserve the environment and to ensure energy supply. This requires advancing the union of the energy market in Europe, with the development of interconnections crucial, an objective "further laggard" by the lack of political will that allows the existence of energy islands, such as that of the Iberian Peninsula, which can play a relevant role in supplying gas to the rest of Europe , as well as for the development of renewable energies.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: I am pleased that there is a debate on the EC agenda that puts together three important topics such as the environment, energy and economic growth. In short, I want to highlight a few important issues for each of us. We are talking about renewable energy and the future opportunities offered by this industry but the European market is being invaded by products from outside the European Union and young people are not getting specific training to integrate professionally in this area. We are talking about energy, but each Member State negotiates separately the import of gas from Russia by creating price differences between member countries. We are talking about a common energy market, but we are regulating it by obliging even energy and gas-producing Member States, such as Romania, to increase their prices, affecting the local population, rather than letting the market act and competition leading to lower prices. We are talking about the environment and energy, but we are not talking about the inequalities generated between the rich and the poor and the fact that we need to support those on low incomes. We are talking about economic growth, but we do not produce or support innovation in energy or the environment. I hope that this Council will also make decisions!

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: in writing – The EU Summit, 23-24 October, in Brussels deals with accelerating capitalist restructuring in all its Member States, promoting new unpopular measures to further reduce wages and pensions, hitting the CSEs, savage cuts in social spending. This is the content of the memorandums and the subject of monitoring of Member States in the context of "enhanced economic governance", with the aim of ensuring the profitability of EU monopolistic groups. , "green technologies" etc. In capitalism, any "energy mix" serves the profits of businesses, while for popular households energy is an inaccessible commodity. Competition within the EU and with other imperialist centres and powerful capitalist countries on production methods, control of energy sources and transport routes, increases the risks of widespread conflict.
