They are already leading to the mattering of peoples in Ukraine, Iraq, Syria, Libya, and the wider region of the South-East Mediterranean and North Africa, where EU-US-NATO imperialist interventions are evolving. These competitions also characterize the new round of Turkish aggression towards Cyprus these days.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The next item is the report by Gérard Deprez (A8-0018/2014) on behalf of the Committee on Budgets, debate on draft abated budget 2/2014 - report on surplus resulting from the implementation of the 2013 budget (12300/2014 - C8-0160/2014 - 2014/2035(BUD))

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, normally the report on the draft amending budget No. 2/2014 that I am presenting to you should have been a formality. Indeed, as stipulated in the financial regulation, the Commission presents an annual draft amending budget which aims to budget the surplus resulting from the previous year's budgetary year, i.e. in this case 2013. Normally, I said. Unfortunately, things are not normal. Anyone who follows the Union's budgetary situation is well aware that the payments situation is becoming critical, if not dramatic. Based on the information available, at the end of 2013 there were more than 23 billion unpaid and they would now, if nothing is done, approach 30 billion. When I talk about unpaid bills, I mean very concretely that they are proper invoices that are waiting to be honoured and cannot be honoured because the payment credits are not sufficient. This situation is totally abnormal. It is in fact a real debt, real but hidden, when the Union's budget must be in balance. This situation is also intolerable and I would like to ask the Council if it remembers that it adopted, not long ago, a directive which was addressed to the Member States and which instructs them to request that the invoices be paid within thirty days. Does it measure what the current situation means for Erasmus students, who will not receive the agreed money when they are entitled to receive it? Is the Council measuring what it means for a state, for a local authority, for a regional authority, already facing a difficult budgetary situation, not to have its bills repaid? Does it measure what it means for an SME or research team not to receive the agreed amounts, when the staff has been hired, is in place and must be paid? The situation has become so critical that the Commission has decided to present the budgetary authority with an amending budget no. 3, in which it is seeking additional payment appropriations for a total amount of EUR 4.8 billion. At the same time, it has tabled several other draft amending budgets, in which it proposes, for the most part, to include in the revenues the proceeds of fines and late interest for a total amount of about 5 billion euros. It is clear that Member States should not put their hands in their pockets to finance the additional payment appropriations in the event of an honourable agreement between the two branches of the budgetary authority. Taking all these elements into account, the Committee on Budgets has taken two important strategic directions, which it asks our assembly to support wholeheartedly. Firstly, we want to deal together, that is, as a whole during the negotiations with the Council, all the draft amending budgets introduced for the 2014 budget year. The aim of this bulk treatment is to prevent the Council from rejecting or scrapping requests for additional appropriations, but retains for the benefit of the Member States the additional revenue which has added, almost miraculously, the initial revenues planned for the year. It is precisely in order to be able to deal in bulk all the draft amending budget that this report asks you to approve an amendment to the draft amending budget No. 2 presented by the Commission. If this amendment is not approved, the Council will have the power, due to the overspending, to get its hands on the surplus of the 2013 financial year, to the benefit of the Member States, thus depriving the EU budget of the possibility of using it to loosen the noose of unpaid bills. The second important direction adopted by the Committee on Budgets has already been expressed today in the organisation and on the agenda of our work: it is a question of getting an agreement with the Council on the 2014 amending budgets before starting negotiations on the 2015 budget. This strategic choice, which has been supported , I would like to stress - by all the political groups in the Committee on Budgets, is necessary for us for two reasons. The first, as I said, is that there is an urgent need for additional funding. This urgency concerns both the beneficiaries, who are waiting for their bills to be paid, and the Union itself, whose credit will be hard hit if it is not able to honour the commitments it has made. The second reason is that the 2015 budget, which we will vote on tomorrow, will not hold up if the 2014 budget, unchanged, leaves it with a slate of unpaid debts weighed down by billions. An agreement on the 2014 amending budget is therefore both a necessity and a prerequisite for the adoption of a 2015 budget that holds up. It is for these reasons that I ask you to approve the report I am presenting to you today.

name: Enrico Zanetti
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, it is a pleasure and an honour for me to take part once again in a sitting of the European Parliament, which has among its items on the agenda some relating to the subject of the Community budget. Specifically, the subject we are dealing with now relates primarily to amending budget proposal No 2 for 2014, which was already approved by the Council at its meeting on 14 July 2014.  This budget, as you know, is part of a procedure which is duly codified in the Financial Regulation, which, once the result of the previous financial year has been defined, requires the necessary budgetary changes to be adopted for the current financial year. In line with the forecasts in the Financial Regulation, the Commission therefore proposed to account for the surplus of around EUR 1 billion in the 2013 budget in 2014.  We note that the European Parliament is preparing to adopt amendments to this purely technical budget, providing for a new budget line on which to set aside this amount pending its use for unforeseen payments. This approach – as we have been told clearly – is affected by the more general discussions we are having on the 2014 amending budgets and the 2015 draft budget.  It goes without saying that the amending proposal itself cannot be accepted by the Council, but therefore clearly inevitably, it will be taken into account in the more comprehensive debate that we will have in the conciliation procedure, and I am sure that in this area we will be able to find the right balance for a decision that meets the various demands in accordance with the rules laid down in the current legislation.

name: Jacek Dominik
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, the Commission proposal for this draft amending budget was tabled in April 2014, in accordance with the Article 18 of the Financial Regulation. It concerns the budgeting of the 2013 surplus. As pointed out by the rapporteur, Mr Deprez, the amount of the surplus is one billion, five million euros, and it mostly comes from the additional revenue from competition fines received towards the end of 2013.  Only a very small part of the 2013 surplus – somewhere in the region of EUR 275 million out of an executed budget of almost EUR 144 billion – comes from the expenditure side of the budget.  At the same time, the Commission has also presented amending budgets requesting additional expenditure of EUR 4.7 billion since the end of last May. Last year, the reinforcement of payments in amending budgets 2 and 8 of 2013, totalling EUR 11.2 billion, had been fully used by the end of 2013. This year again, the situation of payment is tight; it started with a backlog of EUR 23.4 billion. We simply have no possibilities for redeployment, and several budget lines have been fully exhausted. Overall implementation stands at the level of 82%. It is in light of this scarcity of payments across the budget that the Commission understands the amendments proposed by the Parliament to create a reserve for payments in the 2014 budget with the same amount as the surplus.  Out of the seven amending budgets, six are still outstanding. Two of them concern the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund. Together with the Council, we will need to find a compromise on all draft amending budgets on the table – including the three for this year – which reinforces payments amounting to EUR 4.7 billion. The Commission considers that all of the elements needed to do so quickly are available. This year, we have a unique opportunity to cover the additional expenditure with the revenue mainly coming from funds. This means that we can cover it at no cost to Member States’ budgets. Taking this decision will only increase the EU’s credibility and allow us to gain control over the EU budget. I invite Members to act responsibly and to take the appropriate decisions in the forthcoming conciliation.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: on behalf of the Ppe Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, Mr Representative of the Council, Ladies and Gentlemen, I would have liked to have seen firmness, clarity, commitment on the part of the Council. I also hope that we will have that clarity and commitment. I would like to greet the Commissioner and congratulate him on the work he has done to restore credibility to the institutions of the European Union. The Council's position in this and the other amending budgets will demonstrate whether it is in good or bad faith, whether or not we can trust the Council, whether or not there is institutional loyalty on the part of the Council, whether it is reliable and whether we can give it credibility, which we hope to be able to give it. Amending budgets - these budgets are to pay for investments, programmes, projects already carried out and duly authorised, for SMEs, young people, scientists, local authorities, NGOs.  The Council authorised these investments and programmes, it was often he who asked for them. And now there's a question: how can we accept that the Council does not want to pay for what it has asked for and what it has authorised?  It should be stressed that the Council has signed formal declarations annually at the time of conciliation, and Parliament has relied on them, and statements where it assumes that it approves amending budgets necessary for payments that are confirmed. How can we accept that the Council does not comply with the statements it signs?  Well, pacta sunt servanda, the commitments are to be fulfilled and I have the hope that the commitment between the institutions and with the citizens, which we have assumed, particularly in the multiannual financial framework, is to respect, because we need growth, we need jobs. I hope that and Would like to confirm it from the Council and the representative we have here. Thank you very much.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, Commissioner, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, today we are once again debating payments. It is true that on the agenda we are talking about the second amending budget, but it is clear that what is on the table and focuses the debate we are currently having in the Committee on Budgets and in the European Parliament is how we solve the payment crisis that we have been dragging on since 2010.  I get the impression that when we talk about payments, we often already repeat obviousness, but it seems that the Council's position is not so clear in this regard; therefore, we still have to keep repeating obviousness and be patient to see if we can get the Council to change our position once and for all. And the first no-brainer, which we keep repeating in this Parliament, is that we have to pay what we owe. I think it is quite simple to explain to our citizens that, in the European Union, the Council, the Commission and Parliament have taken decisions and reached agreements; that many companies, NGOs, public institutions, private institutions and universities have relied on the proposals we have made have participated in European programmes and now what we have to do is simply pay the bills they have sent us in relation to those agreements that we have reached with them. And so that is a no-brainer that we will tire of repeating, but that it seems that on the part of some countries, at least in the Council, it is not so clear. That's an unacceptable situation. We cannot continue to delay the settlement of defaults.  We have been on the table since 2010 and the situation is becoming increasingly worrying, reaching around 26 billion or 30 billion euros, because we no longer even know what figure we are talking about. And I'm going to say two more obvious things: first of all, that not paying is not to respect those agreements that we've reached. And secondly, that, moreover, not paying what we are doing is not respecting the agreement on the financial framework either, and what we are really doing is cutting the budget through the back door. As the Commission has told you, you have a golden opportunity, it will not cost you a euro to reduce these defaults by at least FIVE billion euros. Take the opportunity!

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Madam President, we are at the beginning of the Parliament and I want to denounce two dysfunctions. The first is the appearance of a sneaky debt due to a growing gap between commitments and payments. Those who have just spoken have made it clear what the position of the Committee on Budgets is and we intend to maintain a strategic line for it to be remedied. The 2014-2020 Multi-Year Framework does not take into account outstanding payments, which at the end of 2013 amounted to $23.4 billion. I thank Commissioner Dominik for his clarity on this issue. The second dysfunction is related to the internal market because we see new resources accumulating with the fines decided by the Court of Justice. This means that the functioning of competition is imperfect: 1.331 billion additional resources at the end of 2013, including late interest, but probably 3.5 billion fines for 2014. This dysfunction of the internal market seems to me to be serious because a poor functioning of competition is detrimental to growth and thus to the reversal of the unemployment curve. It is important to remedy this because the Court of Justice needs four years , I say four years - to deal with competition cases. The Court of Justice had requested additional resources in March 2011 but the Council was unable to find a solution to appoint the judges because it asked for twelve additional judges. For three years, the Council was unable to meet this expectation. So we are probably heading for the appointment of twenty-eight additional judges because that number corresponds to the number of member countries of the European Union.  I hope that this dysfunction will be resolved quickly, firstly because it is detrimental to growth and secondly, because by not making a decision, we delay the collection of these fines.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: thar ceann an Ghrúpa GUE/NGL. – A Uachtaráin, dar leis an gCoimisiún ag deireadh 2013 bhí easnamh i mbuiséad an Aontais de níos mó ná EUR 23.4 billiún i bpolasaithe comhtháthaithe. Inniu tá Ballstáit ag fanacht ar íocaíochtaí, ar éilithe dlisteanacha agus mar thoradh ar seo tá tionchar thar a bheith diúltach aige seo ar ollscoileanna, institiúidí taighde, gnóthaí beaga agus meánmhéide agus tús éifeachtach na gclár éagsúil i gcomhair 2014-2020.  I mo thír féin, tá cosc curtha ar éilithe íocaíochta de EUR 51 milliún –EUR 24 milliún i gCiste Sóisialta na hEorpa agus EUR 27 milliún i gCiste Forbraíochta Réigiúnaí na hEorpa. Is léir nach bhfuil rud ar bith athraithe, go leor airgid ag dul go dtí na bainc agus gan faic ag dul go dtí na daoine. Tá mé ag iarraidh fáil amach an bhfuil aon mheasúnú déanta maidir leis an méid daoine atá ag fulaingt de bharr na moilleanna seo. Go háirithe, cé mhéad daoine ar chaill a bpost nó atá i mbaol a bpost a chailliúint i ngnóthaí beaga agus meánmhéide. Cé mhéad clár d'fhorbairt réigiúnach, iascairí agus institiúidí taighde atá i mbaol mar gheall ar an bpraiseach seo.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, the Greens agree with Mr Deprez’s line to link debt one with debts three and four. Without that link, it will be almost impossible to move ahead with the 2015 Budget. The national contribution to the EU budget was EUR 110.8 billion in 2013, and this year it will be EUR 90.4 billion. That means the Member States are saving at least EUR 10 billion. Yet they claim that they are unable to pay debt three. The Council must see how irresponsibly it is behaving. As Mr Fernandez said, ‘pacta sunt servanda.’ If the Council does not understand that reality, then I am sorry but I am forced to quote another Ancient Roman, who said ‘ceterum censeo, consilio delenda est.’

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is absolutely necessary to address the outstanding situations with the 2014 budget, before we start thinking about 2015. We cannot discuss commitments and figures to be spent if we do not regulate at least some of the debts that we still have to pay.  Of course, I understand the Italian Presidency, which is also bringing the Renzi model to Europe, that is, slogans with effect and fine words for the future. But how do we deal with the present and the past – and I address this to the Council?  Last month in Brussels we had a meeting on the catastrophic situation of EU payments. With Commissioner Dominik pitting alarming figures and figures, with a hole of over EUR 20 billion to be cleared. After all this, you, Under-Secretary Zanetti, had confined yourself to reading a straight document already written completely empty of concrete content and actions.  I would therefore ask you now to find solutions, at least for these amending budgets and for eliminating the problem of payments at its root? For the 2015 budget we have put forward our proposals, but first we want guarantees to close 2014 without holes.

name: Janusz LEWANDOWSKI
text: Madam President, of course it makes sense to discuss the draft amending budget before discussing 2015, as this is the key – by bridging the gap in payments – to reasonable programming for the next year. Mr Deprez, our rapporteur, is right that integrating the 2013 surplus into the revenue side of the 2014 budget should be a technical exercise – just a formality and part of the budgetary routine.  For external observers, this might even seem paradoxical, because we are claiming to have a shortage of money and payments, but, on the other hand, we have a surplus. This is due to the complexity of the Financial Regulation, which I am not going to discuss. But, in the context of the present-day situation – which has been documented and illustrated by Commissioner Dominik in the clearest possible manner – of the drama of payments, it makes sense to bridge the gap before starting real conciliation over 2015. This is not only about draft budget No. 2, but also about all the amending budgets for 2014, making a package. Therefore, the decision of the Parliament to place it in reserve is the right choice before the conciliation.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: Madam President, Minister, thank you for being with us today. It is a mark of respect between our institutions but it is probably the last mark of respect because if this presence tells us: "I listen to you", your position on the budget tells us: "Cause always." I want to denounce the insincerity of the European States which, last November, agreed in the dialogue with Parliament to create a reserve for unforeseen events in the 2014-2020 financial framework. Today, however, the Council refuses to apply it. He proposes to make the budget cavalry and asks us to let the project owners and the local authorities bear the burden of their inadequacy. Without these elements of flexibility, the Council would not have reached an agreement with Parliament. Today, however, the Council is trampling on this agreement and, at the same time, trampling on our House.  Everyone knows that the Union needs a boost for growth and jobs. Everyone knows that it will not be done without fresh money. So let the Council get out of schizophrenia, respect the citizens of Europe and start by paying its debts and keeping its commitments!

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Madam President, Mr Zanetti, Commissioner, thank you actually for agreeing to our position, which we as MePs have. I think that we can agree on this, so I will not continue to discuss the meaning of this measure, which has relatively little impact on our budget. I am the person of the future and I want to look to the future and it is very important for me that we really look to the future.  Mr Zanetti, listen to me carefully, you now have a unique opportunity to write in the history books that, as a member of the Council, you can do something about the deficit in the European budget. Otherwise, if we do nothing about it and do it within a few weeks or months, we do not make a plan, then we will all be regarded, not just by you, not only by the European Commission, but also by us MEPs as untrustworthy.

name: Jens GEIER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Minister, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for the work she has We are discussing a very serious situation today. I have to say that the Council has brought us stones instead of bread. Mr Zanetti, I must have heard your message, it reminded me of statements by the UN Security Council. There is no syllable too much here, every sentence is precisely circled here, and in the end you tell us that the solution to the extremely difficult situation is to take place in the conciliation procedure. That is not the way forward! Your country is waiting for more than two billion outstanding payments, the Federal Republic of Germany is waiting for one billion, and we are not in the top quarter of the countries that expect payments from the EU. However, the same Member States that expect payments are those that say in the Council: 'We want to starve the European Union financially'. I read in the news today the great idea that the EU Council of Foreign Ministers has agreed to introduce White Helmets in order to launch a joint action to combat the Ebola crisis. Very excellent idea! But does anyone in this Chamber think that this is budget-neutral? What do I mean by that? That the Member States are making more and more demands on the EU and that the same Member States are unable or unwilling to finance these demands. That is not the way forward!

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: Madam President, Commissioner, it is announced that in the Council a number of Member States would not wish to validate the 2014 amending budget as proposed by the Commission and amended by the Committee on Budgets. Ladies and gentlemen, this is an exercise in political fiction that I am proposing to you today. Let us imagine that the Council stands by its position and decides, in fact, not to respect its commitments. What are we going to say to the associations, researchers, NGOs and local authorities in our respective countries, who have applied for European structural funds and do not see anything coming? What are we going to say to our citizens in the face of the default that is looming at the level of the European Union, with almost more than 24 billion euros missing? How are we going to explain to our fellow citizens that this Europe, in which they have put a lot of hope, is not at the rendezvous of history? The Council must accept our proposals, which are very reasonable, if we do not want, ladies and gentlemen, to have to answer these questions. At a minimum, the 4 billion dormant in the budget and all the fines of justice, of course, can be mobilized.

name: Jan OLBRYCHT
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Minister, i would like to thank you for your comments. Today, it is known that we are discussing a passage which, of course, will not solve the payment issue to the end. Therefore, DAB II will not solve the problem, but it is an example of Parliament trying to behave rationally, facilitating a mechanism and making certain actions more flexible. I therefore absolutely support our rapporteur's proposal, as it is a matter of a truly technical nature in order to facilitate certain decisions, which will also simplify our discussions on the 2015 budget. We are aware that this is only a partial solution and actually reduces the burden on Member States, not increases them. We are therefore counting on this – and Here I join the Commissioner's call – that we will find a common position with the Council on this issue and that the matter will be resolved quickly, which will open the way for us to move forward with the 2015 budget.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. I would strongly support what Commissioner Dominik said. I would also like to support these statements by Members, from which it has become very clear that the situation with regard to the Union budget in 2014 is indeed becoming critical. It is true that Parliament's decisions are not capable of solved this situation, they can only remedy this situation somewhat. A more sharp and decisive Position of the Council is needed here. I would therefore like to address my question, first of all, to the Representative of the Council, to the representative of the Italian Government: what is the Council doing specifically at this point in time to fill this growing hole in the Union's financial problems? What action does the Council take and what results can we still count on by the end of this year?

name: Jacek Dominik
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, to sum up this whole discussion, it is clearly this: EU credibility is at stake and there is no question to answer; we have to fulfil our obligations. We have a unique situation: to solve the problem at no expense to the Member States. That is a really unique situation as far as I know; it has never happened in the past.  The Commission has this money, it is on the account – EUR 5 billion. Legally, we are not able to use it; we have to give it back to the Member States. So now, the reply awaited from the Council is whether the Council and the Member States prefer to put this money in their own pockets and ignore the commitments they have made in the past, and ignore the payments they have to make, or do they want to really address the problem, show their European will and pay the bills?  The problem is that what we observe is an increasing reluctance by the Member States to pay their bills, to contribute to the European Union budget as such. There is an ongoing tendency to cut as much as possible without any rationale, while at the same time taking on new obligations, new commitments. We have commitments which were taken on during the multiannual financial framework (MFF) negotiations which have not been respected within the first year of its implementation.  This all creates a nightmare for the budget negotiations. We spend days and days trying to figure out whether the Council is going to respect its commitments or not; instead of doing simple calculations to see how much money we have to devote to paying the bills.  The decision on the whole set of amending budgets could be made very easily; the calculation is simple: more than EUR 5 billion available, a little bit less than EUR 5 billion to be paid. The outcome is positive and yet still the Council hesitates. It is an unacceptable situation.  If we do as the Council is proposing – postpone as many decisions as possible – it will not be possible to implement the MFF properly. We will create additional tensions in the budgets for 2015 and 2016. We will probably need a major reform soon and have to make it publically known that the European Union is not able to implement its own decisions from the past and is not a credible partner for researchers, small and medium-sized enterprises and European citizens.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Thank you very much for the Commissioner's closing words, this is a very important issue, a question of credibility, I can also say that, and I ask Minister Zanetti to give his final thoughts on behalf of the Council.

name: Enrico Zanetti
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I have listened to the speeches; I have to say on the specific item on the agenda today, in fact, it seems to me that we are, after all, here we are. Parliament wants to amend the Commission's proposal for amending Amendment No 2 because it wants it to be discussed together with all the other amending bodies, inevitably in a situation where we are going to discuss it in conciliation and, of course, the Council has said only the same thing from this point of view. In other words, in itself, Parliament's amended proposal , which has been removed from an overall assessment, cannot, of course, be accepted by us, on the understanding that since we fully understand how we have been told that the logic is to think on an overall level, then we will reason on an overall level. For the rest, I can only assure you that the Presidency is making every effort to reach an agreement as soon as possible, obviously respecting our joint declaration on payments adopted last year in the context of the adoption of the 2014 budget. I have heard several times about a position that we cannot support from the Council, which is typically focused on Amendment No 3, since we were obviously prepared to approve it as it was on the 2nd, just as we have no problems with Amendment No 4. However, I would like to point out that at the moment, rather than a contrary position, we can legitimately complain about a still defined lack of position, but this is precisely the desire to seek a position that is good rather than fast, precisely in the name of the attention to credibility for the European Union and for the individual institutions.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I believe that at the end of this debate it is very clear that the Commission's position is absolutely clear. We need extra credits! And it is possible to ensure that Member States do not pay money since additional revenue can be made in the 2014 budget year. Parliament's position is also clear and you have seen, Minister, that it is shared by all political groups. Amazing but real phenomenon! This shows that awareness of the seriousness of the problem is acute in the parliamentary ranks. On the other hand, the Council's position is not clear - or is not yet clear. Or maybe it is, but you don't yet have the right to express it. In any case, I heard two things from you. The first is that you have accepted - by necessity, but you have accepted it - that the discussion on all 2014 amending budgets should be globalized. You did not accept, but you heard that we are asking for an agreement on these amending budgets before we start negotiating the 2015 budget. So I just want to say that we understand the efforts you have to make and we support you. But you must tell the members of the Council that we will not, under any circumstances, let the cancer of the unpaid discredit the whole construction of the European Union.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The debate is over. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 22 October 2014.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The next item is the european Union financial year 2015 prepared by Eider Gardiazabal Rubial and Monika Hohlmeier (A8-0014/2014) on behalf of the Committee on Budgets General Budget - Debate on all phase reports (12608/2014 - C8-0144/2014 - 2014/2040(BUD))

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President, Commissioner Dominik and Mr Zanetti, we are now dealing with the last budgetary procedure before opening negotiations with the Council. Today we are debating here and tomorrow we will vote — I hope by a large majority - on the draft budget for 2015, and I can say that our position is absolutely responsible and consistent with the situation we are experiencing. We have been in deep economic crisis for seven years, austerity policies have brought nothing but suffering, and not only are we not coming out of the crisis, but we are facing a high probability of a third recession and, therefore, it is more than clear that we need to change the course of economic policy and, above all, activate demand through the public sector. And that is where the European budget can play an important role, because with only 1% of gross domestic product, the European budget activates public investment by complementing national budgets and also boosts growth and employment. In recent months we have talked a lot about new investment plans, new strategies, focusing on priorities. I would like to remind you that we already had a Lisbon Strategy which failed because of a lack of political will and which, now, even if some have been forgotten, we also have the Europe 2020 Strategy, which will also fail if we do not put on political will and, above all, the necessary funds. In addition, we have just approved the Multiannual Financial Framework, which is nothing more than a table in which we see the political and budgetary priorities for seven years. So we don't have to invent the wheel every year, because of great strategies and White Papers are the drawers full. But here we have the 2015 budget and the financial framework with a number of potentials that we must exploit to the fullest, and that is what we have done in our draft budget, because we propose a budget to the maximum of its capabilities to channel productive economies, so that Europe competes in the world in quality and knowledge, and that we return to be an example of a welfare society that takes care of its people. And that is why we have decided to concentrate our efforts on the core programmes of the Europe 2020 Strategy which are aimed at promoting growth, research, employment and competitiveness; we improve access to funding for small and medium-sized enterprises or put more money into Erasmus scholarships or Marie Curie grants; we also want to allocate funds to energy infrastructure, nor have we forgotten about farmers and fishermen, nor for the damage caused by the Russian veto to our products. We have designed a budget that fights inequalities, supporting the most disadvantaged regions, but also helping the people who are having the worst time, within and outside our borders, with the European Aid Fund for the Most Needy or with policies related to asylum, migration and internal security. And we have also earmarked more money for neighbourhood policy items, development cooperation policy and, of course, essentially, humanitarian aid to be able to deal with all the humanitarian crises we are currently having, all at once, in an unprecedented fact. Nor can we forget about aid to refugees and increasing unRWA's money so that we can continue to help Palestine's refugees. These are all the priorities of the European Parliament; many priorities which, as I have said on other occasions, are the same as those of the European Council. The problem is that your budget, your figures tell a very different story from ours, because you have political priorities, but you don't seem to have budget priorities, and we don't agree with that position, because we can't say we're betting on research while cutting the budget.  Because you, once again, treat the European budget as a heading that is cut as you please. And this is not only the fault of the economic crisis and how the national accounts are, but sometimes also a lack of an absolute vision for the future and a shared project. And we just saw this in the payments debate; it is seen by the attitude we have in not minding to drag a debt of EUR 26 billion which, as has been said, lags the credibility of the European Union and which also has devastating effects on the economic recovery. We have proposed extraordinary measures and I hope that the Council will be ready to negotiate and discuss these extraordinary measures and that together we can find a solution.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Rapporteur. - (DE) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for the excellent work he has First of all, I would like to express my sincere thanks to my colleague, Mrs Eider, for making her words very clear about the priorities that the European Parliament is setting. At the beginning, I want to put a little bit of my frustration, to say so clearly and so loudly. Outside, we are discussing EUR 300 billion in investment aid, while here in the European Parliament we are seeing that we are not even in a position to set up Horizon 2020 with a billion in such a way that we can help small and medium-sized enterprises in terms of innovation and research in the long term, that we can promote innovation and research in the European area. Outside, we are piling up buildings where we do not even know where to pay the small bills. I have to say quite soberly that a little consistency in financial and budgetary policy would make some sense. Before I build all sorts of towers, perhaps I should at least put into practice what I have decided on programmes for further development in the European Union. We are currently in a state where we are sitting on 25 billion bills that we do not want to pay, which the Council does not want to pay. We now have some checks outside to change the criteria afterwards so that the bills become a few fewer. Even the most serious carriers are now stinky, and in some countries, some of which are waiting for a lot of money, which they have properly spent, where the promoters are entitled to the disbursement, there is now a growing suspicion of this European Union, simply because the Council is spending the money in its countries, but at the same time the invoices that are now being sent to the Commissioner. , does not want to pay. I consider this system to be completely unspeakable. When we talk about growth, when we talk about further development, then I would like to make it quite clear that we must also consistently do something about it and not make speeches on Sundays, nor do we use huge projects before we have been able to fill the fine print that we ourselves have given ourselves, so to speak. In addition, I also believe that if you go to the big print, you should also consider, is the money being spent wisely and does it actually make a lasting difference? Horizon 2020 is a very well thought-out programme with very long discussions in advance. I am deeply disappointed that the Council is cutting back on precisely these areas, particularly in the area of humanitarian aid and, in particular, in the area of development aid. This is something I have no understanding for at all. Now to the European Parliament's budget; it looks rather harmless. The European Parliament's budget is in a completely normal way. We have been able to press ahead with our cooperation with the Economic and Social Committee and cooperation with the Committee of the Regions, but there are two children of concern in the other institutions. One is the European Court of Justice, where we currently have to wait up to four years for the judgments, because there is not adequate equipment to make the judgments in a timely manner. This is becoming more and more a budgetary problem or a budgetary risk, because companies are suing the Court of Justice against the non-judgments, but at the same time they have to make security deposits, because they can be potentially condemned accordingly. The second is the European External Action Service, which is currently expected to carry out many tasks, particularly in the time of foreign policy crisis, and in the same breath, but the means by which it is supposed to do so are simply not enough. You don't want much, but it should at least be consistent, and it shouldn't be every negotiation that the foreign representative will conduct in the future on YouTube, but perhaps the IT systems that are at the level of 1980 should finally be brought up to the 2014 level, otherwise the whole thing makes no sense.

name: Enrico Zanetti
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, on 16 September, in this very House, we already had a first opportunity to discuss the draft budget for 2015, when I had the honour of presenting to you the Council's position. Because there is clearly a Council position here. I take note of the various amendments to the Council's position which the European Parliament is debating today and which it intends to vote on tomorrow. These amendments considerably increase the draft budget approved by the Council. Globally, the gap between our respective positions is EUR 1.3 billion in commitments and EUR 6.1 billion in payments. Furthermore, the amendments proposed by Parliament are higher than the European Commission's proposal of more than EUR 700 million in commitments and around EUR 4 billion in payments, even going beyond the ceilings of the multiannual financial framework. This involves the activation of contincengy margins on payments for 2015, with the obligation to recover in subsequent years. While the Council understands that the European Parliament wishes to support the Union's main spending policies with an ambitious budget, it considers the demands for an increase in appropriations, both commitment and payment, which are difficult to meet even in relation to the actual capacity to implement expenditure, that is, linked to the actual implementation of the underlying interventions. Therefore, the Council does not agree with the increase in appropriations that the European Parliament intends to vote on, since it considers these forecasts to be unrealistic, precisely with regard to the issue of the actual implementation of the underlying interventions, and not in line with the need to maintain adequate margins to deal with unforeseen expenditure during the year. In its position, moreover, the Council has left room for around EUR 2 billion in commitment and payment appropriations, which can be activated if the Commission considers that it is necessary during the financial year, in the face of both unforeseen circumstances and faster implementation of budgetary expenditure. This position represents, from the Council's point of view, a balanced compromise between the shared needs to support growth and employment and the equally important priorities linked to the sustainability of public accounts to which all Member States are subject and which involve generalised expenditure restraint, especially for administrative ones. It is precisely in this regard that I would also like to point out that the interinstitutional agreement provides, among other things, for a reduction in the staff of all the institutions, bodies and agencies by 5% until 2017. The Council hopes that the European Parliament will also take this requirement into account, both for the agencies and for parliament's own administration. I am sure that the work in the Conciliation Committee will, as always, be based on a constructive spirit of mutual trust between the institutions, with a view to reaching a balanced and mutually satisfactory agreement on the 2015 budget, in the interests of the European Union and its citizens, without in any way underestiming the sensitivity of the present moment, the wide gap between the starting positions and therefore the need for an absolutely extraordinary commitment on the part of all the actors involved. , starting with the Council.

name: Jacek Dominik
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, the EU budget for 2015 is the second budget under the multiannual financial framework for 2014-2020, which was agreed less than a year ago. We must put all our efforts into making this framework fully operational, fully respecting all the terms of this agreement. We must achieve the political goals set by the Member States and by this Parliament in the agreed legal acts. We must also honour our obligations and pay outstanding bills stemming from past commitments, thus avoiding an unnecessary burden on beneficiaries.  All this has to be achieved within very tight financial circumstances and very tight budgetary ceilings. This is only possible, therefore, if we use all the flexibility that we have. We must maintain the EU as a credible business partner for small and medium-sized enterprises and regional authorities, as a provider of opportunities for students and researchers. Sustainable economic growth, competitiveness, the creation of jobs and the fight against youth unemployment are other urgent priorities of the EU policy and should be reflected in the orientation of EU expenditure for 2015.  We must do this under a clear and agreed framework and provide the necessary predictability and security for our investments and our partners.  All that is reflected in the Commission proposal for the budget 2015.  Last month I expressed before this House the Commission’s concern about the position taken by the Council in its reading of the 2015 Budget. Both the substantial reductions proposed – the commitments of 500 million and the payments of over EUR 2 billion – on the very policies which are at the core of our common objectives are not in line with the political objectives we have set. I therefore welcome the proposal of the Committee on Budgets of the European Parliament which proposes to restore most of the appropriations proposed by the Commission in the draft budget.  I also see that Parliament is proposing a further increase in commitment appropriations to reinforce actions in support of competitiveness for growth and jobs, and for external actions including humanitarian aid. The increase proposed for a total amount of EUR 750 million is within the existing margins under the MFF commitment ceilings. However, even if further reinforcement contributes to increasing investments, we should try and find the right balance with the implementation prospects and the payments availability.  The level of payment appropriations remains the paramount concern that we need to address at this budget conciliation. We must ensure that the legal obligations arising in 2015 are met, and put a stop to the snowball effect of shifting an ever-increasing amount of unpaid bills into future years. Now is the critical moment to achieve this just by approving the amending budget for 2014. It has no additional costs for Member States and recognises the valid needs we have in payments for 2015. We cannot afford to have the EU budget paralysed. We need to bring it under control and we have at this moment a unique opportunity to do so.  In its draft budget, the Commission has proposed using the full amount of payment appropriations under the MFF ceiling for 2015. I thank Parliament for proposing that, for the vast majority of the budget lines, the levels of payments proposed by the Commission should be restored. I understand from Parliament’s position on the draft amending budget and the budget for 2015 that it has taken very seriously the issue of the backlog and that it wishes to solve it as soon as possible. I fully agree that we must act responsibly and address at this stage the needs that we have in payments.  In its amending letter No 1 to the draft budget of 2015, the Commission proposed redeploying EUR 448 million in payment appropriations for programmes that are expected to face payment shortages in 2015. The redeployment of payment appropriations is possible because of the additional assigned revenue accruing to the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund.  The reinforcement of payment appropriations proposed by the Commissionʼs amending letter No 1 go in the same direction as a number of amendments proposed by Parliament where the needs are most pressing, and in particular with the aim of reducing the backlog of unpaid bills and allowing the proper launching of the new programmes.  This is necessary given the tight budgetary situation and is fully in line with the budgetary rules. Please treat this bold move as a sign of the Commission’s determination to stabilise the situation through redeployment too. We must avoid artificial under-budgeting in future as we are now all aware of the problems that such an approach brings. We can work within the overall budget context but we need to make full use of the elements of flexibility agreed in the Multiannual Financial Framework.  We are discussing the budget for 2015, but it remains clear and absolutely indispensable that the first step must be to stabilise the growing backlog of unpaid bills at the end of the year and the adoption of Draft Amending Budget (DAB) No 3 for 2014 which has been on the table since May. I fully share the Parliament’s sense of urgency to make progress on this proposal. As you know, favourable developments on the revenue side in 2014 provide an opportunity to find agreement in this direction. Exceptional additional revenue from fines stemming from the enforcement of competition policy means that the additional payment requests for 2014 will be, in total, at no cost for Member States. We should seize such an opportunity to address the shortage of payment appropriations in 2014.  I would conclude by assuring you that the Commission will do its utmost to act as an honest broker to help increase the efficiency of the budget, ensuring the credibility of the EU and gaining control and stabilising the budget. This is in the interests of us all.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. - First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her efforts to find a compromise with the Council on the budget for the coming year. As rapporteur for the AFET Committee, I cannot agree with the Council that the so-called global European budget would be cut off at present, facing europe and the world as a whole, with military threats to international peace and stability. The cuts made by the Council must therefore not only be restored, but also increased in priority areas, i.e. additional funding must be used to strengthen the European Neighbourhood Policy so that the European Union can properly fulfil its commitments in both eastern and southern countries. The lack of funding for humanitarian aid hampers the smooth implementation of this policy and undermines the European Union's prestige and ability to respond to humanitarian crises. In next year's budget, we want to see adequate funding for both the Middle East peace process and Palestine, to settle crises in Iraq, Syria and Gaza.

name: Reimer BÖGE
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on International Trade. - (DE) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for the excellent work he has In its opinion on the 2015 general budget, the Committee on Trade identified a number of key points, in particular the appropriate funding for the Directorate-General for Trade, so that the European trade agenda can be implemented efficiently and consistently, but, above all, existing agreements can be better monitored and evaluated in their impact. This applies not only to 2015, but also to the coming years. It will be all the more necessary to take this point into account. Secondly, the Commission should provide citizens and the public with more information about their activities and the ongoing negotiations. Thirdly, we support the increase in the macro-financial assistance instrument and deplore cuts to the Neighbourhood Instrument. This does not correspond to the political necessity that we see today. We call on the Commission to re-issue the budget line on fair trade. We warmly welcome the fact that our concern to increase the budget for a comprehensive communication strategy has also been adopted by the Committee on Budgets. Anything else will be necessary if the Commission, the Council and Parliament are to launch a strategy that is successful in the medium term, including in the area of the external trade budget.

name: Markus PIEPER
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control. - (DE) Mr President, I would like to thank Yes, I agree with the complaints made by colleagues: many billions of outstanding funds in cohesion policy. We simply jeopardise the planning security of the region. When we talk about money, however, the criticism cannot be directed solely against the Council. Keyword: incorrect expenditure. Why do correction procedures take five years or more? Why does the Commission allow the same states to always make the same mistakes? Why do we not consistently ask about European added value? Why is the Commission refusing to take more responsibility? Why does the Court of Auditors refuse to take particular care of certain countries? Anyone who, in the small circle of European institutions, simply keeps passing on the Black Peter will soon have it in his own hands. We are all called upon to do more to ensure that the European budget is genuinely protected and used effectively.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: rapporteur on the opinion of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. - (C) The EU budget is a good tool for creating added value when Europe needs it. Programmes such as Erasmus+, the European Youth Guarantee and Horizon 2020 allow us to create growth and jobs, but this will not happen if we do not have the funds in the budget. As a result, the EU currently has over 23 billion unpaid bills. At the beginning of October, President Barroso expressed his concern to the Italian Presidency about the existence of too many unpaid bills. A week later, the leading politicians of the Member States are meeting and are concerned that there is no money to pay for the youth guarantee. That's what you could call political schizophrenia. In English that is 'political schizophrenia'. If you do not give the money and then you ask for more money, then you have probably lost something between your ears.  This is not responsible budgeting. This is not responsible politics. We are going to lift Europe out of the political crisis, and then we need a little backbone from the Council as well.

name: Maria ARENA
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. Mr President, in general, we can say that we would have liked a more ambitious budget for Europe, especially when it comes to employment and we are facing high unemployment rates. We have seen, as my colleague just said, that there is a backlog of $23 billion. With such a backlog, it is therefore difficult for local, regional or national operators to carry out correct employment policies. We can therefore be satisfied that we have increased the amount of this line by 6 billion, but unfortunately, this 6 billion does not compensate for the 23 billion arrears, including arrears in cohesion policies.  We also wanted to improve the situation of social innovation, social dialogue, the European Fund for Aid to the Most Deprived and the Horizon 2020 programme to boost research and development. These are always important priorities for which we feel that the resources put on the table are not sufficient. Therefore, there is again an important call for employment.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in recent years we have fought hard as a Parliament to ensure that the European budget has the necessary funds to ensure the proper implementation of all policies. We have done so responsibly, and we will do so tomorrow with the vote on our position, on the 2015 budget. As chairman of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy, I would remind you of the importance of implementing the new multiannual programmes which fall under our responsibility: the Third Union Action Programme in the field of health; the Environment and Climate Action Programme; the Union's civil protection mechanism. We believe it is essential to provide the necessary appropriations as proposed by the Commission in its DB, so that these new programmes can fully realise their potential. And I think I find an appropriate balance between commitment and payment appropriations. I would also remind you of the importance of Horizon 2020, for research projects in the field of climate, health and the environment, as well as resources for the common agricultural policy – which is already damaged by agreements and restrictions from neighbouring Russia – can only enjoy the full support of the budget. I would like to end by expressing the hope that payments will be made in the way that is necessary.

name: Jerzy BUZEK
text: draft opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. - (C) Mr President, I would like to begin by thank We have already healed the European economy, but we do not yet have a strategy to get out of the crisis. We are in danger of stagnate if we do not drive the economy, especially through small and medium-sized innovative enterprises, by reindustrialisation, by running a modern industry, also by safe and as cheap energy as possible. All this can be achieved by funding programmes such as COSME for small and medium-sized enterprises, such as Horizon 2020 or the Connecting Europe Facility, and it is in these areas that the Council has proposed a cut of more than 10%, a dozen per cent , the largest in the whole budget. It is difficult to imagine that we could meet the expectations of young people in Europe in particular, create attractive new jobs without restoring funding as proposed by the Commission. That's the minimum. And that's what we're calling for.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. - Mr President, thanks to colleagues from across the political spectrum for their cooperation on the IMCO Committee’s 2015 Budget opinion. I would also like to take this opportunity to thank the Secretariat, and in particular Elena, for her knowledge, advice and guidance when we had just two weeks to timetable this opinion. For the IMCO Committee, the new reality of the digital single market has focused minds and led us to prioritise the links between SMEs and consumer rights as it applies online. I was delighted to see the Budget Committee support my proposal for a pilot project to support SMEs in fulfilling their obligations to consumers when selling online. The Commissioner-designate for the Digital Single Market, Andrus Ansip, said that trust is critical to citizens choosing to purchase online. We also know that the online environment is critical to SME growth markets, where reaching 500 million EU customers has huge potential. In this House, we need to make the digital single market work for both consumers and SMEs.

name: Roberts ZĪLE
text: draftser of the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. - Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur Overall, the Committee on Transport welcomes the fact that in the expenditure section "Mobility and Transport" funding will be increased in 2015 compared to this year – 2014. At the same time, the Committee on Transport regrets that the Committee on Budgets did not support our proposals to increase appropriations for the Connecting Europe Facility, which is extremely important not only in the field of transport, but also geopolitically, particularly in eastern Europe. However, it is positive that the Committee on Budgets agrees that the funding should be kept to the extent proposed by the Commission, and i think that this is a good negotiating position with the Council, precisely in the transport sector. I would also like to mention some smaller points. As we can see, cycling and cycling paths are also developing as one of the modes of transport. As a backd you, our internal proposal – without increasing expenditure on the development of cycle path infrastructure within the framework of the transport budget – remains a topical issue in our view. Thank you!

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Regional Development. - Mr President, I hope most Members in the Chamber recognise the importance of EU regional policy and funds. All our regions benefit from EU structural funds. For example, most infrastructure and training schemes in Wales are at least partly funded by the European Union. Therefore, EU regional funds play an important, indeed vital, part in trying to improve economic prosperity right across the EU. I therefore find it difficult to understand any proposal to cut European structural funds.  The Committee on Regional Development was particularly concerned about the EUR 23 billion backlog in payments and the impact this will have on local authorities, businesses, universities and young people. In the UK alone, there is GBP 1.2 billion of backlogs in terms of payments. Therefore, the Committee on Regional Development believes the budget for heading 1b should at least be restored to the draft budget. We call on the Council to accept this as soon as possible and to accept the draft amending budgets which are proposed as well. We call on beneficiaries who are concerned about delays in payments they face to make their views known to Member States, because if they will not listen to us, perhaps they will listen to voters.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture. - (DE) Mr President, I would like to thank In the context of the budget discussions, I would like to draw attention to a particular problem in agriculture: the European agricultural sector is in the midst of a sales crisis. We have seen prices fall, particularly for fruit and vegetables and for dairy products. This is not a market disruption caused by the farmers themselves, but a politically staged crisis. As a result of the Russian embargo reactions, agricultural producer prices are falling. Our farmers must be helped. For example, our milk producers in Estonia, Lithuania, Latvia and Finland need our immediate help at a milk price of 19 cents per litre. To do this, we need annual repayments to the agricultural budget. It is farmers' money for farmers. The Commission's decision to take the money away from us farmers, so to speak, is not appropriate, it is not effective, and is quite simply a naughty thing that we cannot tolerate. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8))

name: Ulrike MÜLLER
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Jahr, can you share with me the view that the money in the agricultural sector cannot be taken alone to finance this Russian embargo? Do you think that in 2015 it will actually have an impact and that the money in the first pillar will not be enough and that farmers will therefore also have to fear cuts?

name: Peter JAHR
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr President, I really believe that we have a sales crisis here, which farmers have not caused themselves, but which has been caused by politics. It would therefore be wrong to activate the emergency fund alone, but we must also tap the funds that are going back to us. There is enough money in the fund, so agriculture could help itself on its own. We must discuss this and debate it with the Commission. Otherwise, next year, direct payments for all farmers will have to be reduced. This is irresponsible and, of course, not a confidence-building measure for farmers in the European Union.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Culture, Youth, the Media and Sport. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as chairman of the Committee on Culture and budget rapporteur, I would like to thank the rapporteur for sharing our opinion on the serious cut – which, in my opinion, is truly unacceptable and contradictory – which the Council has made, by more than 3.3% in heading 3, which is the one which provides for some very popular programmes such as creative Europe which supports culture. , creativity and the audiovisual industry, but also Europe for citizens already cut by 20% in the seven years, as well as the Marie Curie Fellowships, which are an important response to young researchers.  Above all – and I say this in support of other Members – payments for 2014, which have not yet been honoured by the Council, are at risk, and they are seriously undermining the Erasmus programme. It is not possible to talk about Erasmus in the election campaign, by everyone, including by governments, and then cut back and not honour the commitments made with young people who risk being left without grants. We see this as one of the prerequisites for moving forward in the possibility of developing the programmes. We know that there is a lack of resources of over EUR 200 million for Erasmus, but also for other programmes, which have already been financed from the point of view of the Member States, putting the Member States in great difficulty because this will be considered a negative performance of the Erasmus programme.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: draftsman of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. - Mr President, I would like to say, for the area of security, that it must be remembered that it is perhaps more important than ever, not only in view of the situation in Southern and Eastern Europe. It is necessary to further strengthen internal security, combat illegal immigration or link information within the Schengen area. It is therefore necessary to refuse to underfund this area, and therefore we absolutely disagree with the Council's proposal, which has significantly s cut the budget and we want to return it to the level proposed by the European Commission. In addition, it was necessary to increase the budgets of some agencies, such as Europol, Frontex or eu-LISA. These are the main programmes of the current Commission. We are not proposing anything extra, and we are also advocating the digitisation of the European security area.

name: Danuta Maria HÜBNER
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs. - Mr President, the 2015 budget is clearly not ‘business as usual’. The way the multiannual financial framework (MFF) for 2014-2019 was constructed has left us very low ceilings for 2014 and 2015. We have no other choice but to stick to the MFF agreement and use these ceilings fully, in particular with regard to payment appropriations. This is my first comment. My second point is that amendments to the 2014 budget come at a low cost to Member States. There is no reason not to deliver them, because they are the precondition for stabilising the growing backlog.  My third comment: the European Parliament agreed to lower budgets for 2011, 2012 and 2013 to help Member States with their fiscal consolidation. But now is the last wake-up call to address the postponed challenges and to clear the way towards stabilisation of the entire multiannual financial framework.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Development. - (DE) Mr President, I would like to thank I would also like to congratulate the Commission on the draft, because, of course, next year is the year of development policy and we must focus on this, but we also see that urgent matters and rapid payments are of the utmost importance. If we look at the flashpoints that exist around the European Union, it is urgently necessary to be on the spot with payments quickly and not just to create commitments that can then be honoured very late. I believe that the neighbourhood policy and humanitarian aid are an absolute priority. That is why I do not understand why the Council is cutting back massively in this area, just as in category 1, where research, particularly in the case of Ebola and various other diseases, is at stake. We urgently need these research programmes here, and the delay in payment that has occurred here in the meantime is completely irresponsible. That is why I believe that we must have tough negotiations here in order to achieve our objectives.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: on behalf of the Ppe Group. – The People's Party advocates a credible, supportive budget that contributes to growth and jobs. In this sense, the Council's cuts of more than 500 million in commitments and 2 100 million in payments are unacceptable. That is also why we have strengthened programmes for SMEs, youth, research and innovation, as well as the programme to support the most disadvantaged. External solidarity is another concern, as evidenced by the increases we propose in humanitarian aid, support for refugees and neighbourhood policy. The treaties, financial regulations, the European Union 2020 strategy, the multiannual financial framework 2014-2020 must be respected. It is a compromise between the institutions but it is also a commitment to citizens and this Europe 2020 strategy that guides the multiannual financial framework must see its objectives achieved, must also see and have the means necessary for those same objectives to be achieved. In fact, the means have to be up to the point of ambition. The multiannual financial framework, its programmes, funds and priorities is required to be rapidly operational. To talk about the European Union budget is to talk about a budget that accounts for about 1% of gross national income, but a budget that is mainly an investment budget (94% is for investment). It has only 6% expenditure for the administration and functioning of the institutions, thus belying the populists who always criticize the administration of our institutions. And it is also a budget that has high added value and therefore should be used for growth, for jobs.  I hope that the Council will not insist on reducing the budget, meeting the objectives and helping growth and jobs.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: First of all, on behalf of the Group of S and D- - Mr President, I would like to welcome the rapporteur, Eider Gardiazabal, for her excellent work on the 2015 budget. It allows Parliament to have a particularly ambitious position around an agreement that brings together the bulk of its political groups. I want to assure the rapporteur of the support of the Group of Socialists and Democrats, which I represent this evening. We share his determination to restore a European ambition for growth and jobs to the reality of the budget. Minister, last November, we decided on a seven-year agreement in the same chamber, with specific budgetary commitments and necessary flexibility mechanisms. A year later, what does the Council propose to us? It refuses to mobilise the instruments of flexibility and it makes 2 billion budget cuts on strategic expenditure, expenditure that relates to actions already carried out and which are waiting for the Union to pay its bills. Yes, we know the difficult situation of the Member States' public finances, but they themselves have decided to apply an austere bloodletting in the midst of a crisis. For centuries, we have known that applying bleeding worsens the patient's health. And what does the Council propose? A new bloodletting and this time in the Community budget. Yet, meeting after meeting, everyone proclaims that they want a recovery plan for growth and jobs in Europe, but how can we believe in a stimulus package when we start by not paying what we owe? Minister, tell the Council that the only act of confidence that would relaunch this stage is the one proposed to you by MePs today: pay back to the Europeans 10 billion euros out of the 32 you owe them.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the We are talking about an EU budget, which was initially drafted by the Commission with EUR 142 billion. The Council has cut this draft by EUR 2 billion, and now the majority of Parliament's Committee on Budgets is proposing an increase to EUR 164.4 billion. That is, after all, 8% more than the original 2014 budget – against a backdrop of high- and partly over-indebted Member States. They have no money to spend on these increases. Another important point is that the EU has already entered into payment commitments worth EUR 222 billion. Of these, EUR 23 billion is currently due, and the bills are on the table. However, the EU has no money to pay these bills. This is a scandal! In a solution to the problem, the 2015 budget must also be designed accordingly. Therefore, the allowable commitments must be well below the payment budget until the budget gap is closed. Those who refuse to do so will help the EU to break the treaty. In fact, the draft now before us does not include commitment appropriations as high as payments. This means that this bill will not be borne in the future. Against this background, we in the ECR Group reject this draft budget because it is not forward-looking in order to solve the existing budget gap, the existing payment problems. Moreover, we simply do not believe that the budget is actually geared to the demands of the future, which mean, in particular, that sustainable growth must be promoted, that jobs must also be promoted in the long term.

name: Kaja KALLAS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, during the negotiations on the 2015 budget, my Group strongly supported the need to focus on administration efficiency and selected priorities. Savings cannot happen in one day, as we still need to have functioning EU institutions. That is why a budget increase for the Court of Justice is needed to deliver judgments on time, as delays simply hamper the functioning of the single market. The same goes for the budget of the External Action Service, as we need to provide further assistance to Ukraine.  As far as other institutions are concerned, any new spending or creation of posts should be more carefully thought through, as new posts create a snowball effect of new spending with a new need for offices and buildings. It is absolutely essential to apply fully the principles of administration efficiency and transparency on spending as this will help reinforce citizensʼ trust in the EU institutions.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: thar ceann an Ghrúpa GUE/NGL. –  A Uachtaráin, gheall an Chomhairle go raibh siad chun infheistíocht a dhéanamh i ndaoine agus is léir ón dréachtbhuiséad seo go bhfuil an gealltanas sin tréigthe acu agus go bhfuil siad sásta leanúint ar aghaidh sa treo céanna. Aithnítear go forleathan go bhfuil an méid déine atá ag teacht ón Eoraip ag cur brú ollmhór ar ghnáthdhaoine. Tá sé mhíle dhéag daoine i gContae Chiarraí i mo thír féin ag dul agus ag baint úsáid as banc bia. Timpeall na hEorpa tá na mílte páistí ag maireachtáil i mbochtanas agus tá an scéal seo ag dul in olcas. Is fadhb ollmhór í an eisimirce chomh maith leis na céadta daoine ag fágaint ár dtír. Is  daoine óga atá ag fágaint mo thír, an Ghréig, an Spáinn agus an Iodáil agus an Eoraip – iadsan ár dtodhchaí. Tá sé soiléir chomh maith go bhfuil tíortha éagsúla ag fulaingt níos mó ná tíortha eile agus ba mhaith liom fáil amach cad atá sé i gceist a dhéanamh chun na difríochtaí ollmhóra idir na Ballstáit go léir a shocrú. Mar aon leis sin, tá an neamhshuim atá léirithe ag an gCoimisiún i dtaobh na n-iascairí scannalach. In Éirinn tá ár bpobal iascaireachta i gcruachás mór agus is léir nach bhfuil mórán dóchais dóibh ann don todhchaí le tuilleadh gearrtha siar atá i ndán dóibh i 2015. Tá traidisiún phobal an chósta á scriosadh, ní hamháin ar chúrsaí eacnamaíochta ach táthar ag cur deireadh le traidisiún cultúrtha atá ag dul i bhfad siar.  Caithfear an bunstruchtúr a chur in ord go luath ionas go mbeidh fás agus borradh fós ann agus go mbeidh luach á chur i ndaoine mar idir an dá linn tá postanna agus slí bheatha daoine scaoilte le fána agus imithe le sruth. Mar sin tá dualgas agus freagracht ar an gCoimisiún agus ar an gComhairle dul i ngleic leis an bhfadhb seo.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, about forty minutes ago I was forced to quote the Ancient Roman, Cato, and now Mr Zanetti has forced me to quote George Orwell. Because the way that the Council depicts the budget reality would certainly have impressed Big Brother when it comes to propaganda. The Council wants to make us believe that everything is fine; that the Council is enhancing EU competitiveness, thus countering the effects of the crisis and making Europe ready to face further tough globalisation challenges.  In reality, thanks to the Council, universities and research stakeholders will have to wait longer and longer in order to receive their EU funds. Even more SMEs will go bankrupt because EU funds for their projects do not arrive and NGOs will face even tougher bureaucratic hurdles as the Commission will do everything possible to delay its payments as it simply does not have enough money to honour all its contracts – well ʽm.  The result is clear. The EU institutions will become even less credible; maybe some in the Council actually want this. The quality of EU research will go down and our SMEs will become less competitive. This is to say nothing of the victims of natural disasters and civil wars throughout the world. The Council is telling them: do not count on the European Union.  On the other side, Parliament has assumed its responsibilities and I would like to congratulate our rapporteurs for the excellent work they did. They can count on our Group’s support in tomorrow’s vote, except for a few points where we have different views. For example, on the necessity to finance a very cost-intensive fusion energy plant which will only produce results in 2050, if at all. However, I am happy that thanks to the efforts of the Green Group the EU budget will be a little greener by reserving more funds for renewable energy, recycling activities and green entrepreneurial innovations.

name: Marco VALLI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am 29 years old and, for the first time this year, I have been able to contribute to this work on the European Union budget and I would like to make a couple of points, to make a couple of suggestions to my fellow Members and to those who are here to listen to me. Firstly, I would like to go into the substance of the programmes and see the performance of the European funds and the programmes that we are going to allocate, because it is not said that a fund with a good name then has efficient performance, so let us check the Union's expenditure well. Then we reluctantly proposed and rejected, numerous cuts to what are waste and public spending precisely unproductive. Could we make better use of taxpayers' money, by which I mean, do we really need EUR 28 million a year for the parties and EUR 14 million a year for political foundations?
