Are EUR 12 million really needed for propaganda communications on the euro and on Europe? Are hundreds of millions of pre-accession funds needed when Juncker announced that there will be no new entries during his term of office? Can we find a way of getting the money to the taxpayers of Europe, or do you want to continue to mis manage these tens of billions from sacrifices? Sacrifices of workers, workers who open the shutters of their shops every day and pay contributions to advance society.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Mr President, today, once again in the context of the debate on the preliminary draft budget for 2015, it is confirmed that the European Union, in the way it has been organised and exercising its power, has lost its orientation. It has shifted its centre of gravity more towards numbers and economic power than towards its own citizens.  On the one hand, the Council is trying to manipulate European citizens to retain power over them. It promises them growth, money, jobs and a better tomorrow, without being able to really argue where these specific funds will come from. On the other hand, the European Parliament, with its pluralism and babylonian composition, cannot clearly see the way it must go for the good of the citizens of a united Europe. It is lost in the processes and micro-partisanship of its numerous representative members to the delight of their national voters.  What is the benefit of this budget as you plan to implement it? How do you help countries in economic crisis? An artificial crisis leading to the control of nations. But I forgot, you don't deal with people, you don't deal with souls, you deal with business numbers and memoranda. You don't deal with young people, you deal with the unemployed, you deal with programs, corporate finance and employers. In other words, you deal with capital, banks and interests. That's the kind of budget we don't want. Such policies are policies of deception, they are policies of fog and disorientation. Such policies will be demonstrated and voted against.

name: Jan OLBRYCHT
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Discussions on the annual budget are always discussions about the shape of the Union. In fact, we forget that, after all, we are talking about a very small contribution by the Member States to the common budget, because the Member States keep most of the money for themselves, and we are discussing it as if the Union is responsible for everything that is happening in each Member State. We are trying for an EU budget to mobilise certain actions and mechanisms, and yet 2015 is the second year of the financial perspective, that is, the year in which the accounts will run down in line with the n+2 rule of 2013, that is, the last year of settlement of the previous perspective. We can expect spending to build up, so if we know that the budget is going to be very difficult and the spending is going to be bigger, we cannot make a move to reduce the budget – which means that we are in an atmosphere of impending budgetary crisis today. We've already worked it out a few times. Parliament is ready to act decisively and decisively when it comes to concications, and we are ready to defend our position firmly.

name: Jens GEIER
text: Mr. President, dear colleagues! There are two camps in this house. Some complain that the EU is too expensive, and others – including myself – assume that the EU has tasks to perform. In the budgetary procedure, we are constantly faced with the difficult situation wherethe Member States are to assign tasks to the EU on the one hand and, of course, the EU should also carry out these tasks – most of the time, the Member States have thought something about it being done at European level – and then the Member States say: yes, but we do not pay for the task. Now, as a budgetary controller – and I am also – we can certainly think a lot about how to make payments more effective in the European Union. How do we get a little better grip on our budget? We have to say that the management and control systems of the same Member States are not in order and are often used to use European money. We are therefore in an intensive discussion with the Council on how we can get a grip on the European budget and how we manage it better. But, Mr Zanetti, we cannot do that with cuts. And Mr Kölmel, we probably cannot do that by lowering the commitments, because they are not taken out of the air, but are derived from the tasks that the European Union has to perform. With the other institutions concerned, we have a situation in which the European Parliament must increase its budget. This goes back to two special effects that have to do with the end of the legislature. For the first time, larger parts of our colleagues are retiring in accordance with the Members' Statute, and the European Parliament has to pay for it. This is a special effect which the Council must also take note of when discussing the budget of the other institutions.

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: Mr President! Europe has just gone through a huge crisis, many European countries have had to cut their budgets quite drastically. Nevertheless, we are here today dealing with a draft budget in which a majority in this Parliament wants to continue spending, to continue spending, to continue spending money that is not there because we think we are better at spending the money than the nation states that find it for us. That is simply not acceptable! That is why, on behalf of the ECR Group, I would very much like to appeal to my colleagues to keep together with the Council the agreed budget ceiling that existed on the part of the Council, so that together we can get Europe out of the crisis and further along a better path. The way out of this crisis is not, as it is now, that money continues to be proposed for more and more projects, which often end up in too much waste and waste. The way out, it is that we take the spoon in the other hand, take ourselves seriously as a Parliament and take on the task of saving the budget and not spending more on us.

name: Pablo ECHENIQUE
text: Mr President, the absence of democracy and a stone cardboard democracy are two very similar things. In this great European theatre, today we are actors in a drama with a known ending: more austericide, more unemployment, more misery.  In the first act of the work, the European Commission proposes ractic budgets for 2015: neither cohesion, nor R&D, nor stimulus against unemployment, nor promotion of renewable energy, or anything. What's big in the mouths is small and let's see in the numbers.  In the second act of the drama, the Council arrives, cuts 500 million more and then, in the final act, ladies and gentlemen of the whole parliamentary arc are very answerable and very Keynesian, but only with the second part. They accept three-quarters of the cut, but they look great in the media. If you approve of these irresponsible budgets, you cannot be surprised that the millions of people living in an economic emergency turn their backs on the institutions that no longer serve or listen to them. If you turn this Parliament into a theatre, do not be surprised after people turn theatres, streets and squares into real parliaments, into parliaments called to replace it.

name: Monika VANA
text: Mr. President! In the hearing of the Committee on Budgets, The Budget Commissioner-designate Georgieva said that the EU budget directly affects people's lives and that it is a task for us, as European politicians, to explain the added value of the European budget. I would like to support this statement. That is why I find it all the more questionable why the Council is presenting a budget that cuts the very importance of areas of competitiveness, growth and employment, social affairs and research in areas that are so important for people's lives, so that the Europe 2020 targets are even further away than they are now, why, of all things, funding for development cooperation is being cut in the European Year of Development and humanitarian aid is also being cut. Why the problem of out-of-date payments, the payment gap, is still unresolved, so that supporters have to fear for their promised payments, and why there are still such antiquated, outdated subsidies as for bullfighting and for farmers who receive subsidies only for breeding bulls for the purpose of bullfighting. We Greens will put amendments to the vote tomorrow and hope that many Members of this House will assume their responsibilities. It is about the credibility of this House and of the EU budget.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: Mr President, the Group standing up for democracy in this Parliament is back. Democracy will not be silenced. I do not intend to give a speech so much as to ask Members a few questions about their consciences and about how they are going to vote, in the light of the payments problem, and the fact that the European Union is currently spending money which it does not have.  We do not need tax payers to pay for cruelty to animals. Will you vote to scrap EU subsidies for bullfighting? At a time of austerity we do not need a self-aggrandising museum. Will you vote to scrap the House of History? Will you vote to scrap the gentleman’s agreement between the Parliament, Council and Commission that keeps costs for all three high?   Will we vote to cut our own salaries and allowances? Will we vote to scrap funding for Europarl TV? I am going to vote in line with the wishes of my constituents, not in line with the wishes of the Euro elite. Will you do the same? Sadly, for many in this place, I think I already know the answer.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: Mr President, this general budget of the European Union for 2015, presented as the miracle cure for reviving and stimulating growth, creating jobs or promoting competitiveness and investment in all 28 Member States, is just a decoy. As in previous budgets, no real savings will be achieved by the Union, any section, any action, any programme, any project being obviously considered necessary, indispensable and high priority.  On both the left and the right, you are demanding expenses and more expenses that will eventually be financed by a direct European tax. Exit the budgetary rigour, yet required of the Member States. The Union is a supranational authority which obeys only its own rules, including budgetary rules.  Yet the economic and social situation in the euro area should have made you think. Sluggish growth, recession in sight, explosion of unemployment, acceleration of impoverishment, constant rise in business failures, endless relocations, these are some very concrete examples of the results of all your European policies. You have imposed on the people, with the complicity of the governments of the right and the left, the single currency. In France, the purchasing power of our compatriots has melted like snow in the sun, paralyzing the engine of consumption. You have imposed ultraliberal dogma and free and undistorted competition. In France, our companies and our industries have found themselves tied up in the face of totally unfair competition from countries with low production costs. You have imposed the so-called detached workers directive, thus creating legally and with the utmost cynicism, in France, a monstrous social dumping, the least so-called in terms of the costs leading to the least social in sectors otherwise directly linked to investment, such as construction, public works or transport. You are calling for more and more immigration, even as France has more than five million unemployed and 8.4 million poor people.  This is your Europe, that of submission to markets and banks, of ultraliberalism, unemployment, deindustrialization and zero growth.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: Mr President, the Council's position on the 2015 budget proposal is unacceptable. The reduction of payment appropriations for 2015 by 2.1 billion affects in particular the funds for competitiveness for growth and employment and is blatantly contrary to the Council's commitment to overcome the crisis and revive economic growth. Payment appropriations are linked to national contributions and Member States continue to have negative attitudes. The Stability and Growth Pact is not only respected by reducing national contributions, on the contrary. Partnership agreements must ensure maximum convergence between structural and investment funds and national budgets, and national strategies must be developed quickly to make the use of funds more efficient and generate sustainable economic growth. The recurring problem of the insufficiency of payment appropriations must be resolved urgently, the volume of payment arrears in recent years, 23.4 billion at the end of 2013 alone under cohesion policy, must be drastically reduced. I support an increase of 4 billion in the level of payments proposed by the Commission to a number of budget lines, including those dedicated to honouring the obligations under the 2007-2013 Multiannual Financial Framework. Conciliation on the 2015 budget must be conditional on the completion of negotiations on additional payment needs for 2014.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there is an Italian expression which I believe Mr Zanetti is certainly aware of which says 'throw your heart out of the way'. It is an expression that means putting passion and courage to achieve the goals that you have and that you give each other. The objective here, which is a shared objective – I believe in this House – is to return to growth. We all agree, for some time now, that after ten years of so-called austerity, we have finally had a Europe that is once again aiming for growth and aiming to invest in research, development, the environment, training and employment. It aims to invest in Europe. It aims to invest in its future. There are so many tools to achieve this. The Juncker plan, whose proposal we look forward to. Our rapporteur said that there is a revision of the multiannual financial framework and there is also the budget among these instruments. The budget can also be one of the instruments, as the Commission believes, as this Parliament believes. The question is whether the Council also believes in it. If the Council also believes that the budget can be an instrument for arriving at a new situation, a new condition and the conditions for taking a new direction are all there. There is a new Parliament, there is a new Commission that is about to take office, there is a european semester guide that is a vital guide. The question is – and therefore the question I am asking – whether this guide wants to put passion and courage into it, because growth, if one objective is shared, is because also through the budgetary instrument we can achieve this objective in which we all believe.

name: Christian EHLER
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". I would like to ask another question about the budget, which specifically concerns Horizon 2020, that is, the research programme. We are now going to Horizon with EUR 8.6 billion from the old FP7. We are now again making cuts of 1.1 billion, which means that we are with a programme of just under 70 billion, with 10 billion payments that are not available at the moment. Against this background, I would like to ask the Commission once again: what is left of an innovative Europe?

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Excuse me, the question can be put to Members or speakers, not to the Commission or the Council. This is according to the Rules of Procedure.

name: Richard ASHWORTH
text: Mr President, I welcome the Juncker proposals to increase spending on jobs and growth, but unless that extra spending is matched by cuts in inefficient programmes and greater strategic prioritisation, then 12 months from now we will be seeing a bigger pile of unpaid bills and ever-increasing rows. It is the Member States who, on the one hand, have the responsibility for spending 80% of the budget and who, on the other hand, restrict the size of the budget. I am not calling for a bigger budget – Council was right to cap revenue – but I am insisting that there is an urgent need for greater budgetary discipline and control. If we do not, our payments problem will only get worse. Furthermore, should the three institutions prove themselves incapable of exercising that control, should the commitments budget prove to be in excess of funding available, or should this budget place the budgetary authority in an unlawful position, is it not time that we came to consider the establishment of an independent office of budgetary responsibility?

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: Mr President, our position on the budget and in the face of this proposal reflects our position on this European Union with its neoliberal, federalist and militarist matrix.  The European Union budget is the concrete expression of a political line aimed at promoting the dismantling of public services, the loss of social and labour rights and public-private partnerships. This is the budget that supports austerity, the European Semester and all the agencies that monitor and condition member states' policies and punish bad pupils. It is the budget that supports the increasingly aggressive interferences in various parts of the globe, which builds a Fortress Europe, less and less sympathetic to its neighbors.  This farce, or this pseudo-dispute between the Commission and the Council, cannot divert us from the essential, which is the condemnation of the neoliberal policies of this European Union, supported by this budget.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Council has certainly got the approach to dealing with the budget wrong by proposing linear cuts without going into the specifics of the individual budget headings. Parliament, however – in my opinion – repeated the same mistake, restoring the lines as a whole and going even further in some cases. We must therefore avoid ending up in a gruelling and counterproductive tug-of-war for everyone. I have just arrived here, but two things seem quite clear to me: we have scarce resources and there is a problem with backpayers. Let us therefore reduce where possible from the waste of the European institutions, including Parliament. Tomorrow we see who will vote among us to reduce these unnecessary expenditure. I believe that this could be a small signal, but that the citizens of Europe would certainly appreciate it.  In order to limit the problem of payments in the future, however, in my opinion, the solution at the moment is only one: to reduce commitments. And we can start, for example, from pre-accession funds to Turkey, which will certainly not soon join the European Union, or we can block nuclear funding or cancel funding for political foundations. There are a number of options available, all that is needed is political will to do so.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: Mr President, it is late and most European farmers are in bed at this time, but it is also a moment of truth for them. Without wanting to take too long, I will simply say that agriculture is the poor relative of the budget. The agriculture budget for 2015 is the capitulation budget. Capitulation to other necessities to produce, with the generalization of decoupled aid. The capitulation in the face of the decline in the income of farmers, French and European, whose aid decreases sharply because of this budget. The capitulation still - and it is not over - in front of the big competing blocs, such as the United States, which, by its new farm bill, takes over the logic of production that you have abandoned. Finally, the capitulation that leads you today to trim the original objectives of the CAP: to ensure our food self-sufficiency, to preserve decent incomes for European farmers and to guarantee the quality and, in particular, traceability of our products.

name: Ingeborg GRÄSSLE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has It is madness what is being said here, I have to say. After all, the expertise is manageable. I would like to know, as we can say about a capitulation in the case of an agricultural budget of 59 billion. I would like to refer to the 2015 budget as a budget for growth and employment. That is why I find it regrettable that no one wants to use these funds from this budget, in which we are doing so much to combat youth unemployment and the Youth Guarantee. The labour ministers of the Member States have put together a package of EUR 6 billion for the so-called Youth Employment Initiative, and now we see that the implementation of the decisions is in a huge state of a state. In its reading of the draft budget, the Council did not even shy away from cutting payment appropriations in the European Social Fund, which, among other things, also provides funds for combating youth unemployment. It would be urgent to keep the funds in this way, particularly in this area. Unfortunately, the Member States are also in no hurry to implement the agreed measures. In fact, of the EUR 6 billion spent on the Youth Employment Initiative, only a few hundred thousand euros have been spent. To date, only three Member States – France, Italy and Lithuania – have been approved by the Commission for operational programmes for youth employment. It should be noted that only 10 000 school leavers benefit from the French programme. That's why you can only say: get on with it and deliver, and don't just promise!

name: Paul TANG
text: Mr President, I would like to make one point about the 2015 budget. What we are seeing is an annual conflict between the countries and the European institutions. It is too tempting to say yes and to say no, to make commitments and to om not make payments, especially in tough times like this. It is an annual conflict and it is a conflict without winners. The disadvantages are large, it reinforces the picture of overspending, although in fact spending has fallen since 2013. Moreover, the European Commission is, almost secretly, building up a debt, which should not be allowed. Accounts remain, putting investment in knowledge and research at risk. This is not a strengthening of the European economy, especially at a time of low growth and few jobs. It's a conflict with no winners. That is why I am pleased when the European Parliament takes a clear stand and reverses the cuts to heading 1A. But I also welcome the gesture, as the European Parliament makes, to allow each party to come up with the structural solutions to this annual ingrained conflict. I hope that this gesture will be seen by the Commission. I hope that this gesture will be seen by the Member States. In any case, it is seen in the Netherlands and taken positively there. Let us not be trapped in the annual ingrained conflict.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking In this debate, I would like to draw attention to two points. Firstly, the need for Parliament to decide whether to increase the level of payments to EUR 146 billion, which is more than EUR 6 billion more than the Council has decided. This increase in payment appropriations is still only a partial solution to the problem of the backlog of payments, which, as we have heard, is already over EUR 30 billion and eur 10 billion must even be paid out of hand. Secondly, I would strongly warn Parliament against supporting the Commission's decision to fund the fight against Ebola in 2015 from the crisis reserve created under the common agricultural policy. The Commission's decision to allocate nearly €450 million, or most of this reserve, to the fight against the virus is irresponsible if we are confident that Russian sanctions on EU food will also be maintained in 2015. After all, only a few farmers have benefited from the funds triggered in this year's budget, and all sellers on the market are suffering losses.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: Mr President, Minister, Commissioner, at a time when most Member States are making significant efforts to stabilise their economies through fiscal consolidation measures and structural reforms, European funds are among the few predictable stable sources of investment for the next seven years. therefore, I believe that the European Union budget must remain an investment budget. Last year, we, the European Parliament, accepted the reduction of the European Union's multiannual budget for the first time, although, perhaps more than ever, it needed to increase it, particularly in areas such as research, innovation, infrastructure investment, in order for Europe to become more competitive, to better cope with global competition. By accepting a reduction in the budget, we, Parliament, have taken into account the concerns of the net contributors. To these reductions, however, there is also the non-payment of the European Union's debts to those who have provided services to the European Union and rightly expect to be paid. This reduces the outlook for economic growth at Member State level. The Council's attitude is unacceptable and unjustified. The negative consequences for the real economy are significant. The council's breach of commitments has negative effects on the economic recovery at European Union level. Investment in infrastructure, research, innovation is the engine of economic recovery. One last thing I want to say is that I also support mobilising the margin for contingencies. I think it is the only way we can stabilise the current situation.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: First of all, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on a well-built European budget. For the first time we have a budget structure that the European Parliament is proposing, which takes into account the needs of citizens. A budget that prioritises young people, innovation, SMEs or social policies. In this respect, I would like to welcome the fact that this budget includes a pilot project that we have started, which provides for the identification and implementation of solutions aimed at increasing access to health care in rural areas. With this project, we are able to show that the European budget is involved where citizens need it, in the field of health. We are also able to reach out to the countryside and show that the European Union is also acting at this level. I am convinced that pilot projects and preparatory actions initiated by European parliamentarians are extremely useful legislative mechanisms that can increase transparency, but also allow citizens to be involved in budgetary construction. It is now for the Member States and the Council to understand that we need this European budget, that without European financial resources projects of common interest of a European dimension would not exist. We have a duty to show that the European budget meets the daily needs of citizens, and we must show how this budget supports them.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: President-in-Office, thank you for the floor. The budget debate is a bipartisan rhetoric used by states. At home, they highlight the benefits and importance of investment in job creation, and then, at European level, they are reducing the capital expenditure that the European Union needs today more than ever.  I particularly consider it important to keep sufficient resources for research, innovation and education in the 2015 budget to keep the European Union a leader in this area and to create quality jobs and be competitive in the global economy. Growth in the European Union can only be achieved through structural reforms, and that is why we need well-planned funds.  The councils' proposal threatens the credibility of the European Union and violates the agreements agreed. At the end of last year, a new, significantly lower multiannual financial framework for 2014-2020 was adopted. Parliament supported it on condition that Member States ensure that there are no more repeated late payments which prevent the European Commission from honouring its legal and financial commitments. The proposed Council amendments are not in the spirit of this agreement. In fact, we already know today that, with such a proposal, we will be talking again at the end of the second year about the late payments. For this reason, too, it is essential to consider additional revenue from own resources, which, for the time being, has remained only at the level of fines and default interest. Thanks.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: The European Union has its strategy, but it does not provide sufficient budgetary resources to implement it. For all that, 26 billion euros of unpaid invoices speak. This threatens the trust of the whole of a common Europe. We can see that the budget in the future cannot depend on whether or not the Council fulfils its commitments. We therefore need to create a smart European budget that provides the European Union with its own resources to achieve its ambitions without increasing the overall tax burden on the population. Let us take from national level everything that we can do more effectively at European level. There are savings and resources in increased European integration. If the European Union budget is to be credible to citizens, it must set an example in terms of governance, efficiency, transparency and control.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: In any decision-making in the European Parliament, we should bear in mind, above all, our objectives, which are, as a matter of priority, the growth and improvement of the employment of our citizens. The structure of the budget always has a great impact on such objectives. That is why I will always push for less cost of consumption, for administration, but more for supporting small business, science, research, innovative technologies. I will always support such proposals. Although we are trying to have a balanced budget here, our debts are still rising and even a year should reach up to EUR 30 billion, so we need to improve payment discipline and, above all, comply with the rules. On the one hand, we are talking here about payments within 30 to 60 days, but on the other hand, our debts are increasing. I therefore think that we need to introduce penalties for non-payment also at the level of the European institutions in order to improve discipline in payments and to comply with the rules, only then can the European budget really work. We often talk about the expenditure side, but I consider the revenue part of the budget to be even more important, which can only work when the environment for job creation works. We should therefore talk more about improving competitiveness, lower taxes, levies, better labour law and promoting education, science, research. I trust that we will talk more on this subject and that we will do well on this.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I can only reinforce what has already been said by my Social Democrat colleagues, by the rapporteur, Mrs Eider, whom I thank. We are now waiting for the Council to do its part to continue to support the European Union, because that is what it is all about. And I would like to focus, Mr President, on two aspects that I have brought to the attention of the Committee on Budgets through a number of amendments. The first is to give strong support to the fight against organised crime and also to strongly support a common and genuine asylum and immigration reception and management policy. In short, Mr President, I believe that we will have to face up to the serious problems facing the Member States and the citizens of Europe. The second, which is close to my heart and which I think is very topical, is to cut unnecessary expenditure, unproductive spending, in a clear and clear way, I would like to say waste, Mr President. Starting with us exactly, starting with our work. I believe that the time has come for colleagues to choose a single location, a single place to meet, avoiding these very expensive journeys, and I also hope that in the not too distant future we will no longer be denied the right to organise our work, greatly reducing costs and thinking carefully about the sacrifices that are required of European citizens.

name: Janusz LEWANDOWSKI
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking The 2015 budget may not be business as usual. Indeed, the European Parliament's proposal and negotiating position is not business as usual, it is an ambitious proposal that goes beyond the European Commission's proposal and even exceeds the ceiling of the financial perspective, which, moreover, for next year is EUR 2 billion lower than the actual implementation of the 2013 budget. This outlined proposal, which we are likely to vote on tomorrow, corresponds to the dramatic payment situation, which has been very carefully outlined for Parliament's use in the presence of the Italian Presidency by Commissioner Dominic. This proposal also corresponds to the Council's conclusions, because the Council continues to look for measures that can finance growth and jobs, and indeed the European budget at this scale is a partial answer to the conundrum of how to finance growth and jobs in a context of fiscal consolidation, so it plays its part and is a way of leverage private capital on a wider scale.  The years 2014 and 2015 are still the accounts of the previous financial perspective, which have been tested, are legal, should be paid. More than 40% of payments in next year's budget are the accounts of the previous perspective for projects already completed. So it is not only economics that is at stake, the credibility of the institutions of the European Union is at stake.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: Mr President, gender equality is a principle of the European Union and, therefore, compliance with this principle must also be applied in the Community budget. It is important to note that there are some priorities, which we have raised since the negotiations in the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, such as not allowing the single euro to be cut for the European Institute for Gender Equality, which is carrying out important work. In addition, maintaining the budget line for the Daphne programme to combat gender-based violence is another key issue. Today it is integrated into the general 'Rights and Citizenship' programme, but it is necessary to continue to maintain this concept of a programme to combat gender-based violence.  And let us not forget the contributions that are being made from the Community budget to non-governmental organizations and civil society working in this area. We have an important responsibility and gender mainstreaming must be a fundamental issue to consider.

name: Georgios KYRTSOS
text: Mr President, I think that the management of European Union money is very good quality and effective, and I disagree with the view of the British Eurosceptics and the British anti-Europeans, who specialise in criticising so-called waste in the European Union. The management criteria in the European Union are much stricter, because we have a limit on the budget deficit, in EMU, 3% of Gross Domestic Product, whereas for example in the United Kingdom the corresponding deficit is in the order of 6% of Gross Domestic Product. So those who want to give financial management lessons must first drop their own deficit and then tell us exactly what we need to do.  However, I think we are a little miserable in dealing with the budget. We must support the positions of the European Parliament because, among other things, we face new challenges. If, for example, Ukraine collapses in the winter, because we have been indifferent, will we have made savings or will we have paved the way for new spending? And if, for example, Ebola escapes West Africa because we are also indifferent, and come to the European Union, what will we be financially profitable, economically lost, meet to decide or speak by teleconference?  In any case, I believe that the Italian Presidency has responsibilities, Mr Renzi came here with nice ideas, at least he should help us to support the prestige of the European Parliament and the European Union.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. We are aware that the 2015 budget is a budget dependent on three important conditions. Firstly, the backlog, which is already tens of billions of euros. Secondly, from the payments that will flow from the 2007-2013 perspective, and let us have no doubt about that. Finally, the third, very important aspect: the two above elements must not stop us from functioning normally and achieving our 2015 targets.  The three main areas that are important to us are: competitiveness for growth and work, economic, social and territorial cohesion and global Europe. What is particularly striking about the draft budget and the Council's position (the Commission's position is much closer to us)? Namely, the Council is trying to be relatively generous in its commitments, but this is not the time for commitments. Now is the time for payments and this amount cannot be accepted, just as we cannot accept the Council's position.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. Firstly, I would like to congratulate the rapporteurs, they have done a great job. 1 500 amendments had to be decided in the Committee on Budgets. The decision was facilitated by the fact that eligible compromises were created by the submittors.  Fidesz MEPs support the proposal on our table, mainly because the People's Party first adopted the amendments we tabled, which then became part of the compromises mentioned earlier. In particular, compared to the Council's original proposal, Parliament would increase the payment of Structural Funds programmes in the 2015 budget by around EUR 4 billion. In this way, we want to ensure that in 2015 the process that I have already spoken about with several of my fellow Members in terms of unpaid invoices will not continue. In the case of agricultural resources, the European Parliament intends to increase resources to support school milk and school fruit programmes and to mobilise additional resources to mitigate the damage caused by the Russian agricultural embargo. In this connection, we do not see amendment 1 tabled by the European Commission as complementary, and we have concerns about this.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: Madam President, the yearly budget is not just about numbers or figures. We are talking about the backbone of the whole European project. This is why Council proposals to cut the EU budget for 2015 raise so much concern in this House.  First, we are faced with a growing deficit of the budget partly due to faster than planned implementation of many EU-financed projects, but also partly because of late payments by Member States. As a result, the Commission still has a lot of invoices unpaid from previous budgets. This is a dangerous situation which destabilises the investment process in Member States and critically undermines the credibility of the European Union. Therefore, I support Parliament’s call for Member States to respect fully their financial obligations with respect to the EU budget.  Second, the proposed reduction of payments appropriations in Heading 1A – Competitiveness for growth and jobs amounts to more than 1.3 billion. This means that almost two-thirds of all payments cuts suggested by the Council will negatively affect innovation, research and small and medium-sized enterprises, areas with the largest potential for growth and jobs. These proposals clearly fly in the face of everything we have said concerning the necessity to restore strong growth in Europe. Hence, I strongly support Parliament’s position not only to restore the Commission’s budget proposals, but also to consider going above the ceiling in this strategically important heading.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. In my opinion, a particularly important aspect of the Union budget is to provide the necessary resources to repay commitments previously made, especially with regard to cohesion policy and rural development. It should be borne in mind that cohesion policy funding significantly supports Member States and regions in their efforts to create new jobs, increase competitiveness or promote sustainable growth. At the same time, the untimely payment of commitments shows the European Union as an unreliable, unreliable partner, which we cannot afford. Unfortunately, we currently have as many as EUR 26 billion of outstanding commitments, of which 23 billion are in cohesion policy alone. I am therefore convinced that particular emphasis should be placed on maintaining the payment limits proposed by the European Commission, in particular for Headings 1b and 2 of the Union budget.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: Madam President, I did not want to let go of this debate on the report on the Council's position on the draft budget for 2015, but first I would like to congratulate the work of rapporteur Gardiazabal, who I think has done a magnificent job. And now I do, I would like to take this opportunity with the Commissioner and the Council to say that what is being done with this manoeuvre carried out by the Commission – chapucera, in my opinion - through its amending note of 15 October is an undercover cut in CAP funds of just over EUR 450 million which will go to other policies to alleviate something — on which I agree everyone who has spoken—which is the existing budgetary imbalance. But why does the CAP budget have to pay for it? Why do farmers in the European Union have to pay for it?

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Mr. President, the Russian embargo, climate change, record youth unemployment, unpaid bills, over-indebtedness, non-achievement of growth and employment targets, are challenges that the 2015 budget must at least partially respond to in order to achieve the goals set by 2020.  An important segment of the budget is certainly the part related to the Common Agricultural Policy and I would be happy if it were bigger and projects were realized that would ensure the stay of people in the countryside and their dignified life. My view is that special attention should be paid to small family farms that are food producers, guardians of space and biodiversity, and drivers of development and guarantors of life in rural areas. And you have to see that in the budget.  Farmers affected by the Russian embargo need to find their place in this budget, but not in the segment of the Common Agricultural Policy, but within the budget reserves as proposed by the Chair of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: This report also points to a great contradiction of the European Union, but it cannot resolve it. The autonomy of the Member States is diminishing, we are moving towards a federal state, but the budget for joint tasks is only 1% of total income. In the case of a federal state, it is necessary for joint tasks, which, of course, we reject. Active contributors complain that they cannot bear any more burdens, but do not take into account the flow of EUR 100 billion per year from peripheral countries to them, the central countries. Cohesion amounts are decreasing and the gap between regions has increased over the last cycle. This budget clearly shows the difference between reality and EU rhetoric.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Mr Council representative, ladies and gentlemen, we have just learned that the College of Commissioners has adopted an amending letter to the draft budget 2015 in which all the emergency measures taken following the Russian embargo would be financed by the crisis reserve. However, it does not seem to me that this crisis reserve should be used for this purpose. We have said it many times: this is not a market crisis or a health crisis, but a political crisis. If we accept this, we will penalise farmers twice: once because of the consequences of the Russian embargo and a second time because of the reduction in direct aid the following year. According to the information we have received, this amending letter would be discussed directly in the conciliation committee without going through the Committee on Budgets. This is a real problem because it prevents any debate on the subject. I would like to see other sources of funding mobilized for these measures. Wouldn't one of the lines of thought be the use of the margin for unforeseen events, an instrument of last resort?

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I have been a Member of the European Parliament for a few months and I must say that I cannot ignore the procedures and the very perception that not always constructive debates contribute to the European Union budget. The Eu ropean Union budget – the most important policy document – continues to be perceived by the Member States as a burden, as an additional burden on national budgets and not as it should actually be, as an opportunity to strengthen investment initiatives that have added value for Europe.  It would have been desirable if, at a time of major crisis, such as the one we are experiencing, we had discussed a somewhat more ambitious draft budget for Europe, including, for example, the strengthening of the programmes that are at the heart of the Europe 2020 strategy aimed at promoting growth, competitiveness and employment, such as Horizon 2020, COSMOS, Erasmus Place, etc. Research and development investment for businesses and for employment, especially for young people, is, I would say, a sine qua non for giving new life and a further boost to the European project in order to avoid social and economic disintegration. Finally, a final comment on agriculture: the agricultural sector is already experiencing a profound crisis and must be strongly supported.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Mr Council representative, in the face of a world that is moving around us, the debate shows that we need a more united and stronger Europe. If the issue of own resources had been decided in the budget for the period, no doubt tonight's debate and the positions of each other would be easier. It seems that there is a need to look for sources of savings and administrative simplifications that could lead to additional margins. Finally, a final word on this famous corrective letter. After lowering the CAP budget and the direct aid budget, can we now make farmers - and farmers alone - pay for the Russian embargo and ask them next year to pay a fourth time by imposing a further reduction in direct aid? This is unfair and unacceptable.

name: Jacek Dominik
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, I was thinking about what to say now, but I think there is one issue that we have to clarify from the very beginning about this Amending Letter No 1 to the Budget 2015.  It is not true that this letter consists of cuts of any kind to direct payments. The crisis reserve is established by law on an annual basis by simple application of financial discipline. This crisis reserve was created to solve crisis problems in agriculture and that is what is being proposed by the Commission: to apply the crisis reserve to the crisis situation. However, it does not have a direct impact on the level of direct payments for farmers. As you know, Heading 2 for agriculture is one of the biggest in the EU budget. It consists of almost EUR 45 billion. At the end of every budgetary year, calculations are done to see how much is left in additional revenues after fulfilling all the obligations to the farmers.  When you look at the history of this heading in the past there were savings in every annual budget – savings amounting to at least half a billion euro, sometimes even a billion. This money was usually used to top up any direct payments that were legally eligible. So this will also be the case in 2015.  What the Commission has proposed in the Amending Letter is simply to improve the liquidity of the EU budget due to the scarce resources for payments. The only impact it will have is that some headings will have additional payment appropriations available at the beginning of the year when they are most needed, but it does not create any additional restrictions to Heading 2. This Amending Letter does not change either the level of commitments under Heading 2 or the level of payments available under Heading 2.  So what many of you have indicated – that the Commissionʼs decision immediately reduces direct payments to farmers – is not true. You will see the result by the end of the year. We have produced the same type of Amending Letters every year in the past and it has never created such tensions. The same instruments were applied in every EU budget. The additional revenues that were indicated in Heading 2 were transferred to all other headings on an annual basis because farmers are not able to use more money and resources than they are eligible for. Heading 2 has the biggest margins of all headings. So we should not really concentrate too much on this situation. I can assure you that the Amending Letter does not create any reductions in direct payments for farmers and it does not have any direct influence on the level of direct payments that the farmers will have received by the end of the year. If I may make a few comments concerning the budget for 2015 as such. We have to remember that the EU annual budget is just an implementation of commitments taken previously in the MFF; so if someone is arguing about why we spend money, we spend money because that was what was promised by Member States. The Commission is simply asking, or first indicating in its draft budget, how much money we need for a particular year – taking into account the commitments that were made by Member States and taking into account the fact that 90% of the EU budget is spent in the Member States by the Member States – and not the Commission, as we have to remember. It is not the Commission that is trying to find new ways of spending money. Ninety per cent of the budget is decided by Member States. They have the projects to be financed and decided domestically. They launch the projects, they spend the money and they send the bills to the Commission to be refunded. So the Commission’s role is only to collect this information and then present to both arms of the budgetary authority how much money we need to fulfil their obligations or to refund money they have spent.  So this whole process of discussion now as to whether we should cut more or less is actually about whether we should fulfil our obligations or not, whether we want to pay our bills back or not. That is the whole debate we are having here now.

name: Enrico Zanetti
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I have listened to all the speeches, I have heard many of them who were concerned about the aspect related to the quantity of resources. I have heard less, however, that they were concerned instead about the quality aspect and, when using it, about the impact that resources actually have on spending programmes; I fully agree with Commissioner Dominik that a very large part, the absolutely predominant part of this budget, is then spent through the Member States in the Member States, but that is precisely why the questions about the need to make efficiency as efficient as possible are questions that the Council is asking itself.  And I believe that Parliament should also include them more in its debate, together with the more purely quantitative part. I am absolutely convinced, as has been said several times, that this budgetary procedure should not be treated as usual, as usual; I am convinced of this, but this is true not only as far as the Council is concerned, it is also true as far as Parliament is concerned. And I do not believe that a proposal from Parliament, namely to increase commitments and payments significantly in relation to the Commission as well, goes in the direction of an innovative approach, it seems to me, if anything, to be a closer and more usual approach, at most the difference lies in quantity once again rather than in quality. Of course, when I say this, I am fully aware that the Council is also participating too flexibly, too slowly in relation to the positions of the 2014 amending budgets, to make the composition less simple at this early stage, on the understanding that it is precisely in conciliation – and here the approach that Parliament has proposed can only be shared – that we are going to treat all the matches together in an overall framework. What the Council did, however, in its proposal – even when it proposed reductions in relation to the Commission's proposal – was certainly not to proceed with linear cuts, on the contrary, a very careful operation was carried out which, among other things, was based on a fundamental premise and which seems to me to be extremely shared by all the institutions, namely the problem of backpaying. That is why, in the logic of calling for reductions in relation to the Commission's proposal, we have focused more on item 1A–Growth than on item 1B–Cohesion.  The reason for this was precisely that, at the heart of the problem of payments, a problem which mainly affects item 1B in a much broader way, and so, with a view to maximising the financial efficiency of the budget, the cuts have been proposed on payments mainly under item 1A, since they consist of many investment plans, many investment programmes and the , which in this first two years will lead to fewer occurrences of payment, certainly of commitment but less payment, than we already have in the past on item 1B. It is precisely there that we immediately saw a greater need for financial resources. However, I would like to end by reiterating my conviction that both the council's belated stance on the 2014 amending budgets and a quantitatively – as we have said in our opinion – which is not sustainable on the 2015 budget by Parliament will be able to find in conciliation the overall assessment that is required here, which we share and which we are convinced will ultimately lead us to find precisely a solution to the problem. , also for this year in the awareness of everyone that it is certainly a year in which things are a little more difficult than usual and it takes an extraordinary commitment.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President, I wanted to begin my last speech by thanking most of the political groups in this House for supporting the proposal which we are presenting here today as a European Parliament and which we will vote on tomorrow, and in particular to thank all the shadow rapporteurs of the political groups who have been very active in making this proposal a very majority proposal of the European Parliament. Mr Zanetti in his first speech said that our proposal was very difficult to defend, and the truth is that during the debate we had this afternoon, in which around sixty Members will have surgery, I believe that there have been two or three who have criticised Parliament's proposal and the rest have given the Council plenty of reasons to support our position. He also said that it was an unrealistic proposal, and it is clear that this is a matter of positions, but what seems unrealistic to us is that with 26 billion unpaid invoices on the table, the Council still cuts the Commission's proposal by 2 billion. We have put all the tools on the table; that is why we are asking for this increase of 6 billion euros in payments, because it is the maximum that the laws allow us, because our goal in this negotiation for 2015 is not to solve — because we do not have enough room to fix it - but at least to alleviate this crisis of unpaid bills that we have on the table and that we have been dragging since 2010. It is clear that there are quite a few differences between the Council's position and that of the European Parliament, but it is also true that tomorrow, as I said at the beginning, those twenty-one days begin that we have conciliation in which we can see each other tomorrow, late and night, if that is going to mean that Parliament and the Council can reach an agreement. And we are totally open to that negotiation. But I would also like to warn the Council of one thing: if the Council wants to negotiate and is ready to move from its initial position, Parliament will respond quickly, but if the Council is going to come to those negotiations as in the previous years when its position was the starting position and the final position, it certainly will not find us there.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Rapporteur. - (DE) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for the excellent work he has Once again, I greet the Presidency of the Council and the Commissioner. I would like to join Mrs Eider in thanking her and all the co-rapporteurs very warmly for their good cooperation. However, I would also like to make a rather clear one – I would almost have said that I would make an announcement to the Council that some of the statements are simply not correct. Not only is this Parliament advocating simply more money, but this Parliament is advocating that we should perhaps also start the seven-year financial framework that we have just adopted and start the programmes accordingly, that cuts in innovation and research in particular are not the smartest, and that cuts in humanitarian aid at this stage may not necessarily be in line with the optimum level of prudence. Then I would also like to make it very clear that the European Parliament has long made an offer to the Council with regard to the agencies. We have offered that, in our view, we would also be prepared to discuss priorities of changes in the agencies together with the Council, to comply with the 5% reduction, but to redeploy staff and change tasks so that the agencies can carry out their tasks. Unfortunately, the Council is open to those who do not want to talk about it, because there seems to be no agreement anywhere. Parliament must not be accused of things that Parliament is not responsible for. And if it is not to be linear cuts that have been made, then frankly I do not understand the abatement rate at the European Court of Justice. Because if you know that the Court of Justice is using 99.5% of its staff, then a linear cut over all the other institutions in the abatement rate, especially at the ECJ and the European External Action Service, does not make much sense in view of their situation. We are not the ones who generally demand a great deal, but we are simply asking for compliance with what we actually agreed with each other a few months ago. And we want to promote growth and innovation. That is what our main objective is. Perhaps we could represent it together.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, October 22, 2014, at 1 p.m. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: In the negotiation of the EU budget, cohesion and agricultural subsidies, which are the engine of development and job creation, need to be increased in the first place. Anyone who wants to reduce these resources is preventing them from emergeing from the crisis. I therefore call on the members of the European Parliament to support the proposal of the Committee on Budgets. The Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development is united. We will not allow next year's rural development resources, subsidies to producer organisations and beekeeping and oenological aid to be reduced by up to a penny. We will also not tolerate compensation for the Russian agricultural embargo being implemented from the Agricultural Crisis Fund. However, according to the Commission's letter of amendment adopted last week, this EUR 344 million would nevertheless be financed from the Crisis Fund. This would lead to a reduction in direct payments in all Member States. Instead of a crisis fund, assistance should be financed from the proceeds addressed. It is a great success that our amendments, tabled jointly with Tamás Deutsch, have been included in Parliament's proposal. This would provide EUR 7 million more for school fruit programmes and EUR 4 million more for school milk programmes. In addition to helping our dairy and fruit and vegetable sectors, this step serves the health and well-being of our children, one of our main objectives.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. The adoption of the budget by the European Parliament lays the foundations for the re-extinction of the amending budget proposed by the Commission. This will result in tough negotiations with the Council, which otherwise proposes drastic cuts on issues that are priorities for us, under the headings: Competitiveness for growth and work, social and territorial cohesion, sustainable growth and natural resources, security and citizenship. I hope that the progress made by Parliament in terms of the distribution of expenditure and priorities will be a step backwards on the part of the Council in order to reach a real compromise. I would like to stress that, in addition to the items just mentioned, we have the opportunity to deal more specifically with long-term savings by addressing the issue of the need to create a road map for the creation of a single seat for the European Parliament, to support the sugar industry, which is at risk of repercussions as a result of the elimination of quotas, and finally animal welfare by supporting Amendment No 12, which prevents cap appropriations from being used for fund bullfights.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. – European projects deliver benefits for all EU citizens. Often these projects are more effective than 28 separate projects spread across the Union. They deliver added value for people, communities and industry. Together with my Labour colleagues we voted for the EU to do more of what it is good at - delivering jobs and growth across Europe. These European projects include the North West Evergreen Fund in Manchester which has received GBP 19 million in European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) funding to date and the Chrysalis Fund operating across Merseyside which has so far invested GBP 30 million of ERDF. We also voted for the EU to meet its external commitments. The EU acts on our behalf in a number of external areas: whether this is supporting peace projects in Gaza or Northern Ireland, helping to combat Ebola in Africa or working with pro-democracy groups in Ukraine, the EU acts to help deliver peace and security right across the globe. These are areas where we are able to work together to achieve more than the sum of our parts, where the EU makes a real difference and I am proud that Labour MEPs stood together and supported the EU in these areas.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. As we are talking about the budget today, I would also like to refer to the second, hidden administrative apparatus: by outsourcing responsibilities to agencies, the Commission has embellished its budget. This budget trickery even leads the Commission to falsely indicate savings in the budget, even though this would have been exceeded by up to 20% if the EU agencies' budgets were taken into account. These agencies will continue to burden the European Union's budget over the next few years, as a growth trend is apparent. The number of agencies has almost quadrupled since 2000 and the number of employees has increased by 4000%. However, Vice-President Lunacek could be likedone and thinks that further expenditure is reasonable to the European taxpayer. However, I cannot see any added value for the citizens of Europe in the work of the large number of agencies that would justify a further burden. Without any tangible added value, such agencies must be closed immediately. On the one hand, many of these agencies are meaningless, because their remit is already regulated by other European institutions, or because their activities relate to areas in which the European Union has no exclusive competence. However, there are also overlaps in the remit between the agencies. This justifies the closure or merger of individual agencies.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: Written. "When politicians spend public money, it must always aim for the greatest possible efficiency and for the benefits of citizens. The additional annual cost of the two seats is estimated at EUR 180 million. Members and staff of the European Parliament have broadly supported the transition to a single-seat system. In addition to the financial costs, one seat would also reduce the carbon footprint of the EU Parliament, when monthly travel for thousands of officials, representatives and the press could be decided. We are increasingly moving into an electronic world where services and information are accessible to all. The European Parliament has done a great deal to improve its information. You can follow a session from your own terminal, anywhere. For the time being, this is a matter for the Member States to decide. I encourage the political groups in this House to seek a solution for moving to one seat together with the Member States.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on the council and Commission's statements on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in Hungary (2014/2852 (RSP)).

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this debate, in which the Council has been invited to speak, concerns democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in Hungary. The Council is aware of the concerns expressed by certain groups in Parliament on this matter. Although he did not discuss the matter in detail, there was no proposal to invoke a procedure involving the Council on this issue. Let me be clear on the general issues of this issue: fundamental rights are the cornerstone of European integration and the defining element of European democracy and our shared identity. If these values are part of the same raison d'er as the European Union and are the basis of our being together, all the European institutions and the Member States are called upon to work to ensure that full respect for fundamental rights and the rule of law are always guaranteed. I know that this House fully shares this view. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the fundamental rights of the Member States are enshrined in the constitutional traditions of the Member States, in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and in the European Convention on Human Rights, to which all the Member States of the European Union are party and to which the European Union itself will join in due course. All Member States must therefore ensure that national law, whether primary or secondary, respects EU law. Where there are doubts or doubts about this, it is primarily up to the Commission to deal with it and not to the Council. However, I can assure you that I will pay particular attention to what you have to say on this subject in the course of this debate. These considerations will certainly be useful to the Italian Presidency, which, just in these days and starting from the Commission communication of 11 March last, is considering the possibility of organising a debate in the Council on strengthening the rule of law in the Union.

name: Martine Reicherts
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, as guardian of the treaties, the Commission enforces EU law, including the Charter of Fundamental Rights, through infringement procedures, under the control of the Eu Court of Justice and, of course, in addition to the role of national courts working with the Eu Court of Justice to enforce charter rights in the Member States.  The Commission's role is not limited to ensuring the protection of fundamental rights in the application of EU law. The Commission has also made a political commitment to protect the union's values. To this end, in March 2014, it adopted its communication on a new European Union framework to strengthen the rule of law. Communication has the dual purpose of ensuring equal treatment between Member States and promoting political dialogue in the event of a threat to our common values. In the event of a systemic threat to the rule of law in a Member State, the Commission plans to engage in a political dialogue with it. This dialogue must be based on fair cooperation and allow solutions to be found before the situation worsens.  This process is in place to fill the gap that has existed until now between infringement procedures and the use of the mechanisms provided for in Article 7 of the Treaty. The framework for strengthening the rule of law will seek to ensure the proper functioning of all judicial and constitutional mechanisms and safeguards aimed at protecting democracy and fundamental rights in the Member States. If these guarantees are jeopardised, the Commission will not hesitate to take the necessary measures to ensure compliance with EU law and values. The Commission will act within its powers as conferred by the treaties. On the other hand, it will not hesitate, if necessary, to launch infringement proceedings for violation of European Union law and to provoke a political dialogue with the Member State whose national mechanisms to ensure the rule of law are seriously compromised, regardless of that Member State. The European Union framework for strengthening the rule of law applies to all Member States in the same way.  Our debate today, Madam President, is about the rule of law in Hungary. In recent weeks, there has been a disagreement between the Hungarian and Norwegian authorities on the issue of granting grants to certain NGOs. In view of the information available at this stage, the subject matter of this dispute does not appear to fall within the scope of EU law. Indeed, the management of EU funds is not directly affected in this dispute. Furthermore, we have no evidence at this stage that can demonstrate a dysfunction of national mechanisms aimed at protecting the rule of law, nor a dysfunction of the Hungarian judicial system. The NGOs concerned have the opportunity to appeal against the decisions that have been taken. However, the Commission has used all its political clout to encourage the parties to resolve this dispute and we are following this process carefully. Let me now return to Hungarian media legislation. In 2011, the Commission's services indicated that several provisions of the Act did not comply with the provisions of the Audiovisual Media Services Directive, the treatment of the functioning of the European Union and the Charter of Fundamental Rights. Following discussions initiated by the Commission, Hungary adopted amendments in 2011 and 2012 to correct the points highlighted. These amendments now ensure that Hungarian law complies with EU law. The compatibility of Hungary's new tax legislation on advertising revenue generated in the media with EU law is under review. The impact of this tax on freedom of expression and its compatibility with the freedom of establishment guaranteed by the treaties remains to be assessed. We are in the process of examining this situation and we are continuing the dialogue with the Hungarian authorities. Of course, if this review shows a breach of EU law, the dialogue already under way will have to lead to the establishment of new national provisions in Hungary. If this were not to be the case, the Commission will not, of course, hesitate to use its powers in the area of infringement procedure. I would also like to inform you of the conclusion of the case concerning the independence of the Hungarian national data protection authority. Following the Court's ruling of 8 April 2014, the Hungarian authorities acknowledged the violation of EU law and fully compensated the National Commissioner responsible for the authority, who has not indicated his intention to resume his duties. In these circumstances, the Commission closed the infringement procedure. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this evening's debate is an opportunity to remind ourselves that what makes us European is our commitment to this community of values, principles and rights enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights. The Commission, as the guardian of the treaties, has an obligation to ensure that they are respected, whether the Member States are small or large, founders or not. This is the guarantee provided by the new European Union framework to strengthen the rule of law.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, the European Parliament has already dealt many times with the Hungary issue and, in all of them, the European People's Party has expressed its defence of fundamental rights and the rule of law. But we also consider that it is not acceptable to attack a member country for ideological reasons: generic prejudice against a country is as dangerous as the allegations that are going to be expressed here today. If Europe is democracy, it must also be separation of powers. The guardian of the Treaties, as has been said, is the Commission, not Parliament. In Parliament we have political debates, we do not issue sentences. We do not judge, let alone countries; we do politics: our opinions are not neutral. We represent different political parties, and to want to turn our political views into legal sentences is to go beyond what it is for Parliament to do. Hungary is a country that respects the common rules and values of the European Union; that's why he's a member. It is also a country that is willing to negotiate and work, as has just been demonstrated. The European People's Party trusts and believes in Hungary. Three elections have been held in Hungary this year: on all three occasions fidesz, a member party of the European People's Party, has won. Bringing Hungarian politics back to this House could be to continue the election campaign in Strasbourg when it was lost in Hungary.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: On behalf of the S&D Group.  Our common European idea is based on the universal values of human dignity, freedom, equality and solidarity, on the principles of democracy and the rule of law, and when serious violations occur, it is our common duty to demand action. It saddens me that today we are talking about Hungary again precisely because of these accusations. We are witnessing new events of concern and discomfort, let me mention only in the area of media freedom.  The taxation of the advertising revenues of large media adopted by the Hungarian Parliament poses a threat to independent journalism. The measure will hit the very popular foreign commercial television, which has often been critical of Orbano's government in its programme. Similarly, the authorities have strongly interfered with the functioning of a number of independent organisations, non-governmental. The worst blow was again experienced by those most critical of the authorities. I am not only talking about Hungary, but let me also mention the events in Slovenia. A journalist from a prominent journalist in my country has found herself being prosecuted for publishing allegedly classified information about the links of a far-right neo-Nazi group to an opposition party. Prosecutors accuse her of endangering national security, while the journalist acted in the public interest in her conduct. Her prosecution is intolerable.  What will the European Commission, I ask, do to protect the fundamental rights of democracy, not only in Hungary, but throughout the European Union. I want a more concrete answer to that. Thank you very much.

name: Timothy KIRKHOPE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, we must constantly keep in mind that, as members of the European Union, we have signed up to a core set of democratic principles and rights. We must all operate under an umbrella of respect for democracy and the rule of law. If just one of us neglects those principles, then of course it reflects badly upon all of us. Freedom of expression, freedom of the press and freedom to protest are all rights that should never be restricted. Yet very little is achieved through lecturing one another. Far more progress can be made through a dialogue which is constructive and cooperative. More will always be achieved by offering solutions, not just criticisms. I hope, therefore, that our new Commission Vice-President-elect responsible for the rule of law, Mr Timmermans, will provide a clear and direct link between Member States and fundamental rights within the EU. This House is entitled to all of its varied and many opinions but I personally believe, as a lawyer, that alleged wrongdoings should be examined with a clear mind and always with fairness and respect. We here should be a platform for examination, debate and, most of all, for solutions – but it is not the European Union’s function to be both judge and jury in this matter.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, in response to Mr Kirkhope, he is quite right when he says that we should respect each other and not lecture each other. In return, when I express my views, I do not want to be accused of being excessively ideological and attacking, or being part of a left-wing conspiracy, as I keep reading in the Hungarian media. Let us first make very clear that we are not talking about Hungary here tonight. We are talking about Europe – our European Union and our shared values. It is true that we have talked about the situation in Hungary before, but that is because the situation gives reason for concern. Is Hungary the only country where we have reason for concern? No, it is not, but it happens that in Hungary the problem is not just one law where Hungary or the Hungarian Government is not respecting the European treaties. The problem is that there is a whole set of laws which probably do not violate the treaties individually, but the overall impact is stifling. It causes a lot of pressure on pluralism and freedom of speech. We are talking about opposition political parties, the media, the judiciary, the education sector and civil society. The measures are never laws telling people that they cannot speak their minds, but they are fiscal measures, procurement rules and budgetary measures. I think that it is very important that we have this debate because this is as important for the future functioning of the European Union as the debate on the Stability Pact. I hope that the next Commission is going to be more active, more courageous and less legalistic, because this is about the future of the European Union that belongs to all of us.  Finally, to be fair, something was brought to our attention last weekend and that is the entry ban imposed by the United States against certain unnamed Hungarian Government officials. I do not think that is the way and I think that this also calls for a response from the Commission and the Council because we Europeans are responsible for what happens in Europe. We are responsible for safeguarding civil liberties, fundamental rights and the rule of law. I think this is something we debate amongst ourselves and it is not for the Americans to tell us.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, we are living in somewhat surreal moments here and the word is weak. What is happening in Hungary is one of them.
