He now wants to build an illiberal state. His models are China, Russia and Turkey, and he wants to break with the dogmas and ideologies of the West. Unfortunately, the facts accompany the words: NGOs are foreign-paid political agents, accused of "spying for the benefit of the Vikings", as Kehi, the government's supervisory office, says. At issue: NGOs fighting corruption, for LGBT, Roma and human rights in general, funded by a Norwegian fund for civil society, hence the "Vikings". In the crosshairs: NGOs such as Amnesty International and Transparency International. At the same time, the media and the judiciary continue to be put on the line. RTL Club, a subsidiary of a large Luxembourg company, finances 65% of the new media tax, while its audience does not exceed 15%. While the election results are there, the electoral law has been amended to better serve the interests of the majority party. Fidesz has been ubiquitous in the media and the OSCE - excuse me a little - says: "The elections in Hungary are free but not democratic". And what are the European institutions doing? Nothing. Mr Juncker proposed giving the portfolio of culture, education and youth to Tibor Navracsics, the minister who led the reforms challenged by the Council of Europe and our European Parliament. The values of democracy and human rights are universal. They should not vary according to political affiliations. It's true here, it's true elsewhere. There is an urgent need to react and what I have heard so far does not seem to me to be up to the task. (The speaker agreed to answer two "blue card" questions (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Blue card question. – It is quite clear that all Member States must aveend the so-called common European values, but tell me at what point in the Treaties that a country must resolve this with a liberal, supranational cosmopolitan principle, or on conservative principles, with a view to national identity being important. Where is it described that liberal state-building is mandatory for a Member State. Answer that.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: "blue card" question. "Mrs Vergiat, I would just like to say that the rule of law and the law come from the people and sovereignty. Universal values are values enshrined in this sovereignty and natural law, which our institutions do not recognize when this right is multi-millennium and is also enshrined in religions.  It is our institutions, often, that are problematic and flout democracy when they do not respect certain democratic choices, in France and in different countries. Therefore, I cannot understand the position you have on the rule of law. What is the basis of this position?

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: "blue card" answer. Madam President, I think I will be quite brief. As far as I'm concerned, I'm not a liberal. I have no problem, I have no dogmatism in this area and I am not in for the European institutions to ask dogmas, as they do in the economic field at the moment. On the other hand, I have values. These values are the European Charter of Human Rights, the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the European Convention on Human Rights. And as soon as these values are flouted, there is an urgent need to react. As for the second intervention, I will simply refer to the OSCE statement, which said that the elections in Hungary had not been democratic.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. Mr President, we are going back to Mr Orban's proposals for an 'illiberal' state. I do not give an economic explanation, but i understand a state that does not emancipating the principle of freedom for the individual. I think Orban's on his way. I think the facts are clear: judges with early retirement, data protection regulator replaced, media muzzled, NGOs compromised. Then the European Commission can say 'they have turned some of it back', but those judges are not back in their duties, neither are those data protection supervisors, and those NGOs and the media are still under pressure. And then the Council can say 'this is not up to us, we have only discussed fundamental rights in generalities and the Commission has to solve it', but that is not how we get there. It is also a bit of a pity that we are talking to the old European Commission here tonight. I would like to discuss this with the new European Commission, with Frans Timmermans, the new Commissioner for Fundamental Rights who says 'I need to study again'. This European Parliament has studied. We have the facts. We have the proposal to establish an Article 2 procedure. We need to take action now. Not just the European Commission; It's also something we need to look at together. Because as long as this Parliament says that the Navracsics candidate is good enough to do his job, then we are sending the signal that they can continue to do what they are doing there in Budapest. [The Speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.]

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Blue card question. "I have two short questions in 30 seconds. If something is liberal, it can still be Hungary a democracy, and I would like to ask you if you have read the prime minister's speech on this, and if so, do I understand that you, for example, consider the Christian democracy mentioned by the Prime Minister to be truly unsatisviable as a different kind of democracy?

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: "blue card" answer. Yes, Of course I have read the translation of the speech, because I am not able to do so in Hungarian. I don't think if you base yourself on Christian values, you have to discriminate against minorities. I respect Christian values, but you must also respect other values. And I believe that an 'illiberal state' that no longer assumes the individual is a dangerous state that contradicts our Copenhagen criteria, with or without Christian values.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, jacques delors was critical a few years ago when he said that Europe is proceeding with a mask on its face. The state in which human rights are found in Hungary is symptomatic of the blindness and hypocrisy in which the citizens of the European Union find themselves: a great union of markets and total disunity of rights, often even the most basic ones! The Hungarian Government has repeatedly mocked the recommendations on freedom of the press and the independence of the judiciary – and it is not the only one – given that, when it comes to freedom of the press, it has been followed freely by Italy, where, unfortunately, the level of free information is embarrassing to say the least, being managed by a couple of Freemasons who do as they please and decide who is good and who is bad. But that doesn't seem to interest anyone.  As an Italian and as a European, I am concerned about the way in which we endorse the attitude of the Orbán Government, which over the years has caused restrictions on political and civil liberties, seriously undermining respect for human rights within the Territory of the Union. What does the European Union intend to do? We make recommendations and then put our heads in the sand like ostriches?  He has been appointed Commissioner for Culture and Education, fundamental challenges for the future of Europe, Navracsis, a highly questionable figure who, in addition to denying common European values, has been the author of laws considered liberticidal. Today, to try to take off the mask that Delors was talking about in front of the Hungarian people would be a courageous gesture at last and would serve as a warning to the other countries. So let us do it, let us learn to have zero tolerance for those who do not guarantee the exercise of fundamental freedoms! (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Blue card question. – Do you know that, despite the fact that we have debated the state of justice in Hungary for a year and a half, according to data from the Official Judicial Board of the European Commission in March this year, the independence of the judiciary in Hungary received 6 points more than in the previous year, it is in the midfield of the Member States. And in terms of trust in the judiciary, he is in favour of France. These facts and figures , official data from the Commission, prove something different from the ones you are talking about.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". I would like to ask Mr Corrao: if you want to indict Hungary, are you prepared to do the same with regard to the Federal Republic of Germany, where 13 000 investigations are carried out each year against patriotic citizens, where people who are in the wrong party are expelled from the hotel, and where people are sentenced to twelve and a half years in prison, just like Horst Mahler, for violating freedom of expression?

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Answer to a blue card question. I would like to reply to Mr Voigt first by saying: of course, I believe that respect for human rights and the warning from us parliamentarians must apply to all 28 countries of the European Union, so I do not care whether it concerns the Bundestag or France or any other parliament. The important thing is that we monitor that human rights, as enshrined in the European Convention on Human Rights, are respected in all countries. On the other hand, with regard to the first question that my colleague asked, it may well be that the Commission's report shows and has improved from the point of view of protection and the judicial system in Hungary, but what results from reports from many non-governmental organisations, among them the most important, is that many fundamental freedoms are still being violated to date. , including freedom of the press.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: Dear colleagues, The essence of true democracy is not only free choice, but especially the fact that it is not the state that controls and restricts its citizens, but the citizen controls and restricts the state. This shift has not happened in Hungary since the regime change, regardless of the party in power, which is the essence of the European Union. It is the neoliberal, globalist policies and economic policies of the European Union that have intimidated and vulnerable workers who, you know, work in assembly plants for EUR 200 disenfranchised. Farmers cannot sell their crops and loot their land on two sides: domestic oligarchs on the one hand and Westerners on the other. Small business owners can't compete with big multi-companies. There is therefore no strong, independent, raised-headed citizenry that can control power.  This was the outline of the speech that I had originally composed, but in the meantime, something so interesting happened that Mrs In 't Veld, who is the leader of the ongoing attacks and wars against Hungary, approached József Szájer and my fellow Member Kinga Gál just before this debate and had a very convivial 10-minute conversation with friends. Let's give it a try, what transparency and democracy is, please let us know what you're talking about in such a good mood and what this whole theater Hungary about. (L'orateur accepte de repondre a une question "carton bleu" (article 162, paragraphe 8 du reglement))

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: blue-card question. – I am not really sure whether I am actually asking a question to Ms Morvai. I think I can have a conversation with any colleague I like, including yourself, without having to explain myself publicly before you. Yes, in a democracy you can actually have a peaceful conversation with people who do not share your views. This may be new to you, but that is the way we like to do it in the European Parliament. Yes, I disagree with Mr Szájer and Ms Gál on a number of issues, but there are also things that we have in common, so we have a debate. It is called democracy.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: Blue card answer. "Well, if you have such a good relationship, then I do not understand what the problem is with democracy, then you are exercising democracy perfectly here. I just want these certain crippled, disenfranchised workers, small business owners and farmers to feel something about this democracy, and I would also like you to tell me what you were talking about for 10 minutes just before this supposedly wartime debate, in such a ferociously good mood and friendship, while pretending here that I do not know what a great hostility there is between you. It's a matter for the electorate.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I would perhaps suggest that you have this conversation outside the Chamber. I am going to give Ms in ‘t Veld the floor now because she is making a point of order.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: I do not accept it when you say that I am waging war on Hungary. I do not accept that. I was just checking: we have had debates in this Chamber on human rights violations in a number of countries, including EU Member States. Ten years ago, this House adopted a very strong resolution on media freedom under Berlusconi in Italy. Is that war on Italy? No, Madam Morvai, this is the struggle for freedom – freedom of speech and democracy in the European Union. Maybe you should join in.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Dear Kriszta Morvai, I talk to you very politely and convivially, even though we disagree on almost nothing! You are attacking Viktor Orban, because he believes that the burden of the crisis must be borne not by the little people, but by the capital-strong companies. It imposed taxes on banks, financial transactions and the advertising market. Hungary was one of the first to come out of the crisis, with zero per cent inflation, four per cent economic growth and the fastest fall in unemployment. All this without hungary's one cent of debt being released, we did not ask for the free money of the taxpayers of another country.  You say that freedom of the press has been damaged, but you mean that the Hungarian state has uniformly taxed the advertising market, and the tv channel that has so far escaped the public burden with tricks has not escaped this. You say that the Hungarian Government is harassing civilians, but you mean that foundations that share your views can violate financial rules with impunity. You are saying that Viktor Orban does not respect human rights, but what is really wrong with him is that he is a Christian Democrat, not a liberal, which even the Communists are calling for here. There is a problem with freedoms in Europe. Several governments are considering how to prevent the union's fundamental freedom, the free movement of labour. This would really be worth a debate in the European Parliament. But there is no need to worry about Hungarian democracy here, thank you, all right, this is the third time this year he has demonstrated his strength. In elections 10 days ago, Fidesz won 616 mayoral seats, the left 34 and jobbik 14 mayoral seats. Hands off Hungary!

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Madam President! I would also like to make one thing very clear once again: we are not talking about Hungary today, we are talking about the Orban government. It is precisely a democratically elected government that must never disregard fundamental rights and the rule of law. And yet: the lack of independence of the judiciary and the media, insufficient rights for the parliamentary opposition, targeted incitement against minorities – we have been hearing all this for over four years. Viktor Orban has openly promoted this systematic infiltration of European values before the eyes of Europe. How can it be that, in the middle of Europe, a government is first putting the public media on the chain and is now trying, through high taxation, to force the remaining private media out of the country, that NGOs that promote the rights of civil society and receive money from Norway, a friendly state, suddenly become opponents of the system? We must finally recognise that the current curtailments of fundamental rights are not isolated isolated cases and draw conclusions from them. Technical infringement procedures aimed only at the transposition of individual directives cannot put an end to the systematic erosion of European fundamental values. We therefore need a new European procedure for the protection of the rule of law in order to be able to enforce effectively compliance with democratic standards in all Member States. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Blue card question. - Congresswoman, I'm sorry. I came from the civil sphere and became a Fidesz member, and for almost 8 years I have been leading an organisation representing people with disabilities as president. I know exactly how diverse Hungary civil sphere is. There are 65 000 NGOs in Hungary and organisations have a high level of transparency in terms of both legal functioning and financial accounts. My question, Congresswoman, is what would you classify as an NGO in your country if you are mismanagement and your country's authority is taking action and carrying out an audit?

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I would like to say to my colleague, in particular, that we cannot compare apples with pears here. There are always counter-examples of every example we give here. I have spoken to a representative of the Orban government and i-g.i. has raised the issue of anti-Semitic activities in Hungary. His answer was: "Yes, but I am friends with a Jew." That is not the answer. Of course, if there are violations, we have to take action against them. But what is being thrown into confusion here with the NGOs supported by Norway has nothing to do with fraudulent or even criminal intentions.

name: Marek JUREK
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. The Hungarians have twice elected the Fidesz-KDNP government, they have made a national choice, and in fact today the respect for this choice made by the Hungarians is a real test of respect for the rights of nations and diversity, which we are talking about so much about. With my friends to be honest, I regret the change in Hungary's foreign policy and I hope that the Hungarian Government will withdraw from this change. But let's remember how this change happened. One of the most force-firm governments in Europe, the European Parliament, threatened sanctions. For what? For the fact that the Hungarians wanted Christian civilization, for the fact that the Hungarians wanted communism to be accountable, for wanting a strong, just state that guarantees the rights of its citizens, for wanting to break the demographic crisis and demographic development. It is time to realise that attacks on Hungary are simply a destruction of European unity and solidarity. I hope that the promoters of these attacks will finally realise this.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by congratul We must never forget that the independence of the rule of law, the free media and the equal rights of all people are the foundation of European cooperation. Hungary is a country that has repeatedly violated these rights. It started with the establishment of a state-controlled media council, continued with the forced retirement of judges and, tragically, also the criminalisation of the most vulnerable, namely the homeless. Recently, Orbán took his statements to a new level when he simply stated that the world's greatest political leaders, according to him, are Putin and Erdoğan. At the same time, he wanted to put down the concept of liberal democracy as a principle. It is clear that Hungary's disintegration is taking place in area after area. In this House, we have repeatedly adopted resolutions which have not yet been heard by the Council of Ministers, which have shown unimaginable cowardice in this. The Commission claims to follow developments, but while the rights of the citizens of Hungary are being violated, so far we have seen only words and very little action. The EU has been created to protect citizens' rights and not to state's ability to violate these rights. That is why we must now immediately have an Article 7 procedure. This is about the rights of The citizens of Europe. Today, we should all have loyalty to the citizens of Hungary, whose rights are systematically violated. (L'orateur accepte de repondre a une question "carton bleu" (article 162, paragraphe 8 du regulations))

name: Marek JUREK
text: question asked by raising a "blue card". – I wanted to ask you if you believe that during the socialist rule in Hungary, until a few years ago, the opposition and, above all, citizens with opposition views were sufficiently represented in the media? Was it good then? And one more question. Are you really not worried about the fact that crimes against the victims of communism remain unpunished, but that judges educated during communism become ... (The President has received the speaker's vote.)

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: answer ("blue card"). Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for It is not reasonable for us now to highlight the violations of a group and, in some way, to legitimise what is now happening and has been happening in Hungary in a systematic manner for years.  In this House, we have worked on this issue so much. But Article 7 must be effectuated. That is the key with which we can actually get things right in Hungary. The foundation of our joint work in the European Union is based on common values and values and this must not be put out of hand.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: I originally wanted to talk about something else, but my fellow Members Szájer and Kósa have made false accusations against Hungarian NGOs here, so we have to respond to this. In the investigation against Hungarian NGOs, the insinuation varies from week to week, the prosecutor's office, the police and the government itself do not know what they are looking for, they just want to find something. The only thing that has been proven so far in the case of these investigations, my fellow Members, is that the KEHI investigation that has been launched against NGOs has been unlawful. KEHI had no right to investigate these organisations. For the time being, only the hungarian government's infringement has been proven in this case, and this proves more than anything how democracy works in Hungary, how the Hungarian Government works. And, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. Let me draw your attention to one thing. This debate is not about the Hungarian Government and not just about Hungary. The example that is taking place in Hungary, which the European institutions are leaving behind, could also be an example for other political aspirations of other Member States. My fellow Fidesz members, also for political forces with which you may not sympathise.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Madam President! Now we have the situation where the issue of Hungary has been put on the agenda by the ALDE and by the left. However, interest in the subject does not seem to be particularly high on the other side. Populism seems to play a bit of a role. Now it is precisely this left-left majority in the House that is making me have to defend the EPP. That is a very special position. Now even a woman in't Veld manages to contradict herself twice in a speech. I congratulate you on this, because on the one hand you say that the Commissioner should not be so crystal clear about the law. On the other hand, you say that it must uphold the rule of law. It should be clear to you that this is not the same thing. Nevertheless, for the umpteenth time we now have the subject of Hungary on the agenda, and I will tell you one thing: I am a friend of Hungary, and I am also a neighbour as an Austrian. This government was elected by a clear majority to Hungary. You have to respect that, whether you like it or not, doesn't matter here. That is a fact. To date, there has not been a single infringement that has been proven here. And just because a left-left majority here in the House does not fit this government, you must still accept it, and this is far from being a violation of fundamental rights.

name: Frank ENGEL
text: Madam President, I think many of us in this Chamber would agree that the Hungarians are special and I say this with a lot of respect for one of the oldest state-founding nations of our continent. They are special and have always been so. This is one of the reasons why we were particularly glad and proud to have them back. But I am afraid they are not special enough. They are not so special that they could invent a Christian Democracy that was illiberal. They will not manage this. None of us has managed it and indeed none of us has attempted it. Christian Democracy is liberal democracy and only a liberal Christian Democracy is compatible with European democracy. Now this is where there is the choice, and about this choice we might have to talk again. I am not opposed to letting anyone experiment with models of governance, but as soon as we are confronted with a model of governance that is willingly and wittingly going beyond the acceptable borders of what we consider to be European rule of law, there is need for debate.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for A few hours before the National Day of the Hungarian Revolution of 1956, I will state that it was not us Hungarian Social Democrats who brought this subject before Parliament. Yet at this moment, the new Hungarian state party, the Orban regime, prints its press in full force, in which it deters me and our colleagues, even if someone sits in the ranks of the People's Party and accuses them of attacking Hungary simply because we do not agree with the regime that operates at home. They have no sense of shame, so I would like to apologise to you, on behalf of Fidesz, for having to deal with the state of Hungarian democracy over and over again, and now I would also like to apologise to Hungarian society for the fact that while 600 000 Hungarian children are starving while 4 million Hungarians are living below the living wage, while hundreds of thousands of hungarians are leaving the country because of economic conditions, they must also deal with the state of democracy instead. that the government would do what it had to do: get the country's affairs in order. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. I would like us not to focus on the state of Hungarian democracy next time in this House, but in the meantime, we Democrats must draw attention to the fact that processes are taking place... (the president takes the floor) (The speaker agrees to answer a blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: György SCHÖPFLIN
text: Blue card question. - My fellow Member, I would like to thank you for your support. You used the word regime. Now everyone knows that the regime is not a democratic system. Perhaps you would not have noticed that there have been three elections in Hungary this year in which the left has not performed very well?

name: István UJHELYI
text: Blue card answer. "Thank you very much, Congressman, for your question, because now I can continue what I just started. Because of the state of Hungarian democracy, we can safely use the term regime. You have put in place a new electoral system in which you can secure two-thirds power with far fewer votes. A system of municipal elections has been put in place which, for example, in the capital, where there are a majority of left-wing voters, left-wing forces could not win thanks to this electoral system. And you have passed Hungarian legislation, you have carried out a constitution that means that neither the prosecutor's office, nor the Hungarian media, nor the Constitutional Court can do what it should do in a normal democracy. That's why they still have a majority today, but it won't be for long. Things will change in 2018!

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: Madam President, in this house this is the second, third or fourth debate we have on this issue and I hope, if it is occasionally electric, that it can lead this evening to really open dialogue, as the Commission has explained, and that it can above all lead to silencing the concerns that are emerging about the protection of rights and our fundamental values. , which, in essence, unite us, cement the rule of law as well as European democracy and make us Europeans. I too have met in recent days with representatives of RTL Club, who have explained to me the elements that led them to initiate a complaint procedure before the Commission after the adoption of the law of June 2014. Indeed, we do not have to judge - and anyone who is not a Hungarian national does not have to judge - the decisions taken by the Hungarian people under their legislation. On the other hand, as with all States, all those who have decided to sign the treaties and belong to the Union, these laws must respect our common foundation and we must therefore consider whether or not the principle of equality and media pluralism are respected. It is about the credibility of the Union, and therefore of all of us.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. This is the third plenary debate on Hungary. So this is our chance to learn some lessons. First of all, these debates are completely meaningless! By the way, in the past, all disputes have been resolved, but never in this house. In all cases, they were settled by the willingness of the European Commission and the Hungarian Government, which is always ready to negotiate. Secondly, these debates have not harmed the popularity of the Hungarian Government of the People's Party, but they have caused serious damage to the left-wing opposition in Hungary. A few days ago, for the third time this year, the left suffered a poignant electoral defeat, including because of these disputes that offended many Hungarians. Finally, Hungary well-functioning democracy, as evidenced by the fact that the decision of the Hungarian people in free elections by an overwhelming majority, thank GoodNess, cannot be overridden either in Brussels or here in Strasbourg.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: I find my fellow Member Gyürk's concern about the Hungarian left touching. It's an honor to have you so worried about us. Let me say, however, that this is not the case here, and it is not about the Hungarian election results, but about the politics of the Hungarian Government, a policy that has been constantly insting conflicts with the European Community, with the European Union, for four years. Building an illiberal democracy in the European Community, I say to my honourable colleagues, the wooden iron ring, will not succeed. I would like to say that the opposition that this Government is producing is also a problem for the European Community. This is not Hungary problem of the european union, it is a serious infringement of a European Member State. That is why I think that this debate, colleague, belongs here, in this House, because we are MEPs in order to find the political means, to create the institutions and mechanisms by which we can lead those Member States – now Hungary – which have de way down the path of the rule of law back to the European road. (The speaker agrees to answer a blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". I do not share all the decisions, nor do I think everything that is decided in Hungary is right and good. However, I would have liked Fidesz and Hungary to be criticised on a one-sided basis, not only unilaterally, but of applying the same standard to Bulgaria, to Romania, when demonstrators were crushed there, when the media were bought and seized, when extraterritorial areas of a Russian nature were to be declared in breach of EU law. Do you not have the impression that you are a bit one-sided, and should we not stand up for human rights in general in the EU, even when the Socialists are in government?

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: Blue card answer. "Allow me, fellow Member, to remind you that two of you have already said what I have said before. This is not just about Hungary, but about the rule of law of the Member States of the European community in general. Hungary such a Member State. I'm sure there are problems elsewhere, you've lined up a few, but I think that this can only be done in a row, and now Hungary the subject. The next time Romania is brought here to Parliament, that is what we will obviously be talking about.

name: Kati PIRI
text: It is sad that we have to have a debate here about how a Member State is flot out all the important values that we stand for in the EU. It is even sadder that the Council is silent and watching. What is happening in Hungary is not an accumulation of incidents. What is happening in Hungary is the deliberate and effective scrapping of a young rule of law. Prime Minister Orban himself is no longer winning and has explicitly admitted this this summer. A liberal democracy is not spent on him. It is clear: Orban sees democracy purely as a tool for his authoritarian rule, even though everyone knows that elections alone do not make a country democratic. This is not a call from a left-wing politician who is frustrated with a right-wing government. This is a call by a Democrat to other Democrats to say loud and clear: 'we no longer accept this in the European Union'. [(The Speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.]

name: József SZÁJER
text: Blue card question. "I wanted to ask Mr. Niedermüller the same question. I understand you're both socialists. Are you calling for liberalism in the Hungarian Government? That's kind of surprising.

name: Kati PIRI
text: "blue card" answer. It is sad that my colleague in the PPE still defines 'liberal democracy' as a form of state that only liberals can stand for. Fortunately, all democrats – Social Democrats, Christian Democrats, Liberals – are in this House for liberal democracy. That's not just up to social democrats.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: It is very interesting what debates we have in this Parliament on liberal democracy, on Christian democracy. I think that these should be debated more broadly, which would lead further than the debate here about Hungary. Gentlemen, they did not talk about any other country here, while they wanted to debate it in general – they argued only about Hungary and issued court rulings. They said the rule of law was over, they talked about specific violations, but they didn't mention any violations. They can't prove a single thing, just like they did for a year and a half in the Tavares debate, which we listened to over and over again here, and then what happened? No specific violations were found! What I am saying is that they are trying to accept that the Hungarian people have decided on several occasions to give this government a superior confirmation in democratic elections – and I will answer that, yes, there were elections to the European Parliament, the same result as in all elections. You don't want to protect the Hungarian people against what we wanted.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: In fact, I only asked for the floor during this period because it has been said many times during the debate that there is no infringement in Hungary, at least mainly from the Christian Democratic side. I would like to remind everyone, but especially the Commission, that during the spring elections, representatives of the OSCE, i.e. the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe, produced a nice, long report on the Hungarian elections, and there is an evaluation, summary sentence that the governing parties in Hungary have enjoyed disproportionate advantages in the elections, and in addition, the report lists in several points that the Government and the Hungarian authorities have seriously violated the Copenhagen Convention governing elections with European needs. This does not seem to have been dealt with by Europe, even though this certificate was issued by a European organisation.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: Madam President, last year this Parliament raised serious doubts about Hungary's judicial independence and information plurality. The party in government is shielded by amending electoral law in the Constitution—no wonder Gonzalez Pons likes it. It also practices monopolistic control of the media. A national project where people who do not identify with the scheme are excluded; It doesn't matter if they are progressive, homosexual, or belong to ethnic minorities: for the ruling party, they are practically not Hungarians. The growth of xenophobia, homophobia and racism is not coincidental, it has much to do with a European Union policy that gives wings to the far right for not serving the interests of all its sides. In recent elections, the far-right vote barn was in the poorest areas, the areas expendable in this liberal project. Fewer vacuous words, less rhetoric, only a Europe that cares for all its parts equally, which does not divide between centre and periphery is the vaccine against xenophobia and the resurgence of fascism in Europe.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. October 23rd, as long as hungarian people live on earth, will always be a symbol of the struggle for Hungarian freedom. Yes, my fellow Member, this is the eve of this holiday, and you, hungarian members in other factions, are about to intervene in the sovereignty of Hungary through the EU institutions. They do so, of course, on the ticket of fear of democracy. As a politician, I represent a community that gave its members their lives for this freedom. Of course, I understand your plight, because you socialists have ideologues who say, say, 56, is a counter-revolution. Gyula Horn, whose name is in a room in the European Parliament, said it was a counter-revolution. The credibility of this institution is important to me, so I would like to avoid the European Parliament getting into the political fray that is being settled so that four Members can share among them who will be the head of the delegation. I don't want the match-up scenario to prevail here.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. The day after tomorrow we celebrate the 58th anniversary of the outbreak of the Hungarian Revolution and The War of Independence of 56. It is painful and shameful that the Hungarian Socialist Task Force in the European Parliament is using our national holiday to launch another series of attacks on its own country. The representatives of the Socialist delegation in Hungary, with a successor communist opinion, held a public hearing yesterday on violations of media freedom in Hungary. Those who call Hungary under the pretext of European values and defend democracy and the rule of law against Viktor Orban in this plenary session were complicitly silent when, in 2006, also on the anniversary of the revolution, the post-communist Gyurcsány regime disbanded peaceful celebrators and protesters with official force. It is time for the European Union and Parliament not to apply double standards Hungary governments of different party positions.

name: Martine Reicherts
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a big thank you for the richness of the debate that took place today. As has been pointed out by many stakeholders, we live in a rule of law, in a community of law. Article 7, as well as Article 2, were also recalled. We have some leads here that we will have to continue to explore. I thank the Italian Presidency, which intends to put this item on the agenda for a future debate, and I believe that this debate, too, will contribute to enriching our exchanges. You mentioned Vice-President Timmermans, who will, of course, continue to follow this issue with great interest and will make a point of continuing this discussion, knowing full well that the rule of law is a very broad concept in which the safeguarding of fundamental rights is essential, regardless of the country in which we find ourselves.

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I too have followed this debate with great attention and interest. As I said at the beginning, I am not in a position to say more on this subject: the Council has not discussed or adopted a position on the situation in Hungary and, as the Presidency of the Council, I am speaking on behalf of all 27 Member States, so I would repeat what I said at the beginning of the debate. With regard to the initiative on a possible overall general rule of law mechanism, the Italian Presidency undertakes to follow it up. After the new Commission takes office, we will plan further discussions in the Council to take this matter forward.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: in writing. Every single violation of the rule of law affects the principles of the European Union (Article 2 TEU) and, in the case of Hungarian policies in recent years, confirms a protracted and brutal assault of the freedoms on which the Union is founded. The Tavares resolution adopted in this Parliament in 2013 already traced a long path of violations: the amendments to the basic law (implemented in a very short time dodging any debate with the other parties and civil society), the widespread use of organic laws ("cardinals"), the weakening of the system of checks and balances (Constitutional Court, Parliament, data protection authority), the subjugation of the judicial system , electoral law and rules that are the result of media pluralism. While some of these points have recently improved slightly, Prime Minister Orbán's ambiguous statements on democracy, the treatment of some NGOs and the proposal for an internet tax show the authorities' intention to turn the Hungarian State into a state that is no longer completely liberal. The caution shown by the Commission in this parliamentary debate worries me: these infringements do not require so many infringement procedures, but an activation of the procedure provided for in Article 7 TEU in the event of a serious breach by a Member State of the principles of the Union.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Writing. – In recent years, Hungary has taken a worrying direction under Victor Orban. Step by step, the Union's common values have been undermined or openly violated. Freedom of the press, in particular, suffers from the policies of the Hungarian Prime Minister. Own special taxes limit the scope of anti-government media. The crackdown on anti-government NGOs is reminiscent of undemocratic power structures that we usually find outside Europe. It is to be feared that this policy will take place and spread to other states. That is why it is important to take a clear stand against such tendencies. In the last parliamentary term, the EP, with its Tavares report, showed a way forward for dealing with Member States that systematically violate the Copenhagen criteria. The accession of a state to the EU is, of course, subject to these conditions. A stay again only makes sense as long as one commits oneanother to the common basis. If the dialogue with Hungary is not successful, infringement procedures and, ultimately, a withdrawal of voting rights are appropriate. The European Union is a community of values. When a Member State abandons liberal freedoms, as Victor Orban recently hinted in a speech, it is also indirectly saying goodbye to the European Union.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the report by Gabrielius Landsbergis, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade, on customs duties on goods originating in Ukraine (COM(2014)0597 – C8-0165/2014 – 2014/0279(COD)) (A8-0021/2014).

name: Gabrielius LANDSBERGIS
text: rapporteur. - First of all, let me thank all of you who supported Ukraine during our meetings in the Committee on International Trade and here in plenary. I am pleased we have a broad and firm understanding that Europe has to stand by Ukraine by granting the unilateral extension of the autonomous trade measures (ATMs). As we speak, Ukraine continues to struggle on all fronts at the same time. The ceasefire is not being respected; Ukraine is continuing to defend its territorial integrity against attacks from outside; it faces enormous economic and financial difficulties; and it has to undergo deep internal reforms. Europe has made a commitment to help Ukraine – and with today’s decision we will turn our words into deeds. This should help Ukraine to withstand the pressure from Russia, which is willing to obstruct the implementation of the Association Agreement between the EU and Ukraine and to interfere in our bilateral relations and sovereign decisions. There was a time in history when Europe abandoned one eastern European country: 75 years ago Poland was left on its own against aggressors, despite previous statements offering great support. We all know what happened later. What could have been stopped at Poland’s borders finally engulfed the whole world. Ukraine is today’s front, and strong statements and words of support are simply not enough. The extension of the Regulation is part of the EU commitment that was made at the same time as it was decided to postpone implementation of the deep and comprehensive free trade agreement (DCFTA) for 15 months – in the hope of peace. The Ukrainian side favours the ATMs and says that they have helped to increase Ukraine’s exports to the EU and, indeed, to compensate for the fall in exports to countries in the Customs Union. The ATMs provide a much-needed opportunity for Ukrainian producers and businesses to divert their exports away from the increasingly restrictive Russian market, and also an incentive to bringing their operations and standards more into line with those of the EU. I would note too that Member States have already supported the extension of the Regulation, so there is every chance of ensuring that it will remain in effect without any break. Taking into account the call from some colleagues for close monitoring of the implementation of the ATMs and for more reassurance on deadlines, I will urge the Commission to continue to monitor the effects closely. These ATMs have been in place since April 2014, with Parliament’s approval, and we know exactly what they mean in terms of entitlements. All the relevant calculations have been done. Moreover, as Parliament ratified the Association Agreement last month it was expected to come into full force immediately, meaning that the tariff agreement would have been in place since last month. Given the current situation, our timely decision will prove that the European Parliament can act swiftly and decisively. It will also be proof of our political will and recognition of our moral obligation: we are ready to help the Ukrainians and we are not leaving them alone. Colleagues, I count on your firm support for this decision.

name: Martine Reicherts
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, at Parliament’s plenary session of 16 September, Commissioner De Gucht explained in detail the content and context of the outcome of the trilateral consultations between Ukraine, Russia and the EU on 12 September. The Commission agreed, as part of the outcome, to propose to the Council to delay the provisional application of the trade title of the EU Association Agreement with Ukraine until 31 December 2015, and this in the event that Ukraine ratified the Association Agreement. The proposal by the Commission for such a delay was based on a clear request from Ukraine to take an initiative that would allow ratification of the Association Agreements to go ahead while leaving more time to discuss ways of addressing Russian concerns arising from the implementation of the DCFTA. This outcome must be seen in the bigger political context. It is part and parcel of a comprehensive peace process in Ukraine and secures a commitment from Russia to maintain its preferential trade regime with Ukraine. Four days later, on 16 September, Ukraine went ahead with the ratification of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement, which was endorsed simultaneously by the European Parliament here in Strasbourg giving its consent. Many of you, honourable Members, expressed satisfaction when the Association Agreement was ratified. It was truly historic, as it was the first time in the EU’s history that such a simultaneous vote had taken place. As part of the 12 September outcome, the Commission also agreed to submit a proposal to extend, until the end of 2015, the autonomous trade preferences currently granted to Ukraine, as they will otherwise cease to apply as of 1 November. Let me recall the basic elements of these autonomous trade preferences. The unilateral market access granted to Ukraine corresponds to the first year of application of the schedule of concessions negotiated under the DCFTA. The current proposal simply extends the duration of those autonomous preferences by 15 additional months, thus maintaining the same preferences. Suspended duties would present an amount of up to nearly EUR 500 million. Preferences are granted to Ukraine subject to its effective cooperation in customs matters and require Ukraine not to change in any way its tariffs towards the EU. In addition, safeguard controls are in place to prevent market-distorting surges impacting adversely on European companies and industry, including the agriculture sector. EU phytosanitary rules remain fully applicable to Ukrainian products. In order to address concerns expressed by Parliament, the extension of the autonomous trade preferences is subject to Ukraine’s respect for the essential elements of the Association Agreement. Most importantly from an economic point of view, the autonomous trade preferences have a very limited impact on the EU markets, and yet at the same time they represent a gesture of tangible economic and political support to Ukraine in a difficult situation, helping to address Ukraine’s difficult economic, political, security and territorial challenges. I would like to thank Parliament for the efforts already made to pave the way for a swift conclusion of the legislative procedure for this file in order to ensure that trade flows are not disrupted. Parliament is therefore asked to endorse the Commission’s proposal so that these important preferences for Ukraine continue to apply after 1 November.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I think it was important that we had the opportunity to have a debate in Parliament on such an important issue. We fully understand the geopolitical aspects which have led, not least on the basis of what the rapporteur, the Representative of the Commission, has argued, to the accelerated procedure, with which we agree. We do not raise any questions about this approach and we are also, as it were, in support of the peace process, which naturally goes beyond those elements that are contained in the regulatory change that we are debating here.  However, we have raised a number of demands, both in committee and again in the same way in this House, with regard to the Commission in particular. We believe that this measure should be regarded as an exceptional measure, which means that we do not believe that it should exceed the 14-month deadline that has been granted, so that we can go beyond 31 December 2015. At the same time, we consider it essential that in six months' time, in eight months' time, what the Representative of the Commission has indicated to us today as a certainty, namely monitoring, should be examined and deepened, in other words, to show us what impact this regulation has on the measure.

name: David MARTIN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, when we agreed these temporary autonomous measures for Ukraine back in the spring, it was on the assumption that the deep and comprehensive free trade agreement would enter into force by next month. As the Commissioner has just reminded us, after the historic simultaneous signing by the European Parliament and the Ukrainian Parliament, this has been delayed until 2016. The proposal today, therefore, is not for new measures but for an extension of existing measures, and that is why my Group has been able to support an accelerated procedure and why we will not support any amendments to this text. If we do not approve this on Thursday, there will be a gap in preferences when the current trade regime with Ukraine expires at the beginning of November. My Group will not accept a delay in the entry into force of this regulation. It would send the wrong signal to the people of Ukraine if we wilfully stood in the way of European solidarity and support as they struggle to re-establish democracy and economic stability. When these trade measures were first proposed they did not include a human rights clause. However, this new proposal from the Commission has taken on board the demand from the Socialist and Democratic Group that it should include a human rights clause, and for that reason, and for the reason of urgency, we will support this regulation unamended on Thursday.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, the exceptional provocations and aggression by Putin’s Russia in our eastern neighbourhood continue to be cause for great concern. At their root is the choice of the Ukrainians to seek stronger ties with the EU. Choosing rules-based trade and a movement towards an open society will require difficult reforms. The deep and comprehensive trade agreement which is part of the Association Agreement is set to enter into force on 1 January 2016. Meanwhile, preferential trade measures were already adopted in April 2014 as part of the support package for Ukraine. Since their implementation, trade between the EU and Ukraine has increased drastically. Ukrainian exports to the EU increased by 25 % in May and June of this year compared to the same period last year and during the first six months of 2014 exports from Ukraine to Russia fell by 24 %.  These figures show the importance of the autonomous trade measures for the Ukrainian economy. Not extending them would not only seem a political statement but would have a very real economic impact on the country and its people. Given the economic asymmetry between the EU and Ukraine, the increase in exports from Ukraine is economically important for the country but it has relatively little effect on us in the EU. In principle, the autonomous trade measures do not allow illegal products onto the European market. All products must conform to EU standards, but the increase in trade may make it harder to control them. However this should not lead to products coming onto the European market which would otherwise be illegal and which could harm European producers. The regulation before us prolongs the autonomous trade measures and amends the existing regulation to make access by Ukraine to the preferential conditions conditional upon respect for democratic principles, human rights and fundamental freedoms, as well as respect for the rule of law. This is also mentioned in the Association Agreement. It is now important that these conditions are met and that the timeframe is kept. Exceptional circumstances call for exceptional measures but the goal remains to see a structural solution.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, Mrs Reicherts, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has What the Commission has presented here is a sham, from the point of view of the people of Ukraine. For the selected export goods for the whole of 2015, they grant the same quantities for export to the EU that Ukraine has only exhausted in six months. In addition, the Regulation has an expiry date of 31 December 2015, which cannot provide certainty to potential investors in Ukraine. My group calls for a more honest approach and for the regulation to be directly linked to the successful conclusion of the trilateral negotiations with Russia. We should make it clear how this concrete economic policy measure, with real implications for the daily lives of citizens, both in Ukraine and in the EU-28, can finally open up and promote a path to peace and economic prospects. Instead, the regulation continues to put unnecessary pressure on negotiators. In doing so, you should have sought the necessary talks with Russia from the outset in order to find the best way forward for all to achieve a common peace and economic order – not in confrontation, but in the deliberate use of Ukraine's capabilities as a bridge between the EU and the Eurasian Union.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. " Although it is time and late, I think the issue is important enough for both Europe and Ukraine. It is not fish that is being given a fishing rod, giving Ukraine access to aid of up to EUR 500 million. Euro. Today, it is regrettable that, under Russian pressure, Ukraine has been forced to request the postponement of a comprehensive and comprehensive free trade agreement. I therefore believe that it is necessary to adopt this resolution that has been presented. We can't put it off. We must continue to support ukraine's economy, help it to grow from the inside and ensure its stability. We need to send a clear signal to the Ukrainian people, including to business, that we are supporting the Ukrainian economy and its integration into the processes of the European Union. With the Commission's proposal, we will show that the European Union is committed to its eastern neighbourhood partners and is able to find the right response to the challenges, while demonstrating its commitment.

name: Giulia MOI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, guaranteeing unilateral tariff preferences to Ukraine is undoubtedly a clear political signal to Russia. However, this signal must not help to further impoverish our producers and, in particular, farmers. These preferences will place EUR 487 million on the Community budget, with direct consequences for the agricultural sector, especially ma corn and flour, where Ukrainian exports account for more than 60% and where the reduction in duties will lead to losses that are not easily recoverable. This is the second time since the Russian embargo of 7 August that our farmers have suffered the political consequences of this association agreement. We therefore call on the Commission to press for ratification of the Association Agreement to be ratified within the 14 months envisaged, which will also benefit our producers, and for there to be control over what has been exported without wanting to find GMO meal or products that do not comply with European standards in the absence of appropriate phytosanitary reforms.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Madam President! Mrs Reicherts, I would like to ask myself, what does the EU have, what does my country Germany have of the tariff suspensions in these hours? Which goods can enrich the European internal market from Ukraine in the future? Is this action no more or less to pour oil on the fire again, and the wrong political signal, after various war crimes have not yet been solved, for example the murders in Odessa, the terrible, tragic accidents involving flight MH 17? How do such measures affect sanctions and the backlash from Russia? When will the escalation spiral end? If we want to take action here and increase the size of the European internal market, we should do so by taking Ukraine and Russia and trying to include both, and instead suspending the free trade agreement with the United States.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, all too often the European Union has missed opportunities to make its voice and weight heard because it has moved too slowly in the face of emergency situations. On this occasion, however, the timeliness of the initiative to avoid a regulatory vacuum with regard to the removal of customs duties for imports from Ukraine must be viewed positively. Firstly, because we believe that trade policy interests must be consistent with those of foreign policy and that at this stage we must send out a strong signal to a people in difficulty. Let us hope that in the not too distant future the Ukrainian people will be able to identify with the founding values of our Union. Decisions such as these show that we can and must have the courage to put common interests before those of the individual. It is clear that there is a problem with an emergency procedure and that this may indeed be a matter of concern, but – in balancing with the damage that would have occurred if there had not been an extension – the assessment of proceeding in any case prevailed.  This is the best way, in our view, to give Ukrainian producers the opportunity to divert their trade to the European market, giving them the opportunity to survive and at the same time encouraging them to adapt to Eu ropean standards. In addition, we think it is a good thing that Article 2 is included, which reaffirms the obligatory respect for fundamental freedoms, the inviolability of borders and the fight against the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. It is important to stress that autonomous trade measures are not an indiscriminate opening up of the Community market to Ukrainian products competing with Community production, since in the agricultural and agro-industrial sectors the levels of protection remain higher than in other sectors, with quotas and minimum prices that do not distort the competitiveness of local products. In short, we hope that this extension can be perceived as an act of goodwill on the part of the European Union and a stimulus to bring the crisis to a conclusion as soon as possible and certainly not as a way of wasting time, let alone a custom, and we also hope that the real trade treaty will enter into force by 1 January 2016 at the latest.

name: Kaja KALLAS
text: Madam President, we all know that the Ukrainian conflict has resulted not only in more than 3 600 military and civilian casualties but also in major economic costs. That is why I strongly welcome this proposal today, as it aims to lower customs duties on goods from Ukraine until December 2015, when the Association Agreement will enter into force. This is needed for Ukraine’s economy, its businesses and its citizens. It is, however, a shame that it should be needed today because of the delay in applying the free trade elements of the Association Agreement, due to pressure from Russia. Russia should not have a say in EU-Ukraine trade relations, and the Commission needs to ensure that we do not end up in the same situation in December 2015 when the Association Agreement enters into force.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, although it is late, I would like to point out a number of things, particularly for the representative of the Commission.  Let's remember the numbers. Between 2002 and 2012, the EU's surpluses to Ukraine increased five-fold, from two billion to ten billion. It was not the Union that helped Ukraine but Ukraine that helped the Union. Tariffs, already reduced, have not brought Economic growth and development to Ukraine but have led to job destruction, recession and unemployment. The agreement does not bring economic stability but economic instability in Ukraine as well as unfair competition, especially in the agricultural sector. In France, where farmers are suffering more and more, there is more than one suicide per day.  In a few years' time, it is the people of the west after that of eastern Ukraine that will know that the Union and its European institutions bring political and economic instability, even if it must be acknowledged that this agreement has, at least, the advantage of not wanting to oppose the West and the East in the development of Ukraine.

name: Johannes Cornelis van BAALEN
text: Madam President, I, like Mrs Schaake and Mrs Kallas, naturally support this arrangement. This is good for Ukraine and we must support Ukraine. However, I find it unpalatable that this compromise was reached on the basis of Russian blackmail. Ukraine has been put under enormous pressure. This became clear to me in Brussels. That has become clear to me in Moscow and kiev. And in the end, in a year and a half, that Russian pressure should not be rewarded again. That can't happen. I also agree with those who say 'our agricultural sector must not reap the sour benefits'. Animal welfare, public health, of course, nothing can be handed in on such matters. It may be necessary to see whether the agricultural sector can receive some compensation because it is also suffering from a Russian embargo. But again, we must help Ukraine and that is why we are fully in favour of this arrangement.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. Free trade is always profitable for both sides, so there is no reason why we should determine what ukraine is allowed to import and what is not allowed. This is only beneficial for people who live with the preparation of such reports. I understand this perfectly, and In my opinion, the only point of this report, which I have in my hand, is that the producers of beet sugar have given a paw to those who allow goods to be marketed and potato producers have just not. Every commodity from Ukraine and Ukraine should be admitted to the European Union market and vice versa.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. The topic we are discussing has two dimensions. Firstly, aid and support to Ukraine, and secondly, the dignity and credibility of the European Union. The word said, so if the European Union has agreed to enter into force of the Association Agreement with Ukraine only in a year's time, then in order to be credible in its relations with Ukraine and firm in its relations with Russia, the European Union must live up to its word. Autonomous trade measures must therefore be postponed until the end of next year. Otherwise, no one, especially Russia, will ever take us seriously again. It is up to us– the Union, not Russia, to decide when our trade agreements with other countries come into force.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: Madam President, we are equally sympathetic to the Ukrainian people. That is why we condemn the illegal coup d'état, supported by the European Union and the United States. This aid that the European Union wants to give to the Ukrainian people we also know in Portugal. In exchange for financial aid, the European Union will impose the liberalisation of the economy, it will dismantle that country's productive apparatus, which is unable to compete with the big European companies.  What the European Union wants is not to help, it is just to extend its market to new consumers and to have access to Ukraine's raw materials. If the European Union wants to help, demand respect for human rights from ukraine's current government, to stop supporting fascist militias pursuing trade unionists and other social activists, condemn the attempt to illegalize the Communist Party of Ukraine and investigate all crimes committed, with particular emphasis on the crime of Odessa. This is the help that the European Union should give.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. It is clear that what we are trying to do at the moment is to try to strengthen the economic strength of countries in need. This is a clear political signal that, on the one hand, we do not agree with aggression and, on the other hand, we do not leave those in need. Simply put, a stable Ukraine is in our interest. Strengthening Ukraine is in our interest, but above all, ukraine approaching the European Union is in our interest. Of course, this must be done in a clear and transparent manner. This must mean profound structural changes related to political and economic reform in Ukraine, and this should send a clear signal to the citizens of the European Union and Ukraine.

name: Martine Reicherts
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, the EU should definitely continue to support the comprehensive peace process in Ukraine, respecting the country’s territorial integrity and its right to decide on its destiny. We must stand shoulder to shoulder with Ukraine in the face of the extremely difficult political and territorial challenges it faces but also in its process of reforms and economic modernisation.  Parliament’s support in these efforts is vital. Delays in the extension of trade preferences should indeed be avoided as this could have an impact on economic operators’ decisions to import goods from Ukraine. Even retroactive application risks not fully repairing interferences with trade flows and would be cumbersome not only for the economic operators but also for our competent national customs authorities.  Therefore I urge Parliament to endorse the Commission’s proposal without amendments. The Council should then do its part so that the legislative act can be signed into law and enter into force as soon as possible.

name: Gabrielius LANDSBERGIS
text: rapporteur. - Madam President, I would like to thank all my colleagues who participated in the debate. It clearly sends a very strong message to our Ukrainian friends that all the main groups in Parliament support the decision. I would like to make a few points. Regarding certain deadlines, I am sure that, in cooperation with the Commission, we can sort these things out. Regarding Russia, I have a huge question: why do we want to involve a third country in this type of decision? To me it is clear that the Euromaidan people made a decision when they protested against the regime. They made a decision to be part of Europe and we have to respond to that, without involving any third parties, whether Russia or any other country. I strongly believe that on Thursday we will support this decision, and I call on all those Members who are still in doubt to support the decision without the amendments.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 23 October 2014. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. – I want to express my strong support for the reduction or elimination of customs duties through autonomous trade measures (ATMs) on goods originating in Ukraine. I believe that it is time to unite and to show our respect for the pro-European choice made by the Ukrainian people. I see the extension of ATMs as one of the ways to stabilise the countryʼs economy and politics. It would not only help Ukrainian businesses re-orientate from the Russian to the European market but would also help adapt their functioning and standards to EU ones, which will help in preparing for the full implementation of the DCFTA from January 2016. Ukrainian exports to the EU increased by 25 % in the first half of 2014 and will keep increasing if we open our market while Ukraine respects our sanitary and phytosanitary standards.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: Written. – Today we are debating the abolition of customs duties on Ukrainian goods. Or for fullness: the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 374/2014 for the reduction or abolition of customs duties on goods originating in Ukraine. We all know that the intensification of trade relations with Ukraine - and thus the increase in European influence on Ukraine - can have major geopolitical consequences. So I will not go into that now. However, I see another problem: battery cages are banned in the EU and battery eggs are not allowed to be sold, while Ukraine simply allows those unfriendly battery cages. And what turns out? This proposal simply allows animal products from Ukraine, regardless of the living conditions of the animals. How can the EU state with dry eyes that it will put an end to dieron-friendly production methods if we simply allow these products through the back door? Thanks to the European Commission, which has already authorised a large Ukrainian egg producer to export to Europe, there will soon be battery eggs in our shops. I find that incomprehensible! I believe that international security, human rights, democracy and respectful treatment of animals are more important than short-sighted trade policy. That is why I will vote against this report.
